instructorActions: Write on board: 'Medical Certificates: 1) First-Class, 2) Second-Class, 3) Third-Class, 4) BasicMed, 5) Validity Periods.'

Explain first-class medical comprehensively: 'First-class medical: Required for: Airline transport pilot (ATP) operations, Commercial operations requiring first-class medical. Validity period: 12 calendar months if under age 40, 6 calendar months if age 40 or older. Requirements: Most stringent medical standards, Comprehensive medical examination, Specific vision, hearing, and health requirements. The key: First-class medical is required for airline operations - most stringent requirements, shorter validity period for older pilots.'

Explain second-class medical: 'Second-class medical: Required for: Commercial operations (excluding airline operations requiring first-class), Commercial pilot certificate operations. Validity period: 12 calendar months. Requirements: Less stringent than first-class, Comprehensive medical examination, Specific vision, hearing, and health requirements. The key: Second-class medical is required for commercial operations - 12 month validity, less stringent than first-class.'

Explain third-class medical: 'Third-class medical: Required for: Private pilot operations, Student pilot operations, Recreational pilot operations. Validity period: 60 calendar months if under age 40, 24 calendar months if age 40 or older. Requirements: Least stringent medical standards, Basic medical examination, Specific vision and health requirements. The key: Third-class medical is required for private pilot operations - longest validity period, least stringent requirements.'

Present medical certificate scenario: 'Scenario: A 35-year-old private pilot has a third-class medical that was issued 58 months ago. Can they fly? [Wait] Analysis: Third-class medical validity: 60 months if under 40, 24 months if 40+. Pilot is 35 (under 40), so validity is 60 months. Medical was issued 58 months ago, so it's still valid (2 months remaining). Pilot can fly. However, if pilot was 42 years old, validity would be 24 months, and medical would be expired (58 months > 24 months). The key: Medical certificate validity depends on age and medical class - know validity period for your situation.'

Explain BasicMed: 'BasicMed: Alternative to third-class medical for certain operations. Requirements: Must have held medical certificate after July 14, 2006, Must complete medical education course every 24 months, Must have physical examination every 48 months, Must not have been denied medical certificate. Limitations: Private pilot operations only, Cannot fly above 18,000 feet MSL, Cannot fly faster than 250 knots, Cannot fly for compensation or hire, Other limitations apply. The key: BasicMed is alternative to third-class medical for private pilot operations - has specific requirements and limitations.'

Explain medical certificate expiration: 'Medical certificate expiration: Medical expires: At end of validity period (12, 24, or 60 months depending on class and age), Cannot be used after expiration date, Must renew before expiration to continue flying. Expired medical: Pilot cannot act as PIC, Cannot fly solo, Cannot carry passengers, Must renew medical before flight. The key: Medical certificate must be current - expired medical prevents flight operations.'

Explain medical certificate renewal: 'Medical certificate renewal: Must renew before expiration, Renewal requires: New medical examination, Meeting medical standards, Issuance of new medical certificate. If medical expires: Must renew before flight, Cannot fly with expired medical, Renewal process may take time. The key: Plan ahead for medical renewal - don't let medical expire, renew before expiration.'

Present medical renewal scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot's third-class medical expires in 2 weeks. They have a flight planned in 3 weeks. What should they do? [Wait] Analysis: Medical expires in 2 weeks, flight is in 3 weeks. Problem: Medical will be expired for flight. Solution: Renew medical before expiration (within next 2 weeks), Schedule medical examination immediately, Ensure new medical is issued before flight, If medical not renewed in time, must cancel or reschedule flight. The key: Plan ahead for medical renewal - renew before expiration to avoid flight cancellations.'

Emphasize medical requirements importance: 'Understanding medical certificate requirements is critical for: Verifying pilot qualifications, Ensuring pilots have current medicals, Teaching students about medical requirements, Planning medical renewals, Maintaining flight operations. The key: Always verify medical certificate is current - expired medical prevents flight operations.'

instructorActions: Write on board: 'Currency Requirements: 1) Flight Review, 2) Recent Flight Experience, 3) Instrument Currency, 4) Passenger Currency.'

Explain flight review comprehensively: 'Flight review (Part 61.56): Required: Every 24 calendar months, For all pilots (private, commercial, ATP), Cannot be waived. Requirements: 1 hour of ground instruction, 1 hour of flight instruction, Must be conducted by authorized instructor (CFI), Must cover: General operating and flight rules, Safe flight practices, Aircraft systems, Emergency procedures. The key: Flight review is required every 24 months - cannot be waived, must be conducted by CFI.'

Present flight review scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot's last flight review was completed on January 15, 2023. Today is January 10, 2025. Can they fly? [Wait] Analysis: Flight review was January 15, 2023. Today is January 10, 2025. Time since flight review: 24 months minus 5 days = 23 months and 26 days. Flight review is still valid (within 24 months). Pilot can fly. However, if today was January 20, 2025, flight review would be expired (24 months and 5 days > 24 months). The key: Flight review expires after 24 calendar months - calculate carefully, renew before expiration.'

Explain recent flight experience: 'Recent flight experience (Part 61.57): Required for: Carrying passengers, Acting as PIC. Requirements: 3 takeoffs and 3 landings in last 90 days, In same category and class of aircraft, To full stop (for landplanes), Day currency: Day takeoffs and landings, Night currency: Night takeoffs and landings (1 hour after sunset, 1 hour before sunrise). The key: Recent flight experience is required to carry passengers - 3 takeoffs/landings in 90 days, day and night currency separate.'

Present recent flight experience scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot last flew on November 1, 2024 (3 takeoffs and landings). Today is January 25, 2025. Can they carry passengers? [Wait] Analysis: Last flight: November 1, 2024. Today: January 25, 2025. Time since last flight: 85 days. Requirement: 3 takeoffs/landings in last 90 days. 85 days < 90 days, so requirement is met. Pilot can carry passengers. However, if today was February 5, 2025 (96 days), requirement would not be met (96 days > 90 days). The key: Recent flight experience expires after 90 days - must have 3 takeoffs/landings within 90 days to carry passengers.'

Explain instrument currency: 'Instrument currency (Part 61.57): Required for: IFR flight operations, Flying in IMC (instrument meteorological conditions). Requirements: 6 instrument approaches in last 6 months, Holding procedures, Tracking and intercepting courses. Can be accomplished: In actual IMC, Under hood with safety pilot, In flight simulator or training device. The key: Instrument currency is required for IFR operations - 6 approaches in 6 months, can be accomplished various ways.'

Present instrument currency scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot's last instrument approaches were completed on August 15, 2024 (6 approaches). Today is February 10, 2025. Can they fly IFR? [Wait] Analysis: Last approaches: August 15, 2024. Today: February 10, 2025. Time since last approaches: 5 months and 26 days. Requirement: 6 approaches in last 6 months. 5 months 26 days < 6 months, so requirement is met. Pilot can fly IFR. However, if today was February 20, 2025 (6 months 5 days), requirement would not be met (6 months 5 days > 6 months). The key: Instrument currency expires after 6 months - must have 6 approaches within 6 months to fly IFR.'

Explain currency requirements summary: 'Currency requirements summary: Flight review: Every 24 months (cannot be waived), Recent flight experience: 3 takeoffs/landings in 90 days (to carry passengers), Instrument currency: 6 approaches in 6 months (for IFR operations), Each requirement is separate, All must be met for respective operations. The key: Currency requirements are separate - flight review, recent flight experience, and instrument currency each have their own requirements and validity periods.'

Explain currency restoration: 'Currency restoration: If currency expires: Must regain currency before operations, Flight review: Must complete new flight review, Recent flight experience: Must complete 3 takeoffs/landings, Instrument currency: Must complete 6 approaches. Cannot operate until currency is restored. The key: If currency expires, must restore before operations - cannot fly with expired currency.'

Emphasize currency requirements importance: 'Understanding currency requirements is critical for: Verifying pilot currency before flight, Ensuring pilots meet currency requirements, Teaching students about currency, Planning currency maintenance, Maintaining flight operations. The key: Always verify currency requirements are met - expired currency prevents certain operations.'

teachingScript.phase: Logbook Requirements and PIC Requirements (20 minutes)
instructorActions: Write on board: 'Logbook Requirements: What to log, Format, Retention. PIC Requirements: Qualifications, Responsibilities.'

Explain logbook requirements comprehensively: 'Logbook requirements (Part 61.51): What must be logged: Flight time (total time, PIC time, instruction received, solo time), Training received (dual instruction, ground instruction), Endorsements (solo, cross-country, complex, etc.), Currency (flight review, instrument currency), Other required entries. Format requirements: Permanent (ink, not pencil), Legible (readable), Organized (chronological), Complete (all required information). The key: Logbook must document flight experience - permanent, legible, organized, complete.'

Explain logbook retention: 'Logbook retention: Must be kept: For duration of pilot career, For specific periods (varies by entry type), Available for inspection. Loss of logbook: Can reconstruct from other records, May require verification, Keep backup copies. The key: Logbook is permanent record - keep it safe, maintain backup copies.'

Present logbook scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot's logbook was damaged in a fire. They have: Electronic logbook backup, Some paper records, Some flight school records. Can they reconstruct their logbook? [Wait] Analysis: Logbook can be reconstructed from: Electronic backup (if available), Paper records, Flight school records, Maintenance records, Other documentation. Process: Gather all available records, Reconstruct entries chronologically, Verify accuracy, Create new logbook with reconstructed entries. The key: Logbook can be reconstructed from other records - keep backup copies, maintain multiple records.'

Explain PIC qualifications: 'PIC qualifications (Part 61.3): Must have: Appropriate certificate and ratings for flight, Current medical certificate, Currency requirements met (flight review, recent flight experience if carrying passengers), Proper logbook documentation, Understanding of responsibilities. PIC is: Pilot who has final authority and responsibility for operation and safety of flight, Must meet all qualification requirements. The key: PIC must have appropriate certificate, current medical, currency, and understanding of responsibilities.'

Explain PIC responsibilities: 'PIC responsibilities: Final authority: PIC has final authority for operation and safety of flight, Can override others (including passengers, crew), Must make safety decisions. Responsibilities: Ensure aircraft is airworthy, Ensure all requirements are met, Ensure safe operation, Comply with regulations, Make go/no-go decisions. The key: PIC has final authority and responsibility - must ensure safe operation and compliance with regulations.'

Present PIC scenario: 'Scenario: A private pilot is flying with a more experienced pilot in the right seat. The private pilot holds the certificate and is acting as PIC. The experienced pilot suggests flying into weather that the private pilot is not comfortable with. Who has final authority? [Wait] Analysis: PIC has final authority for operation and safety of flight. Even if more experienced pilot is present, PIC (private pilot) has final authority. PIC can: Override suggestions, Make final decisions, Refuse to fly into weather, Make go/no-go decisions. The key: PIC has final authority - even with more experienced pilots present, PIC makes final decisions.'

Explain when pilot can act as PIC: 'When pilot can act as PIC: Must have: Appropriate certificate and ratings, Current medical, Currency requirements met, Understanding of responsibilities. Cannot act as PIC if: Certificate not appropriate, Medical expired, Currency not met, Not qualified for operation. The key: Pilot can only act as PIC if all qualification requirements are met - verify all requirements before acting as PIC.'

Emphasize logbook and PIC requirements importance: 'Understanding logbook and PIC requirements is critical for: Proper documentation of flight experience, Verifying pilot qualifications, Teaching students about logbooks, Ensuring PIC qualifications are met, Maintaining proper records. The key: Logbook documentation and PIC qualifications are essential - maintain proper records, verify all requirements are met.'

Explain student pilot limitations: 'Student pilot limitations: Solo flight only (no passengers), Must have appropriate endorsements, Must fly with CFI for dual instruction, Cannot fly for compensation or hire, Specific airspace restrictions, Cannot fly at night without night training endorsement, Cannot fly cross-country without cross-country endorsement. Explain private pilot limitations: 'Private pilot limitations: Cannot fly for compensation or hire, Can fly for personal use, Can carry passengers, Subject to currency requirements, Must comply with operating limitations, Cannot fly commercial operations. Exceptions: Can share operating expenses (pro rata), Can receive compensation for certain operations (with appropriate authorizations). The key: Private pilot cannot fly for compensation - can fly for personal use and carry passengers.'

Explain commercial pilot limitations: 'Commercial pilot limitations: Can fly for compensation or hire, Subject to additional operating rules, Must have appropriate operations specifications for certain operations, Subject to commercial operating limitations, Must comply with all regulations. The key: Commercial pilot can fly for compensation - subject to additional operating rules and limitations.'

Present limitations scenario: 'Scenario: A private pilot is asked to fly a friend to another airport. The friend offers to pay for all fuel costs. Can the private pilot accept? [Wait] Analysis: Private pilot limitations: Cannot fly for compensation or hire. However, can share operating expenses (pro rata). If friend pays all fuel costs (more than pro rata share), this may be considered compensation. Recommendation: Private pilot can share operating expenses pro rata, but should not accept payment beyond pro rata share. If friend wants to pay all costs, this may violate private pilot limitations. The key: Private pilot can share expenses pro rata, but cannot accept compensation beyond pro rata share.'

Explain CFI limitations: 'CFI limitations: Can provide flight instruction, Can endorse students, Subject to CFI currency requirements, Must maintain CFI certificate, Must comply with CFI operating rules, Cannot provide instruction beyond certificate/rating limitations. The key: CFI can provide instruction - subject to CFI currency requirements and operating rules.'

Explain limitation importance: 'Understanding limitations is critical for: Ensuring compliance with regulations, Teaching students about limitations, Verifying pilot qualifications, Preventing violations, Maintaining safe operations. The key: Always understand and comply with limitations - violations can result in certificate action.'

Emphasize limitations summary: 'Limitations summary: Student pilot: Solo only, no passengers, requires endorsements. Private pilot: Cannot fly for compensation, can fly for personal use. instructorActions: Summarize key concepts: 'Let's review what we covered: Pilot certificate requirements - student, private, commercial, CFI certificates and their specific requirements. Present comprehensive scenario: 'Scenario: A private pilot wants to take a friend flying. Can they take their friend flying? [Wait] Analysis: Certificate: Private pilot certificate is valid (does not expire). Medical: Third-class medical, 35 years old, issued 3 years ago. Validity: 60 months if under 40, so medical is valid (3 years = 36 months < 60 months). Flight review: 18 months ago, valid (18 months < 24 months). Recent flight experience: 45 days ago, valid (45 days < 90 days). Logbook: Current. Conclusion: Pilot can take friend flying - all requirements are met. The key: Verify all requirements - certificate, medical, currency, logbook - all must be current.'

Review objectives: 'Let's check our objectives: Can you explain certificate requirements? Understand medical requirements? Identify currency requirements? Explain logbook requirements? Understand PIC requirements? Recognize limitations? If yes to all, you've mastered this lesson.'

Assign homework: 'Read Part 61 (certificate requirements), Part 67 (medical requirements), Part 91 (currency requirements). Review your own qualifications: Check your certificate, medical, currency status, logbook. Write one paragraph analyzing your own qualification status and what you need to maintain currency.'

Close: 'This knowledge of pilot qualifications will support everything else you do as a CFI. Master this, and you'll be able to verify qualifications properly, teach students about certification, and maintain your own qualifications. Questions before we wrap up?'

lessonPlans.title: Airworthiness Requirements
objectives: Explain airworthiness certificate requirements including standard airworthiness certificate (permanent, does not expire, must be displayed in aircraft), special airworthiness certificates (experimental, limited, restricted categories), and how airworthiness certificate differs from registration and operating limitations

Understand registration requirements including registration certificate (must be in aircraft, expires every 3 years, must be renewed), N-number display requirements (must be displayed on aircraft exterior), and registration expiration and renewal procedures

Identify required equipment including VFR day equipment (Part 91.205: airspeed indicator, altimeter, magnetic compass, engine instruments, fuel gauges, ELT), VFR night equipment (all day equipment plus position lights, anti-collision lights, landing light, electrical system), and how inoperative equipment affects flight operations

Understand maintenance requirements including annual inspection (required every 12 calendar months, conducted by IA or repair station, covers entire aircraft), 100-hour inspection (required if aircraft used for hire, every 100 hours, same scope as annual), and how inspection expiration affects airworthiness

Explain Airworthiness Directives (ADs) including AD types (emergency ADs requiring immediate compliance, regular ADs with specified compliance dates, recurring ADs at specified intervals), AD compliance requirements (must be complied with, documented in maintenance records, verified during inspections), and how non-compliance affects airworthiness

Recognize airworthiness determination including what makes aircraft airworthy (valid airworthiness certificate, current inspections, AD compliance, operational required equipment, safe condition), pilot responsibility for airworthiness determination, and how to verify airworthiness before flight
Teach airworthiness requirements to students effectively explaining certificates, registration, equipment, maintenance, ADs, and airworthiness determination with integrated scenarios

lessonPlans.overview: Airworthiness requirements are fundamental to safe flight operations. Understanding airworthiness certificates, registration, required equipment, maintenance requirements, Airworthiness Directives (ADs), and airworthiness determination enables CFIs to teach students about aircraft airworthiness, help students understand what makes an aircraft legal to fly, verify aircraft airworthiness before flight, ensure students understand maintenance requirements, and teach proper preflight inspection procedures. This lesson covers airworthiness certificate requirements (standard and special certificates, display requirements, permanence), registration requirements (registration certificate, N-number display, expiration and renewal), required equipment (VFR day/night equipment per Part 91.205, ELT requirements, inoperative equipment procedures), maintenance requirements (annual inspection every 12 months, 100-hour inspection if used for hire, maintenance records), Airworthiness Directives (AD types, compliance requirements, documentation), and airworthiness determination (what makes aircraft airworthy, pilot responsibility, verification procedures). Understanding these concepts enables CFIs to teach proper airworthiness requirements and helps pilots determine if aircraft are legal and safe to fly.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering one of the most critical topics for flight instructors - Airworthiness Requirements. This knowledge is essential because as a CFI, you'll constantly be verifying that aircraft are legal and safe to fly. Understanding airworthiness requirements enables you to teach students about aircraft airworthiness, help them understand what makes an aircraft legal to fly, verify aircraft airworthiness before flight, ensure students understand maintenance requirements, and teach proper preflight inspection procedures. This knowledge is also critical for your own operations - you must understand airworthiness requirements to determine if aircraft are legal and safe to fly. Let's ensure you have comprehensive knowledge of airworthiness requirements.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Airworthiness Requirements'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: explain airworthiness certificate requirements including standard and special certificates, understand registration requirements including expiration and renewal, identify required equipment including VFR day/night equipment per Part 91.205, understand maintenance requirements including annual and 100-hour inspections, explain Airworthiness Directives (ADs) including types and compliance requirements, recognize airworthiness determination including what makes aircraft airworthy and pilot responsibility, and teach airworthiness requirements to students effectively. These aren't just checkride topics - these skills are essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about your preflight inspection. What documents do you check? What equipment do you verify? What inspections must be current? These questions touch on airworthiness requirements - let's explore them systematically.'

Listen actively to student response, nodding and taking notes on their examples: 'That's a great example. I'm noting that you mentioned checking the airworthiness certificate and annual inspection. Let's explore all the requirements and how they work together.'

Transition statement: 'Excellent observations. What you're describing touches on several key concepts we'll cover today: airworthiness certificate requirements (standard and special certificates, display requirements, permanence), registration requirements (registration certificate, N-number display, expiration and renewal), required equipment (VFR day/night equipment, ELT, inoperative equipment procedures), maintenance requirements (annual inspection, 100-hour inspection, maintenance records), Airworthiness Directives (AD types, compliance requirements, documentation), and airworthiness determination (what makes aircraft airworthy, pilot responsibility, verification procedures). These aren't just regulatory knowledge - they're practical requirements that affect every flight. Let's explore these systematically.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing several key documents: Part 23 - Airworthiness Standards, covers aircraft certification standards. Part 39 - Airworthiness Directives, covers mandatory AD requirements. Part 43 - Maintenance, covers maintenance requirements and procedures. Part 91 - General Operating and Flight Rules, covers equipment requirements (Part 91.205) and maintenance requirements (Part 91.409). The Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge - covers airworthiness concepts. These documents provide comprehensive guidance, and I recommend you study them thoroughly.'

Explain the importance of airworthiness knowledge: 'Here's why this matters: As a CFI, you'll constantly be: Verifying aircraft airworthiness before flight, Teaching students about airworthiness requirements, Ensuring students understand maintenance requirements, Teaching proper preflight inspection procedures, Helping students determine if aircraft are legal to fly. Understanding airworthiness requirements enables you to: Teach students about airworthiness, Verify aircraft airworthiness properly, Ensure compliance with regulations, Help students understand maintenance, Maintain safe flight operations. Many flight operations issues involve aircraft that weren't airworthy - expired inspections, inoperative equipment, non-compliance with ADs. Understanding airworthiness requirements enables safe flight operations and effective instruction.'

Explain the airworthiness concept: 'The fundamental concept: Aircraft is airworthy if: Has valid airworthiness certificate (permanent, does not expire), Has current registration (expires every 3 years), Has current inspections (annual every 12 months, 100-hour if used for hire), All ADs are complied with (mandatory, must be documented), All required equipment is operational (Part 91.205 for VFR day/night), Aircraft is in condition for safe operation. The key: Airworthiness is not optional - it's required for legal flight operations. Understanding airworthiness enables you to verify compliance and teach students properly.'

Explain airworthiness verification: 'Airworthiness verification is essential: Before every flight, verify: Airworthiness certificate is present and valid, Registration is current (not expired), Required equipment is operational, Inspections are current (annual, 100-hour if applicable), ADs are complied with, Aircraft is in safe condition. As a CFI, you must: Verify aircraft airworthiness before flight, Ensure students understand airworthiness, Teach proper preflight inspection procedures, Help students determine airworthiness, Document airworthiness verification. The key: Always verify airworthiness - don't assume, verify.'

Set CFI context: 'On your CFI checkride, you'll be asked about airworthiness requirements. The examiner wants to see that you understand: Airworthiness certificate requirements and types, Registration requirements and expiration, Required equipment (Part 91.205), Maintenance requirements (annual, 100-hour), AD requirements and compliance, Airworthiness determination procedures. You should be able to teach these concepts clearly and explain how they apply to actual flight operations. This lesson prepares you for that.'

Preview lesson structure: 'We'll cover this in several phases: first, we'll explore airworthiness certificate and registration requirements - standard and special certificates, registration expiration and renewal. Then we'll discuss required equipment - VFR day/night equipment per Part 91.205, ELT requirements, inoperative equipment procedures. Next, we'll cover maintenance requirements - annual inspection, 100-hour inspection, maintenance records. Then we'll discuss Airworthiness Directives - AD types, compliance requirements, documentation. Finally, we'll cover airworthiness determination - what makes aircraft airworthy, pilot responsibility, verification procedures. Each phase builds on the previous one.'

Emphasize practical application: 'Remember: Airworthiness requirements are practical requirements that affect every flight. Before every flight, you must verify: Airworthiness certificate, Current registration, Operational required equipment, Current inspections, AD compliance, Safe condition. As a CFI, you'll constantly be teaching and verifying airworthiness. Understanding airworthiness requirements enables safe flight operations and effective instruction. Let's ensure you have comprehensive knowledge of airworthiness requirements.'

Ask for questions before proceeding: 'Before we dive in, do you have any questions about what we'll cover today? What aspects of airworthiness requirements are you most curious or concerned about? Have you had any experiences where airworthiness was an issue?'

instructorActions: Write on board: 'Required Documents: Airworthiness Certificate, Registration, Operating Limitations, Weight and Balance.'

Explain airworthiness certificate: 'Airworthiness Certificate: Required for all aircraft. Types: Standard (normal category), Special (experimental, limited, restricted). Must be displayed in aircraft (typically in cockpit). Certificate is permanent - does not expire. Aircraft must have valid airworthiness certificate to fly.'

Explain registration: 'Registration: Required for all aircraft. Registration certificate must be in aircraft. Registration number (N-number) must be displayed on aircraft. Registration expires: Every 3 years (must be renewed), When aircraft is sold (new owner must register), When aircraft is destroyed. Must have valid registration to fly.'

Explain operating limitations: 'Operating Limitations: Must be in aircraft. Includes: POH/AFM, Placards, Markings, Weight and balance data, Equipment list. Operating limitations specify: Weight limits, CG limits, Speed limits, Equipment requirements, Operating restrictions. Must comply with all operating limitations.'

Explain weight and balance: 'Weight and Balance: Must have current weight and balance data. Includes: Empty weight, CG location, Equipment list, Loading instructions. Weight and balance must be: Current (updated when equipment added/removed), Accurate, Available in aircraft. Required for safe flight operations.'

Present detailed scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot wants to fly an aircraft on March 15, 2025. They check the aircraft and find: Airworthiness certificate is present (issued in 1995, still valid), Registration certificate shows expiration date of January 10, 2025 (expired 2 months ago), Operating limitations (POH/AFM) are in aircraft, Weight and balance data is current (updated 6 months ago). Can they fly? [Wait] Analysis: Airworthiness certificate: Present and valid (permanent, does not expire). Registration: Expired on January 10, 2025, today is March 15, 2025 (expired 2 months ago). Operating limitations: Present. Weight and balance: Current. Problem: Registration expired 2 months ago. Solution: Aircraft cannot be flown with expired registration. Pilot must: Renew registration before flight (contact FAA, complete renewal process), Verify new registration is issued and current, Ensure all documents are valid before flight. Other documents are valid, but expired registration prevents flight. The key: All documents must be current - expired registration prevents flight, even if other documents are valid.'

Present registration renewal scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot's aircraft registration expires on June 1, 2025. They have a flight planned on May 25, 2025. What should they do? [Wait] Analysis: Registration expires June 1, 2025, flight is May 25, 2025. Registration is still valid (May 25 < June 1). However, registration renewal process can take time. Recommendation: Renew registration well before expiration (at least 30-60 days before), Don't wait until last minute, Verify new registration is issued before expiration, If renewal not completed before expiration, cannot fly until renewal is complete. The key: Plan ahead for registration renewal - don't wait until expiration, renewal process takes time.'

instructorActions: Write on board: 'Required Equipment: Part 91.205 (VFR day/night), ELT, Emergency equipment, Operating equipment.'

Explain VFR day equipment: 'VFR day equipment (Part 91.205): Airspeed indicator, Altimeter, Magnetic compass, Tachometer (for each engine), Oil pressure gauge (for each engine), Temperature gauge (for each liquid-cooled engine), Fuel quantity gauge (for each tank), Landing gear position indicator (if retractable), ELT (Emergency Locator Transmitter). All equipment must be operational.'

Explain VFR night equipment: 'VFR night equipment: All day equipment plus: Position lights (navigation lights), Anti-collision lights (strobe or beacon), Landing light, Electrical system, Spare fuses. Additional equipment required for night flight. All equipment must be operational for night flight.'

Explain ELT: 'ELT (Emergency Locator Transmitter): Required on all aircraft. Types: 121.5 MHz (older), 406 MHz (newer, satellite-capable). Must be: Operational, Inspected annually, Tested monthly (if 406 MHz), Properly installed. ELT activates automatically on impact or manually. Critical for search and rescue.'

Explain emergency equipment: 'Emergency equipment: Recommended but not always required: First aid kit, Fire extinguisher, Survival equipment (for cross-country), Emergency procedures checklist. Required for: Commercial operations, Certain flight operations. Check POH and regulations for specific requirements.'

Explain operating equipment: 'Operating equipment: Required for safe operation: Flight controls (must be operational), Engine controls (must be operational), Navigation equipment (if required for flight), Communication equipment (if required for airspace). All operating equipment must be functional for flight.'

Present detailed night equipment scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot plans a night VFR flight. They check the aircraft: All day VFR equipment is operational (airspeed, altimeter, compass, engine instruments, fuel gauges, ELT), Position lights (navigation lights) work, Anti-collision lights (strobe) work, Landing light is inoperative (bulb burned out), Electrical system is operational, Spare fuses are available. Can they fly at night? [Wait] Analysis: Day VFR equipment: All operational (meets Part 91.205 day requirements). Night VFR equipment: Position lights - operational, Anti-collision lights - operational, Landing light - inoperative (required for night VFR), Electrical system - operational, Spare fuses - available. Problem: Landing light is required for night VFR flight (Part 91.205). If landing light is inoperative, aircraft cannot fly at night. Options: Repair landing light before flight (replace bulb, verify operation), Fly during day only (if flight can be conducted during day), Get maintenance release if landing light is not required (unlikely - landing light is required for night VFR). Solution: Cannot fly at night with inoperative landing light. Must repair before night flight or fly during day only. The key: All required equipment must be operational - inoperative landing light prevents night flight, even if other equipment is operational.'

Present inoperative equipment scenario: 'Scenario: During preflight, pilot finds the fuel quantity gauge for the left tank is inoperative (reads empty but tank is full). All other required equipment is operational. Can they fly VFR day? [Wait] Analysis: Fuel quantity gauge is required equipment per Part 91.205 (for each tank). If inoperative, options: Get maintenance release (defer maintenance per Part 91.213), Placard gauge as inoperative, Verify fuel quantity by visual inspection (dipstick, visual check), Ensure other required equipment is operational. If maintenance release obtained and gauge placarded, can fly. However, must verify fuel quantity by other means (visual inspection, fuel receipt records). The key: Inoperative required equipment may be deferred with maintenance release and placard - but must verify fuel quantity by other means.'

instructorActions: Write on board: 'Maintenance Requirements: Annual inspection, 100-hour inspection, AD compliance, Airworthiness.'

Explain annual inspection: 'Annual inspection (Part 91.409): Required every 12 calendar months. Must be conducted by: A&P (Airframe and Powerplant) mechanic with inspection authorization (IA), Or certified repair station. Inspection covers: Entire aircraft, All systems, All components. Aircraft must have current annual inspection to fly.'

Explain 100-hour inspection: '100-hour inspection: Required if aircraft is used for hire (flight training, charter, etc.). Must be conducted: Every 100 hours of flight time, By A&P mechanic or certified repair station. Same scope as annual inspection. If aircraft is not used for hire, 100-hour inspection is not required (only annual).'

Explain AD compliance: 'AD (Airworthiness Directive) compliance: ADs are mandatory. Must be: Complied with before flight (if required), Documented in maintenance records, Verified during inspections. ADs address: Safety issues, Defects, Mandatory modifications. Non-compliance with ADs makes aircraft unairworthy.'

Explain airworthiness determination: 'Airworthiness determination: Aircraft is airworthy if: Has valid airworthiness certificate, Has current annual inspection (and 100-hour if required), All ADs are complied with, All required equipment is operational, Aircraft is in condition for safe operation. Pilot is responsible for determining airworthiness before flight.'

Explain maintenance records: 'Maintenance records: Must document: Annual inspections, 100-hour inspections, AD compliance, Repairs, Alterations, Modifications. Records must be: Current, Accurate, Available. Pilot must review maintenance records before flight to verify airworthiness.'

Present detailed annual inspection scenario: 'Scenario: An aircraft's annual inspection was completed on February 15, 2024. Today is January 10, 2025. The aircraft has 50 hours since annual. Can the aircraft be flown? What about on February 20, 2025? [Wait] Analysis: Annual inspection: February 15, 2024. Today: January 10, 2025. Time since annual: 10 months and 26 days (still within 12 months). Annual is still valid - aircraft can be flown. On February 20, 2025: Time since annual: 12 months and 5 days (exceeds 12 months). Annual will be expired - aircraft cannot be flown until new annual inspection is completed. If aircraft is used for hire: 100-hour inspection may also be required. If aircraft has 50 hours since annual and is used for hire, 100-hour inspection is not yet required (50 hours < 100 hours). However, if aircraft reaches 100 hours before annual expires, 100-hour inspection is required. The key: Annual inspection expires after 12 calendar months - cannot fly with expired annual. 100-hour inspection is required if aircraft used for hire and reaches 100 hours.'

Present 100-hour inspection scenario: 'Scenario: An aircraft used for flight training has 95 hours since last 100-hour inspection. Annual inspection is current (completed 6 months ago). Can the aircraft be flown? What about after 5 more hours? [Wait] Analysis: 100-hour inspection: 95 hours since last inspection. Annual inspection: Current (6 months ago). Current status: 100-hour inspection is still valid (95 hours < 100 hours), annual inspection is current. Aircraft can be flown. After 5 more hours: 100 hours total since last 100-hour inspection. 100-hour inspection is now required - aircraft cannot be flown until 100-hour inspection is completed. Annual inspection is still current (6 months < 12 months). The key: 100-hour inspection is required every 100 hours if aircraft is used for hire - cannot fly after 100 hours until inspection is completed.'

teachingScript.phase: Airworthiness Directives and Preflight Inspection (15 minutes)
instructorActions: Write on board: 'ADs and Preflight: AD types, Compliance, Preflight inspection, Airworthiness determination.'

Explain AD types: 'AD types: Emergency ADs (immediate compliance required), Regular ADs (compliance by specified date), Recurring ADs (compliance at specified intervals). ADs address: Safety issues, Defects, Mandatory modifications, Mandatory inspections. All ADs are mandatory - must be complied with.'

Explain AD compliance: 'AD compliance: Must be: Completed before flight (if required), Documented in maintenance records, Verified during inspections. Compliance methods: Inspection, Modification, Replacement, Limitation. Check maintenance records to verify AD compliance.'

Explain preflight inspection: 'Preflight inspection: Pilot's responsibility to verify airworthiness. Check: Airworthiness certificate (present, valid), Registration (present, current), Operating limitations (present), Weight and balance (current), Required equipment (operational), Maintenance records (current inspections, AD compliance), Aircraft condition (safe for flight).'

Explain airworthiness determination: 'Airworthiness determination: Before every flight, pilot must determine aircraft is airworthy. Check: All documents are current, All required equipment is operational, All inspections are current, All ADs are complied with, Aircraft is in condition for safe operation. If any item is not met, aircraft is not airworthy - cannot fly.'

Present detailed AD scenario: 'Scenario: During preflight inspection on March 1, 2025, pilot finds: Airworthiness certificate present, Registration current (expires June 2026), Annual inspection current (completed January 15, 2025), Maintenance records show one AD (AD 2024-15-12) with compliance due date of March 15, 2025 (2 weeks away). Can the aircraft be flown? [Wait] Analysis: Airworthiness certificate: Present and valid. Registration: Current (expires June 2026). Annual inspection: Current (January 15, 2025, within 12 months). AD compliance: AD 2024-15-12 due March 15, 2025, today is March 1, 2025 (compliance due in 2 weeks, future date). Analysis: AD compliance is due in 2 weeks (future date), not yet required. Aircraft can be flown until compliance date (March 15, 2025). However, pilot should: Verify AD requirements (read AD to understand what's required), Plan for compliance before due date (schedule maintenance), Ensure compliance is scheduled (don't wait until last minute), Monitor compliance date (cannot fly after March 15 if not complied with). The key: ADs must be complied with by specified date - can fly before due date, but must comply by due date or aircraft becomes unairworthy.'

Present emergency AD scenario: 'Scenario: An emergency AD (AD 2025-05-01) is issued requiring immediate compliance before next flight. Pilot has a flight planned in 2 hours. What should they do? [Wait] Analysis: Emergency AD requires immediate compliance before next flight. Flight is planned in 2 hours. Problem: AD must be complied with before flight. Options: Comply with AD immediately (if possible within 2 hours), Cancel or delay flight until AD is complied with, Verify AD requirements and determine if compliance can be completed. Solution: Cannot fly until AD is complied with. Must either: Comply with AD before flight (if possible), Cancel or delay flight until compliance is complete. Emergency ADs are critical - cannot fly until complied with. The key: Emergency ADs require immediate compliance - cannot fly until AD is complied with, even if flight is already planned.'

instructorActions: Summarize key concepts: 'Let's review what we covered: Airworthiness certificate requirements - standard and special certificates, permanent and does not expire, must be displayed. Registration requirements - expires every 3 years, must be renewed, N-number must be displayed. Required equipment - VFR day equipment (Part 91.205), VFR night equipment (additional requirements), all must be operational. Maintenance requirements - annual inspection every 12 months, 100-hour inspection if used for hire (every 100 hours), maintenance records must be current. Airworthiness Directives - mandatory, must be complied with by specified date, documented in maintenance records. Airworthiness determination - pilot responsibility, verify all requirements before flight. These aren't just regulatory knowledge - they're practical requirements that affect every flight.'

Present comprehensive scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot wants to fly an aircraft on April 10, 2025. Preflight inspection reveals: Airworthiness certificate present (issued 2000, still valid), Registration current (expires August 2026), All VFR day equipment operational, Annual inspection completed February 1, 2025 (2 months ago), Aircraft used for flight training, 85 hours since last 100-hour inspection, All ADs complied with (last AD due March 1, 2025, complied with). Can the aircraft be flown? [Wait] Analysis: Airworthiness certificate: Present and valid (permanent, does not expire). Registration: Current (expires August 2026). Required equipment: All VFR day equipment operational. Annual inspection: Completed February 1, 2025, today is April 10, 2025 (2 months < 12 months, current). 100-hour inspection: 85 hours since last inspection, aircraft used for hire, 85 hours < 100 hours (still valid). ADs: All complied with. Conclusion: Aircraft is airworthy - all requirements met. Can be flown. The key: Verify all requirements - certificate, registration, equipment, inspections, ADs - all must be current and valid.'

Ask synthesis question: 'How do all these airworthiness requirements work together? Give me one example of how airworthiness certificate, registration, equipment, maintenance, and ADs all interact in a single preflight inspection scenario.'

Listen to student response and provide feedback: 'Excellent - you're connecting the concepts. That's exactly how effective CFIs think - holistically, verifying all requirements together. Every preflight requires: Valid airworthiness certificate, Current registration, Operational required equipment, Current inspections, AD compliance, Safe condition. All must be verified before flight.'

Review objectives: 'Let's check our objectives: Can you explain airworthiness certificate requirements? Understand registration requirements? Identify required equipment? Understand maintenance requirements? Explain ADs? Recognize airworthiness determination? If yes to all, you've mastered this lesson.'

Assign homework: 'Read Part 91.205 (equipment requirements) and Part 91.409 (maintenance requirements). Study Part 39 (Airworthiness Directives). Review maintenance records from an actual aircraft. Practice preflight inspection checklist. Write one paragraph analyzing how you would verify airworthiness for a specific aircraft scenario.'

Close: 'This knowledge of airworthiness requirements will support everything else you do as a CFI. Master this, and you'll be able to verify aircraft airworthiness properly, teach students about airworthiness, and maintain safe flight operations. Always verify airworthiness before flight - documents, equipment, inspections, ADs. Questions before we wrap up?'

lessonPlans.title: Weather Information
objectives: Explain weather information sources including METARs (current conditions, updated hourly, contains wind/visibility/weather/clouds/temperature/dew point/altimeter), TAFs (forecast conditions, valid 24-30 hours, updated every 6-12 hours), AIRMETs (weather advisories for all aircraft, valid 6 hours, types: Sierra/IFR, Tango/turbulence, Zulu/icing), SIGMETs (significant weather hazards, valid 4-6 hours, types: convective/thunderstorms, non-convective/severe conditions), PIREPs (pilot reports, real-time conditions), and weather briefings (standard, abbreviated, outlook)

Understand weather interpretation including visibility (VFR minimums: 3 miles controlled airspace, 1 mile Class G day, 3 miles Class G night), clouds and ceiling (VFR minimums: clear of clouds controlled, 500/1000/2000 Class G), wind (affects takeoff/landing, crosswind limits, fuel consumption), weather phenomena (precipitation, thunderstorms, fog, haze), and pressure/temperature (affects altitude indication and aircraft performance)

Identify weather decision-making factors including go/no-go decision (based on current weather, forecasts, advisories, personal minimums), risk assessment (evaluate weather risks, consider conditions, trends, hazards), alternatives (delay, cancel, change route/altitude, land early, divert), and personal minimums (higher than legal minimums, provide safety margin)

Explain weather minimums including VFR minimums by airspace class (controlled airspace: 3 miles visibility, clear of clouds; Class G: 1 mile visibility day, 3 miles night, 500/1000/2000 cloud separation), IFR minimums, and how weather minimums affect flight operations

Understand weather hazards including thunderstorms (avoid completely, severe turbulence, icing, hail, lightning), icing conditions (structural icing, carburetor icing, freezing levels), turbulence (light, moderate, severe), low visibility (fog, precipitation, haze, smoke), and how to identify and avoid weather hazards

Recognize weather briefing procedures including standard briefing (comprehensive, recommended before every flight), abbreviated briefing (specific information), outlook briefing (future flight), what information to request, and how to interpret briefing information
Teach weather information to students effectively explaining weather sources, interpretation, decision-making, minimums, hazards, and briefing procedures with integrated scenarios
references: 14 CFR part 91 (General Operating and Flight Rules)
AC 91-92 (Pilot's Guide to a Preflight Briefing)
AIM Chapter 7 (Safety of Flight - Weather Services)
FAA-H-8083-25 Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge
prerequisites: Completion of Area I lessons (Fundamentals of Instruction)
Completion of LP-III-A (Pilot Qualifications) and LP-III-B (Airworthiness Requirements)
Basic understanding of aviation weather and meteorology

Understanding of VFR and IFR weather minimums
lessonPlans.overview: Weather information is fundamental to safe flight operations. Understanding weather sources, interpretation, decision-making, minimums, hazards, and briefing procedures enables CFIs to teach students about weather, help students understand weather information, verify weather adequacy before flight, ensure students make safe weather decisions, and teach proper weather briefing procedures. This lesson covers weather information sources (METARs current conditions, TAFs forecasts, AIRMETs/SIGMETs advisories, PIREPs pilot reports, weather briefings), weather interpretation (visibility, clouds, wind, weather phenomena, pressure/temperature), weather decision-making (go/no-go decisions, risk assessment, alternatives, personal minimums), weather minimums (VFR minimums by airspace class, IFR minimums), weather hazards (thunderstorms, icing, turbulence, low visibility), and weather briefing procedures (standard, abbreviated, outlook briefings). Understanding these concepts enables CFIs to teach proper weather information and helps pilots make safe weather-related flight decisions.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering one of the most critical topics for flight instructors - Weather Information. This knowledge is essential because weather is a leading cause of aviation accidents. As a CFI, you'll constantly be helping students understand weather, verify weather adequacy before flight, and make safe weather-related decisions. Understanding weather information enables you to teach students about weather sources, help them interpret weather data, ensure students make safe weather decisions, and teach proper weather briefing procedures. This knowledge is also critical for your own operations - you must understand weather to make safe flight decisions. Let's ensure you have comprehensive knowledge of weather information.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Weather Information'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: explain weather information sources including METARs, TAFs, AIRMETs, SIGMETs, PIREPs, and weather briefings, understand weather interpretation including visibility, clouds, wind, weather phenomena, and pressure/temperature, identify weather decision-making factors including go/no-go decisions, risk assessment, alternatives, and personal minimums, explain weather minimums including VFR minimums by airspace class and IFR minimums, understand weather hazards including thunderstorms, icing, turbulence, and low visibility, recognize weather briefing procedures including standard, abbreviated, and outlook briefings, and teach weather information to students effectively. These aren't just checkride topics - these skills are essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about your last flight. What weather information did you check? Where did you get it? How did you decide if the weather was adequate? These questions touch on weather information - let's explore them systematically.'

Listen actively to student response, nodding and taking notes on their examples: 'That's a great example. I'm noting that you mentioned checking METARs and TAFs. Let's explore all the weather sources and how they work together.'

Transition statement: 'Excellent observations. What you're describing touches on several key concepts we'll cover today: weather information sources (METARs, TAFs, AIRMETs, SIGMETs, PIREPs, briefings), weather interpretation (visibility, clouds, wind, weather phenomena, pressure/temperature), weather decision-making (go/no-go decisions, risk assessment, alternatives, personal minimums), weather minimums (VFR minimums by airspace class, IFR minimums), weather hazards (thunderstorms, icing, turbulence, low visibility), and weather briefing procedures (standard, abbreviated, outlook briefings). These aren't just academic knowledge - they're practical requirements that affect every flight. Let's explore these systematically.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing several key documents: AIM Chapter 7 - Weather Services, provides comprehensive guidance on weather sources and services. AC 91-92 - Pilot's Guide to a Preflight Briefing, covers weather briefing procedures. FAA-H-8083-28 - Aviation Weather Handbook, covers weather theory and interpretation. The Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge - covers weather basics. These documents provide comprehensive guidance, and I recommend you study them thoroughly.'

Explain the importance of weather knowledge: 'Here's why this matters: Weather is a leading cause of aviation accidents. As a CFI, you'll constantly be: Helping students understand weather, Verifying weather adequacy before flight, Ensuring students make safe weather decisions, Teaching proper weather briefing procedures, Making your own weather decisions. Understanding weather information enables you to: Teach students about weather, Verify weather adequacy properly, Ensure compliance with weather minimums, Help students make safe decisions, Maintain safe flight operations. Many weather-related accidents involve pilots who didn't understand weather, didn't check weather adequately, or made poor weather decisions. Understanding weather information enables safe flight operations and effective instruction.'

Explain the weather information concept: 'The fundamental concept: Weather information comes from multiple sources: METARs provide current conditions, TAFs provide forecasts, AIRMETs/SIGMETs provide advisories, PIREPs provide real-time reports, Briefings provide comprehensive information. Weather must be interpreted: Visibility, clouds, wind, weather phenomena, pressure/temperature all affect flight. Weather decisions must be made: Go/no-go based on weather, Risk assessment, Alternatives available, Personal minimums. The key: Weather information is not optional - it's required for safe flight operations. Understanding weather enables you to make safe decisions and teach students properly.'

Explain weather decision-making: 'Weather decision-making is essential: Before every flight, determine: Is weather adequate? (Current conditions, forecasts, advisories), What are the risks? (Weather hazards, trends, personal minimums), What are alternatives? (Delay, cancel, change route, divert). As a CFI, you must: Help students understand weather, Verify weather adequacy before flight, Ensure students make safe decisions, Teach proper decision-making, Make your own safe decisions. The key: Always verify weather - don't assume, check multiple sources, interpret carefully, prioritize safety.'

Set CFI context: 'On your CFI checkride, you'll be asked about weather information. The examiner wants to see that you understand: Weather sources (METARs, TAFs, AIRMETs, SIGMETs, PIREPs, briefings), Weather interpretation (visibility, clouds, wind, weather phenomena), Weather decision-making (go/no-go, risk assessment, alternatives), Weather minimums (VFR by airspace class, IFR), Weather hazards (thunderstorms, icing, turbulence), Weather briefing procedures. You should be able to teach these concepts clearly and explain how they apply to actual flight operations. This lesson prepares you for that.'

Preview lesson structure: 'We'll cover this in several phases: first, we'll explore weather information sources - METARs, TAFs, AIRMETs, SIGMETs, PIREPs, and weather briefings. Then we'll discuss weather interpretation - visibility, clouds, wind, weather phenomena, pressure/temperature. Next, we'll cover weather decision-making - go/no-go decisions, risk assessment, alternatives, personal minimums. Then we'll discuss weather minimums - VFR minimums by airspace class, IFR minimums. Finally, we'll cover weather hazards and briefing procedures. Each phase builds on the previous one.'

Emphasize practical application: 'Remember: Weather information is practical knowledge that affects every flight. Before every flight, you must verify: Weather sources checked (METARs, TAFs, AIRMETs, SIGMETs), Weather interpreted (visibility, clouds, wind, weather phenomena), Weather decision made (go/no-go, risk assessment, alternatives), Weather minimums met (VFR or IFR as applicable), Weather hazards avoided (thunderstorms, icing, turbulence). As a CFI, you'll constantly be teaching and verifying weather. Understanding weather information enables safe flight operations and effective instruction. Let's ensure you have comprehensive knowledge of weather information.'

Ask for questions before proceeding: 'Before we dive in, do you have any questions about what we'll cover today? What aspects of weather information are you most curious or concerned about? Have you had any experiences where weather was an issue?'

instructorActions: Write on board: 'Weather Sources: METARs, TAFs, AIRMETs, SIGMETs, PIREPs, Weather briefings.'

Explain METARs: 'METARs (Meteorological Aerodrome Reports): Current weather conditions at airports. Updated: Hourly (or more frequently if conditions change). Contains: Wind, Visibility, Weather, Clouds, Temperature, Dew point, Altimeter setting, Remarks. Use METARs for: Current conditions, Departure and arrival weather, Weather trends. Essential for flight planning.'

Explain TAFs: 'TAFs (Terminal Aerodrome Forecasts): Forecast weather conditions at airports. Valid: 24-30 hours. Updated: Every 6-12 hours. Contains: Forecast wind, Visibility, Weather, Clouds, Time periods. Use TAFs for: Forecast conditions, Planning flight times, Anticipating weather changes. Essential for flight planning.'

Explain AIRMETs: 'AIRMETs (Airmen's Meteorological Information): Weather advisories for conditions affecting all aircraft. Types: AIRMET Sierra (IFR conditions, mountain obscuration), AIRMET Tango (turbulence, low-level wind shear), AIRMET Zulu (icing, freezing levels). Valid: 6 hours. Use AIRMETs for: Weather hazards, Flight planning, Route selection. Check AIRMETs before flight.'

Explain SIGMETs: 'SIGMETs (Significant Meteorological Information): Weather advisories for significant weather hazards. Types: Convective SIGMET (thunderstorms), Non-convective SIGMET (severe turbulence, icing, dust storms, volcanic ash). Valid: 4 hours (convective) or 6 hours (non-convective). Use SIGMETs for: Significant weather hazards, Flight planning, Route avoidance. SIGMETs indicate hazardous weather - avoid or plan around.'

Explain PIREPs: 'PIREPs (Pilot Reports): Weather reports from pilots in flight. Contains: Location, Altitude, Weather conditions, Turbulence, Icing, Visibility. Use PIREPs for: Real-time weather conditions, Weather verification, Route conditions. PIREPs provide actual conditions - very valuable for flight planning.'

Explain weather briefings: 'Weather briefings: Comprehensive weather information from FSS (Flight Service Station) or online. Types: Standard briefing (comprehensive), Abbreviated briefing (specific information), Outlook briefing (future flight). Contains: Current conditions, Forecasts, NOTAMs, AIRMETs/SIGMETs, PIREPs. Use weather briefings for: Complete weather picture, Professional weather information, Flight planning. Recommended before every flight.'

Present detailed weather sources scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot plans a cross-country flight on March 15, 2025, departing at 10:00 AM, flight time 2 hours. They check: METARs for departure and destination airports (current conditions good), TAFs for departure and destination (forecast conditions good). They do NOT check: AIRMETs, SIGMETs, PIREPs, or get a weather briefing. Is this adequate? What should they do? [Wait] Analysis: METARs and TAFs provide current and forecast conditions, but don't include weather advisories. Missing information: AIRMETs (IFR conditions, turbulence, icing advisories), SIGMETs (significant weather hazards, thunderstorms, severe conditions), PIREPs (real-time weather conditions from pilots), Weather briefing (comprehensive information including all sources). Problem: Pilot may miss weather hazards (thunderstorms, icing, turbulence) that aren't in METARs/TAFs. Solution: Pilot should: Check AIRMETs (IFR conditions, turbulence, icing - valid 6 hours), Check SIGMETs (significant weather hazards - valid 4-6 hours), Get weather briefing (comprehensive information from FSS or online), Check PIREPs (actual conditions along route). Weather briefings include all information (METARs, TAFs, AIRMETs, SIGMETs, PIREPs, NOTAMs). The key: Use multiple weather sources - METARs/TAFs for conditions, AIRMETs/SIGMETs for hazards, PIREPs for real-time conditions, briefings for comprehensive information. Never rely on only one or two sources.'

Present METAR interpretation scenario: 'Scenario: METAR for departure airport shows: KABC 151450Z 28015G25KT 10SM BKN030 OVC045 12/08 A2992. What does this tell you? [Wait] Analysis: KABC: Airport identifier. 151450Z: Date 15th, time 1450 UTC (2:50 PM local). 28015G25KT: Wind 280° at 15 knots, gusting to 25 knots. 10SM: Visibility 10 statute miles. BKN030: Broken clouds at 3,000 feet. OVC045: Overcast clouds at 4,500 feet. 12/08: Temperature 12°C, dew point 8°C. A2992: Altimeter setting 29.92 inches. Interpretation: Wind: 280° at 15 knots gusting 25 knots (crosswind component for runway 270° would be significant). Visibility: 10 miles (excellent, well above VFR minimums). Clouds: Broken at 3,000 feet, overcast at 4,500 feet (ceiling 3,000 feet, adequate for VFR). Temperature/dew point: 12°C/8°C (4°C spread, low risk of fog). Altimeter: 29.92 (standard). Conclusion: Weather is adequate for VFR flight, but wind gusts may be a concern. The key: METARs provide current conditions - interpret all elements, not just visibility and ceiling.'

Explain pressure and temperature: 'Pressure: Altimeter setting, affects altitude indication. Temperature: Affects aircraft performance, density altitude. Present detailed weather interpretation scenario: 'Scenario: METAR for departure airport shows: Visibility 2 miles, Ceiling 800 feet broken, Wind 270° at 15 knots gusting 25 knots, Temperature 5°C, Dew point 4°C. Runway is 270°. Can a VFR flight be conducted? What are the concerns? [Wait] Analysis: Visibility: 2 miles. VFR minimums: 3 miles in controlled airspace, 1 mile in Class G (day). If in controlled airspace: 2 miles < 3 miles (below minimum). If in Class G (day): 2 miles > 1 mile (meets minimum). Ceiling: 800 feet broken. VFR minimums: Clear of clouds in controlled airspace, 500 feet below clouds in Class G. If in controlled airspace: 800 feet ceiling may be marginal (need to stay 500 feet below = 300 feet AGL, very low). If in Class G: 800 feet ceiling is adequate (500 feet below = 300 feet AGL, but legal). Wind: 270° at 15 knots gusting 25 knots, runway 270°. Crosswind component: 0 knots (wind aligned with runway), but gusts to 25 knots may be concerning. Temperature/dew point: 5°C/4°C (1°C spread, high risk of fog if temperature drops). Concerns: Visibility below VFR minimums (if in controlled airspace), Low ceiling (marginal even if legal), Strong wind gusts (may exceed aircraft limits), High fog risk (temperature/dew point close). Conclusion: Flight should NOT be conducted - weather below or marginal for VFR minimums, high risk conditions. The key: Interpret weather carefully - visibility and ceiling must meet VFR minimums for airspace class, consider all weather elements, not just visibility and ceiling.'

Present wind interpretation scenario: 'Scenario: METAR shows wind 320° at 20 knots gusting 30 knots. Runway is 270°. Aircraft crosswind limit is 15 knots. Can aircraft land? [Wait] Analysis: Wind: 320° at 20 knots gusting 30 knots. Runway: 270°. Wind angle: 320° - 270° = 50° difference. Crosswind component: Approximately 15 knots (20 knots × sin 50° ≈ 15 knots), gusting to 23 knots (30 knots × sin 50° ≈ 23 knots). Aircraft limit: 15 knots crosswind. Problem: Steady crosswind is at limit (15 knots), gusts exceed limit (23 knots > 15 knots). Solution: Cannot land safely - gusts exceed crosswind limit. Options: Wait for wind to decrease, Use different runway if available, Divert to alternate airport. The key: Interpret wind carefully - calculate crosswind component, consider gusts, compare to aircraft limits, don't exceed limits.'

Explain go/no-go decision: 'Go/No-Go decision: Determine if flight should be conducted based on weather. Factors: Current weather (METARs), Forecast weather (TAFs), Weather advisories (AIRMETs/SIGMETs), Personal minimums, Aircraft capabilities, Pilot experience. Decision: Go (weather adequate), No-Go (weather inadequate), Delay (wait for improvement).'

Explain risk assessment: 'Risk assessment: Evaluate weather risks. Consider: Weather conditions, Weather trends (improving or deteriorating), Weather hazards (thunderstorms, icing, turbulence), Personal minimums, Aircraft limitations, Pilot experience. High risk: Weather below minimums, Thunderstorms, Severe conditions. Low risk: Weather above minimums, Good conditions, No hazards.'

Explain alternatives: 'Alternatives: If weather is marginal or poor. Options: Delay flight (wait for improvement), Cancel flight (weather not adequate), Change route (avoid weather), Change altitude (avoid weather), Land early (weather deteriorating), Divert (weather at destination poor). Always have alternatives - don't fly into adverse weather.'

Explain safety: 'Safety: Weather decision-making prioritizes safety. Principles: Never fly into known adverse weather, Always have alternatives, Use personal minimums, When in doubt, don't go. Weather-related accidents: Often preventable, Often involve poor decision-making, Often involve flying into adverse weather. Safety is paramount - weather can change rapidly.'

Explain personal minimums: 'Personal minimums: Weather conditions below which pilot will not fly. Examples: Visibility minimum (e.g., 5 miles), Ceiling minimum (e.g., 1,500 feet), Wind maximum (e.g., 15 knots crosswind), Weather minimums (no thunderstorms, no icing). Personal minimums: Higher than legal minimums, Provide safety margin, Should be conservative. Use personal minimums for safety.'

Present detailed weather decision-making scenario: 'Scenario: Weather briefing on March 15, 2025 at 8:00 AM shows: Current conditions: Visibility 10 miles, Ceiling 5,000 feet broken, Wind 10 knots, No precipitation. Forecast (TAF): Conditions good until 11:00 AM, then thunderstorms developing, becoming severe by 12:00 PM. Flight planned: Departure 9:00 AM, flight time 1.5 hours, arrival 10:30 AM. Should flight be conducted? What should pilot consider? [Wait] Analysis: Current conditions: Excellent (10 miles visibility, 5,000 feet ceiling, light winds). Forecast: Thunderstorms developing at 11:00 AM, severe by 12:00 PM. Flight timing: Departure 9:00 AM, arrival 10:30 AM (before forecast thunderstorms at 11:00 AM). Considerations: Thunderstorms are extremely hazardous (severe turbulence, icing, hail, lightning, wind shear), Forecast may be inaccurate (thunderstorms can develop faster than forecast), Weather can change rapidly (conditions can deteriorate quickly), Safety margin needed (don't cut it close), Flight may be delayed (preflight, ATC, other delays could push arrival past 11:00 AM), Thunderstorms may develop earlier than forecast. Risk assessment: High risk - thunderstorms forecast within 2 hours of flight, forecast may be inaccurate, no safety margin. Decision: Should NOT fly - thunderstorms too close, too risky, insufficient safety margin. Alternatives: Delay flight until after thunderstorms pass, Cancel flight if thunderstorms persist, Change route to avoid thunderstorm area, Reschedule flight for different day. The key: Never fly into forecast adverse weather - thunderstorms are too hazardous, always maintain safety margin, when in doubt don't go.'

Present personal minimums scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot's personal minimums are: Visibility 5 miles, Ceiling 2,000 feet, Maximum crosswind 15 knots, No thunderstorms, No icing. Weather briefing shows: Visibility 4 miles, Ceiling 1,800 feet, Wind 12 knots (crosswind 8 knots), No thunderstorms, No icing. Should pilot fly? [Wait] Analysis: Personal minimums: Visibility 5 miles, Ceiling 2,000 feet, Crosswind 15 knots, No thunderstorms, No icing. Actual weather: Visibility 4 miles (below personal minimum of 5 miles), Ceiling 1,800 feet (below personal minimum of 2,000 feet), Crosswind 8 knots (within personal minimum of 15 knots), No thunderstorms (meets personal minimum), No icing (meets personal minimum). Problem: Visibility and ceiling below personal minimums. Solution: Should NOT fly - weather below personal minimums. Personal minimums provide safety margin above legal minimums - don't compromise personal minimums. The key: Personal minimums are higher than legal minimums for safety - always respect personal minimums, don't compromise for convenience.'
