lessonPlans.overview: Eights on pylons is an advanced flight maneuver that forms a figure-8 pattern around two pylons (reference points) on the ground. The key difference from eights around pylons is that in eights on pylons, you maintain each pylon at a specific point on the wingtip throughout the turn. This requires adjusting both altitude and bank angle based on ground speed - when ground speed is higher (downwind), you must fly higher and use steeper bank; when ground speed is lower (upwind), you must fly lower and use shallower bank. This maneuver demonstrates the most advanced understanding of ground speed, pivotal altitude, and energy management. CFI candidates must master this maneuver to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates the highest level of aircraft control and aerodynamics understanding. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of eights on pylons procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering eights on pylons - an advanced maneuver that forms a figure-8 pattern around two pylons on the ground. The key difference from eights around pylons is that in eights on pylons, you maintain each pylon at a specific point on the wingtip throughout the turn. This requires adjusting both altitude and bank angle based on ground speed. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Eights on Pylons'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: select two suitable pylons, enter at appropriate altitude, maintain pylon at specific point on wingtip, adjust altitude based on ground speed, adjust bank angle based on ground speed, maintain airspeed ±10 knots, complete figure-8 pattern, maintain coordination, explain pivotal altitude and ground speed relationships, and teach eights on pylons to students.'
Ask opening question: 'Think about maintaining a pylon at a specific point on your wingtip. If your ground speed changes, what happens to the pylon's position? How do you keep it at the same point?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: when ground speed changes, the pylon's position relative to the wingtip changes unless you adjust altitude and bank angle. Eights on pylons teaches this advanced concept. Let's explore this systematically, starting with pivotal altitude and ground speed relationships.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 10, your POH for performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on eights on pylons procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Eights on pylons serves two purposes: First, it's a training maneuver that develops the most advanced control skills (pivotal altitude understanding, ground speed management, altitude and bank angle coordination, energy management). Second, it demonstrates maximum understanding of aerodynamics (ground speed effects, pivotal altitude, energy relationships). The key: Eights on pylons teaches the most advanced aerodynamics - maintaining pylon position by adjusting altitude and bank angle with ground speed.'

Explain pivotal altitude: 'Pivotal altitude is critical to understand. Pivotal altitude is the altitude at which a pylon appears to pivot around a specific point on the wingtip. This altitude varies with ground speed: Higher ground speed = higher pivotal altitude (must fly higher to keep pylon at same point), Lower ground speed = lower pivotal altitude (must fly lower to keep pylon at same point). The key: Pivotal altitude changes with ground speed - higher ground speed requires higher altitude to maintain pylon position.'

Draw pivotal altitude diagram on whiteboard: 'Let me draw the pivotal altitude relationship. At pivotal altitude: Pylon appears to pivot around specific point on wingtip. If ground speed increases (downwind): Pivotal altitude increases, must climb to maintain pylon position. If ground speed decreases (upwind): Pivotal altitude decreases, must descend to maintain pylon position. The key: Altitude must vary with ground speed to maintain pylon at same point on wingtip.'

Explain the maneuver: 'Eights on pylons forms a figure-8 pattern around two pylons. Select two pylons (reference points) on the ground, spaced appropriately (typically 1/2 to 1 mile apart). Enter at appropriate altitude (600-1000 AGL, typically 800 AGL). Fly figure-8 pattern around both pylons. Maintain each pylon at specific point on wingtip throughout turn. Adjust altitude and bank angle with ground speed: Downwind (higher ground speed): Climb to higher altitude, increase bank angle. Upwind (lower ground speed): Descend to lower altitude, decrease bank angle. The key: Altitude and bank angle vary with ground speed to maintain pylon position.'

Explain altitude adjustment: 'Altitude adjustment is critical. Downwind leg: Ground speed is higher, pivotal altitude is higher, must climb to maintain pylon at same point on wingtip (typically 50-100 feet higher than entry altitude). Upwind leg: Ground speed is lower, pivotal altitude is lower, must descend to maintain pylon at same point on wingtip (typically 50-100 feet lower than entry altitude). The key: Altitude varies with ground speed - climb downwind, descend upwind, to maintain pylon position.'

Explain bank angle adjustment: 'Bank angle adjustment is also critical. Downwind leg: Ground speed is higher, must increase bank angle (steeper bank, typically 30-35°) to maintain turn rate and pylon position. Upwind leg: Ground speed is lower, must decrease bank angle (shallower bank, typically 15-20°) to maintain turn rate and pylon position. The key: Bank angle varies with ground speed - steeper downwind, shallower upwind, to maintain pylon position.'

Explain pylon selection: 'Pylon selection is important. Choose two prominent, easily identifiable points on the ground (intersections, buildings, field corners, road junctions). Pylons should be: Clearly visible from altitude (easy to see, distinctive), Spaced appropriately (typically 1/2 to 1 mile apart, allows figure-8 pattern), Suitable for practice (not over populated areas, not over restricted airspace, adequate clearance from obstacles). The key: Select good pylons - they're your reference points for maintaining position.'

Explain entry technique: 'Entry technique: First, perform 90° clearing turns (minimum) to check for traffic. Second, establish cruise flight at appropriate altitude (600-1000 AGL, typically 800 AGL). Third, select and identify two pylons. Fourth, position airplane to begin figure-8 pattern. Fifth, enter turn around first pylon, maintaining pylon at specific point on wingtip. Sixth, adjust altitude and bank angle with ground speed. The key: Enter with proper positioning and begin maintaining pylon at specific point on wingtip.'

Explain maintaining pylon position: 'Maintaining pylon position is the challenge. The pylon must stay at the same point on the wingtip throughout the turn. Technique: Downwind: Climb to higher altitude (50-100 feet higher), increase bank angle (30-35°), maintain pylon at same point on wingtip. Upwind: Descend to lower altitude (50-100 feet lower), decrease bank angle (15-20°), maintain pylon at same point on wingtip. Crosswind: Adjust altitude and bank angle as needed. The key: Altitude and bank angle work together to maintain pylon at same point on wingtip - both vary with ground speed.'

Explain figure-8 pattern: 'Figure-8 pattern: First 180° turn around first pylon: Maintain pylon at specific point on wingtip, adjust altitude and bank angle with ground speed, complete 180° turn. Transition to second pylon: Roll out of first turn, transition to second pylon, establish pylon at specific point on wingtip. Second 180° turn around second pylon: Maintain pylon at specific point on wingtip, adjust altitude and bank angle with ground speed, complete 180° turn. Transition back to first pylon: Roll out of second turn, transition back to first pylon, repeat pattern. The key: Figure-8 pattern requires maintaining pylon position around both pylons, transitioning smoothly between them.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not adjusting altitude with ground speed (pylon moves on wingtip, poor control), Not adjusting bank angle with ground speed (pylon moves on wingtip, poor control), Not maintaining pylon at specific point (pylon drifts, poor control), Poor pylon selection (hard to see, confusing, poor for practice), Not maintaining airspeed (airspeed varies, affects ground speed and pivotal altitude), Poor coordination (ball not centered, uncoordinated flight). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH performance data: 'Let's check your POH for performance data. Typical airspeed for eights on pylons: 90-110 knots (check POH for exact speed). Typical altitude: 600-1000 AGL (check ACS for specific requirement). Typical altitude variation: ±50-100 feet (varies with ground speed). Use this to plan your eights on pylons.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to advanced students as the most complex ground reference maneuver. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe eights on pylons operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

instructorActions: Encourage: 'Your airplane. You've got this. I'll be right here if you need help, but I want you to try it. First, select two pylons, then enter eights on pylons at 800 AGL.'

Guide first turn: 'Beginning first turn around pylon 1... downwind leg, ground speed is higher, so climb to higher altitude... maybe 850 feet... increase bank angle... maybe 32°... maintaining pylon at same point on wingtip... good. diagrams.asciiArt:
EIGHTS ON PYLONS - PIVOTAL ALTITUDE

DOWNWIND LEG:
  Ground speed: Higher
  Pivotal altitude: Higher
  Aircraft altitude: Higher (50-100 ft above entry)
  Bank angle: Steeper (30-35°)
  Reason: Maintain pylon at same point on wingtip

UPWIND LEG:
  Ground speed: Lower
  Pivotal altitude: Lower
  Aircraft altitude: Lower (50-100 ft below entry)
  Bank angle: Shallower (15-20°)
  Reason: Maintain pylon at same point on wingtip

KEY:
  Pivotal altitude changes with ground speed
  Altitude and bank angle adjust to maintain pylon position

Upwind: Lower ground speed = lower pivotal altitude = descend and decrease bank

scenarios.situation: You're performing eights on pylons. On the downwind leg around pylon 1, you notice the pylon is drifting forward on your wingtip. Your current altitude is 800 feet (entry altitude) and your bank angle is 25°. What should you do?
options: Continue as is - it's not a big deal
Climb to higher altitude and increase bank angle to compensate for higher ground speed
Descend to lower altitude to slow down
Roll out and start over
scenarios.correct: Climb to higher altitude and increase bank angle to compensate for higher ground speed
scenarios.explanation: When the pylon drifts forward on the wingtip, it means the pivotal altitude has increased due to higher ground speed (downwind). To maintain the pylon at the same point on the wingtip, you must climb to the higher pivotal altitude and increase bank angle. The pylon drifts forward because your current altitude is too low for the current ground speed - you need to climb to match the higher pivotal altitude. Descending would make it worse. Rolling out defeats the purpose. The key is understanding that higher ground speed requires higher altitude (pivotal altitude) to maintain pylon position.

objectives: Explain the PAVE checklist including Pilot assessment (medical, currency, proficiency, fatigue, stress, knowledge - IMSAFE checklist), Aircraft assessment (documents, equipment, maintenance, condition), enVironment assessment (weather, airspace, terrain, airports), and External pressures (time, money, passengers, personal pressures)

lessonPlans.overview: Preflight assessment is fundamental to safe flight operations. The PAVE checklist provides a systematic approach to evaluating Pilot, Aircraft, enVironment, and External pressures before every flight. Understanding preflight assessment enables CFIs to teach students how to evaluate flight readiness, assess all factors systematically, make safe go/no-go decisions, identify and resist external pressures, and prioritize safety. This lesson covers the PAVE checklist (Pilot assessment using IMSAFE, Aircraft assessment for airworthiness, enVironment assessment for suitability, External pressures identification), pilot readiness assessment (IMSAFE checklist, medical, currency, proficiency, fatigue, stress), aircraft airworthiness assessment (documents, equipment, maintenance, condition), environmental factors assessment (weather, airspace, terrain, airports), external pressures identification (time, money, passengers, personal), and go/no-go decision-making (evaluating all factors, making decision, having alternatives). Understanding these concepts enables CFIs to teach proper preflight assessment and helps pilots make safe flight decisions.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering one of the most critical topics for flight instructors - Preflight Assessment. This knowledge is essential because preflight assessment is the foundation of safe flight operations. Before every flight, pilots must systematically evaluate all factors that affect flight safety. The PAVE checklist provides a structured approach to this evaluation: Pilot (are you ready?), Aircraft (is the aircraft ready?), enVironment (is the environment suitable?), and External pressures (are there pressures affecting your decision?). Understanding preflight assessment enables you to teach students how to evaluate flight readiness, assess all factors systematically, make safe go/no-go decisions, identify and resist external pressures, and prioritize safety. This knowledge is also critical for your own operations - you must use preflight assessment before every flight. Let's ensure you have comprehensive knowledge of preflight assessment.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Preflight Assessment - PAVE Checklist'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: explain the PAVE checklist including Pilot, Aircraft, enVironment, and External pressures assessment, assess pilot readiness using IMSAFE checklist (Illness, Medication, Stress, Alcohol, Fatigue, Emotion), assess aircraft airworthiness including documents, equipment, maintenance, and condition, assess environmental factors including weather, airspace, terrain, and airports, identify external pressures including time, money, passengers, and personal pressures, make go/no-go decisions by evaluating all PAVE factors systematically, and teach preflight assessment to students effectively. These aren't just checkride topics - these skills are essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about your last flight. Before you flew, what did you check? What factors did you consider? What would have made you cancel the flight? These questions touch on preflight assessment - let's explore them systematically.'

Listen actively to student response, nodding and taking notes on their examples: 'That's a great example. I'm noting that you mentioned checking weather and the aircraft. Let's explore all the factors systematically using the PAVE checklist.'

Transition statement: 'Excellent observations. What you're describing touches on several key concepts we'll cover today: the PAVE checklist (Pilot, Aircraft, enVironment, External pressures - systematic approach to assessment), pilot readiness assessment (IMSAFE checklist, medical, currency, proficiency, fatigue, stress), aircraft airworthiness assessment (documents, equipment, maintenance, condition), environmental factors assessment (weather, airspace, terrain, airports), external pressures identification (time, money, passengers, personal pressures), and go/no-go decision-making (evaluating all factors, making decision, having alternatives). These aren't just risk management theory - they're practical skills that determine whether flights are safe. Let's explore these systematically.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing several key documents: AC 91-92 - Pilot's Guide to a Preflight Briefing, provides comprehensive guidance on preflight assessment and risk management. FAA-H-8083-2 - Risk Management Handbook, covers risk assessment and decision-making. The Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge - covers preflight procedures. These documents provide comprehensive guidance, and I recommend you study them thoroughly.'

Explain the importance of preflight assessment knowledge: 'Here's why this matters: Preflight assessment is the foundation of safe flight operations. As a CFI, you'll constantly be: Teaching students how to evaluate flight readiness, Ensuring students assess all factors systematically, Helping students make safe go/no-go decisions, Teaching students to identify and resist external pressures, Using preflight assessment yourself before every flight. Understanding preflight assessment enables you to: Teach safe flight operations, Help students make good decisions, Prevent accidents through systematic assessment, Resist external pressures, Maintain safe flight operations. Many aviation accidents involve pilots who didn't assess all factors adequately - they missed something in their preflight assessment, or they let external pressures affect their decision. Understanding preflight assessment enables safe flight operations and effective instruction.'

Explain the PAVE concept: 'The fundamental concept: PAVE checklist provides systematic preflight assessment. P - Pilot: Are you ready to fly? (medical, currency, proficiency, fatigue, stress, knowledge). A - Aircraft: Is the aircraft ready? (documents, equipment, maintenance, condition). V - enVironment: Is the environment suitable? (weather, airspace, terrain, airports). E - External pressures: Are there pressures affecting your decision? (time, money, passengers, personal). The key: All factors must be evaluated systematically - if any factor is questionable, the decision should be NO-GO. Understanding PAVE enables you to assess flight readiness systematically and make safe decisions.'

Explain preflight assessment importance: 'Preflight assessment is essential: Before every flight, evaluate: Pilot readiness (are you ready?), Aircraft airworthiness (is aircraft ready?), Environment suitability (is environment suitable?), External pressures (are there pressures?). As a CFI, you must: Teach students to use PAVE checklist, Ensure students evaluate all factors, Help students make safe decisions, Teach students to resist external pressures, Use PAVE yourself before every flight. The key: Always use PAVE checklist - don't skip factors, evaluate systematically, prioritize safety.'

Set CFI context: 'On your CFI checkride, you'll be asked about preflight assessment. The examiner wants to see that you understand: PAVE checklist and how to use it, Pilot readiness assessment (IMSAFE), Aircraft airworthiness assessment, Environmental factors assessment, External pressures identification, Go/no-go decision-making. You should be able to teach these concepts clearly and explain how they apply to actual flight operations. This lesson prepares you for that.'

Preview lesson structure: 'We'll cover this in several phases: first, we'll explore the PAVE checklist - Pilot, Aircraft, enVironment, External pressures. Then we'll discuss pilot readiness assessment - IMSAFE checklist, medical, currency, proficiency, fatigue, stress. Next, we'll cover aircraft airworthiness assessment - documents, equipment, maintenance, condition. Then we'll discuss environmental factors - weather, airspace, terrain, airports. Next, we'll cover external pressures - time, money, passengers, personal. Finally, we'll discuss go/no-go decision-making - evaluating all factors, making decision, having alternatives. Each phase builds on the previous one.'

Emphasize practical application: 'Remember: Preflight assessment is practical knowledge you'll use before every flight. Before every flight, you must evaluate: Pilot readiness (IMSAFE), Aircraft airworthiness (documents, equipment, maintenance), Environment suitability (weather, airspace), External pressures (time, money, passengers). As a CFI, you'll constantly be teaching and using preflight assessment. Understanding preflight assessment enables safe flight operations and effective instruction. Let's ensure you have comprehensive knowledge of preflight assessment.'

Ask for questions before proceeding: 'Before we dive in, do you have any questions about what we'll cover today? What aspects of preflight assessment are you most curious or concerned about? Have you had any experiences where preflight assessment was particularly important?'

instructorActions: Write on board: 'PAVE Checklist: P - Pilot (are you ready?), A - Aircraft (is aircraft ready?), V - enVironment (is environment suitable?), E - External pressures (are there pressures affecting decision?).'

Explain PAVE systematically: 'PAVE checklist provides systematic approach to preflight assessment. P - Pilot: Are you ready to fly? Evaluate: Medical (valid medical certificate, feeling well, no illness), Currency (flight review, recent experience, night currency, instrument currency), Proficiency (comfortable with planned flight, adequate experience), Fatigue (well-rested, alert, not tired), Stress (personal stress, work stress, emotional state), Knowledge (understand flight, weather, procedures). A - Aircraft: Is aircraft ready? Evaluate: Documents, equipment, maintenance, condition. V - enVironment: Is environment suitable? Evaluate: Weather, airspace, terrain, airports. E - External pressures: Are there pressures affecting decision? Evaluate: Time, money, passengers, personal pressures. Use PAVE before every flight - systematic approach ensures nothing is missed. The key: All factors must be evaluated - if any factor is questionable, decision should be NO-GO.'

Explain IMSAFE checklist: 'IMSAFE checklist provides systematic pilot assessment. I - Illness: Are you sick? Feeling unwell? Any symptoms? If ill, don't fly. M - Medication: Are you taking medication? Check for side effects, restrictions. If medication affects performance, don't fly. S - Stress: Are you stressed? Personal, work, emotional stress affects performance. If stress is significant, evaluate carefully - may need to cancel. A - Alcohol: Have you consumed alcohol? 8-hour bottle-to-throttle rule minimum, 24 hours recommended. If alcohol consumed, don't fly. F - Fatigue: Are you tired? Well-rested? Adequate sleep? If tired, don't fly. E - Emotion: Are you emotionally ready? Personal issues? Emotional state affects performance. If emotional state is questionable, evaluate carefully. Use IMSAFE before every flight - systematic approach ensures pilot readiness.'

Explain medical requirements: 'Medical assessment: Valid medical certificate required. Private pilot: Third-class medical (valid 60 months if under 40, 24 months if 40 or older), or BasicMed (if eligible). Commercial pilot: Second-class medical (valid 12 months). Airline transport pilot: First-class medical (valid 12 months if under 40, 6 months if 40 or older). Feeling well: No illness, no symptoms, no medication effects. If medical is expired or you're feeling unwell, don't fly. Example: Pilot has third-class medical expired 2 months ago - cannot fly until medical renewed.'

Explain currency requirements: 'Currency assessment: Flight review required (within 24 months), recent flight experience (recommended within 90 days), night currency (3 takeoffs and landings within 90 days for night passenger carrying), instrument currency (6 approaches, holding, tracking within 6 months for IFR). Check currency for planned flight: Day VFR (flight review), Night VFR (flight review, night currency), IFR (flight review, instrument currency). If not current, don't fly without currency. Example: Pilot has flight review current, but hasn't flown in 6 months - should get flight review or proficiency flight before passenger carrying.'

Explain proficiency assessment: 'Proficiency assessment: Comfortable with planned flight? Adequate experience? Factors: Aircraft type (familiar with aircraft?), Route (familiar with route?), Conditions (comfortable with conditions?), Maneuvers (comfortable with planned maneuvers?). If not proficient, don't fly or get additional training. Example: Pilot has 50 hours in Cessna 172, but flight is in complex aircraft - should get training in complex aircraft before flight.'

Explain fatigue assessment: 'Fatigue assessment: Well-rested? Alert? Adequate sleep? Factors: Sleep (adequate sleep last night? 7-9 hours recommended), Rest (well-rested? Not tired?), Alertness (alert? Not drowsy?), Work schedule (long work week? Overtime?). Fatigue affects: Decision-making (impaired), Reaction time (slower), Situational awareness (reduced), Performance (degraded). If tired, don't fly. Example: Pilot worked 12-hour shift, got 4 hours sleep, has flight planned - should not fly due to fatigue.'

Explain stress assessment: 'Stress assessment: Personal stress? Work stress? Emotional state? Factors: Personal (family issues, personal problems), Work (work stress, deadlines), Emotional (emotional state, mood). Stress affects: Decision-making (impaired), Performance (degraded), Situational awareness (reduced). If stress is significant, evaluate carefully - may need to cancel. Example: Pilot has family emergency, is stressed and distracted - should evaluate carefully, may need to cancel flight.'

Explain knowledge assessment: 'Knowledge assessment: Understand flight requirements? Weather? Procedures? Factors: Flight requirements (understand flight? Route? Procedures?), Weather (understand weather? Forecasts? Conditions?), Procedures (understand procedures? Airspace? Communications?). If knowledge is inadequate, don't fly or get additional training. Example: Pilot planning IFR flight but not instrument rated - cannot fly IFR.'

Present specific scenario with numbers: 'Scenario: A pilot has a flight planned for tomorrow at 2:00 PM. They're a private pilot with a third-class medical (expires in 8 months). They have a flight review current (completed 6 months ago). They worked a 10-hour shift yesterday, got 5 hours of sleep last night, and are feeling tired. They have 150 hours total time, 25 hours in the last 90 days. The flight is a cross-country in a Cessna 172 (aircraft they're familiar with). Weather is forecast to be VFR. How do you assess pilot readiness using IMSAFE and PAVE?'

Guide discussion with specific analysis: 'IMSAFE assessment: I - Illness: No illness reported (acceptable). M - Medication: No medication reported (acceptable). S - Stress: No significant stress reported (acceptable). A - Alcohol: No alcohol reported (acceptable). F - Fatigue: Worked 10-hour shift, 5 hours sleep (fatigue - CONCERN). Fatigue affects decision-making, reaction time, situational awareness, performance. E - Emotion: No emotional issues reported (acceptable). IMSAFE decision: FATIGUE is a concern - pilot is tired. PAVE Pilot assessment: Medical: Valid (expires in 8 months - acceptable). Currency: Flight review current (6 months ago - acceptable), Recent experience (25 hours in 90 days - acceptable). Proficiency: Familiar with aircraft (150 hours total, familiar with Cessna 172 - acceptable). Fatigue: Tired from work and lack of sleep (FATIGUE - CONCERN). Stress: No significant stress (acceptable). Knowledge: Understands flight (acceptable). PAVE Pilot decision: FATIGUE is a concern - pilot is not ready. Overall decision: Should NOT fly - fatigue is a significant risk factor. Alternatives: Get adequate rest (8 hours sleep), Reschedule flight for later, Have another pilot fly. Teaching point: Fatigue is a serious risk - if tired, don't fly. Pilot readiness is first priority.'

Present another scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot has a flight planned for today at 10:00 AM. They're a commercial pilot with a second-class medical (expires in 3 months). They have a flight review current (completed 3 months ago). They have 500 hours total time, 80 hours in the last 90 days. They're feeling well-rested (8 hours sleep). However, they're taking prescription medication for a cold (antihistamine with drowsiness warning). The flight is a local flight in a Piper Cherokee (aircraft they're familiar with). Weather is VFR. How do you assess pilot readiness?'

Guide discussion: 'IMSAFE assessment: I - Illness: Has a cold (illness - CONCERN). M - Medication: Taking antihistamine with drowsiness warning (medication side effects - CONCERN). Medication side effects: Drowsiness, impaired reaction time, reduced alertness. S - Stress: No significant stress reported (acceptable). A - Alcohol: No alcohol reported (acceptable). F - Fatigue: Well-rested (acceptable). E - Emotion: No emotional issues reported (acceptable). IMSAFE decision: ILLNESS and MEDICATION are concerns - pilot is sick and medication affects performance. PAVE Pilot assessment: Medical: Valid (expires in 3 months - acceptable), but feeling unwell (illness - CONCERN). Currency: Flight review current (acceptable), Recent experience (80 hours in 90 days - acceptable). Proficiency: Familiar with aircraft (acceptable). Fatigue: Well-rested (acceptable). Stress: No significant stress (acceptable). Knowledge: Understands flight (acceptable). PAVE Pilot decision: ILLNESS and MEDICATION are concerns - pilot is not ready. Overall decision: Should NOT fly - illness and medication side effects are risk factors. Alternatives: Wait until illness resolves, Stop medication and wait for effects to clear, Reschedule flight. Teaching point: Illness and medication side effects are serious risks - if sick or medication affects performance, don't fly.'

Explain decision-making process: 'Decision-making process: Evaluate all pilot factors systematically. If all pilot factors are acceptable (medical valid, current, proficient, well-rested, no significant stress, adequate knowledge), proceed to aircraft assessment. If any pilot factor is questionable (illness, medication effects, fatigue, significant stress, lack of currency, inadequate proficiency), decision is NO-GO - don't fly. Pilot readiness is first priority - if pilot is not ready, flight should not be conducted. Always evaluate all factors - don't skip any factor, don't rationalize concerns away.'

Emphasize teaching points: 'Key teaching points: IMSAFE checklist provides systematic pilot assessment - use it before every flight. All pilot factors must be acceptable - if any factor is questionable, don't fly. Fatigue is a serious risk - if tired, don't fly. Illness and medication side effects are serious risks - if sick or medication affects performance, don't fly. Stress can affect performance - if stress is significant, evaluate carefully. Pilot readiness is first priority - if pilot is not ready, flight should not be conducted. Always evaluate all factors systematically - don't skip factors, don't rationalize concerns away.'

Pilot Factors: Medical (valid, feeling well), currency (current), proficiency (adequate), fatigue (well-rested), stress (manageable), knowledge (adequate)

instructorActions: Write on board: 'Aircraft Assessment: Documents (airworthiness, registration, operating limitations), Equipment (Part 91.205 required equipment), Maintenance (annual, 100-hour if required, ADs), Condition (safe condition, fuel/oil, no damage).'

Explain aircraft assessment systematically: 'Aircraft assessment: Is aircraft ready to fly? Evaluate systematically: Documents (airworthiness certificate, registration, operating limitations - all must be present and current), Equipment (required equipment operational - Part 91.205, depends on flight conditions), Maintenance (annual inspection within 12 months, 100-hour inspection if used for hire within 100 hours, all ADs complied with), Condition (aircraft in safe condition, no damage, proper configuration, adequate fuel/oil, no leaks, controls free and correct). Aircraft must be airworthy - if not, don't fly. The key: All factors must be acceptable - if any factor is questionable, decision should be NO-GO.'

Explain documents in detail: 'Documents assessment: Airworthiness certificate (must be present, valid, not expired - check expiration date). Registration (must be present, current, not expired - check expiration date). Operating limitations (POH/AFM must be present, placards must be legible, weight and balance data must be current). All documents must be current and present. Check documents during preflight - expired or missing documents prevent flight. Example: Aircraft has airworthiness certificate expired 3 months ago - cannot fly until certificate renewed.'

Explain equipment requirements for VFR day: 'VFR day equipment (Part 91.205): Airspeed indicator (required), Altimeter (required), Magnetic compass (required), Tachometer (required), Oil pressure gauge (required), Temperature gauge (required for liquid-cooled engines), Oil temperature gauge (required for air-cooled engines), Fuel quantity gauges (required), Manifold pressure gauge (required for altitude engines), ELT (required). All required equipment must be operational. If any required equipment is inoperative, aircraft cannot be flown (unless minimum equipment list allows). Example: Airspeed indicator inoperative - aircraft cannot be flown (required equipment).'

Explain equipment requirements for VFR night: 'VFR night equipment (Part 91.205): All VFR day equipment plus: Position lights (required - red on left, green on right, white on tail), Anti-collision lights (required - red or white strobe), Landing light (required if for hire), Electrical system (required - must power all required equipment). All required equipment must be operational. If any required equipment is inoperative, aircraft cannot be flown at night. Example: Position light inoperative - aircraft cannot be flown at night (required equipment), but can be flown day VFR.'

Explain maintenance requirements: 'Maintenance assessment: Annual inspection (must be current, within 12 months of last annual - check date). 100-hour inspection (if aircraft used for hire, must be within 100 hours of last 100-hour inspection - check hours). AD compliance (all applicable ADs must be complied with - check AD list). Maintenance records must be current and available. Check maintenance records during preflight - expired inspections or non-compliant ADs prevent flight. Example: Aircraft annual inspection expired 2 months ago - cannot fly until annual inspection completed.'

Explain 100-hour inspection requirement: '100-hour inspection: Required if aircraft is used for hire (flight instruction, charter, etc.). Must be within 100 hours of last 100-hour inspection. Check aircraft hours since last 100-hour inspection. If aircraft is used for hire and 100-hour inspection is overdue, aircraft cannot be flown. Example: Aircraft used for flight instruction, last 100-hour inspection at 1,200 hours, current hours 1,295 hours - 100-hour inspection overdue (95 hours since last inspection), aircraft cannot be flown until 100-hour inspection completed.'

Explain AD compliance: 'AD compliance: All applicable ADs must be complied with. Check AD list for aircraft make/model. Verify compliance in maintenance records. If AD is not complied with, aircraft cannot be flown (unless AD allows operation with restrictions). Example: AD 2023-15-03 requires inspection of fuel selector valve within 50 hours - if not complied with, aircraft cannot be flown until AD complied with.'

Explain condition assessment: 'Condition assessment: Aircraft in safe condition? Check: No damage (no visible damage, no structural damage, no corrosion), Proper configuration (all components properly configured, no loose items), Fuel adequate (sufficient fuel for flight plus reserve - 30 minutes day VFR, 45 minutes night VFR), Oil adequate (sufficient oil - check minimum oil quantity), No leaks (no fuel leaks, no oil leaks, no hydraulic leaks), Controls free and correct (all controls move freely, correct direction, no binding), No obstructions (no obstructions in air intakes, no obstructions in control surfaces). Aircraft must be in condition for safe flight - if condition is questionable, don't fly.'

Present specific scenario with numbers: 'Scenario: During preflight of a Cessna 172N (N12345), pilot finds: Airworthiness certificate present (issued 2 years ago, valid), Registration present (expires in 8 months, current), Annual inspection completed 8 months ago (current - within 12 months), 100-hour inspection completed 15 hours ago (current - within 100 hours), Aircraft used for flight instruction. During preflight inspection: Fuel quantity shows 18 gallons in each tank (36 gallons total, 48 gallons capacity), Oil quantity shows 6 quarts (acceptable), No visible damage, All controls free and correct. However, one navigation light (left position light) is inoperative. The flight is planned for today at 6:00 PM (sunset at 7:30 PM, flight will be during daylight). Can the aircraft be flown? What are the considerations?'

Guide discussion with specific analysis: 'Aircraft assessment: Documents: Airworthiness certificate (present, valid - acceptable), Registration (present, current - acceptable), Operating limitations (POH present - acceptable). Equipment: VFR day equipment (all required equipment operational - acceptable), Navigation light (left position light inoperative - CONCERN for night flight). Maintenance: Annual inspection (completed 8 months ago, current - acceptable), 100-hour inspection (completed 15 hours ago, current - acceptable), AD compliance (assumed compliant - acceptable). Condition: Fuel (36 gallons, adequate for flight - acceptable), Oil (6 quarts, adequate - acceptable), No damage (acceptable), Controls (free and correct - acceptable). Equipment consideration: Navigation light inoperative. Flight conditions: Flight at 6:00 PM, sunset at 7:30 PM - flight will be during daylight (day VFR). Equipment requirements: Day VFR does not require position lights (Part 91.205). Decision: Aircraft can be flown for day VFR flight (navigation light not required for day VFR). However, aircraft cannot be flown for night VFR flight (position lights required for night VFR). Teaching point: Equipment requirements depend on flight conditions - check requirements for planned flight. If flight was planned for night, aircraft could not be flown.'

Present another scenario: 'Scenario: During preflight of a Piper PA-28-181 (N67890), pilot finds: Airworthiness certificate present (issued 3 years ago, valid), Registration present (expires in 2 months, current), Annual inspection completed 11 months ago (current - within 12 months), Aircraft not used for hire (private use only). During preflight inspection: Fuel quantity shows 12 gallons in each tank (24 gallons total, 50 gallons capacity), Oil quantity shows 5 quarts (minimum 4 quarts, acceptable), No visible damage, All controls free and correct. All required equipment operational. However, maintenance records show: Annual inspection completed 11 months ago, but aircraft has 1,850 hours total time, and last 100-hour inspection was at 1,750 hours (100 hours ago). Can the aircraft be flown? What are the considerations?'

Guide discussion: 'Aircraft assessment: Documents: Airworthiness certificate (present, valid - acceptable), Registration (present, current - acceptable), Operating limitations (POH present - acceptable). Equipment: All required equipment operational (acceptable). Maintenance: Annual inspection (completed 11 months ago, current - acceptable), 100-hour inspection (last at 1,750 hours, current hours 1,850 hours - exactly 100 hours since last inspection, current - acceptable), AD compliance (assumed compliant - acceptable). Condition: Fuel (24 gallons, adequate for flight - acceptable), Oil (5 quarts, adequate - acceptable), No damage (acceptable), Controls (free and correct - acceptable). 100-hour inspection consideration: Aircraft not used for hire (private use only) - 100-hour inspection not required. However, if aircraft is used for hire, 100-hour inspection would be required. Decision: Aircraft can be flown (all factors acceptable). Teaching point: 100-hour inspection is required only if aircraft is used for hire - check aircraft use and inspection requirements.'

Present third scenario: 'Scenario: During preflight of a Cessna 152 (N11111), pilot finds: Airworthiness certificate present (issued 1 year ago, valid), Registration present (expires in 6 months, current), Annual inspection completed 13 months ago (overdue - more than 12 months), Aircraft not used for hire. During preflight inspection: Fuel quantity shows 8 gallons in each tank (16 gallons total, 26 gallons capacity), Oil quantity shows 4 quarts (minimum 4 quarts, acceptable), No visible damage, All controls free and correct. All required equipment operational. Can the aircraft be flown? What are the considerations?'

Guide discussion: 'Aircraft assessment: Documents: Airworthiness certificate (present, valid - acceptable), Registration (present, current - acceptable), Operating limitations (POH present - acceptable). Equipment: All required equipment operational (acceptable). Maintenance: Annual inspection (completed 13 months ago, OVERDUE - more than 12 months - CONCERN), 100-hour inspection (not required - aircraft not used for hire), AD compliance (assumed compliant - acceptable). Condition: Fuel (16 gallons, adequate for flight - acceptable), Oil (4 quarts, adequate - acceptable), No damage (acceptable), Controls (free and correct - acceptable). Maintenance consideration: Annual inspection overdue (13 months since last inspection, more than 12 months allowed). Aircraft cannot be flown until annual inspection completed. Decision: Aircraft CANNOT be flown - annual inspection overdue. Alternatives: Complete annual inspection before flight, Use another aircraft. Teaching point: Annual inspection must be current (within 12 months) - expired inspection prevents flight.'

Explain decision-making process: 'Decision-making process: Evaluate all aircraft factors systematically. If all aircraft factors are acceptable (documents current, required equipment operational, maintenance current, condition safe), proceed to environment assessment. If any aircraft factor is questionable (missing/expired documents, inoperative required equipment, expired inspections, non-compliant ADs, unsafe condition), decision is NO-GO - don't fly. Aircraft airworthiness is essential - if aircraft is not airworthy, flight should not be conducted. Always evaluate all factors - don't skip any factor, don't rationalize concerns away.'

Emphasize teaching points: 'Key teaching points: Aircraft assessment includes documents, equipment, maintenance, and condition - all must be acceptable. Equipment requirements depend on flight conditions (day VFR vs. night VFR) - check requirements for planned flight. Annual inspection must be current (within 12 months) - expired inspection prevents flight. 100-hour inspection required if aircraft used for hire (within 100 hours) - check aircraft use and inspection requirements. AD compliance required - all applicable ADs must be complied with. Aircraft condition must be safe - if condition is questionable, don't fly. Aircraft airworthiness is essential - if aircraft is not airworthy, flight should not be conducted. Always evaluate all factors systematically - don't skip factors, don't rationalize concerns away.'
studentActions: Participate in discussion about aircraft assessment
Ask questions about airworthiness requirements
keyPoints: Aircraft Assessment: Documents, equipment, maintenance, condition - all must be acceptable
Documents: Airworthiness certificate, registration, operating limitations - all must be current
Equipment: Required equipment operational (Part 91.205), depends on flight conditions
Maintenance: Annual inspection, 100-hour if required, AD compliance - all must be current
Condition: Aircraft in safe condition, no damage, proper configuration, adequate fuel/oil
Equipment requirements depend on flight conditions - check requirements for planned flight

teachingScript.phase: PAVE Checklist - Environment and External Pressures (25 minutes)
instructorActions: Write on board: 'Environment: Weather (visibility, clouds, wind, thunderstorms, icing), Airspace (controlled airspace, restrictions, NOTAMs), Terrain (obstacles, elevation, routes), Airports (runway conditions, services, NOTAMs). External Pressures: Time (schedule, deadlines), Money (cost of cancellation), Passengers (expectations, commitments), Personal (pride, ego, proving something).'

Explain environment assessment systematically: 'Environment assessment: Is environment suitable for flight? Evaluate systematically: Weather (current conditions, forecasts, advisories - visibility, clouds, wind, thunderstorms, icing), Airspace (controlled airspace requirements, restrictions, NOTAMs), Terrain (obstacles, elevation, routes), Airports (runway conditions, services, NOTAMs). Environment must be suitable - if not, don't fly. The key: All factors must be acceptable - if any factor is questionable, decision should be NO-GO.'

Explain weather assessment in detail: 'Weather assessment: Current conditions (METARs - check visibility, clouds, wind, temperature, pressure), Forecasts (TAFs - check forecast conditions, trends), Advisories (AIRMETs - check for turbulence, icing, IFR conditions, SIGMETs - check for severe weather, thunderstorms). Check: Visibility (meets VFR minimums - 3 statute miles, clear of clouds), Clouds (meets VFR minimums - 500 feet below, 1,000 feet above, 2,000 feet horizontal), Wind (within limits - check surface wind, crosswind component, gusts), Thunderstorms (avoid completely - check for thunderstorms, convective activity), Icing (avoid in winter - check for icing conditions, temperature, moisture). Weather must be acceptable - if marginal or deteriorating, don't fly. Example: METAR shows visibility 2.5 statute miles, scattered clouds at 800 feet - below VFR minimums (3 miles visibility required), should not fly.'

Explain VFR minimums: 'VFR minimums: Class E airspace (below 10,000 feet MSL): 3 statute miles visibility, 500 feet below clouds, 1,000 feet above clouds, 2,000 feet horizontal from clouds. Class E airspace (at or above 10,000 feet MSL): 5 statute miles visibility, 1,000 feet below clouds, 1,000 feet above clouds, 1 statute mile horizontal from clouds. Class G airspace (below 1,200 feet AGL): 1 statute mile visibility, clear of clouds. Class G airspace (at or above 1,200 feet AGL): 1 statute mile visibility, 500 feet below clouds, 1,000 feet above clouds, 2,000 feet horizontal from clouds. If weather does not meet VFR minimums, cannot fly VFR.'

Explain airspace assessment: 'Airspace assessment: Controlled airspace (Class B, C, D, E - check requirements, clearances, communications), Restrictions (temporary flight restrictions - TFRs, check for TFRs along route), NOTAMs (check for NOTAMs affecting flight - runway closures, equipment outages, airspace restrictions), Requirements (communications - two-way radio required in Class B, C, D, equipment - transponder required in Class B, C, clearances - clearance required in Class B, C, D). Check: Airspace requirements, Restrictions, NOTAMs. Airspace must be accessible - if restricted or requirements not met, don't fly. Example: TFR active along route - cannot fly through TFR, must avoid or cancel flight.'

Explain terrain assessment: 'Terrain assessment: Obstacles (check for obstacles along route - towers, mountains, buildings), Elevation (check terrain elevation, minimum safe altitude - MSA, minimum en route altitude - MEA), Routes (check for safe routes, alternate routes, escape routes). Terrain must be safe - if terrain is hazardous, don't fly or change route. Example: Route crosses mountain range at 8,000 feet MSL, aircraft service ceiling 10,000 feet MSL - route is safe, but must maintain adequate altitude above terrain.'

Explain airport assessment: 'Airport assessment: Runway conditions (check runway condition reports - NOTAMs, check for runway closures, construction), Services (check for available services - fuel, maintenance, weather), NOTAMs (check for NOTAMs affecting airport - runway closures, equipment outages, services unavailable). Airports must be accessible - if airport is closed or services unavailable, don't fly or use alternate airport. Example: Destination airport runway closed for maintenance - cannot land at destination, must use alternate airport or cancel flight.'

Explain external pressures in detail: 'External pressures: Factors affecting decision-making that can lead to poor decisions. Types: Time pressure (schedule, deadlines, running late, appointments - pressure to fly even when conditions are marginal), Financial pressure (cost of cancellation, fuel costs, rental costs - pressure to fly to avoid costs), Passenger pressure (expectations, commitments, waiting passengers, disappointed passengers - pressure to fly to meet expectations), Personal pressure (pride, ego, proving something, not wanting to cancel, fear of looking bad - pressure to fly to maintain image). External pressures can lead to poor decisions - recognize and resist pressures. The key: Safety is priority - external pressures should not affect safety decisions.'

Explain recognizing external pressures: 'Recognizing external pressures: Ask yourself: Am I feeling pressure to fly? Why? Is it time pressure? Financial pressure? Passenger pressure? Personal pressure? If you feel pressure, identify the source. Common signs: Feeling rushed, Feeling obligated, Feeling like you must fly, Rationalizing concerns away, Minimizing risks. If you recognize pressure, evaluate it carefully - don't let pressure affect safety decisions.'

Explain resisting external pressures: 'Resisting external pressures: Safety is priority - external pressures should not affect safety decisions. If weather is marginal, don't fly regardless of pressures. If aircraft is not airworthy, don't fly regardless of pressures. If pilot is not ready, don't fly regardless of pressures. Always prioritize safety - external pressures are not valid reasons to fly when factors are questionable. Have alternatives ready - delay, cancel, reschedule, change route/aircraft/pilot.'

Present specific scenario with numbers: 'Scenario: A pilot has a flight planned for today at 2:00 PM. The flight is a cross-country from KXYZ to KABC (150 nautical miles, estimated flight time 1.5 hours). Passengers: Two friends waiting at destination airport. Weather: Current METAR at KXYZ: Visibility 4 statute miles, scattered clouds at 1,200 feet, broken clouds at 2,500 feet, wind 15 knots gusting to 22 knots from 280 degrees. Forecast: Improving conditions expected by 4:00 PM. The pilot is running 30 minutes late (planned departure 1:30 PM, actual time 2:00 PM). Passengers have been waiting at destination since 1:00 PM. Flight rental cost: $150 per hour, cancellation fee: $50. How do external pressures affect the decision? What should the pilot do?'

Guide discussion with specific analysis: 'Environment assessment: Weather: Current METAR shows visibility 4 statute miles (meets VFR minimums - 3 miles required), scattered clouds at 1,200 feet (meets VFR minimums - 500 feet below required), broken clouds at 2,500 feet (acceptable), wind 15 knots gusting to 22 knots from 280 degrees (check crosswind component - if runway is 09/27, crosswind from 280 degrees is approximately 15 knots crosswind, acceptable for most aircraft). Weather is acceptable (meets VFR minimums). Forecast: Improving conditions expected (positive trend). Airspace: Check for TFRs, NOTAMs (assumed clear - acceptable). Terrain: Route is clear (acceptable). Airports: Check for NOTAMs (assumed clear - acceptable). Environment decision: ACCEPTABLE (weather meets VFR minimums, improving forecast). External pressures: Time pressure: Running 30 minutes late (pressure to fly - CONCERN). Financial pressure: Cancellation fee $50, rental cost $150 per hour (pressure to fly to avoid costs - CONCERN). Passenger pressure: Passengers waiting at destination since 1:00 PM (pressure to fly to meet expectations - CONCERN). Personal pressure: Not wanting to disappoint passengers, not wanting to cancel (pressure to fly - CONCERN). External pressures are SIGNIFICANT (multiple pressures present). Decision factors: Environment is acceptable (weather meets VFR minimums, improving forecast), External pressures are significant (time, financial, passenger, personal pressures). However, environment is acceptable - flight can be conducted safely. Decision: Can proceed with flight (environment is acceptable), but must resist external pressures and evaluate weather carefully. If weather deteriorates, must cancel regardless of pressures. Teaching point: External pressures should not affect safety decisions - if environment is acceptable, can proceed, but must monitor conditions and be ready to cancel if conditions deteriorate. If environment was marginal, should not fly regardless of pressures.'

Present another scenario: 'Scenario: A pilot has a flight planned for today at 5:00 PM. The flight is a local flight (30 minutes). Passengers: None. Weather: Current METAR: Visibility 2.5 statute miles, overcast clouds at 600 feet, wind 8 knots from 180 degrees. Forecast: Conditions expected to remain marginal. The pilot has no time pressure, no financial pressure, no passenger pressure. However, the pilot has been looking forward to this flight all week and doesn't want to cancel. How do external pressures affect the decision? What should the pilot do?'

Guide discussion: 'Environment assessment: Weather: Current METAR shows visibility 2.5 statute miles (BELOW VFR minimums - 3 miles required), overcast clouds at 600 feet (BELOW VFR minimums - 500 feet below required). Weather is MARGINAL (does not meet VFR minimums). Forecast: Conditions expected to remain marginal (not improving). Airspace: Check for TFRs, NOTAMs (assumed clear - acceptable). Terrain: Local flight, clear (acceptable). Airports: Check for NOTAMs (assumed clear - acceptable). Environment decision: MARGINAL (weather does not meet VFR minimums). External pressures: Time pressure: None (no pressure). Financial pressure: None (no pressure). Passenger pressure: None (no passengers). Personal pressure: Looking forward to flight, doesn't want to cancel (personal pressure - CONCERN). External pressures are MINIMAL (only personal pressure). Decision factors: Environment is marginal (weather does not meet VFR minimums), External pressures are minimal (only personal pressure). Decision: Should NOT fly - weather does not meet VFR minimums. Personal pressure should not affect decision - if weather is marginal, don't fly regardless of personal pressure. Alternatives: Wait for weather improvement, Reschedule flight, Cancel flight. Teaching point: External pressures should not affect safety decisions - if weather is marginal, don't fly regardless of pressures. Personal pressure (not wanting to cancel) is not a valid reason to fly when weather is marginal.'

Explain decision-making process: 'Decision-making process: Evaluate environment and external pressures systematically. If environment is suitable (weather meets VFR minimums, airspace accessible, terrain safe, airports accessible) and external pressures are manageable (no significant pressures), proceed to go/no-go decision. If environment is marginal (weather does not meet VFR minimums, restrictions, hazards) or external pressures are significant (time, financial, passenger, personal pressures), decision is NO-GO - don't fly. Safety is priority - external pressures should not affect safety decisions. Always evaluate all factors - don't skip any factor, don't let pressures affect decisions.'

Emphasize teaching points: 'Key teaching points: Environment assessment includes weather, airspace, terrain, and airports - all must be suitable. Weather must meet VFR minimums (3 miles visibility, 500 feet below clouds) - if weather is marginal, don't fly. Airspace must be accessible (check TFRs, NOTAMs, requirements) - if restricted, don't fly. External pressures should be recognized and resisted - don't let pressures affect safety decisions. If environment is marginal, don't fly regardless of external pressures. Safety is priority - external pressures are not valid reasons to fly when factors are questionable. Always evaluate all factors systematically - don't skip factors, don't let pressures affect decisions.'

Ask questions about decision-making
keyPoints: Environment Assessment: Weather, airspace, terrain, airports - all must be suitable
Weather: Current conditions, forecasts, advisories - must meet VFR minimums, avoid thunderstorms/icing
Airspace: Controlled airspace, restrictions, NOTAMs - must be accessible, requirements met
External Pressures: Time, money, passengers, personal - recognize and resist pressures
Decision-Making: If environment suitable and no significant pressures, proceed; if marginal or pressures significant, don't fly
External pressures should not affect safety decisions - if weather is marginal, don't fly regardless of pressures

instructorActions: Write on board: 'Go/No-Go Decision: Evaluate all PAVE factors systematically (Pilot, Aircraft, enVironment, External pressures), Make decision (GO if all acceptable, NO-GO if any questionable), Have alternatives ready (delay, cancel, change route/aircraft/pilot).'

Explain decision process systematically: 'Decision process: Evaluate all PAVE factors systematically. P - Pilot: Ready? (medical, currency, proficiency, fatigue, stress, knowledge - all acceptable?). A - Aircraft: Airworthy? (documents, equipment, maintenance, condition - all acceptable?). V - enVironment: Suitable? (weather, airspace, terrain, airports - all acceptable?). E - External pressures: Manageable? (time, money, passengers, personal - no significant pressures?). If all factors are acceptable, decision is GO. If any factor is questionable, decision is NO-GO. Systematic evaluation ensures nothing is missed. The key: All factors must be evaluated - don't skip any factor, don't rationalize concerns away.'

Explain GO decision criteria: 'GO decision: All PAVE factors are acceptable. Pilot: Ready (medical valid, current, proficient, well-rested, no significant stress, adequate knowledge). Aircraft: Airworthy (documents current, required equipment operational, maintenance current, condition safe). Environment: Suitable (weather meets VFR minimums, airspace accessible, terrain safe, airports accessible). External pressures: Manageable (no significant time, financial, passenger, or personal pressures). When all factors are acceptable, flight can be conducted safely. However, continue to monitor conditions - if any factor changes, re-evaluate decision.'

Explain NO-GO decision criteria: 'NO-GO decision: Any PAVE factor is questionable. Examples: Pilot not ready (ill, tired, stressed, not current, not proficient), Aircraft not airworthy (missing/expired documents, inoperative required equipment, expired inspections, non-compliant ADs, unsafe condition), Environment not suitable (weather does not meet VFR minimums, restrictions, hazards), External pressures significant (time pressure, financial pressure, passenger pressure, personal pressure). When any factor is questionable, flight should not be conducted. The key: If any factor is questionable, decision is NO-GO - don't rationalize concerns away, don't let external pressures affect decision.'

Explain alternatives in detail: 'Alternatives: If decision is NO-GO, have alternatives ready. Options: Delay flight (wait for weather improvement, wait for maintenance, wait for pilot readiness), Cancel flight (reschedule for later, cancel completely), Change route (avoid weather problems, avoid restrictions, use alternate route), Change aircraft (if aircraft issue, use another aircraft), Change pilot (if pilot issue, have another pilot fly). Always have alternatives - don't force a flight when factors are questionable. The key: Have alternatives ready before making decision - don't wait until decision is made to think about alternatives.'

Explain decision-making framework: 'Decision-making framework: Step 1: Evaluate all PAVE factors systematically (Pilot, Aircraft, enVironment, External pressures). Step 2: Determine if all factors are acceptable (GO) or any factor is questionable (NO-GO). Step 3: If GO, proceed with flight (but continue to monitor conditions). If NO-GO, identify alternatives (delay, cancel, change route/aircraft/pilot). Step 4: Implement decision (proceed with flight or implement alternative). Step 5: Continue to monitor conditions (if any factor changes, re-evaluate decision). The key: Systematic evaluation, clear decision, alternatives ready, continuous monitoring.'

Present comprehensive scenario: 'Complete PAVE assessment scenario: A pilot has a flight planned for tomorrow at 10:00 AM. The flight is a cross-country from KXYZ to KABC (200 nautical miles, estimated flight time 2 hours). Pilot: Private pilot, third-class medical (expires in 6 months), flight review current (completed 4 months ago), 200 hours total time, 30 hours in last 90 days, well-rested (8 hours sleep), no stress, adequate knowledge. Aircraft: Cessna 172N (N12345), airworthiness certificate current, registration current, annual inspection completed 6 months ago (current), 100-hour inspection completed 20 hours ago (current), all required equipment operational, fuel 36 gallons (adequate), oil 6 quarts (adequate), no damage, controls free and correct. Environment: Weather - METAR shows visibility 5 statute miles, scattered clouds at 2,000 feet, wind 10 knots from 270 degrees, forecast improving. Airspace - no TFRs, no restrictions, NOTAMs clear. Terrain - route clear, safe altitudes. Airports - destination airport open, services available. External pressures: No time pressure, no financial pressure, no passenger pressure, no personal pressure. Complete PAVE assessment: What is the decision? What alternatives are available?'

Guide discussion with complete analysis: 'Complete PAVE assessment: P - Pilot: Medical (valid, expires in 6 months - ACCEPTABLE), Currency (flight review current, 4 months ago - ACCEPTABLE, recent experience 30 hours in 90 days - ACCEPTABLE), Proficiency (200 hours total, familiar with aircraft - ACCEPTABLE), Fatigue (well-rested, 8 hours sleep - ACCEPTABLE), Stress (no stress - ACCEPTABLE), Knowledge (adequate - ACCEPTABLE). Pilot decision: ACCEPTABLE (all factors acceptable). A - Aircraft: Documents (airworthiness current, registration current - ACCEPTABLE), Equipment (all required equipment operational - ACCEPTABLE), Maintenance (annual current, 6 months ago - ACCEPTABLE, 100-hour current, 20 hours ago - ACCEPTABLE), Condition (fuel adequate, oil adequate, no damage, controls free - ACCEPTABLE). Aircraft decision: ACCEPTABLE (all factors acceptable). V - enVironment: Weather (visibility 5 miles - ACCEPTABLE, clouds 2,000 feet - ACCEPTABLE, wind 10 knots - ACCEPTABLE, forecast improving - ACCEPTABLE), Airspace (no TFRs, no restrictions - ACCEPTABLE), Terrain (route clear - ACCEPTABLE), Airports (destination open - ACCEPTABLE). Environment decision: ACCEPTABLE (all factors acceptable). E - External pressures: Time (no pressure - ACCEPTABLE), Money (no pressure - ACCEPTABLE), Passengers (no pressure - ACCEPTABLE), Personal (no pressure - ACCEPTABLE). External pressures decision: ACCEPTABLE (no significant pressures). Overall PAVE assessment: ALL FACTORS ACCEPTABLE. Decision: GO - all PAVE factors are acceptable, flight can be conducted safely. Alternatives: Continue to monitor conditions (weather, aircraft, pilot), Have backup plan ready (alternate airport, alternate route), Be ready to cancel if conditions change. Teaching point: When all PAVE factors are acceptable, decision is GO - but continue to monitor conditions and be ready to change decision if conditions change.'

Present NO-GO scenario: 'Complete PAVE assessment scenario: A pilot has a flight planned for today at 3:00 PM. The flight is a local flight (1 hour). Pilot: Private pilot, third-class medical (expires in 2 months), flight review current (completed 8 months ago), 150 hours total time, 5 hours in last 90 days. However, pilot worked 12-hour shift yesterday, got 4 hours of sleep last night, and is feeling tired. Aircraft: Cessna 152 (N22222), airworthiness certificate current, registration current, annual inspection completed 13 months ago (OVERDUE - more than 12 months), all required equipment operational, fuel adequate, oil adequate, no damage, controls free and correct. Environment: Weather - METAR shows visibility 2.5 statute miles, overcast clouds at 500 feet, wind 15 knots gusting to 25 knots, forecast deteriorating. Airspace - no TFRs, no restrictions. Terrain - local flight, clear. Airports - local airport open. External pressures: Passengers waiting at airport (pressure to fly), running 45 minutes late (time pressure), cancellation fee $75 (financial pressure). Complete PAVE assessment: What is the decision? What alternatives are available?'

Guide discussion with complete NO-GO analysis: 'Complete PAVE assessment: P - Pilot: Medical (valid, expires in 2 months - ACCEPTABLE), Currency (flight review current, 8 months ago - ACCEPTABLE, but recent experience only 5 hours in 90 days - CONCERN for proficiency), Proficiency (150 hours total, but low recent experience - CONCERN), Fatigue (worked 12-hour shift, 4 hours sleep - FATIGUE CONCERN), Stress (no stress - ACCEPTABLE), Knowledge (adequate - ACCEPTABLE). Pilot decision: QUESTIONABLE (fatigue concern, low recent experience concern). A - Aircraft: Documents (airworthiness current, registration current - ACCEPTABLE), Equipment (all required equipment operational - ACCEPTABLE), Maintenance (annual inspection OVERDUE, 13 months ago - OVERDUE CONCERN), Condition (fuel adequate, oil adequate, no damage - ACCEPTABLE). Aircraft decision: QUESTIONABLE (annual inspection overdue). V - enVironment: Weather (visibility 2.5 miles - BELOW VFR MINIMUMS, clouds 500 feet - BELOW VFR MINIMUMS, wind 15 knots gusting to 25 knots - CONCERN, forecast deteriorating - CONCERN), Airspace (no TFRs - ACCEPTABLE), Terrain (local flight, clear - ACCEPTABLE), Airports (local airport open - ACCEPTABLE). Environment decision: QUESTIONABLE (weather does not meet VFR minimums, deteriorating forecast). E - External pressures: Time (running late, 45 minutes - TIME PRESSURE CONCERN), Money (cancellation fee $75 - FINANCIAL PRESSURE CONCERN), Passengers (waiting at airport - PASSENGER PRESSURE CONCERN), Personal (no personal pressure - ACCEPTABLE). External pressures decision: SIGNIFICANT (multiple pressures present). Overall PAVE assessment: MULTIPLE FACTORS QUESTIONABLE (pilot fatigue, aircraft maintenance overdue, weather below VFR minimums, external pressures significant). Decision: NO-GO - multiple PAVE factors are questionable, flight should not be conducted. Alternatives: Delay flight (wait for weather improvement, wait for maintenance, wait for pilot readiness), Cancel flight (reschedule for later when all factors are acceptable), Change aircraft (if maintenance issue resolved, use another aircraft), Change pilot (if pilot issue, have another pilot fly). Teaching point: If any PAVE factor is questionable, decision is NO-GO - don't rationalize concerns away, don't let external pressures affect decision. Have alternatives ready.'

Explain continuous monitoring: 'Continuous monitoring: Even if decision is GO, continue to monitor all PAVE factors. If any factor changes (weather deteriorates, aircraft issue develops, pilot becomes fatigued, external pressures increase), re-evaluate decision. If any factor becomes questionable, decision may change from GO to NO-GO. The key: Preflight assessment is not just a one-time check - it's continuous evaluation. Monitor conditions throughout flight preparation and be ready to change decision if conditions change.'

Emphasize teaching points: 'Key teaching points: Evaluate all PAVE factors systematically - don't skip any factor. If all factors are acceptable, decision is GO - but continue to monitor conditions. If any factor is questionable, decision is NO-GO - don't rationalize concerns away. Have alternatives ready before making decision - delay, cancel, change route/aircraft/pilot. External pressures should not affect safety decisions - if factors are questionable, don't fly regardless of pressures. Continue to monitor conditions - if any factor changes, re-evaluate decision. Safety is priority - always prioritize safety over external pressures.'
studentActions: Participate in discussion about go/no-go decisions
Ask questions about decision-making
keyPoints: Decision Process: Evaluate all PAVE factors systematically, if all acceptable GO, if any questionable NO-GO
GO Decision: All PAVE factors acceptable - pilot ready, aircraft airworthy, environment suitable, pressures manageable
NO-GO Decision: Any PAVE factor questionable - don't fly if any factor is unacceptable
Alternatives: Delay, cancel, change route/aircraft/pilot - always have alternatives ready
If any PAVE factor is questionable, decision is NO-GO - have alternatives ready

instructorActions: Summarize key concepts comprehensively: 'Let's review what we've covered: PAVE checklist provides systematic preflight assessment. P - Pilot: Are you ready? Evaluate using IMSAFE checklist (Illness, Medication, Stress, Alcohol, Fatigue, Emotion), medical certificate validity, currency requirements (flight review, recent experience, night currency, instrument currency), proficiency level (comfortable with planned flight, adequate experience), and personal factors (well-rested, alert, manageable stress). A - Aircraft: Is aircraft ready? Evaluate documents (airworthiness certificate, registration, operating limitations), required equipment (Part 91.205 VFR day/night equipment, all operational), maintenance (annual inspection within 12 months, 100-hour inspection if used for hire within 100 hours, AD compliance), and condition (safe condition, adequate fuel/oil, no damage, proper configuration). V - enVironment: Is environment suitable? Evaluate weather (current conditions, forecasts, advisories - visibility, clouds, wind, thunderstorms, icing), airspace (controlled airspace requirements, restrictions, NOTAMs), terrain (obstacles, elevation, routes), and airports (runway conditions, services, NOTAMs). E - External pressures: Are there pressures affecting decision? Evaluate time pressure (schedule, deadlines), financial pressure (cost of cancellation), passenger pressure (expectations, commitments), and personal pressure (pride, ego, proving something). Go/No-Go decision: Evaluate all PAVE factors systematically - if all factors are acceptable, decision is GO; if any factor is questionable, decision is NO-GO. Always have alternatives ready (delay, cancel, change route/aircraft/pilot).'

Ask synthesis question: 'Now let's integrate everything. How do all PAVE factors work together in a preflight assessment? Give me one complete example: A pilot has a flight planned. Describe a scenario with specific numbers and conditions, then walk me through a complete PAVE assessment and go/no-go decision. Include: Pilot factors (medical, currency, proficiency, fatigue, stress), Aircraft factors (documents, equipment, maintenance, condition), Environment factors (weather with actual METAR data, airspace, terrain), External pressures (time, money, passengers, personal), and your go/no-go decision with alternatives.'

Listen actively to student response, taking notes: 'I'm listening carefully to your PAVE assessment. I'm noting how you're evaluating each factor systematically. Let me check: Are you evaluating all PAVE factors? Are you using specific numbers and conditions? Are you making a clear go/no-go decision? Are you identifying alternatives?'

Provide specific feedback: 'Excellent work! You're integrating all the preflight assessment knowledge effectively. I particularly liked how you: [specific positive feedback]. One thing to consider: [specific constructive feedback]. That's exactly how effective risk management works - all factors considered together systematically. Your ability to evaluate all PAVE factors and make clear go/no-go decisions demonstrates strong understanding of preflight assessment.'

Review objectives systematically: 'Let's check your mastery against our objectives: Can you explain the PAVE checklist including Pilot, Aircraft, enVironment, and External pressures assessment? [Check student response]. Can you assess pilot readiness using IMSAFE checklist, medical, currency, proficiency, fatigue, and stress? [Check student response]. Can you assess aircraft airworthiness including documents, equipment, maintenance, and condition? [Check student response]. Can you assess environmental factors including weather, airspace, terrain, and airports? [Check student response]. Can you identify external pressures including time, money, passengers, and personal pressures? [Check student response]. Can you make go/no-go decisions by evaluating all PAVE factors systematically? [Check student response]. Can you teach preflight assessment to students effectively? [Check student response]. If yes to all, you've mastered this lesson. If any need work, let's address those now.'

Assign comprehensive homework: 'Your homework assignments: 1) Review AC 91-92 - Pilot's Guide to a Preflight Briefing thoroughly. Study the PAVE checklist and risk management principles. 2) Practice PAVE checklist for various scenarios. Create 5 different scenarios with specific numbers and conditions, then complete PAVE assessment and go/no-go decision for each. Include scenarios with: All factors acceptable (GO decision), Pilot factor questionable (NO-GO decision), Aircraft factor questionable (NO-GO decision), Environment factor questionable (NO-GO decision), External pressures significant (NO-GO decision). 3) Study go/no-go decision-making. Practice evaluating all PAVE factors systematically and making clear decisions. 4) Practice identifying external pressures. In your next 5 flights (or flight planning sessions), identify any external pressures you feel and practice resisting them. 5) Journal assignment: Write one complete example of how you would teach preflight assessment to a student. Include: How you would explain PAVE checklist, How you would teach pilot assessment using IMSAFE, How you would teach aircraft assessment, How you would teach environment assessment, How you would teach external pressures identification, How you would teach go/no-go decision-making, One specific scenario with numbers and conditions that you would use in teaching. This journal entry should be 2-3 pages and demonstrate your ability to teach preflight assessment effectively.'

Emphasize practical application: 'Remember: Preflight assessment is practical knowledge you'll use before every flight. Before every flight, you must evaluate: Pilot readiness (IMSAFE, medical, currency, proficiency, fatigue, stress), Aircraft airworthiness (documents, equipment, maintenance, condition), Environment suitability (weather, airspace, terrain, airports), External pressures (time, money, passengers, personal). As a CFI, you'll constantly be teaching and using preflight assessment. Understanding preflight assessment enables safe flight operations and effective instruction. Always evaluate all PAVE factors systematically, make go/no-go decisions based on all factors, have alternatives ready, and prioritize safety over external pressures.'

Close with encouragement: 'Preflight assessment is fundamental to safe flight operations. Master the PAVE checklist, and you can evaluate flight readiness systematically and make safe decisions. Always evaluate all PAVE factors, make go/no-go decisions based on all factors, have alternatives ready, and prioritize safety over external pressures. This knowledge is essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction. You've done excellent work today. Questions before we wrap up?'
