instructorActions: Write on board: 'Engine Start Sequence: Master on, Fuel pump (if required), Mixture (idle cutoff carbureted, full rich fuel-injected), Throttle cracked (1/4 to 1/2 inch), Starter engage, Monitor engine (oil pressure, RPM, instruments, sound), Mixture rich when engine fires (carbureted), Adjust throttle.'

Explain starting sequence systematically: 'Starting sequence: Follow POH procedures exactly - procedures vary by aircraft type. Typical sequence: Step 1: Master switch ON (provides electrical power for starter, after pre-start checks with master off). Step 2: Fuel pump ON if required (fuel-injected engines typically require fuel pump on to prime fuel system, carbureted engines may not require - check POH). Step 3: Mixture set correctly (carbureted: idle cutoff before start to prevent flooding, fuel-injected: full rich before start). Step 4: Throttle cracked (typically 1/4 to 1/2 inch open, provides air for combustion, check POH for specific setting). Step 5: Starter engage (turn key to start position, engage starter, crank engine). Step 6: Monitor engine (watch oil pressure should rise, RPM should increase, engine should fire, engine sound should be smooth). Step 7: Mixture rich when engine fires (carbureted engines only - when engine fires, move mixture to rich immediately to keep engine running). Step 8: Adjust throttle (adjust throttle to maintain idle RPM, typically 600-800 RPM, check POH). Follow POH exactly - procedures vary by aircraft type. Example: Cessna 172N (carbureted): Master on, Mixture idle cutoff, Throttle 1/4 inch, Starter engage, When engine fires (RPM increases to 300-400 RPM), Mixture rich immediately, Adjust throttle to 700 RPM idle. Piper PA-28-181 (fuel-injected): Master on, Fuel pump on, Mixture full rich, Throttle 1/2 inch, Starter engage, Monitor engine, Adjust throttle to 800 RPM idle.'

Explain carbureted engine procedures in detail: 'Carbureted engine: Specific procedures for carbureted engines. Mixture idle cutoff before start: Prevents flooding (too much fuel in cylinders), Allows engine to draw fuel when starter engages, Prevents rough start. Throttle cracked: Typically 1/4 to 1/2 inch open, Provides air for combustion, Check POH for specific setting. Starter engage: Turn key to start position, Engage starter, Crank engine (typically 5-10 seconds maximum, don't over-crank). When engine fires: Engine fires when RPM increases (typically 300-400 RPM), Engine sound changes (smooth running sound), Oil pressure may start to rise. Mixture rich immediately: When engine fires, move mixture to rich immediately (within 1-2 seconds), If mixture not moved to rich, engine will die immediately (no fuel with mixture cutoff), Timing is critical - must move mixture quickly. Monitor engine: Watch oil pressure (should rise within 30 seconds), RPM (should stabilize at idle 600-800 RPM), Engine sound (smooth running), Engine instruments (normal indications). Adjust throttle: Adjust throttle to maintain idle RPM (typically 600-800 RPM, check POH), Don't over-adjust, Let engine warm up. Example: Cessna 172N start: Mixture idle cutoff, Throttle 1/4 inch, Starter engage, Engine fires at 350 RPM after 3 seconds, Mixture rich immediately, RPM stabilizes at 700 RPM, Oil pressure rises to 40 PSI within 20 seconds, Engine running smoothly.'

Explain fuel-injected engine procedures comprehensively: 'Fuel-injected engine: Specific procedures for fuel-injected engines. Mixture full rich before start: Fuel-injected engines need fuel before start, Mixture full rich provides fuel, Prevents no-start condition. Fuel pump ON: Fuel pump primes fuel system (pressurizes fuel lines, provides fuel to injectors), Typically required for fuel-injected engines, Check POH for specific procedure. Throttle cracked: Typically 1/2 inch open (slightly more than carbureted), Provides air for combustion, Check POH for specific setting. Starter engage: Turn key to start position, Engage starter, Crank engine (typically 5-10 seconds maximum). Monitor engine: Watch oil pressure (should rise within 30 seconds), RPM (should stabilize at idle 700-900 RPM), Engine sound (smooth running), Engine instruments (normal indications). Adjust throttle: Adjust throttle to maintain idle RPM (typically 700-900 RPM, check POH), Don't over-adjust, Let engine warm up. Example: Piper PA-28-181 start: Fuel pump on, Mixture full rich, Throttle 1/2 inch, Starter engage, Engine fires at 400 RPM after 2 seconds, RPM stabilizes at 800 RPM, Oil pressure rises to 45 PSI within 15 seconds, Engine running smoothly.'

Explain monitoring during start: 'Monitoring: Watch engine carefully during start. Oil pressure: Should rise within 30 seconds (typically 30-60 PSI for most aircraft, check POH for specific range), If no oil pressure within 30 seconds: Shut down immediately (indicates serious problem - no oil, pump failure, blockage). RPM: Should increase when engine fires (typically 300-400 RPM when firing, then stabilize at idle 600-900 RPM), Should stabilize quickly (within 10-15 seconds), If RPM unstable or rough: Troubleshoot or shut down. Engine instruments: Oil pressure (should rise), Oil temperature (should start warming up), Fuel pressure (should be normal), RPM (should stabilize), Ammeter (should show charging). Engine sound: Should be smooth running (no knocking, no sputtering, no backfiring), If sound abnormal: Troubleshoot or shut down. If engine doesn't start: Stop starter after 10 seconds maximum (prevents starter damage, prevents battery drain), Troubleshoot (check fuel, battery, mixture, throttle), Try again with corrections. Monitor engine - abnormal indications require immediate action. Example: Engine starts, RPM increases to 350 RPM, then drops to 0 RPM (engine dies) - problem: Mixture not moved to rich (carbureted), or fuel pump not on (fuel-injected). Solution: Correct procedure, try again.'

Explain common issues and troubleshooting: 'Common issues: Engine doesn't start, Engine starts rough, Engine fires. Engine doesn't start: Causes: Flooded (too much fuel in cylinders - carbureted engines), No fuel (fuel selector wrong, fuel pump off, fuel empty), Weak battery (battery voltage low, starter weak), Mixture wrong (idle cutoff when should be rich, or vice versa). Troubleshooting: If flooded (carbureted): Mixture idle cutoff, Throttle full open, Crank engine 10-15 seconds to clear fuel, Then try start again with proper procedure. If no fuel: Check fuel selector (on proper tank), Check fuel quantity (adequate fuel), Check fuel pump (on if required), Check fuel lines (no leaks). If weak battery: Check battery voltage (should be 12 volts or more), Charge battery if needed, Check connections. If mixture wrong: Check mixture setting (idle cutoff carbureted, full rich fuel-injected), Set correctly, Try again. Engine starts rough: Causes: Mixture wrong (too rich or too lean), Throttle wrong (too much or too little), Engine cold (needs warm-up). Troubleshooting: Adjust mixture (richer or leaner as needed), Adjust throttle (idle RPM), Let engine warm up (2-3 minutes typically). Engine fires: Causes: Fuel leak (fuel leaking onto hot engine), Over-priming (too much fuel), Fuel in engine compartment. Actions: Continue cranking first (may extinguish fire), Then shut down (mixture cutoff, throttle full, master off), Then evacuate if fire persists. Know troubleshooting - common issues have solutions.'

Present specific scenario with numbers: 'Scenario: A student is starting a Cessna 172N (carbureted engine, O-320 engine) on a warm day (temperature 80°F). Pre-start checks completed correctly. Starting procedure: Master switch ON (correct), Fuel pump not applicable (carbureted), Mixture idle cutoff (correct), Throttle 1/4 inch open (correct), Starter engage. Student engages starter, engine fires after 4 seconds (RPM increases to 350 RPM), but student forgets to move mixture to rich. Engine RPM increases to 350 RPM, then drops to 200 RPM, then engine dies (RPM drops to 0). Student tries again: Starter engage, engine fires after 3 seconds (RPM increases to 320 RPM), student remembers to move mixture to rich, but moves it too slowly (takes 4 seconds to move mixture). Engine RPM increases to 320 RPM, mixture moved to rich after 4 seconds, but engine dies before mixture reaches rich (RPM drops to 0 before mixture rich). Student tries third time: Starter engage, engine fires after 3 seconds (RPM increases to 340 RPM), student moves mixture to rich immediately (within 1 second), engine continues running. RPM stabilizes at 700 RPM, oil pressure rises to 40 PSI within 20 seconds, engine running smoothly. What happened? How do you teach proper mixture movement?'

Guide discussion with specific analysis: 'First attempt: Engine fires (RPM 350 RPM after 4 seconds - engine is firing), Mixture not moved to rich (mixture still idle cutoff - no fuel), Engine dies (RPM drops to 0 - engine can't run without fuel). Problem: Student forgot to move mixture to rich, engine died immediately. Second attempt: Engine fires (RPM 320 RPM after 3 seconds - engine is firing), Mixture moved too slowly (takes 4 seconds to move mixture - too slow), Engine dies (RPM drops to 0 before mixture reaches rich - engine can't run without fuel long enough). Problem: Student moved mixture too slowly, engine died before mixture reached rich. Third attempt: Engine fires (RPM 340 RPM after 3 seconds - engine is firing), Mixture moved immediately (within 1 second - fast enough), Engine continues running (RPM stabilizes at 700 RPM, oil pressure 40 PSI, engine smooth). Success: Student moved mixture quickly enough, engine continued running. Teaching points: Mixture movement timing is critical - must move mixture to rich immediately when engine fires (within 1-2 seconds maximum). If mixture not moved quickly enough, engine will die (no fuel with mixture cutoff). Practice: Have student practice mixture movement (practice moving mixture quickly, practice timing), Emphasize: When engine fires (RPM increases), move mixture to rich immediately (within 1-2 seconds), Monitor engine (RPM should stabilize, oil pressure should rise). Teaching: Mixture movement is critical for carbureted engines - move to rich immediately when engine fires, timing is essential, practice until automatic.'

Present another scenario: 'Scenario: An experienced pilot is starting a Piper PA-28-181 (fuel-injected engine, O-360 engine) on a cold morning (temperature 40°F). Pre-start checks completed correctly. Starting procedure: Master switch ON (correct), Fuel pump ON (required for fuel-injected - primes fuel system), Mixture full rich (correct), Throttle 1/2 inch open (correct), Starter engage. Pilot engages starter, engine fires after 2 seconds (RPM increases to 400 RPM), RPM stabilizes at 800 RPM, oil pressure rises to 45 PSI within 15 seconds, engine running smoothly. How does this proper starting procedure ensure successful engine start?'

Guide discussion: 'Proper starting procedure: Fuel-injected engine: Fuel pump ON (primes fuel system, pressurizes fuel lines, provides fuel to injectors - critical for fuel-injected), Mixture full rich (provides fuel before start - required for fuel-injected), Throttle 1/2 inch (provides air for combustion - correct for fuel-injected), Starter engage (cranks engine, engine fires quickly). Successful start: Engine fires quickly (2 seconds - fuel system primed, mixture rich, proper procedure), RPM stabilizes quickly (800 RPM - proper idle RPM for fuel-injected), Oil pressure rises quickly (45 PSI within 15 seconds - normal operation), Engine running smoothly (no rough running, no problems). Teaching point: Fuel-injected engines require different procedure than carbureted - fuel pump ON, mixture full rich before start, throttle slightly more open. Proper procedure ensures successful start - fuel system primed, mixture correct, throttle correct, engine fires quickly and runs smoothly.'

Explain starting checklist: 'Starting checklist: Use checklist systematically. Typical checklist items: Master switch on, Fuel pump on if required, Mixture (idle cutoff carbureted, full rich fuel-injected), Throttle cracked (1/4 to 1/2 inch), Starter engage, Monitor engine (oil pressure, RPM, instruments, sound), Mixture rich when engine fires (carbureted), Adjust throttle (idle RPM). Use checklist - don't skip items, follow sequence, monitor engine, adjust as needed. The key: Follow POH exactly - procedures vary by aircraft type, use checklist systematically, monitor engine carefully.'

Emphasize teaching points: 'Key teaching points: Starting sequence: Follow POH exactly (procedures vary by aircraft type), Master on, Fuel pump on if required, Mixture correct for engine type (idle cutoff carbureted, full rich fuel-injected), Throttle cracked (1/4 to 1/2 inch), Starter engage, Monitor engine. Carbureted engine: Mixture idle cutoff before start (prevents flooding), Mixture rich immediately when engine fires (within 1-2 seconds - critical timing), Monitor engine (oil pressure, RPM, instruments, sound). Fuel-injected engine: Fuel pump ON before start (primes fuel system), Mixture full rich before start (provides fuel), Monitor engine (oil pressure, RPM, instruments, sound). Monitoring: Watch oil pressure (should rise within 30 seconds), RPM (should stabilize at idle 600-900 RPM), Engine instruments (normal indications), Engine sound (smooth running). Common issues: Engine doesn't start (flooded, no fuel, weak battery - troubleshoot), Engine starts rough (mixture, throttle - adjust), Engine fires (continue cranking first, then shut down, then evacuate). Always follow POH exactly - procedures vary by aircraft type, use checklist systematically, monitor engine carefully.'

teachingScript.phase: Hot Starts and Engine Fires (20 minutes)
instructorActions: Write on board: 'Hot Start: Engine hot from recent operation (vaporizes fuel, difficult to start) - Procedure: Mixture idle cutoff, Throttle full open, Crank engine to clear fuel, Mixture rich, Throttle cracked, Starter engage. Engine Fires: Fire visible, smoke, fuel smell - Actions: Continue cranking first (may extinguish), Mixture idle cutoff, Throttle full open, Master switch off, Evacuate if fire persists.'

Explain hot starts comprehensively: 'Hot starts: Engine is hot from recent operation (engine shut down less than 15-30 minutes ago, engine temperature still high 200°F+). Problem: Hot engine vaporizes fuel (fuel turns to vapor in hot engine, vapor doesn't burn well, difficult to start, can cause flooding). Hot start procedure (carbureted engines): Step 1: Mixture idle cutoff (prevents additional fuel, prevents flooding). Step 2: Throttle full open (provides maximum air flow, helps clear fuel vapor). Step 3: Crank engine (crank for 10-15 seconds to clear fuel vapor from cylinders, draws air through engine, clears fuel). Step 4: Mixture rich (after clearing fuel, set mixture to rich). Step 5: Throttle cracked (set throttle to normal start position, typically 1/4 to 1/2 inch). Step 6: Starter engage (start engine normally, engine should start more easily after clearing fuel). Hot start procedure: Clear fuel first (crank with throttle full open, mixture cutoff), Then start normally (mixture rich, throttle cracked, starter engage). Know hot start procedure - hot engines require different technique. Example: Cessna 172N hot start: Engine shut down 10 minutes ago, engine temperature 220°F. Normal start procedure doesn't work (engine won't start, too much fuel vapor). Hot start procedure: Mixture idle cutoff, Throttle full open, Crank engine 12 seconds (clears fuel vapor), Mixture rich, Throttle 1/4 inch, Starter engage, Engine starts successfully after 3 seconds.'

Explain fuel-injected hot starts: 'Fuel-injected hot starts: Fuel-injected engines handle hot starts differently. Problem: Hot engine vaporizes fuel in fuel lines (fuel vapor in lines, injectors may not work properly, difficult to start). Procedure: Step 1: Fuel pump OFF (don't prime hot engine, prevents additional fuel vapor). Step 2: Mixture idle cutoff (prevents fuel flow). Step 3: Throttle full open (provides maximum air flow). Step 4: Crank engine (crank for 10-15 seconds to clear fuel vapor, draws air through engine). Step 5: Fuel pump ON (after clearing, turn fuel pump on). Step 6: Mixture full rich (set mixture to rich). Step 7: Throttle cracked (set throttle to normal start position). Step 8: Starter engage (start engine normally). Fuel-injected hot start: Don't prime (fuel pump off), Clear fuel vapor (crank with throttle full open), Then start normally (fuel pump on, mixture rich, throttle cracked). Example: Piper PA-28-181 hot start: Engine shut down 20 minutes ago, engine temperature 210°F. Hot start procedure: Fuel pump OFF, Mixture idle cutoff, Throttle full open, Crank engine 10 seconds (clears fuel vapor), Fuel pump ON, Mixture full rich, Throttle 1/2 inch, Starter engage, Engine starts successfully after 2 seconds.'

Explain engine fires systematically: 'Engine fires: Fire during engine start. Causes: Fuel leak (fuel leaking from fuel lines, fuel selector, fuel pump onto hot engine, fuel ignites), Over-priming (too much fuel in cylinders, fuel leaks out, ignites), Fuel in engine compartment (fuel spilled during refueling, fuel in engine compartment, ignites during start). Recognition: Fire visible (flames visible around engine, typically near fuel lines, engine compartment), Smoke (smoke from engine compartment, typically white or black smoke), Fuel smell (strong fuel smell, indicates fuel leak or spill). Actions - Step 1: Continue cranking (continue cranking engine for 5-10 seconds, draws fuel into engine cylinders, may extinguish fire by drawing fuel away from fire, often extinguishes small fires). Step 2: Mixture idle cutoff (stops fuel flow to engine, prevents additional fuel feeding fire). Step 3: Throttle full open (clears fuel from engine, helps extinguish fire). Step 4: Master switch OFF (stops electrical power, stops fuel pump, prevents additional fuel flow, reduces fire risk). Step 5: Evacuate if fire persists (if fire continues after 10-15 seconds, evacuate aircraft immediately, fire extinguisher if available, but safety first - evacuate). Engine fire procedure: Continue cranking first (often extinguishes fire), Then shut down (mixture cutoff, throttle full, master off), Then evacuate if needed (if fire persists, evacuate immediately). The key: Continue cranking first - often extinguishes fire by drawing fuel into engine. Don't panic - follow procedure systematically.'

Explain fire prevention in detail: 'Fire prevention: Proper procedures prevent fires. Techniques: Don't over-prime (don't prime engine excessively, follow POH procedures, over-priming causes fuel to leak, increases fire risk), Check for fuel leaks (check fuel lines, fuel selector, fuel pump for leaks before start, fix leaks before starting), Use proper starting procedure (follow POH exactly, don't skip steps, proper procedure reduces fire risk), Monitor during start (watch for fire, smoke, fuel smell during start, catch problems early). Prevention: Proper procedures (follow POH, don't skip steps), No over-priming (prime only as required, follow POH), Check for leaks (inspect fuel system before start, fix leaks), Monitor carefully (watch during start, catch problems early). Prevent fires - proper procedures reduce fire risk significantly. Example: Student over-primes carbureted engine (primes 8 times instead of 3-4 times), fuel leaks from carburetor, fuel ignites during start - fire occurs. Prevention: Follow POH (prime 3-4 times as required), Don't over-prime, Monitor during start, Catch problems early.'

Present specific scenario with numbers: 'Scenario: A student is starting a Cessna 172N (carbureted engine) after the aircraft was shut down 8 minutes ago (engine still hot, temperature 215°F). The student uses normal start procedure: Mixture idle cutoff, Throttle 1/4 inch, Starter engage. Student engages starter, cranks engine for 10 seconds, but engine doesn't start (engine won't fire, too much fuel vapor). Student tries again: Same procedure, cranks for 10 seconds, engine still won't start. Student tries third time: Same procedure, cranks for 12 seconds, engine still won't start. Battery voltage drops to 11.2 volts (battery getting weak from multiple start attempts). What's the problem? How do you teach hot start procedure?'

Guide discussion with specific analysis: 'Problem: Hot engine (engine temperature 215°F, shut down 8 minutes ago - engine is hot), Normal start procedure doesn't work (too much fuel vapor, engine won't start), Multiple start attempts (battery getting weak, 11.2 volts - may not have enough power for more attempts). Hot start procedure needed: Mixture idle cutoff (prevents additional fuel), Throttle full open (provides maximum air flow, helps clear fuel vapor), Crank engine 10-15 seconds (clears fuel vapor from cylinders, draws air through engine), Mixture rich (after clearing fuel, set mixture to rich), Throttle 1/4 inch (set throttle to normal start position), Starter engage (start engine normally, engine should start after clearing fuel). Teaching points: Recognize hot engine (engine shut down less than 15-30 minutes ago, engine temperature high 200°F+), Use hot start procedure (clear fuel first, then start normally), Don't use normal start procedure for hot engine (won't work, wastes battery, causes frustration). Practice: Have student practice recognizing hot engine, Practice hot start procedure, Emphasize: Clear fuel first (crank with throttle full open, mixture cutoff), Then start normally (mixture rich, throttle cracked, starter engage). Teaching: Hot engines require different procedure - clear fuel vapor first, then start normally. Know when to use hot start procedure - engine shut down recently, engine temperature high.'

Present engine fire scenario: 'Scenario: During engine start of a Cessna 172N, fire is visible around the engine (flames visible near fuel lines, smoke from engine compartment, strong fuel smell). Student panics, releases starter, and starts to evacuate aircraft immediately. Fire continues burning (fire not extinguished, continues to burn, fuel feeding fire). What should the student do? How do you teach engine fire procedures?'

Guide discussion: 'Student's actions: Released starter immediately (stopped cranking, didn't continue cranking), Started to evacuate (panicked, didn't follow procedure). Problem: Fire not extinguished (continues burning, fuel feeding fire, fire getting worse), Student didn't follow procedure (didn't continue cranking, didn't shut down properly). Correct procedure: Step 1: Continue cranking (continue cranking engine for 5-10 seconds, draws fuel into engine cylinders, may extinguish fire by drawing fuel away from fire - often extinguishes small fires). Step 2: Mixture idle cutoff (stops fuel flow to engine, prevents additional fuel feeding fire). Step 3: Throttle full open (clears fuel from engine, helps extinguish fire). Step 4: Master switch OFF (stops electrical power, stops fuel pump, prevents additional fuel flow). Step 5: Evacuate if fire persists (if fire continues after 10-15 seconds, evacuate aircraft immediately, fire extinguisher if available, but safety first - evacuate). Teaching points: Continue cranking first (often extinguishes fire - critical step, don't skip), Then shut down (mixture cutoff, throttle full, master off), Then evacuate if needed (if fire persists, evacuate immediately). Practice: Brief fire procedures before every flight, Emphasize: Continue cranking first (often extinguishes), Then shut down, Then evacuate if needed, Practice responses, Don't panic - follow procedure. Teaching: Engine fire - continue cranking first (often extinguishes), then shut down, then evacuate if needed. Don't panic - follow procedure systematically.'

Explain fire response timing: 'Fire response timing: Critical timing for fire response. Continue cranking: 5-10 seconds (draws fuel into engine, may extinguish fire, most fires extinguish within 5-10 seconds of continued cranking). If fire extinguished: Mixture cutoff, Throttle full, Master off, Check for damage, Troubleshoot cause, Don't restart until cause found and fixed. If fire persists: After 10-15 seconds of cranking, if fire continues, evacuate immediately (fire not extinguished, getting worse, safety first - evacuate). Fire extinguisher: If fire persists and fire extinguisher available, use fire extinguisher (but safety first - if fire large, evacuate immediately, don't risk injury). The key: Continue cranking first - often extinguishes fire within 5-10 seconds. If fire persists after 10-15 seconds, evacuate immediately.'

Emphasize teaching points: 'Key teaching points: Hot starts: Recognize hot engine (engine shut down less than 15-30 minutes ago, engine temperature high 200°F+), Use hot start procedure (clear fuel first - crank with throttle full open, mixture cutoff, then start normally - mixture rich, throttle cracked, starter engage), Don't use normal start for hot engine (won't work, wastes battery). Engine fires: Recognize fire (fire visible, smoke, fuel smell), Continue cranking first (5-10 seconds, often extinguishes fire - critical step), Then shut down (mixture cutoff, throttle full, master off), Then evacuate if needed (if fire persists after 10-15 seconds, evacuate immediately). Fire prevention: Don't over-prime (follow POH, prime only as required), Check for fuel leaks (inspect fuel system before start, fix leaks), Use proper starting procedure (follow POH exactly, don't skip steps), Monitor during start (watch for fire, smoke, fuel smell). Know hot start and fire procedures - emergencies require immediate correct action. Practice procedures - don't panic, follow procedure systematically.'

instructorActions: Write on board: 'Post-Start Checks: Oil pressure (must rise within 30 seconds, 30-60 PSI typical, if no pressure shut down immediately), RPM (should stabilize at idle 600-900 RPM, smooth operation), Engine instruments (oil pressure, oil temperature, fuel pressure, RPM, ammeter - all normal), Systems (electrical charging, fuel flow, controls, avionics - all operational), Taxi readiness (engine normal, systems operational, clear to proceed).'

Explain oil pressure comprehensively: 'Oil pressure: Check oil pressure immediately after engine start. Normal: Oil pressure should rise within 30 seconds (typically 30-60 PSI for most aircraft, check POH for specific range), Indicates normal operation (oil pump working, oil circulating, engine lubricated), Pressure should stabilize quickly (within 30 seconds, then remain stable). Abnormal: If no oil pressure within 30 seconds (pressure gauge shows 0 PSI, no pressure indication), If pressure very low (pressure below 20 PSI, indicates problem), If pressure very high (pressure above 80 PSI, may indicate blockage). Action: If no pressure within 30 seconds: Shut down immediately (indicates serious problem - no oil, pump failure, blockage, engine damage will occur if continued), Don't continue (engine will be damaged without oil, expensive repair, safety risk), Troubleshoot (check oil quantity, check for leaks, check pump, don't restart until problem fixed). Oil pressure: Critical indicator - no pressure indicates serious problem. Check immediately after start - if no pressure, shut down immediately. Example: Cessna 172N after start: Engine running, RPM 700, but oil pressure gauge shows 0 PSI after 30 seconds. Problem: No oil pressure (serious problem - no oil, pump failure, or blockage). Action: Shut down immediately (mixture cutoff, throttle idle, master off), Don't continue (engine will be damaged without oil), Troubleshoot (check oil quantity, check for leaks, check pump).'

Explain RPM monitoring: 'RPM: Check engine RPM after start. Normal: RPM should stabilize at idle quickly (typically 600-900 RPM for most aircraft, check POH for specific range), Should stabilize within 10-15 seconds (RPM increases when engine fires, then stabilizes at idle), Smooth operation (RPM steady, no fluctuations, no rough running). Abnormal: If RPM unstable (RPM fluctuating, not steady, indicates problem), If RPM rough (engine running rough, RPM unstable, indicates problem), If RPM too high (RPM above 1000, throttle may be too open), If RPM too low (RPM below 500, engine may stall). Action: If RPM unstable or rough: Troubleshoot (check mixture, check throttle, check engine), May need to shut down (if problem severe, shut down and troubleshoot), Adjust as needed (adjust mixture, adjust throttle, let engine warm up). RPM: Should stabilize quickly, smooth operation indicates normal start. Monitor RPM - rough operation requires attention. Example: Engine starts, RPM increases to 400 RPM when firing, then stabilizes at 750 RPM within 12 seconds, RPM steady, engine running smoothly - normal operation.'

Explain engine instruments systematically: 'Engine instruments: Check all engine instruments after start. Oil pressure: Should rise within 30 seconds (typically 30-60 PSI, check POH), Should remain stable (pressure steady, no fluctuations). Oil temperature: Should start warming up (temperature increasing, typically 100-200°F during warm-up, check POH for normal range), Should reach operating temperature (typically 180-220°F for most aircraft, check POH). Fuel pressure: Should be normal (typically 3-8 PSI for carbureted, 20-30 PSI for fuel-injected, check POH), Should remain stable (pressure steady, no fluctuations). RPM: Should stabilize at idle (600-900 RPM, check POH), Should be steady (RPM stable, no fluctuations). Ammeter: Should show charging (positive indication, typically +5 to +15 amps, indicates alternator/generator working), Should remain stable (charging steady, no fluctuations). All instruments should show normal indications. Monitor instruments - abnormal indications require attention. Example: After engine start: Oil pressure 45 PSI (normal), Oil temperature 120°F and increasing (warming up, normal), Fuel pressure 5 PSI (normal for carbureted), RPM 750 (normal idle), Ammeter +8 amps (charging, normal). All instruments normal - engine operating normally.'

Explain systems checks: 'Systems: Check aircraft systems after start. Electrical system: Check charging (ammeter shows positive, typically +5 to +15 amps, indicates alternator/generator working), Check voltage (voltmeter shows 13-14 volts when charging, indicates electrical system working), Check lights (position lights, strobe lights working if turned on). Fuel system: Check fuel flow (fuel flowing normally, no interruptions), Check for leaks (no fuel leaks visible, no fuel smell in cockpit, no fuel on ground), Check fuel quantity (fuel quantity adequate, gauges showing normal). Controls: Check controls free and correct (flight controls move freely, correct direction, no binding), Check trim (trim working, set correctly). Avionics: Can turn on after warm-up (typically 2-3 minutes after start, allows engine to stabilize, prevents voltage fluctuations), Check avionics working (radios, GPS, transponder working when turned on). Systems should operate normally. Check systems - ensure everything is working. Example: After engine start: Electrical charging (+10 amps, 13.5 volts - normal), Fuel flow normal (no leaks, fuel quantity adequate - normal), Controls free and correct (all controls working - normal), Avionics ready (can turn on after 2-3 minutes - normal). All systems operational - ready for flight.'

Explain taxi readiness: 'Taxi readiness: Ensure ready to taxi before moving aircraft. Check: Engine running smoothly (RPM stable, engine sound smooth, no rough running, no problems), Oil pressure normal (pressure within normal range, typically 30-60 PSI, stable), Systems operational (electrical charging, fuel flow normal, controls free, avionics ready), Controls free (flight controls move freely, correct direction, no binding), Clear to taxi (area clear, no obstacles, ready to proceed). Ready to taxi: Engine normal (running smoothly, all indications normal), Systems operational (all systems working, no problems), Clear to proceed (area clear, ready to taxi). Don't taxi until ready - ensure everything is normal before moving aircraft. Example: After engine start and 2-minute warm-up: Engine running smoothly (RPM 750, stable), Oil pressure 45 PSI (normal, stable), Oil temperature 180°F (operating temperature), Fuel pressure 5 PSI (normal), Ammeter +10 amps (charging), Electrical system normal (13.5 volts), Fuel system normal (no leaks, adequate fuel), Controls free and correct, Avionics ready. All systems normal - ready to taxi.'

Present specific scenario with numbers: 'Scenario: After engine start of a Cessna 172N, student checks post-start: Oil pressure gauge shows 0 PSI after 30 seconds (no pressure indication), RPM stabilizes at 750 RPM (normal), Oil temperature 110°F and increasing (normal), Fuel pressure 5 PSI (normal), Ammeter +8 amps (charging, normal). Engine is running (RPM 750, engine sound smooth), but oil pressure is 0 PSI. Student wants to continue (thinks engine is running fine, wants to proceed). What should the student do? How do you teach post-start checks?'

Guide discussion with specific analysis: 'Post-start check: Oil pressure: 0 PSI after 30 seconds (ABNORMAL - should be 30-60 PSI, indicates serious problem), RPM: 750 RPM (normal - engine running), Oil temperature: 110°F (normal - warming up), Fuel pressure: 5 PSI (normal), Ammeter: +8 amps (normal - charging). Problem: No oil pressure (serious problem - no oil, pump failure, blockage, engine damage will occur if continued). Engine running: Engine is running (RPM 750, sound smooth), but without oil pressure, engine will be damaged (engine parts not lubricated, friction will cause damage, expensive repair $5,000-$15,000+, safety risk). Action: Shut down immediately (mixture cutoff, throttle idle, master off, don't continue), Don't continue (engine will be damaged without oil, expensive repair, safety risk), Troubleshoot (check oil quantity - should be 6-8 quarts, check for leaks, check pump, don't restart until problem fixed). Teaching points: Oil pressure is critical (must rise within 30 seconds, no pressure = shut down immediately), Don't continue without oil pressure (engine will be damaged, expensive repair, safety risk), Check oil pressure immediately after start (within 30 seconds, verify pressure normal), Recognize normal vs. abnormal (normal: 30-60 PSI, abnormal: 0 PSI or very low/high). Practice: Check oil pressure immediately after every start, Recognize normal pressure (30-60 PSI), Recognize abnormal pressure (0 PSI, very low, very high), Know when to shut down (no pressure within 30 seconds = shut down immediately). Teaching: Post-start checks are critical - oil pressure must be normal within 30 seconds, if not, shut down immediately. Don't continue without oil pressure - engine will be damaged.'

Present another scenario: 'Scenario: After engine start of a Piper PA-28-181, pilot checks post-start: Oil pressure 50 PSI within 20 seconds (normal), RPM stabilizes at 800 RPM (normal), Oil temperature 115°F and increasing (normal), Fuel pressure 25 PSI (normal for fuel-injected), Ammeter +12 amps (charging, normal). Engine running smoothly (RPM 800, engine sound smooth), all systems operational. After 2-minute warm-up: Oil pressure 50 PSI (stable, normal), Oil temperature 200°F (operating temperature, normal), RPM 800 (stable, normal), All instruments normal, All systems operational. How do these normal post-start checks indicate ready to taxi?'

Guide discussion: 'Normal post-start checks: Oil pressure: 50 PSI within 20 seconds (normal - within 30 seconds, within normal range 30-60 PSI, stable), RPM: 800 RPM (normal - stabilized at idle, smooth operation), Oil temperature: 200°F (normal - operating temperature, engine warmed up), Fuel pressure: 25 PSI (normal - within normal range for fuel-injected, stable), Ammeter: +12 amps (normal - charging, electrical system working). All systems: Electrical charging (13.5 volts, normal), Fuel flow normal (no leaks, adequate fuel), Controls free and correct, Avionics ready. Ready to taxi: Engine normal (running smoothly, all indications normal), Systems operational (all systems working, no problems), Clear to proceed (area clear, ready to taxi). Teaching point: Normal post-start checks indicate ready to taxi - oil pressure normal, RPM stable, instruments normal, systems operational. Always perform post-start checks - verify everything is normal before taxiing.'

Explain post-start checklist: 'Post-start checklist: Use checklist systematically. Typical checklist items: Oil pressure (must rise within 30 seconds, verify normal range), RPM (should stabilize at idle, verify smooth operation), Oil temperature (should be warming up, verify normal), Fuel pressure (should be normal, verify stable), Ammeter (should show charging, verify normal), Electrical system (charging, voltage normal), Fuel system (flow normal, no leaks), Controls (free and correct), Avionics (ready after warm-up). Use checklist - don't skip items, verify each item, ensure everything is normal before taxiing. The key: Post-start checks are critical - verify everything is normal before proceeding, if anything abnormal, shut down and troubleshoot.'

Emphasize teaching points: 'Key teaching points: Oil pressure: Must rise within 30 seconds (typically 30-60 PSI, check POH), Critical indicator - no pressure = shut down immediately, Don't continue without oil pressure (engine will be damaged). RPM: Should stabilize at idle (600-900 RPM, check POH), Smooth operation (RPM steady, no fluctuations), If rough or unstable, troubleshoot or shut down. Engine instruments: All should show normal indications (oil pressure, oil temperature, fuel pressure, RPM, ammeter), Monitor instruments - abnormal indications require attention. Systems: Electrical charging, fuel flow normal, controls free, avionics ready - all should be operational. Taxi readiness: Engine normal, systems operational, clear to proceed - don't taxi until ready. Post-start checks are critical - verify everything is normal before proceeding, if anything abnormal, shut down and troubleshoot immediately.'

instructorActions: Summarize key concepts comprehensively: 'Let's review what we've covered: Engine starting requires systematic procedures. Pre-start checks: Area clear (check 360 degrees around propeller, verify no people within 10 feet, no equipment, no obstacles, announce 'Clear!' loudly before starting), Controls set (flight controls free and correct, trim set for takeoff, parking brake SET critical - prevents movement, throttle idle 1/4 to 1/2 inch, mixture idle cutoff for carbureted or full rich for fuel-injected, propeller as required), Fuel checked (fuel selector on proper tank, fuel quantity adequate, fuel pump on if required, mixture correct for engine type), Electrical checked (master switch OFF before start critical - prevents load and voltage fluctuations, avionics OFF before start critical - prevents damage, lights as required, battery adequate). Starting procedures: Follow POH exactly (procedures vary by aircraft type), Carbureted engine (mixture idle cutoff before start, throttle cracked, starter engage, when engine fires move mixture to rich immediately within 1-2 seconds, monitor engine, adjust throttle), Fuel-injected engine (fuel pump ON before start, mixture full rich before start, throttle cracked, starter engage, monitor engine, adjust throttle), Monitoring (watch oil pressure should rise, RPM should stabilize, engine instruments normal, engine sound smooth). Hot start procedures: Recognize hot engine (engine shut down less than 15-30 minutes ago, engine temperature high 200°F+), Hot start procedure (clear fuel first - crank with throttle full open, mixture cutoff, then start normally - mixture rich, throttle cracked, starter engage). Engine fire procedures: Recognize fire (fire visible, smoke, fuel smell), Continue cranking first (5-10 seconds, often extinguishes fire - critical step), Then shut down (mixture cutoff, throttle full, master off), Then evacuate if needed (if fire persists after 10-15 seconds, evacuate immediately). Post-start checks: Oil pressure (must rise within 30 seconds, typically 30-60 PSI, if no pressure shut down immediately), RPM (should stabilize at idle 600-900 RPM, smooth operation), Engine instruments (oil pressure, oil temperature, fuel pressure, RPM, ammeter - all normal), Systems (electrical charging, fuel flow normal, controls free, avionics ready), Taxi readiness (engine normal, systems operational, clear to proceed). All procedures work together - pre-start checks ensure safe start, starting procedures ensure proper start, hot start procedures handle hot engines, fire procedures handle emergencies, post-start checks verify normal operation.'

Ask synthesis question: 'Now let's integrate everything. How do pre-start checks, starting procedures, hot start procedures, engine fire procedures, and post-start checks work together? Give me one complete example: A pilot is starting a Cessna 172N (carbureted engine) on a warm day. Describe the complete engine start from pre-start checks through post-start checks. Include specific details: What pre-start checks are performed? What starting procedure is used? How is the engine monitored? What post-start checks are performed? What are the normal indications? What would cause you to shut down?'

Listen actively to student response, taking notes: 'I'm listening carefully to your engine start example. I'm noting how you're integrating all the procedures. Let me check: Are you covering pre-start checks? Starting procedures? Monitoring? Post-start checks? Are you using specific numbers and conditions? Are you identifying when to shut down?'

Provide specific feedback: 'Excellent work! You're integrating all the engine starting knowledge effectively. I particularly liked how you: [specific positive feedback]. One thing to consider: [specific constructive feedback]. That's exactly how effective engine starting works - all procedures considered together systematically. Your ability to perform pre-start checks, start engine correctly, handle hot starts, respond to fires, and perform post-start checks demonstrates strong understanding of engine starting.'

Review objectives systematically: 'Let's check your mastery against our objectives: Can you perform pre-start checks including area clear, controls set, fuel checked, and electrical checked? [Check student response]. Can you start the engine correctly following POH procedures for both carbureted and fuel-injected engines? [Check student response]. Can you handle hot starts correctly including recognizing hot engine conditions and using hot start procedure? [Check student response]. Can you respond to engine fires immediately including continuing cranking first, then shutting down, then evacuating if needed? [Check student response]. Can you perform post-start checks including oil pressure, RPM, engine instruments, systems, and taxi readiness? [Check student response]. Can you teach engine starting to students effectively? [Check student response]. If yes to all, you've mastered this lesson. If any need work, let's address those now.'

Assign comprehensive homework: 'Your homework assignments: 1) Review POH for specific engine starting procedures for your aircraft type. Study pre-start checks, starting procedures, hot start procedures, engine fire procedures, and post-start checks. Note specific procedures, pressures, RPMs, and temperatures for your aircraft. 2) Study hot start procedures. Practice recognizing hot engine conditions (engine shut down recently, engine temperature high). Practice hot start procedure (clear fuel first, then start normally). 3) Review engine fire procedures. Study fire recognition (fire visible, smoke, fuel smell), fire procedures (continue cranking first, then shut down, then evacuate if needed), and fire prevention (don't over-prime, check for leaks, use proper procedures). 4) Practice post-start checks. In your next engine start, practice checking oil pressure (must rise within 30 seconds), RPM (should stabilize at idle), engine instruments (all normal), systems (all operational). Journal your post-start checks: What were the indications? Were they normal? What would cause you to shut down? 5) Practice engine starting procedures. In your next flight, practice complete engine start: Pre-start checks (area clear, controls set, fuel checked, electrical off), Starting procedure (follow POH, monitor engine), Post-start checks (oil pressure, RPM, instruments, systems). Journal your experience: What procedures did you follow? What were the indications? Were there any problems? 6) Journal assignment: Write one complete example (2-3 pages) of how you would teach engine starting to a student. Include: How you would teach pre-start checks, How you would teach starting procedures (carbureted and fuel-injected), How you would teach hot start procedures, How you would teach engine fire procedures, How you would teach post-start checks, One specific scenario with numbers and conditions (actual engine start with specific pressures, RPMs, temperatures) that you would use in teaching, including complete engine start analysis. This journal entry should demonstrate your ability to teach engine starting effectively.'

Emphasize practical application: 'Remember: Engine starting is practical knowledge you'll use on every flight. On every flight, you must: Perform pre-start checks (area clear, controls set, fuel checked, electrical off), Start engine correctly (follow POH, monitor engine, handle hot starts if needed), Respond to fires if they occur (continue cranking first, then shut down, then evacuate if needed), Perform post-start checks (oil pressure, RPM, instruments, systems). As a CFI, you'll constantly be teaching and using engine starting procedures. Understanding engine starting enables safe engine operations and effective instruction. Always follow POH procedures, perform pre-start and post-start checks, know hot start and fire procedures.'

Close with encouragement: 'Engine starting is fundamental to flight operations. Master these procedures, and you can start engines safely and teach effectively. Always follow POH procedures, perform pre-start and post-start checks, know hot start and fire procedures. This knowledge is essential for safe engine operations and effective instruction. You've done excellent work today. Questions before we wrap up?'

lessonPlans.title: Normal Takeoff and Climb
objectives: Apply power smoothly and maintain directional control ±5° heading deviation
Rotate at proper speed ±5 knots of VX or VY as appropriate
Establish and maintain VY climb ±5 knots
Maintain runway centerline ±1/2 runway width
Demonstrate proper crosswind technique for wind conditions
references: FAA-H-8083-25 Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge
prerequisites: Student understands basic flight controls
Student can identify and explain VX, VY, and V speeds
Student has completed preflight and before takeoff checks
Weather is within student proficiency limits
lessonPlans.overview: The normal takeoff is the foundation of all takeoff procedures. This lesson covers the coordination of power application, elevator control, rudder inputs, and precise airspeed control. Crosswind techniques are integrated from the beginning, as purely calm wind conditions are rare. Students learn to sequence their attention between attitude, airspeed, and directional control while simultaneously teaching a student. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of takeoff procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering normal takeoff and climb - the foundation of all takeoff procedures. This is one of the most frequently performed maneuvers in aviation, and mastering it is essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Normal Takeoff and Climb'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: apply power smoothly and maintain directional control, rotate at proper speed, establish and maintain VY climb, maintain runway centerline, demonstrate proper crosswind technique, and teach normal takeoff to students.'
Ask opening question: 'Think about your own flight training. What happens during a takeoff? What controls do you use? What are you watching?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key elements of takeoff: power application, directional control, rotation, and climb. Let's explore these systematically, starting with the fundamentals.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 5, your POH for specific procedures and performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on normal takeoff procedures.'

Draw takeoff phases on whiteboard: 'Let me break down the takeoff into phases: Ground roll - from power application to rotation, Rotation - establishing climb attitude, Initial climb - from liftoff to VY, Climb to pattern altitude - maintaining VY. Each phase has specific techniques and standards.'

Explain VY importance: 'VY - best rate of climb speed. This is critical because it gives you the maximum altitude gain per minute. If there are obstacles, VY gets you over them fastest. For most trainers, VY is around 75-85 knots. Check your POH for the exact speed.'

Demonstrate with model airplane: 'Watch the control positions. During ground roll: Ailerons control wind drift (full aileron into wind initially), Rudder controls direction (right rudder to counteract left-turning tendencies), Elevator is neutral until rotation. Let me show you...'

Explain left-turning tendencies: 'Why do we need right rudder? Four forces: P-factor (propeller blade on right side has more angle of attack), Torque (engine rotation tries to roll left), Spiraling slipstream (prop wash hits left side of tail), Gyroscopic precession (prop acts like a gyro). All these make the airplane want to turn left - right rudder counteracts this.'
Show POH takeoff performance chart: 'Let's calculate takeoff distance together. We need: Weight, Temperature, Altitude, Wind. Here's how to use the chart...'

Discuss crosswind component: 'If wind is 270° at 12 knots and runway is 240°, what's the crosswind? Use the crosswind component chart or mental math: 30° difference, so about 6 knots crosswind. This is manageable, but we'll need proper technique.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Inadequate right rudder (airplane veers left), Premature rotation (prolonged ground roll), Delayed rotation (tire/prop damage risk), Poor airspeed control (not maintaining VY), Drifting off centerline. We'll address each of these during practice.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to every student. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe takeoff operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

instructorActions: Pre-takeoff briefing: 'Before we take off, let me walk you through what I'll be doing. I'll clear the area thoroughly, align with centerline, apply full power smoothly, maintain directional control with right rudder, rotate at proper speed, establish VY climb, and maintain centerline throughout. Watch my control inputs and listen to my narration.'
Clear area thoroughly: 'Clearing the area... checking final approach... checking base leg... checking departure path... area is clear.'
Align with centerline: 'Aligning with runway centerline... checking alignment with runway edge lights... centered.'
Apply power smoothly: 'Applying full power smoothly... monitoring engine instruments... oil pressure normal, temperature normal, RPM normal... accelerating.'
Call out airspeed alive: 'Airspeed is alive... applying right rudder to counteract left-turning tendencies... feel that pressure? That's what you need to maintain.'
Maintain directional control: 'Maintaining centerline with rudder... ailerons neutral for now... watching for any drift... staying centered.'
At rotation speed: 'Approaching rotation speed... 65 knots... 67 knots... rotating to climb attitude... feel for liftoff... there we go, we're flying!'
After liftoff: 'Positive rate of climb established... maintaining runway heading... accelerating to VY... 70 knots... 75 knots...'
At VY: 'VY is 79 knots... pitching to maintain 79 knots... trimming for hands-off flight... maintaining VY ±5 knots... continuing climb to pattern altitude.'

Complete after-takeoff checklist: 'Now I'll complete the after-takeoff checklist while maintaining VY: Flaps up (if extended), Mixture set, Fuel pump off (if used), Landing light on, Transponder to altitude. All while maintaining 79 knots and centerline.'

Explain technique: 'Notice how I kept my eyes outside most of the time - brief instrument scans only. The runway edge lights and centerline kept me aligned. I used trim to reduce control pressure, which makes airspeed control much easier.'

teachingScript.phase: Guided Practice - Student First Attempt (10 minutes)
instructorActions: Encourage: 'Your airplane. You've got this. I'll be right here if you need help, but I want you to try it. Line up with centerline... take your time... when you're ready, apply full power smoothly.'
If student forgets rudder: Gently apply right rudder and say 'Feel that pressure? That's what you need. As we accelerate, you'll need more right rudder. Try it now - add a bit more.'
Prompt for rotation: 'Airspeed is approaching rotation speed... 60 knots... 63 knots... start thinking about rotation... 65 knots... ease back on the yoke... smooth, continuous pull...'
If student rotates too early: 'That was a bit early - we rotated at 60 knots but should wait until 67. Notice how we had a longer ground roll? Let's try again and wait for the proper speed.'
If student rotates too late: 'That was a bit late - we were at 72 knots. The risk is tire or prop damage if we wait too long. Next time, start the rotation at 65 knots.'
During climb: 'Check your airspeed... what do you notice? We're at 85 knots, but VY is 79. What do you need to do?'
Guide airspeed correction: 'Right - we need to pitch up slightly to slow down. Ease back a bit... there, 80 knots... a bit more... perfect, 79 knots. Now trim to hold that speed.'
Provide positive feedback: 'Excellent! That rotation was smooth, and you maintained centerline well. The airspeed control is getting better - you're learning to feel the airplane.'
Address errors constructively: 'I noticed you drifted left a bit during the ground roll. That's the left-turning tendency. Next time, anticipate it and add more right rudder as we accelerate.'

instructorActions: Brief before takeoff: 'Wind is 270° at 12 knots and runway is 240°, so we have about 6 knots of crosswind from the right. Here's my plan: Full aileron into the wind (right aileron) before starting roll, reduce aileron as speed increases, maintain centerline with rudder, establish crab angle immediately after liftoff, maintain runway heading with coordinated flight.'
During lineup: 'I'm putting in full right aileron now, before we start rolling. This prevents the wind from lifting the upwind wing. Watch how I hold this position...'

Takeoff roll: 'Applying full power... maintaining right aileron... as speed increases, I'll reduce aileron deflection... 30 knots, reducing aileron... 40 knots, less aileron... 50 knots, aileron almost neutral... maintaining centerline with rudder.'

Liftoff: 'Rotating... establishing crab angle immediately... see how I'm headed into the wind? The nose is pointing right of the runway heading, but we're tracking straight down the extended centerline.'
Climb: 'Maintaining runway heading with coordinated flight... aileron neutral now... using rudder to maintain heading... this is the crab technique - we accept the crab angle and maintain our track.'

Explain technique: 'The key is accepting the crab, not fighting it. Many students try to keep the nose straight, which causes drift. Instead, we crab into the wind and maintain our track over the ground. This is more efficient and safer.'
Common mistake: 'A common mistake is fighting the wind instead of accepting the crab. If you try to keep the nose straight with aileron, you'll drift. The crab technique is the correct approach.'

Fixating on instruments - not maintaining outside reference - This affects safety and performance
Insufficient power application - poor acceleration - This leads to unsafe operations and poor learning outcomes
Poor trim usage - excessive control pressure - This leads to unsafe operations and poor learning outcomes
Inadequate clearing turns - collision hazard - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness

diagrams.title: Normal Takeoff Phases
diagrams.description: Visual representation of the four phases of normal takeoff: Ground roll, Rotation, Initial climb, and Climb to pattern altitude. Shows control positions, airspeeds, and key transition points. Essential for understanding takeoff sequence and timing.
keyPoints: Ground Roll: Power application to rotation, maintain centerline with rudder, ailerons control wind drift
Rotation: Establish climb attitude at proper speed (typically 60-70 knots), smooth continuous pull
Initial Climb: From liftoff to VY, accelerate to best rate of climb speed, maintain centerline
Climb to Pattern Altitude: Maintain VY ±5 knots, complete after-takeoff checklist, continue to pattern altitude

diagrams.title: Crosswind Takeoff Technique
diagrams.description: Illustration of crosswind takeoff technique showing aileron position on ground, transition during acceleration, and crab angle after liftoff. Demonstrates how to maintain runway centerline in crosswind conditions.
diagrams.asciiArt:
CROSSWIND TAKEOFF

GROUND ROLL:
  Wind from right → Full right aileron
  Maintain centerline with rudder
  Reduce aileron as speed increases

LIFTOFF:
  Establish crab angle immediately
  Nose points into wind
  Track maintains centerline

CLIMB:
  Aileron neutral
  Maintain crab with rudder
  Track = Centerline, Heading ≠ Track
keyPoints: Full aileron into wind before starting roll
Reduce aileron deflection as speed increases
Establish crab angle immediately after liftoff
Maintain runway heading with coordinated flight
Accept the crab - don't fight the wind

diagrams.title: Left-Turning Tendencies
diagrams.description: Diagram showing the four forces that cause left-turning tendencies during takeoff: P-factor, torque, spiraling slipstream, and gyroscopic precession. Essential for understanding why right rudder is required.
keyPoints: P-Factor: Propeller blade on right side has more angle of attack, creates more thrust
Torque: Engine rotation tries to roll airplane left
Spiraling Slipstream: Prop wash hits left side of vertical stabilizer
Gyroscopic Precession: Propeller acts like a gyro, reacts to pitch changes
All four forces require right rudder to counteract

interactiveElements.title: Takeoff Technique Scenario
interactiveElements.description: Interactive scenario for practicing takeoff technique and decision-making

scenarios.situation: You're taking off on runway 27. Wind is 270° at 15 knots. During takeoff roll, the airplane starts drifting to the left side of the runway. What should you do?
options: Apply more right rudder to maintain centerline
Abort the takeoff immediately
Apply left aileron to correct drift
Reduce power and correct
scenarios.correct: Apply more right rudder to maintain centerline
scenarios.explanation: Left drift during takeoff roll is typically caused by inadequate right rudder to counteract left-turning tendencies (P-factor, torque, spiraling slipstream, gyroscopic precession). Apply more right rudder to maintain centerline. Only abort if you lose directional control or if an obstacle appears. Ailerons are for crosswind correction, not for directional control on the ground.

scenarios.situation: You're taking off on a hot day (95°F) at a high-elevation airport (5,000 feet MSL). Your aircraft is at maximum gross weight. As you apply power, acceleration seems slow. At what point should you consider aborting the takeoff?
options: If not at rotation speed by 50% of available runway
If acceleration is slow, continue as long as runway remains
Abort immediately if acceleration seems slow
Continue as long as runway is visible ahead
scenarios.correct: If not at rotation speed by 50% of available runway
scenarios.explanation: Hot temperatures and high elevation reduce engine power and increase density altitude, requiring longer takeoff distances. If you haven't reached rotation speed by 50% of the available runway, consider aborting. Check POH takeoff performance charts for your weight, temperature, and altitude to determine expected takeoff distance. If actual performance doesn't match expected performance by mid-point, abort while sufficient runway remains for safe stop.

lessonPlans.title: Normal Approach and Landing
objectives: Maintain stabilized approach ±5 knots airspeed, ±100 feet altitude
Touch down in touchdown zone (first 1/3 of runway)
Maintain runway centerline ±1/2 runway width
Demonstrate proper crosswind technique for wind conditions
Execute go-around if necessary before touchdown
references: FAA-H-8083-25 Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge
prerequisites: Student understands traffic pattern procedures
Student can maintain altitude and airspeed in level flight
Student has completed normal takeoff training
Weather within student capability
lessonPlans.overview: The normal approach and landing is the most frequently performed maneuver in aviation. This lesson covers the stabilized approach concept, energy management, wind correction, flare technique, and touchdown execution. Students learn to coordinate throttle, pitch, and trim while managing crosswind conditions and teaching simultaneously. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of landing procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering normal approach and landing - the most frequently performed maneuver in aviation. Every flight ends with a landing, so mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Normal Approach and Landing'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: maintain a stabilized approach, touch down in the touchdown zone, maintain runway centerline, demonstrate proper crosswind technique, execute go-arounds when necessary, and teach normal landing to students.'
Ask opening question: 'Think about your own flight training. What makes a good landing? What do you watch during the approach? What happens during the flare?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key elements of landing: stabilized approach, energy management, flare technique, and touchdown. Let's explore these systematically, starting with the stabilized approach concept.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 9, your POH for specific procedures and performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on normal landing procedures.'

Draw approach profile on whiteboard: 'Let me break down the landing into phases: Downwind leg - abeam touchdown point, reduce power, first notch of flaps. Base leg - continue descent, second notch of flaps, turn to final. Final approach - establish stabilized approach, full flaps, maintain approach speed. Roundout - 10-20 feet AGL, reduce power to idle. Flare - gradual back pressure, hold off. Touchdown - main wheels first, maintain centerline.'

Explain stabilized approach: 'A stabilized approach is the key to consistent landings. By 500 feet AGL, you should be: On the correct airspeed (typically 1.3 Vso, about 65 knots for a Cessna 172), On the glidepath (aim point not moving in windscreen), Fully configured (flaps set, gear down if applicable), Aligned with runway centerline. If you're not stabilized by 500 feet, go around - don't try to salvage it.'

Explain approach speed: 'Approach speed is typically 1.3 times the stall speed in landing configuration. For a Cessna 172, Vso is about 50 knots, so approach speed is 65 knots. This gives you a 30% safety margin above stall. Check your POH for the exact speed.'

Demonstrate with model airplane: 'Watch the control inputs. On final: Pitch controls airspeed, power controls descent rate. If you're too fast, pitch up slightly. If you're too low, add power. If the aim point is rising in the windscreen, you're too low - add power. If it's falling, you're too high - reduce power.'
Show POH landing performance chart: 'Let's calculate landing distance together. We need: Weight, Temperature, Altitude, Wind, Runway condition. Here's how to use the chart...'

Explain energy management: 'Energy management is critical. Too much energy (fast/high) = floating and long landing. Too little energy (slow/low) = stall risk and hard landing. The stabilized approach manages energy properly - on speed, on glidepath.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Unstabilized approach (varying speeds and descent rates), High approach (difficulty landing in touchdown zone), Low approach (risk of undershooting), Fast approach (floating and long landing), Slow approach (stall risk), Poor flare technique (hard landing or bounce), Inadequate crosswind correction (drift off centerline), Delayed go-around decision (unsafe landing). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to every student. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe landing operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

Review landing checklist and verify understanding of each item
Identify crosswind correction method (crab vs wing-low)
Review traffic pattern procedures and entry points
Ask questions about technique and energy management
Practice control movements with model airplane
Identify stabilized approach criteria and visual references
Review go-around procedures and decision points
keyPoints: Stabilized by 500 feet AGL is the goal
Pitch controls airspeed, power controls descent rate
Aim point should not move in windscreen

instructorActions: Narrate throughout: 'Turning base... reducing power... flaps 20'
Turn final: 'Aligning with centerline... establishing approach speed... full flaps'
On final: 'Airspeed 65 knots... aiming for the numbers... slight power adjustment'
Over threshold: 'Power to idle... eyes to far end of runway... gradual back pressure'
Flare: 'Hold it off... hold it off... there's the touchdown'
Rollout: 'Maintain centerline with rudder... elevator back... braking as needed'
Guide systematically: 'Let me help you refine this further'

keyPoints: Smooth, coordinated control inputs - no abrupt movements
Eyes transition from aim point to far end during flare - this helps maintain proper pitch
Gradual power reduction prevents sink - don't pull power abruptly
Main wheels touch first in tricycle gear - nose wheel stays off until slow
Aim point steady in windscreen = on glidepath
Roundout begins 10-20 feet AGL, not at the runway

instructorActions: Encourage: 'Your airplane. You've got this. I'll be right here if you need help. Enter the pattern and set up for landing.'
On downwind: 'Abeam touchdown point... what's your first action? Right - reduce power and first notch of flaps. Good.'
Turn base: 'Turning base... continue descent... second notch of flaps... checking for traffic... good.'
Turn final: 'Turning final... align with centerline... establish approach speed... full flaps... what's your airspeed?'
If too fast: 'Check your airspeed... we're at 75 knots, but approach speed is 65. What do you need to do? Right - pitch up slightly to slow down. There, 70 knots... a bit more... perfect, 65 knots.'
If aim point rising: 'Notice the aim point is rising in the windscreen - that means we're too low. Add a touch of power... there, aim point is steady now.'
If not stabilized: 'We're at 400 feet and not stabilized - airspeed is varying, descent rate is inconsistent. What should we do? Right - go around. Let's try again.'
Over threshold: 'Over the threshold... power to idle... eyes to the far end of the runway... beginning roundout...'
During flare: 'Gradual back pressure... hold it off... feel the sink rate decreasing... there's the touchdown... good!'
After landing: 'Excellent! That was a smooth touchdown right in the touchdown zone. Your centerline control was spot on. What do you think went well?'
Address errors constructively: 'I noticed you flared a bit early on that one - we ballooned slightly. Next time, wait until you're closer to the runway before starting the roundout.'
Provide positive feedback: 'Your approach speeds are getting much more consistent. You're really learning to feel the airplane.'
studentActions: Perform complete pattern and landing with instructor backup and guidance
Self-announce at each point: 'Abeam touchdown point, reducing power', 'Turning base', 'Final checklist complete', 'Over threshold'
Maintain approach speed ±5 knots and stabilized approach

keyPoints: First landings often have late flare - normal, improves with practice
Bouncing requires immediate go-around decision - never try to salvage a bounce
Positive feedback builds confidence - celebrate small improvements
Each landing teaches something new - analyze what worked and what didn't
Stabilized approach = consistent landing - focus on getting stabilized first
Go-around is not failure - it's good judgment

instructorActions: Brief before landing: 'Wind is 270° at 12 knots and runway is 240°, so we have about 6 knots of crosswind from the right. We'll use the wing-low method for crosswind landing. Here's the technique: On final, we'll crab into the wind to maintain centerline. Just before touchdown, we'll transition to wing-low - upwind wing down, opposite rudder to maintain alignment. The upwind main wheel will touch first.'

Demonstrate on final: 'On final approach, I'm crabbing into the wind to maintain centerline. See how the nose is pointing right of the runway heading, but we're tracking straight down the centerline? That's the crab angle.'

Near touchdown: 'Now, just before touchdown, I'm transitioning to wing-low. Right aileron down (into the wind), left rudder to maintain alignment. This prevents drift and allows the upwind wheel to touch first.'
Touchdown: 'Upwind main wheel touches first... holding aileron into wind... maintaining centerline...'
Rollout: 'As we slow down, I need more aileron deflection to maintain control. Full aileron into wind now... maintaining centerline with rudder...'

Explain technique: 'The key is transitioning from crab to wing-low just before touchdown. If you try to land in a crab, you'll put side loads on the landing gear, which can cause damage. The wing-low method allows the upwind wheel to touch first, then the other wheels.'
Common mistake: 'A common mistake is trying to land in a crab. Never do that - always transition to wing-low before touchdown. The transition should be smooth and coordinated.'
studentActions: Observe crosswind corrections during demonstration carefully
Practice crab-to-wing-low transition with instructor guidance
Feel increased control pressures and aileron deflection needed
Maintain centerline alignment using crab angle on approach
Transition to wing-low method before touchdown
Apply upwind aileron and opposite rudder for coordination
Touch down on upwind main wheel first in crosswind
Maintain aileron deflection into wind during rollout
Understand the difference between crab and wing-low methods
keyPoints: Crab keeps you aligned with runway on approach - use it until just before touchdown
Wing-low prevents drift at touchdown - transition smoothly before touchdown
Never land in a crab - side loads damage gear and can cause ground loop
Full aileron deflection often needed at slow speeds - don't be afraid to use full deflection
Upwind wheel touches first - this is correct technique
Transition timing is critical - too early causes drift, too late causes side loads

instructorActions: Summarize key concepts: 'Let's review what we covered: Normal landing requires a stabilized approach by 500 feet AGL, maintaining approach speed (typically 1.3 Vso), proper flare technique beginning 10-20 feet AGL, and touchdown in the touchdown zone. Crosswind landings require crab on approach, transition to wing-low before touchdown, and upwind wheel touching first.'

Ask synthesis question: 'How do stabilized approach, energy management, flare technique, and crosswind correction all work together? Give me one example of a landing where all these elements came together perfectly.'
Listen to student response and provide feedback: 'Excellent - you're integrating all the landing knowledge. That's exactly how effective landings work - all elements coordinated together.'

Review objectives: 'Let's check our objectives: Can you maintain stabilized approach? Touch down in touchdown zone? Maintain centerline? Demonstrate crosswind technique? Execute go-around? Teach normal landing? If yes to all, you've mastered this lesson.'
Address specific performance: 'Your landings today showed real improvement. Your approach speeds got more consistent, and your flare timing is much better. The areas to focus on next time are...'
Ask reflection question: 'Which landing felt best? Why? What made it work?'
Address errors: 'On landing 3, what happened when you ballooned? Right - you flared too early. How can you prevent that next time?'
Relate to ACS: 'ACS standard is touchdown within 400 feet of specified point, which is the first third of the runway. You're meeting that standard consistently now.'

Assign homework: 'Review Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 9. Chair fly the landing procedure - visualize and verbalize each step. Calculate landing distance for different conditions using your POH. Watch cockpit videos of normal landings and critique the technique. Journal one example of how you would teach normal landing to a student.'
Preview next lesson: 'Next time, we'll work on short-field landings, which require more precision and energy management.'

Close: 'Normal landing is the foundation of all landing procedures. Master this, and the other landing variations will be easier. Always aim for a stabilized approach, proper flare, and touchdown in the touchdown zone. Questions before we wrap up?'

Every landing teaches pattern recognition - analyze what worked and what didn't

diagrams.title: Traffic Pattern and Approach Profile

diagrams.title: Stabilized Approach Criteria
diagrams.description: Illustration showing the four elements of a stabilized approach: airspeed, glidepath, configuration, and alignment. Demonstrates what constitutes a stabilized approach and when to execute go-around.
diagrams.asciiArt:
STABILIZED APPROACH CRITERIA

By 500 feet AGL:

1. AIRSPEED: On approach speed (1.3 Vso)
   ±5 knots tolerance

2. GLIDEPATH: Aim point steady in windscreen
   On PAPI/VASI if available

3. CONFIGURATION: Flaps set, gear down
   Landing checklist complete

4. ALIGNMENT: On runway centerline
   ±1/2 runway width tolerance

If not stabilized → GO AROUND
keyPoints: All four criteria must be met by 500 feet AGL
If any criterion is not met, execute go-around
Aim point steady in windscreen = on glidepath
Approach speed is typically 1.3 Vso - check POH

diagrams.title: Flare and Touchdown Sequence
diagrams.description: Diagram showing the three phases of landing: roundout, hold-off, and touchdown. Illustrates proper flare technique, sight picture transition, and touchdown attitude.
keyPoints: Roundout: Begins 10-20 feet AGL, reduce power to idle, begin back pressure
Hold-off: Gradual back pressure, eyes to far end of runway, feel sink rate decrease
Touchdown: Main wheels first, maintain centerline, elevator back to keep nose wheel off
Sight picture transitions from aim point to far end of runway during flare

diagrams.title: Crosswind Landing Technique
diagrams.description: Illustration of crosswind landing technique showing crab angle on approach and transition to wing-low method before touchdown. Demonstrates proper crosswind correction throughout landing.
diagrams.asciiArt:
CROSSWIND LANDING

APPROACH:
  Crab into wind
  Maintain centerline
  Nose points into wind

BEFORE TOUCHDOWN:
  Transition to wing-low
  Upwind wing down
  Opposite rudder

TOUCHDOWN:
  Upwind main wheel first
  Hold aileron into wind
  Maintain centerline

ROLLOUT:
  Increase aileron deflection
  Full aileron at slow speeds
  Never land in a crab!
keyPoints: Crab on approach to maintain centerline
Transition to wing-low just before touchdown
Upwind wheel touches first - correct technique
Never land in a crab - side loads damage gear
Full aileron deflection often needed at slow speeds

scenarios.situation: You're on final approach. At 400 feet AGL, you're 10 knots fast and high above the glidepath. The aim point is moving down in the windscreen. What should you do?

scenarios.correct: Execute go-around - not stabilized by 500 feet AGL
scenarios.explanation: A stabilized approach should be established by 500 feet AGL. If you're not stabilized (on speed, on glidepath, fully configured, aligned with centerline) by 500 feet, execute a go-around. Transition to wing-low at 100 feet AGL
Use wing-low from the beginning of final approach

Just before touchdown (about 10-20 feet AGL), transition to wing-low technique: upwind wing down with opposite rudder to maintain centerline. Never land in a crab - the side loads can damage landing gear. The wing-low method keeps the aircraft aligned with the runway at touchdown.
