lessonPlans.overview: Rough water landing in a seaplane requires careful assessment of water conditions and proper technique to protect the floats from damage. Rough water is characterized by choppy conditions with waves 1-3 feet high, wind 10-20 knots, and a disturbed surface. The technique involves maintaining a stabilized approach in rough conditions, touching down at minimum controllable airspeed with proper technique, and protecting the floats from damage during landing. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of rough water landing procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering rough water landing in a seaplane - essential for operations in choppy conditions. Rough water can stress the floats and make approach and landing difficult. This technique requires careful assessment and proper technique to protect the aircraft. Mastering this is essential for safe operations in rough conditions and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Rough Water Landing (ASES)'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: assess rough water conditions and associated hazards, demonstrate rough water landing technique to minimize float stress, maintain stabilized approach in rough conditions, touch down at minimum controllable airspeed with proper technique, protect floats from damage during landing, and teach rough water landing to students.'
Ask opening question: 'What makes rough water landing different from normal seaplane landing? What happens to the floats when landing in rough water? How would you protect the floats during landing?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenges: rough water creates stress on floats during landing, makes approach control difficult, and requires different technique. Let's explore rough water landing systematically, starting with recognizing rough water conditions.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Seaplane Operations Handbook Chapter 13, your POH for specific seaplane procedures, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on rough water landing procedures.'

Explain rough water conditions: 'Rough water is characterized by choppy conditions with waves, wind, and disturbed surface. Typical conditions: Wave height 1-3 feet (waves are visible and significant, creates stress on floats), Wind 10-20 knots (creates waves and makes control difficult), Choppy surface (water is disturbed, not smooth, creates drag and stress). This creates several hazards: First, float stress (waves hit floats during landing, creates stress, can damage floats, can cause structural damage). Second, approach control difficulty (rough water makes approach control difficult, requires more power, harder to maintain stabilized approach). Third, touchdown stress (rough water creates stress on floats at touchdown, can damage floats, requires proper technique). Fourth, directional control difficulty (rough water makes directional control difficult after touchdown, water rudder less effective, ailerons needed for control).'

Draw rough water landing scenario on whiteboard: 'Let me draw a rough water landing scenario. Here's the choppy water with waves 1-3 feet high. Here's the wind direction creating the waves. Here's our approach path. The goal is to maintain stabilized approach, touch down at minimum controllable airspeed with proper technique, and protect the floats from damage.'

Explain the technique: 'Rough water landing technique: First, assess water conditions (wave height, wind speed, wave pattern, determine if conditions are acceptable). Second, enter pattern normally (pattern altitude 1,000 feet AGL). Third, on final approach: Maintain stabilized approach (approach speed 60-65 knots typical, use power to control descent rate, maintain ±5 knots airspeed, ±100 feet altitude), Maintain directional control (use ailerons to assist, anticipate wave effects, maintain heading). Fourth, during roundout: Begin at 20-30 feet AGL, reduce power gradually, maintain approach speed. Fifth, at touchdown: Touch down at minimum controllable airspeed (50-55 knots), Touch down on top of a wave if possible (reduces impact, protects floats), Extend water rudder immediately, Maintain directional control. The key: Maintain stabilized approach, touch down at minimum controllable airspeed with proper technique, protect floats from stress.'

Explain approach technique: 'Approach technique is critical. Maintain stabilized approach: Approach speed 60-65 knots typical (slightly faster than normal for better control), Use power to control descent rate (maintain 200-300 fpm descent), Maintain ±5 knots airspeed (consistent airspeed control), Maintain ±100 feet altitude (consistent altitude control). Use ailerons to assist: Rough water makes control difficult, ailerons help maintain heading, compensate for wave effects. Anticipate wave effects: Waves can affect approach, anticipate and correct early, maintain stabilized approach. The goal: Stabilized approach despite rough water conditions.'

Explain touchdown technique: 'Touchdown technique is critical. Touch down at minimum controllable airspeed (50-55 knots typical, slower than normal touchdown, reduces impact). Touch down on top of a wave if possible (reduces impact on floats, protects floats, smoother touchdown). Extend water rudder immediately (for directional control after touchdown, essential in rough water). Maintain directional control (use water rudder and ailerons, anticipate wave effects, maintain heading). The goal: Smooth touchdown at minimum controllable airspeed, protect floats from stress, maintain directional control.'

Explain float protection: 'Float protection is critical. Rough water creates stress on floats when waves hit them during landing. To protect floats: Touch down at minimum controllable airspeed (reduces impact, protects floats), Touch down on top of a wave if possible (reduces impact, smoother touchdown), Use proper technique (smooth control inputs, avoid abrupt movements, reduce stress), Maintain directional control (prevents side loads on floats, reduces stress). The goal: Minimize float stress during landing.'

Explain directional control: 'Directional control is more difficult in rough water. Water rudder: Primary control for direction after touchdown, less effective in rough water, may need assistance. Ailerons: Assist with directional control, help maintain heading, compensate for wave effects. Anticipate wave effects: Waves can push aircraft off course after touchdown, anticipate and correct early, maintain heading. The technique: Use water rudder for primary control, use ailerons to assist, anticipate wave effects and correct early.'

Demonstrate with model seaplane: 'Watch the sequence. Pattern entry: Enter at pattern altitude (1,000 feet AGL). On final: Maintain stabilized approach (60-65 knots), use power to control descent rate, use ailerons to assist with control. During roundout: Begin at 20-30 feet AGL, reduce power gradually, maintain approach speed. At touchdown: Touch down at minimum controllable airspeed (52 knots), on top of a wave if possible, extend water rudder immediately, maintain directional control. After touchdown: Maintain directional control with water rudder and ailerons. Let me show you...'

Show POH rough water procedures: 'Let's check your POH for rough water landing procedures. Some seaplanes have specific rough water techniques - check your POH. The POH will specify approach speeds, minimum controllable airspeed, and procedures for rough water conditions.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Inadequate water assessment (missed hazards, conditions too rough, float damage risk), Unstabilized approach (inconsistent airspeed or altitude, poor touchdown, float stress), Normal touchdown speed (too fast, excessive impact, float damage), Not touching down on wave top (hitting trough, excessive impact, float damage), Poor directional control (not using ailerons, drift off course, side loads on floats), Water rudder not extended (poor directional control after touchdown, drift off course). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students who may encounter rough water conditions. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe rough water operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

instructorActions: Encourage: 'Your airplane. You've got this. I'll be right here if you need help, but I want you to try it. First, assess the rough water conditions - what do you see? Wave height? Wind speed? Is it acceptable for landing?'

Guide assessment: 'Good - you identified the waves are about 2 feet high, wind is 15 knots, water is choppy. These are rough water conditions. We'll need to maintain stabilized approach and touch down at minimum controllable airspeed to protect the floats. Ready to proceed?'
Guide pattern entry: 'Enter the pattern at 1,000 feet... abeam touchdown point... reduce power slightly... first notch of flaps... good. Now turn base when ready.'
Turn base: 'Turning base... continue descent... second notch of flaps... maintaining approach speed... 62 knots... good. Turn to final when ready.'
On final: 'Turning final... establish rough water approach... maintain approach speed 60-65 knots... 63 knots... full flaps... use power to control descent rate... what's your VSI showing?'
If descent rate too high: 'Check your VSI - we're showing 400 fpm descent, but we want 200-300 fpm. What do you need to do? Right - add a touch of power. There, 250 fpm... perfect.'
If not stabilized: 'We're at 400 feet and not stabilized - airspeed is varying, descent rate is inconsistent. What should we do? Right - go around. Let's try again.'
During approach: 'Maintaining stabilized approach... 63 knots... VSI showing 250 fpm... use ailerons to assist with control if needed... maintaining heading... good.'
Beginning roundout: 'Approaching roundout altitude... altimeter showing 25 feet AGL... begin roundout... reduce power gradually... maintain approach speed... maintain heading...'

At touchdown: 'Over touchdown zone... look for wave top... reducing power... 55 knots... 52 knots... minimum controllable airspeed... touching down... extend water rudder immediately... maintain directional control... excellent!'

Provide positive feedback: 'Excellent! You assessed the rough water conditions well, maintained stabilized approach despite rough water, and touched down at minimum controllable airspeed. The float protection technique was good - you touched down on a wave top. You're really getting the feel for this.'

Address errors constructively: 'I noticed you touched down at approach speed instead of minimum controllable airspeed - in rough water, we touch down at minimum controllable airspeed (50-55 knots) to reduce impact and protect the floats. Next time, slow to minimum controllable airspeed before touchdown.'

interactiveElements.title: Rough Water Landing Scenario
interactiveElements.description: Interactive scenario for practicing rough water landing decision-making

scenarios.situation: You're on final approach for a seaplane landing. The water is choppy with waves about 2.5 feet high. Wind is 18 knots. Your approach speed is 63 knots and you're maintaining a stabilized approach. At 100 feet AGL, you notice your airspeed has increased to 70 knots due to wind gusts. What should you do?
options: Continue the approach - the airspeed will decrease naturally
Go around - the approach is no longer stabilized
Reduce power to slow down - this will fix the airspeed
Touch down at the higher speed - it's still acceptable
scenarios.correct: Go around - the approach is no longer stabilized
scenarios.explanation: In rough water, maintaining a stabilized approach is critical for safe landing and float protection. The ACS requires ±5 knots airspeed tolerance. At 100 feet AGL with airspeed at 70 knots (7 knots above the 63 knot target), the approach is no longer stabilized. Continuing the approach risks poor touchdown, excessive float stress, and potential damage. The correct action is to execute a go-around, re-enter the pattern, and establish a new stabilized approach.

lessonPlans.overview: The forward slip to a landing is a technique used to increase descent rate without increasing airspeed. This is useful when the approach is too high, when obstacles require a steeper descent angle, or when you need to lose altitude rapidly. The technique involves using opposite aileron and rudder to create drag, increasing descent rate to 500-800 fpm (compared to normal 300-400 fpm), then recovering from the slip before touchdown. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of forward slip procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

Ask opening question: 'Think about a situation where you're on final approach and realize you're too high. What options do you have? How could you increase your descent rate without increasing airspeed?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: we need to lose altitude quickly, but we can't increase airspeed (that would cause floating and long landing). The forward slip solves this by creating drag without increasing airspeed. Let's explore forward slip systematically, starting with when to use it.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 9, your POH for specific procedures, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on forward slip procedures.'

Explain when to use forward slip: 'Forward slip is used when: First, approach is too high (aim point falling in windscreen, too much altitude, need to lose altitude quickly). Second, obstacles require steeper descent (trees, power lines, buildings ahead, need steeper approach angle). Third, need increased descent rate (normal descent rate 300-400 fpm insufficient, need 500-800 fpm). The forward slip increases descent rate to 500-800 fpm (compared to normal 300-400 fpm) without increasing airspeed. This allows you to correct a high approach or clear obstacles while maintaining proper approach speed.'

Draw forward slip diagram on whiteboard: 'Let me draw a forward slip. Here's the airplane in normal approach. Here's the airplane in forward slip: Left aileron down (bank left), Right rudder (yaw right), Opposite controls create drag. The increased drag increases descent rate from 300-400 fpm to 500-800 fpm, but airspeed remains the same (approach speed 65 knots).'

Explain the technique: 'Forward slip technique: First, recognize need for slip (approach too high, obstacles ahead, need increased descent rate). Second, enter slip smoothly (apply aileron in direction of desired bank - typically 20-30° bank, apply opposite rudder to maintain runway alignment - rudder opposite aileron, maintain approach speed 65 knots). Third, maintain slip (keep aileron and rudder deflected, maintain approach speed, maintain runway alignment, monitor descent rate 500-800 fpm). Fourth, recover from slip (at 50-100 feet AGL, neutralize aileron and rudder simultaneously, return to normal approach attitude, continue normal landing). The key: Opposite aileron and rudder create drag, increasing descent rate without increasing airspeed.'

Explain control inputs: 'Control inputs are critical. Aileron: Bank airplane in desired direction (typically 20-30° bank, creates drag, increases descent rate). Rudder: Opposite to aileron (maintains runway alignment, prevents turn, creates additional drag). The combination: Left aileron down + right rudder = slip to the left (aircraft banks left but tracks straight), Right aileron down + left rudder = slip to the right (aircraft banks right but tracks straight). The key: Aileron banks the airplane, rudder keeps it aligned with runway - opposite controls create drag.'

Explain descent rate: 'Descent rate increases significantly. Normal approach: Descent rate 300-400 fpm (typical for normal approach, 3° glidepath). Forward slip: Descent rate 500-800 fpm (increased drag creates steeper descent, 2-3 times normal descent rate). The increased descent rate allows you to lose altitude quickly without increasing airspeed. Monitor VSI during slip - should show 500-800 fpm descent rate.'

Explain recovery: 'Recovery is critical. Recover at appropriate altitude: 50-100 feet AGL (sufficient altitude for normal landing, allows time to stabilize, prevents low recovery). Recovery technique: Neutralize aileron and rudder simultaneously (both controls neutral at same time, prevents yaw or roll), Return to normal approach attitude (wings level, nose on horizon), Continue normal landing (normal flare, normal touchdown). The key: Recover early enough (50-100 feet AGL) to allow normal landing, recover smoothly (neutralize controls simultaneously).'

Explain directional control: 'Directional control is maintained with rudder. During slip: Rudder maintains runway alignment (prevents turn, keeps aircraft tracking straight), Rudder opposite to aileron (left aileron = right rudder, right aileron = left rudder). The ball: Ball will be deflected (not centered, indicates slip), This is normal (slip creates uncoordinated flight, ball deflection expected). The key: Use rudder to maintain runway alignment, don't let aircraft turn during slip.'

Demonstrate with model airplane: 'Watch the sequence. Normal approach: Wings level, nose on horizon, approach speed 65 knots, descent rate 350 fpm. Enter slip: Left aileron down (bank left 25°), Right rudder (maintain alignment), Maintain approach speed 65 knots. During slip: Maintain aileron and rudder, Descent rate increases to 600 fpm, Runway alignment maintained. Recover: At 75 feet AGL, neutralize aileron and rudder simultaneously, Return to normal approach, Continue normal landing. Let me show you...'

Show POH slip procedures: 'Let's check your POH for forward slip procedures. Some aircraft have specific slip limitations - check your POH. The POH will specify maximum bank angles, airspeed limits, and procedures for forward slips.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not recognizing need for slip (continuing high approach, missing touchdown zone, obstacle clearance risk), Using same-side aileron and rudder (aircraft turns, loses alignment, doesn't create proper slip), Not maintaining approach speed (airspeed increases, defeats purpose, causes floating), Recovering too low (below 50 feet AGL, insufficient altitude for normal landing, risk of hard landing), Recovering too high (above 100 feet AGL, slip not effective, still too high), Not neutralizing controls simultaneously (yaw or roll during recovery, poor landing). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students who may encounter high approaches or obstacles. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe slip operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

instructorActions: Pre-landing briefing: 'Before we land, let me walk you through what I'll be doing. I'll enter the pattern normally, establish a normal approach, then demonstrate a forward slip when I'm too high. I'll use opposite aileron and rudder to increase descent rate, maintain runway alignment, recover at 75 feet AGL, and complete a normal landing. Watch my control inputs and listen to my narration.'
Enter pattern: 'Entering downwind at pattern altitude... 1,000 feet AGL... abeam touchdown point... reducing power slightly... first notch of flaps... maintaining pattern altitude.'
Turn base: 'Turning base... continuing descent... second notch of flaps... maintaining approach speed... 65 knots... turning to final.'
On final - normal approach: 'Turning final... establishing approach speed... 65 knots... full flaps... aim point steady in windscreen... normal approach established.'
Recognize high approach: 'I notice the aim point is falling in the windscreen - that means I'm too high. I'm at 400 feet AGL and should be lower. I'll use a forward slip to increase my descent rate.'

Enter slip: 'Entering forward slip... left aileron down (banking left 25°)... right rudder (maintaining runway alignment)... maintaining approach speed 65 knots... feel the increased drag? Descent rate increasing...'

During slip: 'Maintaining slip... VSI showing 650 fpm descent (increased from 350 fpm)... maintaining approach speed 65 knots... maintaining runway alignment with rudder... ball deflected to the right (normal for slip)... losing altitude quickly...'
Monitor descent: 'Descent rate 650 fpm... altitude 300 feet... 250 feet... 200 feet... 150 feet... maintaining slip... approach speed still 65 knots... runway alignment maintained...'

Complete landing: 'Normal approach continued... over threshold... power to idle... eyes to far end of runway... gradual back pressure... flare... touchdown... excellent!'

Explain technique: 'Notice how I entered the slip when I recognized I was too high, used opposite aileron and rudder to increase descent rate from 350 fpm to 650 fpm, maintained approach speed at 65 knots, kept runway alignment with rudder, and recovered at 75 feet AGL. The slip allowed me to correct the high approach and land in the touchdown zone.'

interactiveElements.title: Forward Slip Scenario
interactiveElements.description: Interactive scenario for practicing forward slip decision-making

scenarios.situation: You're on final approach at 300 feet AGL. Approach speed is 65 knots. The aim point is falling in the windscreen, indicating you're too high. Your current descent rate is 350 fpm. The touchdown zone is 1,200 feet ahead. Should you use a forward slip?
options: Yes, enter a forward slip to increase descent rate
No, continue normal approach - you'll make it
Yes, but reduce power instead of using slip
No, go around - approach is too high
scenarios.correct: Yes, enter a forward slip to increase descent rate
scenarios.explanation: The aim point falling in the windscreen indicates you're too high. With a descent rate of 350 fpm and 300 feet AGL remaining, you would need 51 seconds to descend 300 feet, but you're only 1,200 feet from the touchdown zone. At 65 knots (110 feet per second), you'll reach the touchdown zone in 11 seconds, but you'll still be 240 feet high. A forward slip will increase descent rate to 500-800 fpm, allowing you to lose altitude quickly and land in the touchdown zone. Reducing power would slow the aircraft and could cause a stall. Going around is an option, but if conditions allow, a forward slip can correct the high approach safely.

tolerances: Descent rate ±100 fpm (500-800 fpm during slip)

lessonPlans.overview: Go-around (rejected landing) is a fundamental safety maneuver that must be executed confidently whenever an approach becomes unstable or landing cannot be safely completed. This critical lesson teaches the immediate action sequence: full power application, pitch control to prevent ballooning, proper configuration changes, and transition to climb. CFI candidates learn to recognize approach instability early, make decisive go-around decisions, execute the maneuver smoothly while teaching, and emphasize to students that go-arounds are normal, professional operations - never something to avoid due to embarrassment.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering go-arounds - one of the most important safety maneuvers in aviation. A go-around is a rejected landing, and it's a normal, professional procedure - never something to be embarrassed about. This is a fundamental safety skill that every CFI must master and teach effectively.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Go-Around / Rejected Landing'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: recognize when a go-around is necessary early, execute immediate go-around decision decisively, apply full power smoothly with proper rudder control, establish positive rate of climb at VY, retract flaps incrementally to prevent sink, recognize and correct common errors, and teach this critical maneuver effectively during your CFI checkride.'
Ask opening question: 'Think about your flight training. Have you ever been on an approach that didn't feel right? What made it feel wrong? What would you do in that situation?'
Listen actively to student response, nodding and taking notes on their experiences with unstable approaches

Transition: 'Excellent examples. What you're describing - unstabilized approaches, feeling wrong, uncertainty - are exactly when go-arounds become necessary. Let's break down the go-around procedure systematically and understand why it's such a critical safety maneuver.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll reference the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 9 on go-arounds, your POH for go-around procedures and flap retraction sequences, and ACS Area VII Task N which requires maintaining VY +10/-5 knots during climb.'

Emphasize mindset: 'CRITICAL - go-arounds are normal, professional operations. They're not failures. They're smart decisions. Every professional pilot does go-arounds regularly - it's a sign of good judgment, not poor flying. Teaching students that go-arounds are normal prevents them from trying to salvage bad approaches, which is dangerous.'

Explain decision criteria in detail: 'When do you go around? Unstabilized approach - not on speed, not on glidepath, not aligned. Too high or too low - outside normal approach parameters. Too fast or too slow - approach speed not maintained. Not aligned with runway - drifting left or right. Obstacles in path - trees, buildings, other aircraft. Traffic on runway - aircraft not cleared. Or any time landing doesn't feel right - trust your instincts. The decision should be made by 500 feet AGL - earlier is better. Don't wait until you're over the runway - that's too late.'

Draw go-around sequence on whiteboard: 'Here's the complete go-around sequence: Step 1 - Announce 'Going around' on radio immediately - communication is critical. Step 2 - Full power smoothly but decisively - not abruptly, but not tentative. Step 3 - Right rudder immediately with power - power causes left yaw, must counteract. Step 4 - Pitch for VY immediately - prevents settling, power first then pitch. Step 5 - Retract flaps incrementally - not all at once, prevents sink. Step 6 - Establish positive rate of climb - verify on VSI. Step 7 - Climb to pattern altitude - re-enter pattern properly.'

Demonstrate with model airplane: 'Watch this model. Normal approach - stable, on speed, on glidepath. Unstable approach - too high, too fast, not aligned. Decision point - go around! Full power, right rudder, pitch for VY, retract flaps. See how immediate the decision and execution are? That's professional.'

Explain power application technique: 'Full power smoothly - not abruptly. Smooth application prevents excessive yaw and maintains control. But apply it decisively - this is not a time to be tentative. Hesitation is dangerous. The power application should be smooth but immediate - no delay.'

Emphasize rudder requirement: 'Right rudder immediately with power - this is critical. Power causes left yaw due to P-factor, torque, and slipstream. You must counteract it immediately. Insufficient rudder causes left turn and loss of control. The rudder application must be simultaneous with power - not after.'

Explain pitch control technique: 'Pitch for VY immediately after power application. VY is typically 79 knots for most training aircraft - check your POH. CRITICAL - if you pitch up before adding power, the airplane settles. Power first, then pitch. The sequence is: power, rudder, pitch. VY gives best climb performance and prevents settling.'

Explain settling prevention: 'Settling is dangerous - the airplane loses altitude when you pitch up without power. This can result in ground contact or obstacle strike. The solution: power first, then pitch. Power provides the energy to climb. Pitching without power causes the airplane to settle into the ground.'

Discuss flap retraction technique: 'Retract flaps incrementally - not all at once. Retracting all flaps at once causes significant sink, which is dangerous at low altitude. Retract to takeoff flaps first (typically 10 degrees), then clean, or follow your POH procedure. Some aircraft have specific sequences - check your POH. The key is incremental - gradual retraction prevents sink.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors include: hesitating on go-around decision - delay is dangerous, inadequate right rudder - causes left yaw and loss of control, pitching up before adding power - causes settling, retracting flaps all at once - causes sink, not announcing go-around - communication failure, attempting to salvage unstabilized approach - dangerous decision.'

Set CFI context: 'On your CFI checkride, the examiner will ask you to teach go-arounds. You must explain decision criteria, demonstrate proper technique with power, rudder, pitch, and flaps, and correct student errors like hesitation or inadequate rudder. This is a critical safety teaching task - ACS Area VII Task N.'

Show POH procedures: 'Let's check your POH for go-around procedures. Look for sections on rejected landing, go-around, or balked landing. Check flap retraction sequence - some aircraft have specific procedures. Also verify VY speed - typically 79 knots but check your aircraft.'

lessonPlans.title: Power-Off 180° Accuracy Landing
objectives: Enter power-off approach from 180° position (abeam touchdown point at pattern altitude)
Establish and maintain best glide speed (65-70 knots typical) without power
Plan and execute 180° turn to align with runway using energy management
Control altitude and airspeed for precise touchdown in designated zone
Touch down in touchdown zone (first 1/3 of runway) with power idle
references: FAA-H-8083-25 Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge
prerequisites: Normal approach and landing proficiency (LP-VII-B)
Student understands best glide speed and energy management
Student can perform emergency procedures
Student understands glide performance and distance calculations
Weather is within student proficiency limits
lessonPlans.overview: The power-off 180° accuracy landing is an advanced landing technique that simulates an engine failure in the traffic pattern. The pilot must manage energy carefully, maintain proper glidepath using best glide speed (typically 65-70 knots), and touch down in the designated touchdown zone without using power. This maneuver develops judgment, energy management, and emergency landing skills. The technique requires entering from 180° position (abeam touchdown point), establishing best glide speed, planning the 180° turn, managing energy throughout approach, and touching down precisely. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of power-off 180° accuracy landing procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering power-off 180° accuracy landing - an advanced landing technique that simulates an engine failure in the traffic pattern. This maneuver requires careful energy management, precise glidepath control, and accurate touchdown. Mastering this is essential for emergency procedures and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Power-Off 180° Accuracy Landing'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: enter power-off approach from 180° position, establish and maintain best glide speed without power, plan and execute 180° turn to align with runway, control altitude and airspeed for precise touchdown, touch down in touchdown zone with power idle, and teach power-off 180° accuracy landing to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about an engine failure in the traffic pattern. If your engine fails abeam the touchdown point, what would you do? How would you manage your energy? What speed would you use?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: we have no power, so we must manage our energy carefully using best glide speed and precise planning. The power-off 180° accuracy landing simulates this exact scenario. Let's explore this systematically, starting with the entry point.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 9, your POH for best glide speed and performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on power-off 180° accuracy landing procedures.'

Explain the maneuver: 'The power-off 180° accuracy landing simulates an engine failure abeam the touchdown point. Entry point: Abeam touchdown point at pattern altitude (typically 1,000 feet AGL). Power: Reduce to idle (simulate engine failure, no power available). Speed: Establish best glide speed (typically 65-70 knots for trainers, check POH - this gives maximum glide distance). Turn: Plan and execute 180° turn to align with runway (base leg, final approach). Energy management: Control altitude and airspeed throughout approach (adjust turn radius, adjust glidepath, manage energy). Touchdown: Touch down in touchdown zone (first 1/3 of runway, precise touchdown). The key: Energy management - you have one chance, no power to correct, must plan carefully.'

Draw power-off 180° profile on whiteboard: 'Let me draw the power-off 180° profile. Here's the pattern altitude (1,000 feet AGL). Here's abeam touchdown point - this is where we reduce power to idle. Here's best glide speed (65-70 knots). Here's the 180° turn (base leg, final approach). Here's the touchdown zone (first 1/3 of runway). The goal: Use energy management to arrive at the touchdown zone with power idle.'

Explain best glide speed: 'Best glide speed is critical. Best glide speed: Typically 65-70 knots for trainers (check POH for exact speed - this is the speed that gives maximum glide distance). Why best glide: Maximum glide distance (gives you the most distance from your altitude, allows planning the approach), Predictable performance (glide distance is predictable at best glide, allows accurate planning). The key: Maintain best glide speed throughout - don't deviate, this is your energy management speed.'

Explain energy management: 'Energy management is critical. You have limited energy (altitude = potential energy, airspeed = kinetic energy, no power to add energy). Energy management: If too high (too much altitude, will overshoot touchdown zone), use forward slip or S-turns (increase descent rate, lose altitude, extend approach). If too low (too little altitude, will undershoot touchdown zone), use tighter turn or steeper approach (reduce distance, increase descent rate, shorten approach). If on glidepath (correct altitude, correct distance), maintain best glide speed, plan normal turn, normal approach. The key: Assess energy continuously, adjust approach as needed, plan ahead.'

Explain the 180° turn: 'The 180° turn is critical. Turn planning: Assess altitude and distance (how much altitude do I have? How far to runway? Can I make it?), Plan turn radius (tighter turn = shorter distance but more altitude loss, wider turn = longer distance but less altitude loss), Plan turn timing (when to start turn? When to roll out on final?). Turn execution: Base leg (typically 45-90° of the turn, assess energy, adjust as needed), Final approach (remaining turn to align with runway, final energy assessment, adjust glidepath). The key: Plan the turn based on energy, adjust as needed, don't wait until final to assess.'

Explain glidepath control: 'Glidepath control without power. Without power: Can't add power to correct (no power available, must use other methods), Must use pitch and configuration (pitch controls airspeed, flaps control descent rate, turns control distance). Glidepath control: If too high (aim point falling, too much altitude), Use forward slip (increase descent rate, lose altitude quickly), Use S-turns (extend approach, lose altitude, increase distance). If too low (aim point rising, too little altitude), Use tighter turn (reduce distance, shorten approach), Use steeper approach (increase descent rate, reduce distance). If on glidepath (aim point steady, correct altitude), Maintain best glide speed, normal approach. The key: Assess glidepath continuously, adjust using pitch, flaps, and turns.'

Explain touchdown precision: 'Touchdown precision is critical. Touchdown zone: First 1/3 of runway (typically 1,000-1,500 feet for most runways, check runway length). Precision required: Must touch down in touchdown zone (not short, not long, precise touchdown), No power to correct (can't add power if short, can't go around if long, one chance). Energy management: Manage energy to arrive at touchdown zone (assess continuously, adjust approach, plan touchdown). The key: Precise energy management throughout approach leads to precise touchdown.'

Demonstrate with model airplane: 'Watch the sequence. Entry: Abeam touchdown point at 1,000 feet AGL, reduce power to idle, establish best glide speed 68 knots. Base leg: Plan 180° turn, assess energy, adjust turn radius as needed, maintain best glide speed. Final approach: Complete turn to align with runway, assess glidepath, adjust as needed, maintain best glide speed. Touchdown: Touch down in touchdown zone, power idle throughout. Let me show you...'

Show POH best glide performance: 'Let's check your POH for best glide speed and performance. Best glide speed: Typically 65-70 knots (check POH for exact speed). Glide ratio: Typically 8:1 to 10:1 (8-10 feet forward for every 1 foot down, check POH). From 1,000 feet AGL at best glide: Typically 8,000-10,000 feet forward distance (check POH, varies with weight, altitude, conditions). Use this to plan your approach.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not establishing best glide speed (using wrong speed, poor glide performance, can't make runway), Poor energy assessment (not assessing altitude and distance, poor planning, overshoot or undershoot), Poor turn planning (turn too tight or too wide, poor energy management, can't make runway), Not adjusting approach (sticking to plan when energy wrong, not using slips or S-turns, missing touchdown zone), Using power (adding power to correct, defeats purpose, not power-off landing), Poor touchdown precision (not in touchdown zone, short or long landing). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as an emergency procedure. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe emergency landing operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

teachingScript.phase: Guided Practice - Student First Attempt (10 minutes)
instructorActions: Encourage: 'Your airplane. You've got this. I'll be right here if you need help, but I want you to try it. Enter the pattern normally, and when you're abeam the touchdown point, reduce power to idle and establish best glide speed.'
Guide pattern entry: 'Enter the pattern at 1,000 feet... maintaining pattern altitude... good. Now, when you're abeam the touchdown point, reduce power to idle.'
Abeam touchdown point: 'Abeam touchdown point... reduce power to idle... good. Now establish best glide speed... best glide is 68 knots... maintain 68 knots... good.'

Guide energy assessment: 'Now assess your energy... you're at 1,000 feet AGL, runway is about 3,000 feet away... do you have adequate altitude and distance? Good. Plan your 180° turn... when ready, turn base.'
Turn base: 'Turning base... maintaining best glide speed 68 knots... good. Assess energy... altitude 900 feet... energy looks good... continue turn...'

If student deviates from best glide: 'Check your airspeed... we're at 75 knots, but best glide is 68 knots. What do you need to do? Right - pitch up slightly to slow to best glide. There, 68 knots... perfect. Maintain that speed.'

scenarios.situation: You're on downwind at 1,000 feet AGL. You reduce power to idle abeam the touchdown point and establish best glide speed (68 knots). You assess your energy: altitude 1,000 feet AGL, runway is 3,000 feet away. You begin your 180° turn. At the base leg position, you're at 800 feet AGL and the runway is 2,000 feet away. The aim point is falling in the windscreen, indicating you're too high. What should you do?
options: Continue normal approach - you'll make it
Use a forward slip to increase descent rate and lose altitude
Add power to correct the approach
Go around - approach is too high
scenarios.correct: Use a forward slip to increase descent rate and lose altitude
scenarios.explanation: The aim point falling in the windscreen indicates you're too high. At 800 feet AGL with 2,000 feet to the runway, you have excess altitude. A forward slip will increase descent rate from the normal 300-400 fpm to 500-800 fpm, allowing you to lose altitude quickly and arrive at the touchdown zone. Adding power defeats the purpose of a power-off landing. Going around is not an option in a power-off landing (simulated engine failure). Continuing normal approach would result in overshooting the touchdown zone.

tolerances: Best glide speed ±5 knots (65-70 knots typical)

lessonPlans.overview: Straight-and-level flight is the foundation of all flight training. While it seems simple, maintaining constant altitude, heading, and airspeed requires understanding the relationship between pitch, power, and trim. This lesson teaches the fundamental control relationships: pitch primarily controls altitude (secondary: airspeed), power primarily controls airspeed (secondary: altitude), and trim eliminates control pressures. CFI candidates must master this maneuver to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it forms the basis for all other flight maneuvers. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of straight-and-level flight procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering straight-and-level flight - the foundation of all flight training. While it seems simple, maintaining constant altitude, heading, and airspeed requires understanding fundamental control relationships. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Straight-and-Level Flight'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: establish straight-and-level flight from any attitude, maintain altitude ±100 feet using pitch and trim, maintain heading ±10 degrees using rudder, maintain airspeed ±10 knots using power, use proper trim technique, develop instrument cross-check, and teach straight-and-level flight to students.'
Ask opening question: 'Think about maintaining straight-and-level flight. What makes it challenging? What do you think controls altitude? Airspeed? Heading? Why do we need trim?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: we must maintain three parameters simultaneously - altitude, heading, and airspeed - using three controls - pitch, power, and rudder. The relationships are interconnected, and trim is essential. Let's explore these systematically, starting with the fundamental control relationships.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 4, your POH for cruise performance and trim procedures, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on straight-and-level flight procedures.'

Explain control relationships: 'Here's the fundamental relationship: Pitch primarily controls altitude - pull back, nose goes up, altitude increases. Power primarily controls airspeed - add power, airspeed increases. But they're interconnected - changing one affects the other. For example: If you pull back (pitch up) to gain altitude, airspeed decreases. If you add power to increase airspeed, altitude increases. Understanding these relationships is critical.'

Draw control relationship diagram on whiteboard: 'Let me draw the control relationships. Pitch controls altitude (primary effect) and airspeed (secondary effect). Power controls airspeed (primary effect) and altitude (secondary effect). Rudder controls heading. Trim eliminates control pressures - it's not optional, it's mandatory for precision. The key: Use pitch for altitude, power for airspeed, rudder for heading, trim to eliminate pressures.'

Explain pitch for altitude: 'Pitch primarily controls altitude. Technique: To gain altitude - pull back (pitch up), nose rises, altitude increases, airspeed decreases (secondary effect). To lose altitude - push forward (pitch down), nose lowers, altitude decreases, airspeed increases (secondary effect). The key: Pitch is the primary control for altitude, but it affects airspeed as a secondary effect. If you need to gain altitude without losing airspeed, pitch up and add power. If you need to lose altitude without gaining airspeed, pitch down and reduce power.'

Explain power for airspeed: 'Power primarily controls airspeed. Technique: To increase airspeed - add power (increase RPM), airspeed increases, altitude increases (secondary effect). To decrease airspeed - reduce power (decrease RPM), airspeed decreases, altitude decreases (secondary effect). The key: Power is the primary control for airspeed, but it affects altitude as a secondary effect. If you need to increase airspeed without gaining altitude, add power and pitch down slightly. If you need to decrease airspeed without losing altitude, reduce power and pitch up slightly.'

Explain trim: 'Trim is critical. Without trim, you're fighting the controls constantly - holding back pressure, forward pressure, or side pressure. With trim, you can fly hands-off. The sequence is: First, establish attitude with pitch (nose on horizon for level flight). Second, set power for desired airspeed (typically 2300 RPM for cruise in trainers). Third, trim to eliminate control pressures (trim nose up to eliminate back pressure, trim nose down to eliminate forward pressure). The key: Trim is not optional - it's mandatory for precision flight. Proper trim allows hands-off flight and reduces workload.'

Explain visual attitude reference: 'Visual attitude is primary. The horizon picture tells you if you're level, climbing, or descending. Technique: Nose on horizon = level flight. Nose above horizon = climbing. Nose below horizon = descending. The key: Look outside first - the horizon picture is your primary reference. Instruments confirm what you see. Don't fixate on instruments - that causes spatial disorientation and loss of outside awareness.'

Explain scan pattern: 'Your scan pattern is: Attitude (outside) → Altitude → Heading → Airspeed → Engine. Visual attitude is primary - you should see the horizon picture. Instruments confirm what you see. Scan outside primarily, then scan instruments to confirm. Don't fixate on one instrument - that causes loss of awareness. The key: Outside is primary, instruments confirm. Scan continuously, don't stare.'

Explain small corrections: 'Small corrections early prevent large deviations. Technique: If altitude drifts up 20 feet, use small forward pressure to stop the drift, then retrim. Don't chase it with large inputs - that causes pilot-induced oscillations. If heading drifts left 5 degrees, use small right rudder to correct, then maintain. If airspeed drifts 5 knots slow, add small power increase (50 RPM), then retrim if needed. The key: Small corrections early prevent large deviations. Don't wait until you're 100 feet off altitude or 20 degrees off heading - correct early with small inputs.'

Explain pilot-induced oscillations: 'Pilot-induced oscillations are dangerous. Cause: Large control inputs cause overcorrection, then you correct the other way, creating oscillations. Prevention: Small corrections early, use trim, don't chase deviations. If you find yourself oscillating, stop making inputs, let the airplane stabilize, then make small corrections. The key: Small corrections early prevent oscillations. Use trim to eliminate control pressures.'

Show POH cruise performance: 'Let's check your POH for cruise performance. Typical cruise power: 2300 RPM (check POH for exact setting). Typical cruise airspeed: 110-120 knots (varies with altitude, weight, temperature). Typical cruise altitude: Any altitude (check POH for best altitude). Use this to establish straight-and-level flight.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Chasing altitude with excessive control inputs (causes oscillations, poor control), Not using trim (fighting controls, fatigue, poor precision), Fixating on one instrument (loss of awareness, spatial disorientation), Over-controlling (pilot-induced oscillations, poor control), Not scanning outside references (loss of visual attitude reference, spatial disorientation), Misunderstanding pitch/power relationship (incorrect technique, poor control). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to every student. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe flight operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

Show airspeed correction: 'Airspeed is 5 knots slow. Small power increase - add 50 RPM. Good. Now retrim if needed. See how I used a small power adjustment? That's the technique.'

Demonstrate hands-off: 'Now watch - hands off the controls. The airplane maintains altitude, heading, and airspeed. That's proper trim. If I hadn't trimmed, I'd be fighting the controls. See how the airplane maintains straight-and-level flight hands-off? That's the goal.'

Explain throughout: 'Notice I'm using pitch for altitude, power for airspeed, trim to eliminate pressures, and rudder for heading. That's the technique. The key is understanding the relationships and using small corrections early.'

diagrams.title: Control Relationships
diagrams.description: Visual representation of control relationships in straight-and-level flight showing pitch, power, rudder, and trim effects.
diagrams.asciiArt:
CONTROL RELATIONSHIPS

PITCH:
  Primary: Altitude
  Secondary: Airspeed
  Pull back → Nose up → Altitude ↑, Airspeed ↓
  Push forward → Nose down → Altitude ↓, Airspeed ↑

POWER:
  Primary: Airspeed
  Secondary: Altitude
  Add power → Airspeed ↑, Altitude ↑
  Reduce power → Airspeed ↓, Altitude ↓

RUDDER:
  Primary: Heading
  Right rudder → Nose right → Heading ↑
  Left rudder → Nose left → Heading ↓

TRIM:
  Eliminates control pressures
  Trim nose up → Eliminates back pressure
  Trim nose down → Eliminates forward pressure
keyPoints: Pitch primarily controls altitude, secondarily affects airspeed
Power primarily controls airspeed, secondarily affects altitude
Rudder controls heading
Trim eliminates control pressures - mandatory for precision

scenarios.situation: You're maintaining straight-and-level flight at 3,500 feet MSL. Your cruise power is set at 2,300 RPM, and your airspeed is 115 knots. You notice the altimeter shows 3,520 feet (20 feet high). What should you do?
options: Pull back to lose altitude
Make a small forward pressure to stop the drift, then retrim
Reduce power to lose altitude
Do nothing - 20 feet is within tolerance
scenarios.correct: Make a small forward pressure to stop the drift, then retrim
scenarios.explanation: The altitude has drifted up 20 feet. The correct technique is to use a small forward pressure to stop the drift, then retrim. Pulling back would make it worse. Reducing power would affect airspeed. While 20 feet is within the ±100 feet tolerance, good technique requires making small corrections early to prevent larger deviations. The key is small correction early, then retrim.

lessonPlans.title: Level Turns
objectives: Enter and exit turns smoothly
Maintain altitude ±100 feet in turns
Maintain standard rate or specified bank angle
Demonstrate coordination throughout
Roll out on specified headings ±10°
prerequisites: Straight-and-level proficiency
Understanding of turn coordination
lessonPlans.overview: Level turns are fundamental flight maneuvers that require coordination, altitude control, and precise heading management. In a level turn, the airplane banks while maintaining constant altitude, requiring back pressure to overcome the vertical component of lift. This lesson teaches coordinated flight, bank angle control, altitude maintenance during turns, and rollout timing. CFI candidates must master both shallow and steep turns while maintaining altitude ±100 feet and rolling out precisely on specified headings.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering level turns - fundamental maneuvers that require coordination, altitude control, and precise heading management. In a level turn, the airplane banks while maintaining constant altitude. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Level Turns'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: enter and exit turns smoothly, maintain altitude ±100 feet in turns, maintain standard rate (3° per second) or specified bank angle (typically 15-30°), demonstrate coordination throughout (ball centered), roll out on specified headings ±10 degrees, and teach level turns to students.'
Ask opening question: 'Think about turning an airplane. What happens to altitude when you bank? Why do you need back pressure in turns? What happens if you don't use rudder when rolling in?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: in a level turn, we must maintain altitude while banking, which requires understanding lift components, coordination, and rollout timing. Let's explore these systematically, starting with lift components.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 4, your POH for turn performance, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on level turn procedures.'

Explain lift components: 'When you bank, lift has two components: Vertical component (opposes weight, maintains altitude) and Horizontal component (causes turn, creates centripetal force). The vertical component decreases as bank increases, so you need back pressure to maintain altitude. At 30° bank, vertical lift is about 87% of total lift (cos 30° = 0.866). At 45° bank, vertical lift is about 71% of total lift (cos 45° = 0.707). Steeper bank equals less vertical lift, so more back pressure needed. The key: Bank angle determines how much back pressure you need - steeper bank requires more back pressure.'

Draw lift component diagram on whiteboard: 'Let me draw the lift components. Here's the airplane in level flight - all lift is vertical. Here's the airplane in a 30° bank - lift has vertical and horizontal components. Vertical component maintains altitude, horizontal component causes turn. As bank increases, vertical component decreases, so you need more back pressure. At 30° bank, you need about 15% more back pressure. At 45° bank, you need about 41% more back pressure.'

Explain bank angle and turn rate: 'Bank angle determines turn rate. Standard rate turn: 3 degrees per second (360 degrees in 2 minutes). This is typically achieved with 15-20° bank at cruise speed. Steeper bank equals faster turn rate: 30° bank gives about 6 degrees per second, 45° bank gives about 9 degrees per second. The key: Standard rate is 3° per second - this is used for instrument flying and traffic patterns. Steeper banks turn faster but require more back pressure and increase stall speed.'

Explain adverse yaw: 'Adverse yaw is critical to understand. When you roll in with aileron, the down-going aileron (on the outside wing) creates more drag than the up-going aileron (on the inside wing). This drag difference causes the nose to yaw opposite the turn direction. For example: Rolling right, the left wing goes down (more drag), nose yaws left (opposite turn direction). You need right rudder to counteract this adverse yaw and keep the ball centered. The key: Rudder counteracts adverse yaw - use rudder in the same direction as the turn to keep the ball centered.'

Explain coordination: 'Coordinated flight means the ball is centered - no slipping or skidding. Ball centered: Coordinated flight (correct). Ball to the inside of turn: Slipping (too much rudder or not enough bank). Ball to the outside of turn: Skidding (not enough rudder or too much bank). The key: Ball must be centered for coordinated flight. Use rudder to center the ball - rudder in same direction as turn to counteract adverse yaw.'

Explain rollout timing: 'Rollout timing is critical. Lead the rollout by approximately half the bank angle. If you're in a 30° bank, start rolling out 15° before your desired heading. If you're in a 20° bank, start rolling out 10° before your desired heading. This prevents overshooting. The key: Lead by half the bank angle - this accounts for the time it takes to roll out. If you wait until you're on heading, you'll overshoot by the lead angle.'

Explain back pressure management: 'Back pressure management is critical. Shallow turn (15° bank): Minimal back pressure needed, about 3-5% more than level flight. Medium turn (30° bank): Moderate back pressure needed, about 15% more than level flight. Steep turn (45° bank): Significant back pressure needed, about 41% more than level flight. The key: Back pressure increases with bank angle - steeper bank requires more back pressure. Feel the back pressure - it should increase as bank increases.'

Explain trim in turns: 'In prolonged turns, trim off the back pressure. This reduces workload and allows you to maintain altitude more precisely. Technique: Establish the turn, apply back pressure to maintain altitude, then trim to eliminate the back pressure. This allows you to maintain altitude hands-off during the turn. The key: Trim off back pressure in prolonged turns - this reduces workload and improves precision.'

Explain overbanking tendency: 'Overbanking tendency is important to understand. In a turn, the outside wing travels faster than the inside wing, creating more lift on the outside wing. This causes the airplane to want to overbank (increase bank angle). You must use aileron pressure to maintain the desired bank angle. The key: Monitor bank angle constantly - the airplane wants to overbank, so you must use aileron to maintain desired bank.'

Explain stall speed in turns: 'Stall speed increases in turns. Level flight: Stall speed is Vso (for example, 50 knots). 30° bank: Stall speed increases by about 7% (to about 53 knots). 45° bank: Stall speed increases by about 19% (to about 60 knots). 60° bank: Stall speed increases by about 41% (to about 71 knots). The key: Maintain adequate airspeed in turns - stall speed increases with bank angle. Don't turn at low airspeed - this increases stall risk.'

Show POH turn performance: 'Let's check your POH for turn performance. Typical standard rate turn: 15-20° bank at cruise speed (check POH for exact bank angle). Typical steep turn: 45° bank (check POH for limitations). Use this to plan your turns.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Uncoordinated flight (ball not centered, adverse yaw not counteracted), Altitude loss in turns (insufficient back pressure, not maintaining altitude), Rolling in without rudder (adverse yaw, uncoordinated flight), Over-banking or under-banking (not maintaining specified bank angle), Late rollout (overshooting heading, not leading rollout), Not adding back pressure (descending turn, altitude loss). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to every student. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe turning flight and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

instructorActions: Narrate throughout: 'Watch everything I do. I'm entering a level turn to the right. First, I'm rolling in with aileron, and I'm using right rudder to counteract adverse yaw.'
Enter turn: 'Rolling in now - aileron right, rudder right to keep ball centered. See how I'm using both together? That's coordination. Ball is centered - no slipping or skidding.'
Maintain altitude: 'Now I'm adding back pressure to maintain altitude. The vertical component of lift decreased when I banked, so I need back pressure. Steeper bank equals more back pressure needed.'
Maintain bank: 'Maintaining 30-degree bank. This gives me a standard rate turn - 3 degrees per second. I'm maintaining altitude with back pressure, and the ball is centered.'
Show coordination: 'Watch the ball - it's centered. That means coordinated flight. If the ball were to the right, I'd be slipping. If to the left, I'd be skidding. Centered is correct.'
Lead rollout: 'Rolling out now - I'm leading by half the bank angle. I was in 30-degree bank, so I'm starting rollout 15 degrees before my desired heading. That prevents overshooting.'
Rollout: 'Rolling out - aileron left, rudder left to counteract adverse yaw. Releasing back pressure as I roll out. Rolling out on heading - 180 degrees. That's a level turn.'
Demonstrate shallow turn: 'Now watch a shallow turn - 15-degree bank. Less back pressure needed, slower turn rate. Same principles apply.'
Explain throughout: 'Notice I used rudder to counteract adverse yaw, back pressure to maintain altitude, and led the rollout. That's the technique.'
Debrief immediately: 'What were the three most critical things you noticed? The coordination with rudder? The back pressure for altitude? The rollout lead?'

lessonPlans.overview: Straight climbs and climbing turns are fundamental flight maneuvers that require coordination, airspeed control, and precise heading management. In a climb, the airplane gains altitude while maintaining specific airspeed (VY for best rate, VX for best angle). Climbing turns combine climb performance with turning flight, requiring coordination of pitch, power, bank, and rudder. This lesson teaches climb entry, airspeed control, trim usage, coordination, and climbing turn techniques. CFI candidates must master both VY and VX climbs, straight climbs, and climbing turns while maintaining ACS standards and simultaneously teaching. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of straight climbs and climbing turns procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering straight climbs and climbing turns - fundamental maneuvers that require coordination, airspeed control, and precise heading management. In a climb, the airplane gains altitude while maintaining specific airspeed. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Straight Climbs and Climbing Turns'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: establish straight climb using proper entry technique, maintain VY (best rate of climb) airspeed ±5 knots, maintain VX (best angle of climb) airspeed ±5 knots when required, maintain climb rate of 500-800 fpm for VY, maintain specified heading ±10° in straight climbs, perform climbing turns maintaining bank angle and airspeed, use proper trim technique, demonstrate coordination throughout, and teach straight climbs and climbing turns to students.'
Ask opening question: 'Think about climbing an airplane. What airspeed do you use? Why is there a difference between VY and VX? What happens to coordination in a climbing turn?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: in a climb, we must maintain specific airspeed while gaining altitude, which requires understanding pitch, power, and trim relationships. Climbing turns add bank angle and coordination. Let's explore these systematically, starting with VY and VX.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 4, your POH for climb performance and airspeeds, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on straight climbs and climbing turns procedures.'

Explain VY (best rate of climb): 'VY is the best rate of climb speed - the speed that gives you maximum altitude gain per minute. For most trainers, VY is 75-85 knots (check POH for exact speed). Technique: Full power (or specified climb power), pitch to maintain VY airspeed, trim to eliminate back pressure. Climb rate: Typically 500-800 fpm at VY (varies with altitude, weight, temperature). Use VY when: Clearing obstacles after takeoff, climbing to cruise altitude, maximizing altitude gain. The key: VY gives you the fastest climb rate - maximum altitude per minute.'

Explain VX (best angle of climb): 'VX is the best angle of climb speed - the speed that gives you maximum altitude gain per distance forward. For most trainers, VX is 65-70 knots (check POH for exact speed). Technique: Full power, pitch to maintain VX airspeed, trim to eliminate back pressure. Climb rate: Typically 300-500 fpm at VX (slower than VY but steeper angle). Use VX when: Clearing obstacles close to runway, maximizing altitude gain over short distance, obstacle clearance is critical. The key: VX gives you the steepest climb angle - maximum altitude per distance forward.'

Draw climb profile diagram on whiteboard: 'Let me draw the climb profiles. VY climb: Lower pitch attitude (8-10° nose up), higher airspeed (75-85 knots), faster climb rate (500-800 fpm), less steep angle. VX climb: Higher pitch attitude (12-15° nose up), lower airspeed (65-70 knots), slower climb rate (300-500 fpm), steeper angle. The key: VY for fastest climb, VX for steepest climb.'

Explain climb entry: 'Climb entry technique: First, establish cruise power (if not already set). Second, smoothly increase power to climb power (full power or specified climb power, typically 2500 RPM). Third, smoothly pitch up to climb attitude (8-10° nose up for VY, 12-15° nose up for VX). Fourth, maintain climb airspeed (VY or VX) with pitch. Fifth, trim to eliminate back pressure. The key: Smooth entry - don't jerk the controls. Establish power first, then pitch, then trim.'

Explain airspeed control in climb: 'Airspeed control in climb is critical. Technique: Pitch controls airspeed in climb - pitch up, airspeed decreases; pitch down, airspeed increases. Power is set for climb (full power or climb power), so pitch is the primary control for airspeed. If airspeed is too fast: Pitch up slightly to slow down. If airspeed is too slow: Pitch down slightly to speed up. The key: Pitch for airspeed in climb - power is already set. Monitor airspeed constantly - it's easy to let it drift.'

Explain trim in climb: 'Trim is essential in climb. Technique: After establishing climb attitude and airspeed, trim to eliminate back pressure. This reduces workload and allows precise airspeed control. Without trim, you're holding constant back pressure, which causes fatigue and imprecise control. With trim, you can maintain climb hands-off. The key: Trim off back pressure in climb - this is mandatory for precision flight.'

Explain coordination in straight climb: 'Coordination in straight climb is important. Technique: Use rudder to maintain heading and keep ball centered. In a straight climb, you still need rudder to counteract left-turning tendencies (P-factor, torque, spiraling slipstream, gyroscopic precession). Right rudder pressure is needed to maintain heading and keep ball centered. The key: Coordination is still required in climb - use rudder to maintain heading and keep ball centered.'

Explain climbing turns: 'Climbing turns combine climb performance with turning flight. Technique: Enter climb first (establish power, pitch, trim), then enter turn (bank with aileron, rudder to counteract adverse yaw, back pressure to maintain altitude). In climbing turn: Maintain climb airspeed (VY or VX) with pitch, maintain bank angle with aileron, maintain coordination with rudder, maintain altitude with back pressure. The key: Climbing turns require coordination of all controls - pitch for airspeed, aileron for bank, rudder for coordination, back pressure for altitude.'

Explain back pressure in climbing turns: 'Back pressure in climbing turns is critical. In a climbing turn, you need back pressure to maintain altitude (just like in level turns). The amount of back pressure depends on bank angle - steeper bank requires more back pressure. However, in a climbing turn, you're already climbing, so the back pressure requirement is less than in a level turn. The key: Back pressure in climbing turns maintains altitude - amount depends on bank angle.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not maintaining climb airspeed (airspeed drifts, poor climb performance), Not using trim (holding back pressure, fatigue, imprecise control), Uncoordinated flight (ball not centered, adverse yaw not counteracted), Not maintaining heading in straight climb (drifting off heading, not using rudder), Poor climb entry (jerky controls, not smooth), Not maintaining bank angle in climbing turns (over-banking or under-banking), Altitude loss in climbing turns (insufficient back pressure). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH climb performance: 'Let's check your POH for climb performance. VY speed: Typically 75-85 knots (check POH for exact speed). VX speed: Typically 65-70 knots (check POH for exact speed). lessonPlans.overview: Straight descents and descending turns are fundamental flight maneuvers that require coordination, airspeed control, and precise heading management. In a descent, the airplane loses altitude while maintaining specific airspeed. Descending turns combine descent performance with turning flight, requiring coordination of pitch, power, bank, and rudder. This lesson teaches descent entry, airspeed control, descent rate management, trim usage, coordination, and descending turn techniques. CFI candidates must master power-off descents, power-on descents, straight descents, and descending turns while maintaining ACS standards and simultaneously teaching. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of straight descents and descending turns procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering straight descents and descending turns - fundamental maneuvers that require coordination, airspeed control, and precise heading management. In a descent, the airplane loses altitude while maintaining specific airspeed. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Straight Descents and Descending Turns'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: establish straight descent using proper entry technique, maintain specified descent airspeed ±10 knots, maintain descent rate of 300-500 fpm, maintain specified heading ±10° in straight descents, perform descending turns maintaining bank angle and airspeed, use proper trim technique, demonstrate coordination throughout, manage power and pitch to control descent rate and airspeed, and teach straight descents and descending turns to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about descending an airplane. How do you control descent rate? What's the relationship between power and pitch in a descent? What happens to coordination in a descending turn?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: in a descent, we must maintain specific airspeed while losing altitude, which requires understanding power, pitch, and trim relationships. Descending turns add bank angle and coordination. Let's explore these systematically, starting with power-off and power-on descents.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 4, your POH for descent performance, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on straight descents and descending turns procedures.'

Explain power-off descent: 'Power-off descent is used when you want to lose altitude quickly or simulate engine failure. Technique: Reduce power to idle, pitch down to maintain desired airspeed (typically cruise speed or slower), trim to eliminate forward pressure. Descent rate: Typically 500-800 fpm at idle power (varies with airspeed, weight, configuration). Airspeed control: Pitch controls airspeed - pitch down to speed up, pitch up to slow down. The key: Power-off descent gives you faster descent rate, but you have no power to correct if needed.'

Explain power-on descent: 'Power-on descent is used for normal descents when you want controlled descent rate. Technique: Reduce power to desired setting (typically 1500-2000 RPM), pitch down to maintain desired airspeed (typically cruise speed), trim to eliminate forward pressure. Descent rate: Typically 300-500 fpm with power (varies with power setting, airspeed, weight). Airspeed control: Power and pitch work together - power controls descent rate, pitch controls airspeed. The key: Power-on descent gives you controlled descent rate with power available to correct if needed.'

Draw descent profile diagram on whiteboard: 'Let me draw the descent profiles. Power-off descent: Idle power, pitch down 5-10° nose down, descent rate 500-800 fpm, faster descent. Power-on descent: Reduced power (1500-2000 RPM), pitch down 3-5° nose down, descent rate 300-500 fpm, controlled descent. The key: Power-off for faster descent, power-on for controlled descent.'

Explain descent entry: 'Descent entry technique: First, reduce power to desired setting (idle for power-off, reduced power for power-on). Second, smoothly pitch down to descent attitude (3-5° nose down for power-on, 5-10° nose down for power-off). Third, maintain desired airspeed with pitch. Fourth, trim to eliminate forward pressure. The key: Smooth entry - don't jerk the controls. Reduce power first, then pitch, then trim.'

Explain airspeed control in descent: 'Airspeed control in descent is critical. Technique: Pitch controls airspeed in descent - pitch down, airspeed increases; pitch up, airspeed decreases. Power affects descent rate - more power, slower descent rate; less power, faster descent rate. If airspeed is too fast: Pitch up slightly to slow down. If airspeed is too slow: Pitch down slightly to speed up. If descent rate is too fast: Add power slightly. If descent rate is too slow: Reduce power slightly. The key: Pitch for airspeed, power for descent rate - but they're interconnected.'

Explain trim in descent: 'Trim is essential in descent. Technique: After establishing descent attitude and airspeed, trim to eliminate forward pressure. This reduces workload and allows precise airspeed control. Without trim, you're holding constant forward pressure, which causes fatigue and imprecise control. With trim, you can maintain descent hands-off. The key: Trim off forward pressure in descent - this is mandatory for precision flight.'

Explain coordination in straight descent: 'Coordination in straight descent is important. Technique: Use rudder to maintain heading and keep ball centered. In a straight descent, you still need rudder to counteract left-turning tendencies (P-factor, torque, spiraling slipstream, gyroscopic precession). Right rudder pressure may be needed to maintain heading and keep ball centered, depending on power setting. The key: Coordination is still required in descent - use rudder to maintain heading and keep ball centered.'

Explain descending turns: 'Descending turns combine descent performance with turning flight. Technique: Enter descent first (reduce power, pitch, trim), then enter turn (bank with aileron, rudder to counteract adverse yaw, adjust pitch to maintain airspeed). In descending turn: Maintain descent airspeed with pitch, maintain bank angle with aileron, maintain coordination with rudder, maintain descent rate with power. The key: Descending turns require coordination of all controls - pitch for airspeed, aileron for bank, rudder for coordination, power for descent rate.'

Explain pitch management in descending turns: 'Pitch management in descending turns is critical. In a descending turn, you may need to adjust pitch to maintain airspeed. The turn itself doesn't require additional pitch change, but you must maintain airspeed. If airspeed increases in turn: Pitch up slightly to slow down. If airspeed decreases in turn: Pitch down slightly to speed up. The key: Maintain airspeed in descending turns - use pitch to control airspeed.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not maintaining descent airspeed (airspeed drifts, poor descent control), Not using trim (holding forward pressure, fatigue, imprecise control), Uncoordinated flight (ball not centered, adverse yaw not counteracted), Not maintaining heading in straight descent (drifting off heading, not using rudder), Poor descent entry (jerky controls, not smooth), Not maintaining bank angle in descending turns (over-banking or under-banking), Excessive descent rate (too fast, difficult to control), Insufficient descent rate (too slow, not losing altitude). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH descent performance: 'Let's check your POH for descent performance. Typical descent speed: Cruise speed or slower (check POH for recommended speeds). Typical descent power: 1500-2000 RPM for power-on descent (check POH for exact setting). Typical descent rate: 300-500 fpm for power-on, 500-800 fpm for power-off (varies with airspeed, weight, configuration). Use this to plan your descents.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to every student. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe descent operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'
