lessonPlans.overview: Elevator trim stall demonstration is a critical safety maneuver that shows why improper trim usage can cause stalls. Elevator trim stalls occur when the airplane is trimmed for a specific airspeed/attitude, and then the pilot tries to change that airspeed/attitude without retrimming. The trim tab applies force to maintain the trimmed condition, and if the pilot tries to change the condition without retrimming, the trim force can cause the airplane to stall. This is typically demonstrated by trimming for slow flight (e.g., 70 knots), then trying to maintain altitude at a slower speed (e.g., 60 knots) without retrimming. The trim force continues to pull the nose up, requiring increasing back pressure to maintain altitude, eventually leading to a stall. This demonstration teaches students the critical importance of proper trim usage and retrimming when changing airspeed or attitude. CFI candidates must master this demonstration to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of trim aerodynamics and prepares students to use trim properly. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of elevator trim stall demonstration procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering elevator trim stall demonstration - a critical safety maneuver that shows why improper trim usage can cause stalls. Elevator trim stalls occur when the airplane is trimmed for a specific airspeed/attitude, and then the pilot tries to change that airspeed/attitude without retrimming. The trim tab applies force to maintain the trimmed condition, and if you try to change the condition without retrimming, the trim force can cause the airplane to stall. This is typically demonstrated by trimming for slow flight, then trying to maintain altitude at a slower speed without retrimming. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Elevator Trim Stall Demonstration'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: understand how elevator trim works, demonstrate elevator trim stall, recognize and announce first indication of stall, recover immediately by reducing angle of attack and retrimming, explain why improper trim usage can cause stalls, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, minimize altitude loss (±100 feet), return to straight-and-level flight, and teach elevator trim stall demonstration to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about trimming the airplane for a specific airspeed. What happens if you then try to fly at a different airspeed without retrimming? What does the trim tab do? Can trim force cause a stall?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key concept: trim applies force to maintain the trimmed condition. If you try to change the condition without retrimming, the trim force continues to pull in the trimmed direction, requiring increasing control pressure to overcome it. Eventually, this can lead to a stall. Let's explore this systematically, starting with how trim works.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 5, your POH for trim procedures and performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on elevator trim stall demonstration procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Elevator trim stall demonstration serves two purposes: First, it's a safety demonstration that shows why improper trim usage is dangerous (why trim can cause stalls, why retrimming is critical, why proper trim usage is essential). Second, it teaches proper trim usage (when to retrim, how to retrim, understanding trim effects). The key: Elevator trim stall demonstration teaches why proper trim usage is critical - this is a demonstration to show the danger of improper trim usage.'

Explain how trim works: 'Elevator trim works by applying force to the elevator. Trim tab: Small tab on elevator that deflects to apply force, Deflects opposite to desired elevator movement, Applies force to maintain trimmed condition. Trimmed for slow flight (70 knots): Trim tab deflects to pull nose up, Applies force to maintain 70-knot attitude, If you try to slow to 60 knots without retrimming: Trim force continues to pull nose up, Requires increasing back pressure to maintain altitude, Eventually leads to stall. The key: Trim applies force to maintain trimmed condition - if you change condition without retrimming, trim force works against you.'

Explain trim force: 'Trim force is significant. Trimmed for 70 knots: Trim tab applies force to maintain 70-knot attitude, This force is substantial (can be 10-20 pounds of force), If you try to slow to 60 knots: Trim force continues to pull nose up, You must apply increasing back pressure to overcome trim force, Eventually, you can't overcome trim force, Stall occurs. The key: Trim force is substantial - if you change airspeed without retrimming, trim force works against you and can cause stall.'

Explain entry technique: 'Entry technique: First, perform 90° clearing turns (minimum) to check for traffic. Second, establish cruise flight at appropriate altitude (minimum 4000 AGL for practice, higher is better). Third, establish slow flight (typically 70 knots, approach speed). Fourth, trim for slow flight (trim to relieve control pressure at 70 knots). Fifth, reduce airspeed without retrimming (reduce power, try to maintain altitude at slower speed, e.g., 60 knots). Sixth, notice increasing back pressure required (trim force pulling nose up, requires increasing back pressure). Seventh, recognize stall warning (horn, buffet, control feel - occurs because trim force is pulling nose up). The key: Enter gradually - trim for one condition, then try to change condition without retrimming, trim force causes stall.'

Explain stall recognition: 'Stall recognition is critical. First indication of elevator trim stall: Stall warning horn (5-10 knots before stall), Buffet (3-5 knots before stall), Control feel (controls become mushy, increasing back pressure required), High angle of attack (trim force pulling nose up). The key difference: Stall occurs because trim force is pulling nose up - you're fighting the trim. When you recognize first indication: Announce: 'Stall warning' or 'Buffet' or 'First indication of elevator trim stall', Begin recovery immediately. The key: Recognize first indication immediately and begin recovery - elevator trim stall occurs because trim force is working against you.'

Explain recovery technique: 'Recovery technique: Reduce angle of attack immediately (pitch forward, nose down - this is the most critical step). Retrim (adjust trim to relieve control pressure - this removes trim force that was causing stall). Return to straight-and-level flight (establish level flight attitude). The key: Reduce angle of attack first - this is the most critical step. Then retrim - this removes the trim force that was causing the stall.'

Explain recovery sequence: 'Recovery sequence: First, reduce angle of attack immediately (pitch forward, nose down - this is the most critical step). Second, retrim (adjust trim to relieve control pressure - this removes trim force that was causing stall). Third, return to straight-and-level flight (establish level flight attitude). Fourth, accelerate to normal cruise speed. Fifth, retrim for cruise flight. The key: Reduce angle of attack first - this is the most critical step. Then retrim - this removes the trim force that was causing the stall.'

Explain why this is a demonstration: 'This is a demonstration, not a practice maneuver. Why: Elevator trim stalls show why improper trim usage is dangerous, We demonstrate to show the danger, not to practice, Students should always retrim when changing airspeed/attitude, The goal is to show why proper trim usage is critical. The key: This is a demonstration to show danger - students should always retrim when changing conditions. The goal is proper trim usage, not practice of trim stalls.'

Explain relationship to real-world: 'Elevator trim stalls relate to real-world scenarios. In approach: If pilot trims for approach speed (70 knots), then slows to 60 knots without retrimming, trim force pulls nose up, requires increasing back pressure, can lead to stall. In go-around: If pilot trims for approach, then applies full power for go-around without retrimming, trim force may not be appropriate, can affect control. Prevention: Always retrim when changing airspeed/attitude, Understand trim effects, Use trim properly. The key: Elevator trim stalls teach why proper trim usage is critical - always retrim when changing airspeed or attitude.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not retrimming when changing airspeed (trim force works against you, can cause stall), Not understanding trim effects (poor understanding, improper trim usage), Not recognizing stall warning (delayed recovery, more altitude loss), Not reducing angle of attack enough (secondary stall risk), Not retrimming during recovery (trim force still present, can cause secondary stall), Trying to save altitude (secondary stall risk). We'll address each of these during the demonstration.'

Show POH trim procedures: 'Let's check your POH for trim procedures. Typical trim settings: Cruise trim (for cruise speed), Approach trim (for approach speed), Landing trim (for landing speed). Use trim to relieve control pressure at each airspeed. Use this to plan the demonstration.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll use this demonstration to teach students why proper trim usage is critical. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe flight operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: This is a demonstration to show why proper trim usage is critical - students should always retrim when changing conditions.'

diagrams.title: Elevator Trim Stall Recovery
diagrams.description: Visual representation of elevator trim stall recovery sequence.
diagrams.asciiArt:
ELEVATOR TRIM STALL RECOVERY

ENTRY:
  Establish slow flight (70 knots)
  Trim for slow flight
  Trim force maintains 70-knot attitude

TRY TO SLOW WITHOUT RETRIMMING:
  Reduce power
  Try to maintain altitude at 60 knots
  Trim force still pulling nose up
  Increasing back pressure required
  Fighting trim force

STALL WARNING:
  Horn (trim force causing stall)
  Buffet (trim force causing stall)
  Control feel (mushy, increasing back pressure)
  High angle of attack

RECOVERY:
  1. Reduce angle of attack immediately (nose down)
  2. Retrim (remove trim force that was causing stall)
  3. Return to straight-and-level flight

RESULT:
  Altitude loss: 100-200 feet (acceptable)
  Airspeed: Increasing to cruise
  Level flight: Established
  Trim force: REMOVED

KEY:
  Reduce angle of attack FIRST
  Retrim to remove trim force
  This is a DEMONSTRATION - shows why proper trim usage is critical
keyPoints: Trim applies force to maintain trimmed condition
Changing airspeed without retrimming causes trim force to work against you
Recovery: Reduce angle of attack first, then retrim
This is a demonstration to show why proper trim usage is critical

diagrams.title: How Trim Works
diagrams.description: Illustration showing how elevator trim applies force.
diagrams.asciiArt:
HOW TRIM WORKS

TRIMMED FOR 70 KNOTS:
  Trim tab deflects
  Applies force to elevator
  Maintains 70-knot attitude
  Relieves control pressure

TRY TO SLOW TO 60 KNOTS WITHOUT RETRIMMING:
  Trim force still pulling nose up
  (Trimmed for 70 knots, not 60 knots)
  Requires increasing back pressure
  To overcome trim force
  Eventually leads to stall

RETRIMMING:
  Adjust trim for new condition
  Removes trim force from old condition
  Applies force for new condition
  Relieves control pressure

KEY:
  Trim applies force to maintain trimmed condition
  Must retrim when changing condition
keyPoints: Trim applies force to maintain trimmed condition
Changing condition without retrimming causes trim force to work against you
Retrimming removes old trim force and applies new trim force

interactiveElements.title: Elevator Trim Stall Scenario
interactiveElements.description: Interactive scenario for practicing elevator trim stall decision-making

scenarios.situation: You've trimmed the airplane for approach speed (70 knots). You then reduce power to slow to 60 knots, but you forget to retrim. You hear the stall warning horn and feel buffet. What should you do?
options: Continue as is - try to maintain altitude
Reduce angle of attack immediately, then retrim
Just retrim - that will fix it
Pull back more to try to maintain altitude
scenarios.correct: Reduce angle of attack immediately, then retrim
scenarios.explanation: When you recognize stall warning due to trim force, you must recover immediately. Reduce angle of attack immediately (pitch forward, nose down) - this is the most critical step. Then retrim - this removes the trim force that was causing the stall. The trim was set for 70 knots, so when you slowed to 60 knots without retrimming, the trim force continued to pull the nose up (because it was still trimmed for 70 knots). You had to fight this trim force with increasing back pressure, and eventually the trim force caused the stall. Continuing as is will result in a full stall. Just retrimming isn't enough - you also need to reduce angle of attack first. Pulling back more will make the stall worse. The key is understanding that trim applies force to maintain trimmed condition, and if you change condition without retrimming, trim force works against you and can cause stall.

lessonPlans.overview: Secondary stall demonstration is a critical safety maneuver that shows why improper stall recovery can cause another stall immediately after the first one. Secondary stalls occur when a pilot recovers from a stall but doesn't reduce angle of attack enough, or pulls back too aggressively trying to save altitude, causing another stall immediately after the initial stall recovery. This is a common error during stall recovery - the pilot tries to save altitude by pulling back too aggressively, or doesn't reduce angle of attack enough during recovery, causing the airplane to stall again. This demonstration teaches students the critical importance of proper stall recovery technique: reduce angle of attack immediately and smoothly, don't try to save altitude at the expense of proper recovery, some altitude loss is acceptable. CFI candidates must master this demonstration to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of proper stall recovery and prepares students to avoid secondary stalls. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of secondary stall demonstration procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering secondary stall demonstration - a critical safety maneuver that shows why improper stall recovery can cause another stall immediately after the first one. Secondary stalls occur when a pilot recovers from a stall but doesn't reduce angle of attack enough, or pulls back too aggressively trying to save altitude, causing another stall immediately after the initial stall recovery. This is a common error during stall recovery. This demonstration teaches students the critical importance of proper stall recovery technique. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Secondary Stall Demonstration'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: understand what secondary stall means, demonstrate secondary stall, recognize and announce first indication of secondary stall, recover immediately by reducing angle of attack, explain why improper stall recovery causes secondary stalls, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, minimize altitude loss (±100 feet), return to straight-and-level flight, and teach secondary stall demonstration to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about recovering from a stall. What happens if you don't reduce angle of attack enough? What happens if you pull back too aggressively trying to save altitude? Can you stall again immediately after recovering from a stall?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key danger: improper stall recovery can cause another stall immediately after the first one. Secondary stall demonstration shows exactly why this happens and how to prevent it. Let's explore this systematically, starting with what secondary stall means.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 5, your POH for stall speeds and performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on secondary stall demonstration procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Secondary stall demonstration serves two purposes: First, it's a safety demonstration that shows why improper stall recovery is dangerous (why not reducing angle of attack enough causes secondary stall, why trying to save altitude causes secondary stall, why proper recovery technique is critical). Second, it teaches proper stall recovery (reduce angle of attack immediately and smoothly, don't try to save altitude, some altitude loss is acceptable). The key: Secondary stall demonstration teaches why proper stall recovery is critical - this is a demonstration to show the danger of improper recovery.'

Explain what secondary stall means: 'Secondary stall means stalling again immediately after recovering from an initial stall. Causes: Not reducing angle of attack enough during recovery (angle of attack still high, can stall again), Pulling back too aggressively trying to save altitude (increases angle of attack, causes secondary stall), Abrupt recovery (overcorrecting, can cause secondary stall). The key: Secondary stall occurs when angle of attack is still high or increases again immediately after initial stall recovery.'

Explain why secondary stall occurs: 'Secondary stall occurs because: Angle of attack is still high after initial recovery (didn't reduce enough), Angle of attack increases again (pulled back too aggressively), Critical angle of attack is exceeded again (stall occurs again). In secondary stall: Initial stall occurs, Pilot recovers but doesn't reduce angle of attack enough, OR pilot pulls back too aggressively trying to save altitude, Angle of attack exceeds critical angle of attack again, Secondary stall occurs immediately. The key: Secondary stall occurs because angle of attack is still high or increases again - this is why proper recovery is critical.'

Explain entry technique: 'Entry technique: First, perform 90° clearing turns (minimum) to check for traffic. Second, establish cruise flight at appropriate altitude (minimum 4000 AGL for practice, higher is better). Third, induce initial stall (power-off or power-on stall, recognize stall warning, allow stall to occur). Fourth, recover from initial stall improperly (don't reduce angle of attack enough, OR pull back too aggressively trying to save altitude). Fifth, recognize secondary stall warning (horn, buffet, control feel - occurs immediately after initial recovery). The key: Enter gradually - induce initial stall, then recover improperly, secondary stall occurs immediately.'

Explain improper recovery: 'Improper recovery causes secondary stall. Not reducing angle of attack enough: Initial stall occurs, Pilot reduces angle of attack but not enough, Angle of attack is still high, Can stall again immediately. Pulling back too aggressively: Initial stall occurs, Pilot recovers but then pulls back too aggressively trying to save altitude, Angle of attack increases again, Secondary stall occurs. The key: Improper recovery causes secondary stall - either not reducing angle of attack enough, or pulling back too aggressively trying to save altitude.'

Explain stall recognition: 'Stall recognition is critical. First indication of secondary stall: Stall warning horn (5-10 knots before stall, occurs immediately after initial recovery), Buffet (3-5 knots before stall, occurs immediately after initial recovery), Control feel (controls become mushy, occurs immediately after initial recovery), High angle of attack (still high or increased again). The key difference: Stall occurs immediately after initial stall recovery - this is the secondary stall. When you recognize first indication: Announce: 'Stall warning' or 'Buffet' or 'First indication of secondary stall', Begin recovery immediately. The key: Recognize first indication immediately and begin recovery - secondary stall occurs immediately after initial recovery, don't delay.'

Explain recovery technique: 'Recovery technique: Reduce angle of attack immediately and smoothly (pitch forward, nose down - this is the most critical step, reduce enough this time). Don't try to save altitude (some altitude loss is acceptable, preventing secondary stall is priority). Smooth recovery (don't overcorrect, don't pull back aggressively). Return to straight-and-level flight (establish level flight attitude). The key: Reduce angle of attack immediately and smoothly - reduce enough this time. Don't try to save altitude - preventing secondary stall is the priority.'

Explain recovery sequence: 'Recovery sequence: First, reduce angle of attack immediately and smoothly (pitch forward, nose down - reduce enough this time, don't just reduce a little). Second, don't try to save altitude (some altitude loss is acceptable, preventing secondary stall is priority). Third, smooth recovery (don't overcorrect, don't pull back aggressively). Fourth, return to straight-and-level flight (establish level flight attitude). Fifth, accelerate to normal cruise speed. The key: Reduce angle of attack immediately and smoothly - reduce enough this time. Don't try to save altitude - preventing secondary stall is the priority.'

Explain why this is a demonstration: 'This is a demonstration, not a practice maneuver. Why: Secondary stalls show why improper recovery is dangerous, We demonstrate to show the danger, not to practice, Students should always use proper recovery technique, The goal is to show why proper recovery is critical. The key: This is a demonstration to show danger - students should always use proper recovery technique. The goal is proper recovery, not practice of secondary stalls.'

Explain relationship to real-world: 'Secondary stalls relate to real-world scenarios. In stall recovery: If pilot doesn't reduce angle of attack enough, secondary stall can occur, If pilot tries to save altitude by pulling back, secondary stall can occur, If pilot overcorrects during recovery, secondary stall can occur. Prevention: Reduce angle of attack immediately and smoothly (reduce enough), Don't try to save altitude (some altitude loss is acceptable), Smooth recovery (don't overcorrect). The key: Secondary stalls teach why proper recovery is critical - reduce angle of attack enough, don't try to save altitude, smooth recovery.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not reducing angle of attack enough (secondary stall risk), Pulling back too aggressively trying to save altitude (secondary stall risk), Not understanding that some altitude loss is acceptable (tries to save altitude, causes secondary stall), Abrupt recovery (overcorrecting, can cause secondary stall), Not recognizing secondary stall warning (delayed recovery, more altitude loss). We'll address each of these during the demonstration.'

Show POH stall speeds: 'Let's check your POH for stall speeds. Typical clean stall speed: 50 knots (check POH for exact speed). Typical approach speed: 65-70 knots (check POH for exact speed). Typical stall warning: 5-10 knots before stall (check POH for exact speed). Use this to plan the demonstration.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll use this demonstration to teach students why proper stall recovery is critical. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe flight operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: This is a demonstration to show why proper recovery is critical - students should always use proper recovery technique.'

diagrams.description: Visual representation of secondary stall recovery sequence.
diagrams.asciiArt:
SECONDARY STALL RECOVERY

INITIAL STALL:
  Stall warning
  Stall occurs
  Angle of attack exceeds critical

IMPROPER RECOVERY:
  Don't reduce angle of attack enough
  OR pull back too aggressively
  Angle of attack still high
  OR angle of attack increases again

SECONDARY STALL:
  Stall warning again
  Stall occurs again
  Immediately after initial recovery
  Angle of attack exceeds critical again

PROPER RECOVERY:
  1. Reduce angle of attack immediately and smoothly
  2. Reduce enough this time (not just a little)
  3. Don't try to save altitude
  4. Return to straight-and-level flight

RESULT:
  Altitude loss: 100-200 feet per recovery (acceptable)
  Airspeed: Increasing to cruise
  Level flight: Established
  Secondary stall: PREVENTED

KEY:
  Reduce angle of attack ENOUGH
  Don't try to save altitude
  This is a DEMONSTRATION - shows why proper recovery is critical

scenarios.explanation: When you recognize secondary stall warning, you're experiencing a secondary stall because you didn't reduce angle of attack enough during initial recovery. You must recover immediately. Reduce angle of attack immediately and smoothly (pitch forward, nose down) - this is the most critical step. Reduce enough this time (not just a little) - you need to reduce angle of attack enough to prevent secondary stall. Don't try to save altitude - some altitude loss is acceptable, preventing secondary stall is the priority. Continuing as is will result in a full secondary stall. Pulling back more will make the secondary stall worse. Just reducing a little more isn't enough - you need to reduce enough this time. The key is understanding that proper recovery requires reducing angle of attack enough, and not trying to save altitude at the expense of proper recovery.

lessonPlans.overview: Spin awareness and spins is a critical safety topic that every CFI candidate must master. A spin is an aggravated stall that results in autorotation, where the airplane descends in a corkscrew path. Spins occur when the airplane stalls in uncoordinated flight (stall + uncoordinated flight = spin entry). Spins are extremely dangerous, especially at low altitude, because they result in rapid altitude loss and are difficult to recover from. The recovery technique is PARE: Power idle, Ailerons neutral, Rudder opposite to spin, Elevator forward. This lesson covers spin awareness (understanding how spins occur and how to prevent them) and spin demonstration (entering and recovering from spins). CFI candidates must master this to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of spin aerodynamics and prepares students to recognize and avoid spins. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of spin awareness and spin procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering spin awareness and spins - a critical safety topic that every CFI candidate must master. A spin is an aggravated stall that results in autorotation, where the airplane descends in a corkscrew path. Spins occur when the airplane stalls in uncoordinated flight - stall plus uncoordinated flight equals spin entry. Spins are extremely dangerous, especially at low altitude, because they result in rapid altitude loss and are difficult to recover from. The recovery technique is PARE: Power idle, Ailerons neutral, Rudder opposite to spin, Elevator forward. This lesson covers both spin awareness (understanding how spins occur and how to prevent them) and spin demonstration (entering and recovering from spins). Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Spin Awareness and Spins'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: understand spin entry conditions, understand spin phases, demonstrate spin entry and recovery using PARE, recognize and announce spin entry and recovery, explain why spins are dangerous, explain how to prevent spins, minimize altitude loss during spin and recovery (±500 feet typical), return to straight-and-level flight, and teach spin awareness and spins to students.'
Ask opening question: 'Think about a stall in uncoordinated flight. What happens? What's the difference between a stall and a spin? How do you recover from a spin?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key concept: stall plus uncoordinated flight equals spin entry. Spins are extremely dangerous because they result in rapid altitude loss and are difficult to recover from. Let's explore this systematically, starting with spin entry conditions.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 5, AC 61-67 on Stall and Spin Awareness Training, your POH for spin recovery procedures, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on spin awareness and spin procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Spin awareness and spins serve two purposes: First, it's a safety topic that teaches spin awareness (understanding how spins occur, understanding how to prevent spins, recognizing spin entry conditions). Second, it teaches spin recovery (entering and recovering from spins using PARE technique, understanding spin phases, understanding recovery procedures). The key: Spin awareness and spins teach both prevention (avoid uncoordinated stalls) and recovery (PARE technique) - this is critical for safe flight operations.'

Explain spin entry conditions: 'Spin entry requires two conditions: Stall: Angle of attack exceeds critical angle of attack, Wing stalls. Uncoordinated flight: Ball not centered, One wing more stalled than the other. When both occur simultaneously: Stall + uncoordinated flight = spin entry. The key: Spin entry requires both stall AND uncoordinated flight - if you maintain coordination during stall, spin will not occur.'

Explain spin phases: 'Spin has four phases: Entry: Stall occurs in uncoordinated flight, Autorotation begins, Airplane starts to rotate. Incipient: Autorotation develops, Airplane rotates 1-2 turns, Altitude loss begins, Recovery is still possible. Developed: Autorotation fully developed, Airplane rotates continuously, Rapid altitude loss (500-1000 feet per turn), Recovery requires proper technique. Recovery: PARE technique applied, Autorotation stops, Airplane returns to normal flight. The key: Spin phases progress from entry to developed - recovery is easier in incipient phase, more difficult in developed phase.'

Explain PARE recovery: 'PARE is the spin recovery technique. P - Power: Idle (reduce power to idle, removes thrust that can worsen spin). A - Ailerons: Neutral (center ailerons, ailerons can worsen spin). R - Rudder: Opposite to spin (apply full rudder opposite to spin direction, stops autorotation). E - Elevator: Forward (pitch forward, reduce angle of attack, breaks stall). The key: PARE - Power idle, Ailerons neutral, Rudder opposite, Elevator forward. Apply rudder opposite to spin direction first - this stops autorotation.'

Explain recovery sequence: 'Recovery sequence: First, recognize spin (autorotation, rapid altitude loss, rotation). Second, apply PARE immediately: Power idle (reduce power to idle), Ailerons neutral (center ailerons), Rudder opposite to spin (apply full rudder opposite to spin direction - this stops autorotation), Elevator forward (pitch forward, reduce angle of attack). Third, hold controls until rotation stops (autorotation stops, rotation slows, then stops). Fourth, recover from dive (pitch up smoothly, level wings, return to level flight). Fifth, return to straight-and-level flight. The key: Apply PARE immediately - rudder opposite to spin direction stops autorotation, then elevator forward breaks stall.'

Explain why spins are dangerous: 'Spins are extremely dangerous because: Rapid altitude loss: 500-1000 feet per turn in developed spin, At low altitude, spin is often fatal, No time to recover. Disorientation: Rapid rotation causes disorientation, Difficult to determine spin direction, Difficult to apply correct recovery. Recovery difficulty: Requires proper technique (PARE), Incorrect technique can worsen spin, Recovery takes time. The key: Spins are extremely dangerous, especially at low altitude - rapid altitude loss and disorientation make recovery difficult.'

Explain how to prevent spins: 'Prevent spins by: Maintaining coordination during stalls (ball centered, prevents uncoordinated flight), Avoiding uncoordinated stalls (cross-controlled stalls lead to spin entry), Recognizing stall warning (recover before stall occurs), Proper stall recovery (reduce angle of attack, maintain coordination). The key: Prevent spins by maintaining coordination during stalls - if you maintain coordination, spin will not occur even if you stall.'

Explain entry technique: 'Entry technique: First, perform 90° clearing turns (minimum) to check for traffic. Second, establish cruise flight at appropriate altitude (minimum 5000 AGL for practice, higher is better - spins require significant altitude). Third, establish uncoordinated flight (ball deflected, cross-controlled, or uncoordinated turn). Fourth, induce stall in uncoordinated flight (increase pitch, stall occurs, uncoordinated flight causes spin entry). Fifth, recognize spin entry (autorotation begins, rotation starts, rapid altitude loss begins). The key: Enter gradually - establish uncoordinated flight, then induce stall, spin entry occurs.'

Explain spin recognition: 'Spin recognition is critical. Signs of spin entry: Autorotation (airplane rotates around vertical axis), Rapid altitude loss (500-1000 feet per turn), Rotation (continuous rotation, difficult to stop), Disorientation (rapid rotation causes disorientation). When you recognize spin: Announce: 'Spin entry' or 'Autorotation' or 'Spin', Apply PARE immediately. The key: Recognize spin immediately and apply PARE immediately - delay makes recovery more difficult.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not applying rudder opposite to spin (spin continues, recovery delayed), Applying aileron (worsens spin, delays recovery), Not reducing power (thrust can worsen spin), Not reducing angle of attack enough (stall continues, spin continues), Delayed recovery (more altitude loss, more difficult recovery), Not recognizing spin direction (applies wrong rudder, worsens spin). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH spin recovery: 'Let's check your POH for spin recovery procedures. Some aircraft have specific spin recovery procedures - check your POH. Typical recovery: PARE technique. Use this to plan spin recovery.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical safety topic. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe flight operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Spins are extremely dangerous, especially at low altitude - always maintain adequate altitude for spin practice.'

teachingScript.phase: Demonstration - Spin Entry and Recovery (15 minutes)
instructorActions: Pre-maneuver briefing: 'Before we perform spin entry and recovery, let me walk you through what I'll be doing. I'll perform 90° clearing turns, establish cruise flight at high altitude, establish uncoordinated flight, induce stall in uncoordinated flight, recognize spin entry, then recover using PARE technique. Watch my control inputs and listen to my narration. Spins require significant altitude - we'll practice at 5,500 feet AGL.'

Perform clearing turns: 'Performing 90° clearing turns... turning left 90°... scanning for traffic... turning right 90°... scanning for traffic... area is clear. Always clear the area before spins - spins require significant altitude.'

Establish cruise: 'Establishing cruise flight... cruise power 2300 RPM... cruise airspeed 110 knots... altitude 5,500 feet AGL... straight-and-level established. We need high altitude for spins - spins result in rapid altitude loss.'

Establish uncoordinated flight: 'Establishing uncoordinated flight to demonstrate spin entry... applying left aileron and right rudder (cross-controlled)... ball deflected to right... uncoordinated flight established. Notice the ball is deflected - this indicates uncoordinated flight. When we stall in this condition, spin entry will occur.'

Induce stall: 'Inducing stall in uncoordinated flight... increasing pitch... angle of attack increasing... maintaining uncoordinated flight... airspeed decreasing... 100 knots... 90 knots... 80 knots... 70 knots... 65 knots... approaching stall...'

Spin entry: 'Stall warning! I hear the horn... feeling buffet... controls getting mushy... stall occurs in uncoordinated flight... SPIN ENTRY! Autorotation begins... rotation starting... rapid altitude loss beginning... altitude 5,400 feet... 5,300 feet... rotation continuing... this is spin entry - stall plus uncoordinated flight equals spin.'

PARE recovery: 'Recovering using PARE... P - Power idle (reducing power to idle)... A - Ailerons neutral (centering ailerons)... R - Rudder opposite to spin (applying full right rudder - spin is to left, so opposite is right)... E - Elevator forward (pitching forward, reducing angle of attack)... holding controls... rotation slowing... rotation stopping... autorotation stopped... altitude 4,800 feet (lost 700 feet)... recovering from dive... pitching up smoothly... leveling wings... returning to straight-and-level flight... altitude 4,700 feet... airspeed increasing... 80 knots... 90 knots... 100 knots... 110 knots... cruise speed established... recovery complete.'

Explain technique: 'Notice how the spin occurred because we stalled in uncoordinated flight - stall plus uncoordinated flight equals spin entry. I applied PARE immediately: Power idle, Ailerons neutral, Rudder opposite to spin (right rudder for left spin), Elevator forward. The rudder opposite to spin direction stopped the autorotation, then the elevator forward broke the stall. Altitude loss was 700 feet - typical for a developed spin. The key was recognizing spin entry immediately and applying PARE correctly - rudder opposite to spin direction stops autorotation.'

diagrams.title: Spin Recovery (PARE)
diagrams.description: Visual representation of spin recovery using PARE technique.
diagrams.asciiArt:
SPIN RECOVERY (PARE)

SPIN ENTRY:
  Stall + Uncoordinated flight
  Autorotation begins
  Rotation starts
  Rapid altitude loss

PARE RECOVERY:
  P - Power: Idle (removes thrust)
  A - Ailerons: Neutral (ailerons can worsen spin)
  R - Rudder: Opposite to spin (stops autorotation)
    If spin is to left, apply RIGHT rudder
    If spin is to right, apply LEFT rudder
  E - Elevator: Forward (breaks stall)

HOLD CONTROLS:
  Until rotation stops
  Autorotation stops
  Rotation slows, then stops

RECOVER FROM DIVE:
  Pitch up smoothly
  Level wings
  Return to straight-and-level flight

RESULT:
  Altitude loss: 500-1000 feet per turn (typical)
  Airspeed: Increasing to cruise
  Level flight: Established
  Spin: RECOVERED

KEY:
  Rudder opposite to spin stops autorotation
  Apply PARE immediately

diagrams.asciiArt:
SPIN ENTRY CONDITIONS

REQUIRES BOTH:
  1. STALL
     Angle of attack exceeds critical
     Wing stalls

  2. UNCOORDINATED FLIGHT
     Ball not centered
     One wing more stalled than the other

RESULT:
  Stall + Uncoordinated flight = SPIN ENTRY
  Autorotation begins
  Rotation starts
  Rapid altitude loss

PREVENTION:
  Maintain coordination during stalls
  If coordination maintained, spin will NOT occur
  Even if you stall, if coordinated, no spin

KEY:
  Both conditions required
  Maintain coordination to prevent spin

lessonPlans.overview: Straight-and-level flight using only flight instruments is a fundamental instrument flying skill that every CFI candidate must master. This maneuver requires maintaining altitude, heading, and airspeed using only flight instruments, without reference to outside visual cues. The technique requires proper instrument scan, understanding primary and supporting instruments, and recognizing and correcting deviations promptly. Straight-and-level flight (instruments) develops understanding of instrument interpretation, attitude control, and the relationship between attitude indicator, altimeter, and airspeed indicator. CFI candidates must master this maneuver to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of instrument flying fundamentals and prepares students for instrument flight training. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of straight-and-level flight (instruments) procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering straight-and-level flight using only flight instruments - a fundamental instrument flying skill. This maneuver requires maintaining altitude, heading, and airspeed using only flight instruments, without reference to outside visual cues. The technique requires proper instrument scan, understanding primary and supporting instruments, and recognizing and correcting deviations promptly. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Straight-and-Level Flight (Instruments)'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: maintain straight-and-level flight using only flight instruments, maintain altitude ±100 feet, maintain heading ±10°, maintain airspeed ±10 knots, use proper instrument scan technique, recognize and correct deviations promptly, explain instrument scan technique, explain relationship between instruments, and teach straight-and-level flight (instruments) to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about flying straight-and-level using only instruments. What instruments do you need to watch? How do you know if you're maintaining altitude? How do you know if you're maintaining heading? How do you know if you're maintaining airspeed?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: instrument flying requires interpreting multiple instruments simultaneously and making corrections based on instrument indications. Straight-and-level flight (instruments) teaches us to maintain altitude, heading, and airspeed using only instruments. Let's explore this systematically, starting with the purpose and instrument scan technique.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Instrument Flying Handbook Chapter 3, your POH for performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on straight-and-level flight (instruments) procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Straight-and-level flight (instruments) serves two purposes: First, it's a fundamental instrument flying skill that develops understanding of instrument interpretation (reading instruments, understanding what they mean, making corrections based on instrument indications). Second, it teaches practical skills needed for instrument flight (maintaining altitude, heading, and airspeed using only instruments, proper instrument scan, recognizing deviations). The key: Straight-and-level flight (instruments) teaches fundamental instrument flying skills - the foundation for all instrument flight.'

Explain primary instruments: 'Primary instruments for straight-and-level flight: Attitude indicator: Shows aircraft attitude (pitch and bank), Primary instrument for pitch and bank control. Altimeter: Shows altitude, Primary instrument for altitude control. Heading indicator: Shows heading, Primary instrument for heading control. Airspeed indicator: Shows airspeed, Primary instrument for airspeed control. The key: Primary instruments are the main instruments you use to control the aircraft - attitude indicator for attitude, altimeter for altitude, heading indicator for heading, airspeed indicator for airspeed.'

Explain supporting instruments: 'Supporting instruments help confirm primary instrument indications: Vertical speed indicator: Confirms altitude trend (climbing, descending, level), Supports altimeter. Turn coordinator: Confirms bank attitude and coordination, Supports attitude indicator. Compass: Confirms heading, Supports heading indicator. The key: Supporting instruments help confirm what primary instruments are telling you - they provide additional information.'

Explain instrument scan: 'Instrument scan technique: Primary scan: Focus on primary instruments (attitude indicator, altimeter, heading indicator, airspeed indicator), Scan these instruments regularly (every 2-3 seconds), Recognize deviations immediately. Supporting scan: Check supporting instruments periodically (vertical speed indicator, turn coordinator, compass), Confirm primary instrument indications, Use to verify corrections. The key: Scan primary instruments regularly, check supporting instruments periodically - this gives you complete picture of aircraft state.'

Explain maintaining altitude: 'Maintaining altitude requires: Attitude indicator: Set pitch attitude for level flight (typically level flight attitude), Use attitude indicator to maintain pitch attitude. Altimeter: Monitor altitude constantly, Recognize altitude deviations immediately (±100 feet tolerance), Correct with pitch changes (pitch up to climb, pitch down to descend). Vertical speed indicator: Confirm altitude trend (should be zero for level flight), Supports altimeter. The key: Use attitude indicator to set pitch attitude, use altimeter to monitor altitude, correct with pitch changes.'

Explain maintaining heading: 'Maintaining heading requires: Heading indicator: Monitor heading constantly, Recognize heading deviations immediately (±10° tolerance), Correct with bank changes (bank left to turn left, bank right to turn right). Turn coordinator: Confirm bank attitude and coordination, Supports heading indicator. Compass: Confirm heading, Supports heading indicator. The key: Use heading indicator to monitor heading, use attitude indicator to set bank attitude, correct with bank changes.'

Explain maintaining airspeed: 'Maintaining airspeed requires: Airspeed indicator: Monitor airspeed constantly, Recognize airspeed deviations immediately (±10 knots tolerance), Correct with power changes (increase power to increase airspeed, decrease power to decrease airspeed). Attitude indicator: Confirm pitch attitude (affects airspeed), Supports airspeed indicator. The key: Use airspeed indicator to monitor airspeed, use power to control airspeed, use attitude indicator to confirm pitch attitude.'

Explain correction technique: 'Correction technique: Recognize deviation immediately (altitude, heading, or airspeed deviation), Determine correction needed (pitch, bank, or power change), Apply correction smoothly (small corrections, don't overcorrect), Monitor instruments to confirm correction (check primary instruments), Trim to relieve control pressure (after correction is established). The key: Recognize deviation immediately, apply correction smoothly, monitor to confirm correction.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Fixating on one instrument (miss other instruments, poor control), Not scanning regularly (miss deviations, poor control), Overcorrecting (poor control, oscillations), Not recognizing deviations promptly (exceed tolerances), Poor instrument scan technique (miss information, poor control), Not using supporting instruments (miss information, poor control). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show instrument panel: 'Let's review the instrument panel. Primary instruments: Attitude indicator (center, top), Altimeter (left side), Heading indicator (top), Airspeed indicator (left side). Supporting instruments: Vertical speed indicator (left side), Turn coordinator (bottom), Compass (top). Use this to plan your instrument scan.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a fundamental instrument flying skill. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe instrument flight operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

teachingScript.phase: Guided Practice - Student First Attempt (20 minutes)
instructorActions: Encourage: 'Your airplane. I'll guide you through this. First, cover the instruments, then establish straight-and-level flight, and maintain altitude, heading, and airspeed using only instruments.'
Guide covering instruments: 'Cover the instruments... cover outside windows... now you're flying using only instruments. This simulates instrument flight conditions.'

Guide establishment: 'Establish straight-and-level flight... set pitch attitude on attitude indicator (level flight attitude)... set bank attitude on attitude indicator (wings level)... set power (cruise power 2300 RPM)... monitor altimeter (altitude 4,500 feet)... monitor heading indicator (heading 360°)... monitor airspeed indicator (airspeed 110 knots)... good. Straight-and-level established.'

Guide instrument scan: 'Now scan your instruments... attitude indicator... altimeter... heading indicator... airspeed indicator... scan regularly, every 2-3 seconds... good. Check supporting instruments periodically... vertical speed indicator... turn coordinator... good.'

Guide maintaining altitude: 'Maintaining altitude... scan altimeter... what's your altitude? Good. Check vertical speed indicator... what's your vertical speed? Good. If altitude deviates, correct with pitch... pitch up to climb, pitch down to descend... monitor altimeter to confirm correction... good.'

Guide maintaining heading: 'Maintaining heading... scan heading indicator... what's your heading? Good. Check turn coordinator... ball centered? Wings level? Good. If heading deviates, correct with bank... bank left to turn left, bank right to turn right... monitor heading indicator to confirm correction... good.'

Guide maintaining airspeed: 'Maintaining airspeed... scan airspeed indicator... what's your airspeed? Good. Check attitude indicator... pitch attitude level? Good. If airspeed deviates, correct with power... increase power to increase airspeed, decrease power to decrease airspeed... monitor airspeed indicator to confirm correction... good.'

INSTRUMENT SCAN PATTERN

PRIMARY INSTRUMENTS (Scan regularly, every 2-3 seconds):
  Attitude Indicator (Center, top)
    - Shows pitch and bank attitude
    - Primary for attitude control
  Altimeter (Left side)
    - Shows altitude
    - Primary for altitude control
  Heading Indicator (Top)
    - Shows heading

  Airspeed Indicator (Left side)
    - Shows airspeed
    - Primary for airspeed control

SUPPORTING INSTRUMENTS (Check periodically):
  Vertical Speed Indicator (Left side)
    - Shows altitude trend
    - Supports altimeter
  Turn Coordinator (Bottom)
    - Shows bank attitude and coordination
    - Supports attitude indicator
  Compass (Top)
    - Shows heading
    - Supports heading indicator

SCAN TECHNIQUE:
  Scan primary instruments regularly
  Check supporting instruments periodically
  Recognize deviations immediately
  Correct smoothly

KEY:
  Don't fixate on one instrument
  Scan all primary instruments regularly

diagrams.title: Straight-and-Level Flight (Instruments) Control
diagrams.description: Illustration showing how to maintain altitude, heading, and airspeed using instruments.
diagrams.asciiArt:
STRAIGHT-AND-LEVEL FLIGHT (INSTRUMENTS) CONTROL

MAINTAINING ALTITUDE:
  Primary: Altimeter (monitor altitude)
  Supporting: Vertical speed indicator (altitude trend)
  Control: Attitude indicator (set pitch attitude)
  Correction: Pitch changes (pitch up to climb, pitch down to descend)
  Tolerance: ±100 feet

MAINTAINING HEADING:
  Primary: Heading indicator (monitor heading)
  Supporting: Turn coordinator (bank attitude), Compass (heading)
  Control: Attitude indicator (set bank attitude)
  Correction: Bank changes (bank left to turn left, bank right to turn right)
  Tolerance: ±10°

MAINTAINING AIRSPEED:
  Primary: Airspeed indicator (monitor airspeed)
  Supporting: Attitude indicator (pitch attitude)
  Control: Power (throttle)
  Correction: Power changes (increase power to increase airspeed, decrease power to decrease airspeed)
  Tolerance: ±10 knots

KEY:
  Use primary instruments to monitor
  Use attitude indicator and power to control
  Recognize deviations immediately
  Correct smoothly

lessonPlans.overview: Constant airspeed climbs using only flight instruments is a fundamental instrument flying skill that builds on straight-and-level flight. This maneuver requires establishing and maintaining a constant airspeed climb using only flight instruments, without reference to outside visual cues. The technique requires proper instrument scan, understanding primary and supporting instruments for climbs, and recognizing and correcting deviations promptly. Constant airspeed climbs develop understanding of instrument interpretation during climbs, attitude control, and the relationship between attitude indicator, airspeed indicator, and vertical speed indicator. CFI candidates must master this maneuver to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of instrument flying fundamentals and prepares students for instrument flight training. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of constant airspeed climb procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering constant airspeed climbs using only flight instruments - a fundamental instrument flying skill that builds on straight-and-level flight. This maneuver requires establishing and maintaining a constant airspeed climb using only flight instruments, without reference to outside visual cues. The technique requires proper instrument scan, understanding primary and supporting instruments for climbs, and recognizing and correcting deviations promptly. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Constant Airspeed Climbs'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: establish constant airspeed climb using only instruments, maintain climb airspeed ±10 knots, maintain climb rate, maintain heading ±10° during climb, use proper instrument scan technique, recognize and correct deviations promptly, explain instrument scan technique for climbs, explain relationship between instruments during climbs, and teach constant airspeed climbs to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about climbing at a constant airspeed using only instruments. What instruments do you need to watch? How do you maintain climb airspeed? How do you maintain climb rate? How do you maintain heading during climb?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: climbing at constant airspeed requires coordinating pitch attitude, power, and bank attitude using only instruments. Constant airspeed climbs teach us to maintain climb airspeed, climb rate, and heading using only instruments. Let's explore this systematically, starting with the purpose and instrument scan technique for climbs.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Instrument Flying Handbook Chapter 3, your POH for climb performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on constant airspeed climb procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Constant airspeed climbs serve two purposes: First, they're a fundamental instrument flying skill that develops understanding of instrument interpretation during climbs (reading instruments, understanding what they mean, making corrections based on instrument indications). Second, they teach practical skills needed for instrument flight (maintaining climb airspeed, climb rate, and heading using only instruments, proper instrument scan, recognizing deviations). The key: Constant airspeed climbs teach fundamental instrument flying skills for climbs - essential for instrument flight.'

Explain primary instruments for climbs: 'Primary instruments for constant airspeed climbs: Attitude indicator: Shows aircraft attitude (pitch and bank), Primary instrument for pitch and bank control during climb. Airspeed indicator: Shows airspeed, Primary instrument for airspeed control during climb. Vertical speed indicator: Shows climb rate, Primary instrument for climb rate control. Heading indicator: Shows heading, Primary instrument for heading control during climb. The key: Primary instruments for climbs are attitude indicator (attitude), airspeed indicator (airspeed), vertical speed indicator (climb rate), heading indicator (heading).'

Explain supporting instruments: 'Supporting instruments help confirm primary instrument indications: Altimeter: Confirms altitude change (climbing), Supports vertical speed indicator. Turn coordinator: Confirms bank attitude and coordination, Supports attitude indicator. Compass: Confirms heading, Supports heading indicator. The key: Supporting instruments help confirm what primary instruments are telling you - they provide additional information.'

Explain instrument scan for climbs: 'Instrument scan technique for climbs: Primary scan: Focus on primary instruments (attitude indicator, airspeed indicator, vertical speed indicator, heading indicator), Scan these instruments regularly (every 2-3 seconds), Recognize deviations immediately. Supporting scan: Check supporting instruments periodically (altimeter, turn coordinator, compass), Confirm primary instrument indications, Use to verify corrections. The key: Scan primary instruments regularly, check supporting instruments periodically - this gives you complete picture of aircraft state during climb.'

Explain establishing climb: 'Establishing constant airspeed climb: First, determine climb airspeed (typically best rate of climb speed, check POH - typically 70-80 knots for most aircraft). Second, increase power to climb power (typically full power or recommended climb power, check POH - typically 2500-2700 RPM). Third, set climb attitude on attitude indicator (pitch up to climb attitude, typically 5-10° nose up). Fourth, monitor airspeed indicator (airspeed should stabilize at climb airspeed). Fifth, monitor vertical speed indicator (climb rate should stabilize). Sixth, maintain heading on heading indicator. The key: Establish climb by increasing power, setting climb attitude, then monitoring airspeed and climb rate.'

Explain maintaining climb airspeed: 'Maintaining climb airspeed requires: Airspeed indicator: Monitor airspeed constantly, Recognize airspeed deviations immediately (±10 knots tolerance), Correct with pitch changes (pitch up to decrease airspeed, pitch down to increase airspeed - opposite of level flight). Attitude indicator: Set pitch attitude for climb, Supports airspeed indicator. Power: Set climb power, Supports airspeed indicator. The key: Use airspeed indicator to monitor airspeed, use pitch attitude to control airspeed during climb (pitch up slows airspeed, pitch down increases airspeed).'

Explain maintaining climb rate: 'Maintaining climb rate requires: Vertical speed indicator: Monitor climb rate constantly, Recognize climb rate deviations immediately, Correct with power changes (increase power to increase climb rate, decrease power to decrease climb rate). Attitude indicator: Set pitch attitude for climb, Supports vertical speed indicator. Altimeter: Confirm altitude change (climbing), Supports vertical speed indicator. The key: Use vertical speed indicator to monitor climb rate, use power to control climb rate (increase power increases climb rate, decrease power decreases climb rate).'

Explain maintaining heading during climb: 'Maintaining heading during climb requires: Heading indicator: Monitor heading constantly, Recognize heading deviations immediately (±10° tolerance), Correct with bank changes (bank left to turn left, bank right to turn right). Attitude indicator: Set bank attitude, Supports heading indicator. Turn coordinator: Confirm bank attitude and coordination, Supports heading indicator. The key: Use heading indicator to monitor heading, use attitude indicator to set bank attitude, correct with bank changes.'

Explain correction technique: 'Correction technique: Recognize deviation immediately (airspeed, climb rate, or heading deviation), Determine correction needed (pitch, power, or bank change), Apply correction smoothly (small corrections, don't overcorrect), Monitor instruments to confirm correction (check primary instruments), Trim to relieve control pressure (after correction is established). The key: Recognize deviation immediately, apply correction smoothly, monitor to confirm correction.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Fixating on one instrument (miss other instruments, poor control), Not scanning regularly (miss deviations, poor control), Overcorrecting (poor control, oscillations), Not recognizing deviations promptly (exceed tolerances), Poor instrument scan technique (miss information, poor control), Not using supporting instruments (miss information, poor control), Confusing pitch and power control (pitch controls airspeed, power controls climb rate). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH climb performance: 'Let's check your POH for climb performance. Typical climb airspeed: 70-80 knots (best rate of climb speed, check POH for exact speed). Typical climb power: 2500-2700 RPM or full power (check POH for exact setting). Typical climb rate: 500-700 feet per minute (varies with aircraft, weight, altitude). Use this to plan your constant airspeed climbs.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a fundamental instrument flying skill. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe instrument flight operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

teachingScript.phase: Guided Practice - Student First Attempt (20 minutes)
instructorActions: Encourage: 'Your airplane. I'll guide you through this. First, cover the instruments, then establish constant airspeed climb, and maintain climb airspeed, climb rate, and heading using only instruments.'
Guide covering instruments: 'Cover the instruments... cover outside windows... now you're flying using only instruments. This simulates instrument flight conditions.'

Guide establishment: 'Establish constant airspeed climb... increase power to climb power (2500 RPM)... set climb attitude on attitude indicator (pitch up, 5° nose up)... monitor airspeed indicator... airspeed decreasing... 100 knots... 90 knots... 80 knots... 75 knots... climb airspeed 75 knots established... monitor vertical speed indicator... climb rate 600 feet per minute... monitor heading indicator... heading 360°... good. Constant airspeed climb established.'

Guide instrument scan: 'Now scan your instruments... attitude indicator... airspeed indicator... vertical speed indicator... heading indicator... scan regularly, every 2-3 seconds... good. Check supporting instruments periodically... altimeter... turn coordinator... good.'

Guide maintaining climb airspeed: 'Maintaining climb airspeed... scan airspeed indicator... what's your airspeed? Good. Check attitude indicator... what's your pitch attitude? Good. If airspeed deviates, correct with pitch... pitch down to increase airspeed, pitch up to decrease airspeed... monitor airspeed indicator to confirm correction... good.'

Guide maintaining climb rate: 'Maintaining climb rate... scan vertical speed indicator... what's your climb rate? Good. Check altimeter... altitude increasing? Good. If climb rate deviates, correct with power... increase power to increase climb rate, decrease power to decrease climb rate... monitor vertical speed indicator to confirm correction... good.'

Guide maintaining heading: 'Maintaining heading... scan heading indicator... what's your heading? Good. Check turn coordinator... ball centered? Wings level? Good. If heading deviates, correct with bank... bank left to turn left, bank right to turn right... monitor heading indicator to confirm correction... good.'

If confusing pitch and power: 'I notice you're using power to correct airspeed - remember, during climbs, pitch controls airspeed (pitch down increases airspeed, pitch up decreases airspeed), and power controls climb rate (increase power increases climb rate). diagrams.title: Constant Airspeed Climb Control
diagrams.description: Visual representation of how to maintain climb airspeed, climb rate, and heading using instruments.
diagrams.asciiArt:
CONSTANT AIRSPEED CLIMB CONTROL

ESTABLISHING CLIMB:
  Increase power to climb power (2500 RPM)
  Set climb attitude on attitude indicator (5° nose up)
  Monitor airspeed indicator (climb airspeed 75 knots)
  Monitor vertical speed indicator (climb rate 600 fpm)
  Monitor heading indicator (heading 360°)

MAINTAINING CLIMB AIRSPEED:
  Primary: Airspeed indicator (monitor airspeed)
  Control: Attitude indicator (set pitch attitude)
  Correction: Pitch changes
    Pitch DOWN to INCREASE airspeed
    Pitch UP to DECREASE airspeed
  (Opposite of level flight)
  Tolerance: ±10 knots

MAINTAINING CLIMB RATE:
  Primary: Vertical speed indicator (monitor climb rate)
  Control: Power (throttle)
  Correction: Power changes
    Increase power to INCREASE climb rate
    Decrease power to DECREASE climb rate

MAINTAINING HEADING:
  Primary: Heading indicator (monitor heading)
  Control: Attitude indicator (set bank attitude)
  Correction: Bank changes
    Bank left to turn left
    Bank right to turn right
  Tolerance: ±10°

KEY:
  Pitch controls AIRSPEED
  Power controls CLIMB RATE
  Don't confuse them!
keyPoints: Pitch controls airspeed during climbs (pitch down increases airspeed)
Power controls climb rate (increase power increases climb rate)
Don't confuse pitch and power - pitch for airspeed, power for climb rate
Maintain heading using bank attitude

scenarios.correct: Correct with pitch: Pitch down slightly to increase airspeed
scenarios.explanation: When you recognize an airspeed deviation during climb, you must correct it promptly. Airspeed is 3 knots slow (within tolerance, but should be corrected). During climbs, pitch controls airspeed - pitch down to increase airspeed, pitch up to decrease airspeed (opposite of level flight). Don't use power to correct airspeed - power controls climb rate, not airspeed. Don't wait for it to correct itself - make the correction. lessonPlans.overview: Constant airspeed descents using only flight instruments is a fundamental instrument flying skill that builds on constant airspeed climbs. This maneuver requires establishing and maintaining a constant airspeed descent using only flight instruments, without reference to outside visual cues. The technique requires proper instrument scan, understanding primary and supporting instruments for descents, and recognizing and correcting deviations promptly. Constant airspeed descents develop understanding of instrument interpretation during descents, attitude control, and the relationship between attitude indicator, airspeed indicator, and vertical speed indicator. CFI candidates must master this maneuver to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of instrument flying fundamentals and prepares students for instrument flight training. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of constant airspeed descent procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering constant airspeed descents using only flight instruments - a fundamental instrument flying skill that builds on constant airspeed climbs. This maneuver requires establishing and maintaining a constant airspeed descent using only flight instruments, without reference to outside visual cues. The technique requires proper instrument scan, understanding primary and supporting instruments for descents, and recognizing and correcting deviations promptly. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Constant Airspeed Descents'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: establish constant airspeed descent using only instruments, maintain descent airspeed ±10 knots, maintain descent rate, maintain heading ±10° during descent, use proper instrument scan technique, recognize and correct deviations promptly, explain instrument scan technique for descents, explain relationship between instruments during descents, and teach constant airspeed descents to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about descending at a constant airspeed using only instruments. What instruments do you need to watch? How do you maintain descent airspeed? How do you maintain descent rate? How do you maintain heading during descent?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: descending at constant airspeed requires coordinating pitch attitude, power, and bank attitude using only instruments. Constant airspeed descents teach us to maintain descent airspeed, descent rate, and heading using only instruments. Let's explore this systematically, starting with the purpose and instrument scan technique for descents.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Instrument Flying Handbook Chapter 3, your POH for descent performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on constant airspeed descent procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Constant airspeed descents serve two purposes: First, they're a fundamental instrument flying skill that develops understanding of instrument interpretation during descents (reading instruments, understanding what they mean, making corrections based on instrument indications). Second, they teach practical skills needed for instrument flight (maintaining descent airspeed, descent rate, and heading using only instruments, proper instrument scan, recognizing deviations). The key: Constant airspeed descents teach fundamental instrument flying skills for descents - essential for instrument flight.'

Explain primary instruments for descents: 'Primary instruments for constant airspeed descents: Attitude indicator: Shows aircraft attitude (pitch and bank), Primary instrument for pitch and bank control during descent. Airspeed indicator: Shows airspeed, Primary instrument for airspeed control during descent. Vertical speed indicator: Shows descent rate, Primary instrument for descent rate control. Heading indicator: Shows heading, Primary instrument for heading control during descent. The key: Primary instruments for descents are attitude indicator (attitude), airspeed indicator (airspeed), vertical speed indicator (descent rate), heading indicator (heading).'

Explain supporting instruments: 'Supporting instruments help confirm primary instrument indications: Altimeter: Confirms altitude change (descending), Supports vertical speed indicator. Turn coordinator: Confirms bank attitude and coordination, Supports attitude indicator. Compass: Confirms heading, Supports heading indicator. The key: Supporting instruments help confirm what primary instruments are telling you - they provide additional information.'

Explain instrument scan for descents: 'Instrument scan technique for descents: Primary scan: Focus on primary instruments (attitude indicator, airspeed indicator, vertical speed indicator, heading indicator), Scan these instruments regularly (every 2-3 seconds), Recognize deviations immediately. Supporting scan: Check supporting instruments periodically (altimeter, turn coordinator, compass), Confirm primary instrument indications, Use to verify corrections. The key: Scan primary instruments regularly, check supporting instruments periodically - this gives you complete picture of aircraft state during descent.'

Explain establishing descent: 'Establishing constant airspeed descent: First, determine descent airspeed (typically approach speed or descent speed, check POH - typically 90-100 knots for most aircraft). Second, reduce power to descent power (typically idle or recommended descent power, check POH - typically 1500-1800 RPM). Third, set descent attitude on attitude indicator (pitch down to descent attitude, typically 2-5° nose down). Fourth, monitor airspeed indicator (airspeed should stabilize at descent airspeed). Fifth, monitor vertical speed indicator (descent rate should stabilize, typically 500-700 feet per minute). Sixth, maintain heading on heading indicator. The key: Establish descent by reducing power, setting descent attitude, then monitoring airspeed and descent rate.'

Explain maintaining descent airspeed: 'Maintaining descent airspeed requires: Airspeed indicator: Monitor airspeed constantly, Recognize airspeed deviations immediately (±10 knots tolerance), Correct with pitch changes (pitch up to decrease airspeed, pitch down to increase airspeed - same as level flight). Attitude indicator: Set pitch attitude for descent, Supports airspeed indicator. Power: Set descent power, Supports airspeed indicator. The key: Use airspeed indicator to monitor airspeed, use pitch attitude to control airspeed during descent (pitch up slows airspeed, pitch down increases airspeed - same as level flight).'

Explain maintaining descent rate: 'Maintaining descent rate requires: Vertical speed indicator: Monitor descent rate constantly, Recognize descent rate deviations immediately, Correct with power changes (increase power to decrease descent rate, decrease power to increase descent rate). Attitude indicator: Set pitch attitude for descent, Supports vertical speed indicator. Altimeter: Confirm altitude change (descending), Supports vertical speed indicator. The key: Use vertical speed indicator to monitor descent rate, use power to control descent rate (increase power decreases descent rate, decrease power increases descent rate).'

Explain maintaining heading during descent: 'Maintaining heading during descent requires: Heading indicator: Monitor heading constantly, Recognize heading deviations immediately (±10° tolerance), Correct with bank changes (bank left to turn left, bank right to turn right). Attitude indicator: Set bank attitude, Supports heading indicator. Turn coordinator: Confirm bank attitude and coordination, Supports heading indicator. The key: Use heading indicator to monitor heading, use attitude indicator to set bank attitude, correct with bank changes.'

Explain correction technique: 'Correction technique: Recognize deviation immediately (airspeed, descent rate, or heading deviation), Determine correction needed (pitch, power, or bank change), Apply correction smoothly (small corrections, don't overcorrect), Monitor instruments to confirm correction (check primary instruments), Trim to relieve control pressure (after correction is established). The key: Recognize deviation immediately, apply correction smoothly, monitor to confirm correction.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Fixating on one instrument (miss other instruments, poor control), Not scanning regularly (miss deviations, poor control), Overcorrecting (poor control, oscillations), Not recognizing deviations promptly (exceed tolerances), Poor instrument scan technique (miss information, poor control), Not using supporting instruments (miss information, poor control), Confusing pitch and power control (pitch controls airspeed, power controls descent rate). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH descent performance: 'Let's check your POH for descent performance. Typical descent airspeed: 90-100 knots (approach speed or descent speed, check POH for exact speed). Typical descent power: 1500-1800 RPM or idle (check POH for exact setting). Typical descent rate: 500-700 feet per minute (varies with aircraft, weight, altitude). Use this to plan your constant airspeed descents.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a fundamental instrument flying skill. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe instrument flight operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

diagrams.title: Constant Airspeed Descent Control
diagrams.description: Visual representation of how to maintain descent airspeed, descent rate, and heading using instruments.
diagrams.asciiArt:
CONSTANT AIRSPEED DESCENT CONTROL

ESTABLISHING DESCENT:
  Reduce power to descent power (1500 RPM)
  Set descent attitude on attitude indicator (3° nose down)
  Monitor airspeed indicator (descent airspeed 90 knots)
  Monitor vertical speed indicator (descent rate 600 fpm)
  Monitor heading indicator (heading 360°)

MAINTAINING DESCENT AIRSPEED:
  Primary: Airspeed indicator (monitor airspeed)
  Control: Attitude indicator (set pitch attitude)
  Correction: Pitch changes
    Pitch UP to DECREASE airspeed
    Pitch DOWN to INCREASE airspeed
  (Same as level flight)
  Tolerance: ±10 knots

MAINTAINING DESCENT RATE:
  Primary: Vertical speed indicator (monitor descent rate)
  Control: Power (throttle)
  Correction: Power changes
    Increase power to DECREASE descent rate
    Decrease power to INCREASE descent rate

MAINTAINING HEADING:
  Primary: Heading indicator (monitor heading)
  Control: Attitude indicator (set bank attitude)
  Correction: Bank changes
    Bank left to turn left
    Bank right to turn right
  Tolerance: ±10°

KEY:
  Pitch controls AIRSPEED (same as level flight)
  Power controls DESCENT RATE
  Don't confuse them!
keyPoints: Pitch controls airspeed during descents (same as level flight - pitch up decreases airspeed)
Power controls descent rate (increase power decreases descent rate)
Don't confuse pitch and power - pitch for airspeed, power for descent rate
Maintain heading using bank attitude

scenarios.situation: You're maintaining a constant airspeed descent at 90 knots. You scan your airspeed indicator and notice airspeed is 93 knots (3 knots fast). What should you do?
options: Continue as is - it's only 3 knots fast
Correct with pitch: Pitch up slightly to decrease airspeed
Decrease power to decrease airspeed
