scenarios.correct: Correct with pitch: Pitch up slightly to decrease airspeed
scenarios.explanation: When you recognize an airspeed deviation during descent, you must correct it promptly. Airspeed is 3 knots fast (within tolerance, but should be corrected). During descents, pitch controls airspeed - pitch up to decrease airspeed, pitch down to increase airspeed (same as level flight). Don't use power to correct airspeed - power controls descent rate, not airspeed. Don't wait for it to correct itself - make the correction. The key is understanding that during descents, pitch controls airspeed (same as level flight) and power controls descent rate - don't confuse them.

lessonPlans.overview: Turns to headings using only flight instruments is a fundamental instrument flying skill that builds on straight-and-level flight. This maneuver requires turning to specific headings using only flight instruments, while maintaining altitude and airspeed, without reference to outside visual cues. The technique requires proper instrument scan, understanding primary and supporting instruments for turns, using proper bank angle (standard rate turn: 3° per second, typically 15-20° bank), and rolling out on the specified heading. Turns to headings develop understanding of instrument interpretation during turns, attitude control, and the relationship between attitude indicator, heading indicator, and turn coordinator. CFI candidates must master this maneuver to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of instrument flying fundamentals and prepares students for instrument flight training. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of turns to headings procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering turns to headings using only flight instruments - a fundamental instrument flying skill that builds on straight-and-level flight. This maneuver requires turning to specific headings using only flight instruments, while maintaining altitude and airspeed, without reference to outside visual cues. The technique requires proper instrument scan, understanding primary and supporting instruments for turns, using proper bank angle (standard rate turn: 3° per second, typically 15-20° bank), and rolling out on the specified heading. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Turns to Headings'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: turn to specific headings using only instruments, maintain altitude ±100 feet during turn, maintain airspeed ±10 knots during turn, use proper bank angle (standard rate turn), use proper instrument scan technique, roll out on specified heading ±10°, recognize and correct deviations promptly, explain instrument scan technique for turns, explain relationship between instruments during turns, and teach turns to headings to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about turning to a specific heading using only instruments. What instruments do you need to watch? How do you maintain altitude during the turn? How do you maintain airspeed during the turn? How do you know when to roll out?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: turning to a specific heading requires coordinating bank attitude, pitch attitude, and power using only instruments. Turns to headings teach us to maintain altitude and airspeed during turns, use proper bank angle, and roll out on the specified heading. Let's explore this systematically, starting with the purpose and instrument scan technique for turns.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Instrument Flying Handbook Chapter 3, your POH for performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on turns to headings procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Turns to headings serve two purposes: First, they're a fundamental instrument flying skill that develops understanding of instrument interpretation during turns (reading instruments, understanding what they mean, making corrections based on instrument indications). Second, they teach practical skills needed for instrument flight (maintaining altitude and airspeed during turns, using proper bank angle, rolling out on specified heading). The key: Turns to headings teach fundamental instrument flying skills for turns - essential for instrument flight.'

Explain primary instruments for turns: 'Primary instruments for turns to headings: Attitude indicator: Shows aircraft attitude (pitch and bank), Primary instrument for pitch and bank control during turn. Heading indicator: Shows heading, Primary instrument for heading control and roll-out timing. Altimeter: Shows altitude, Primary instrument for altitude control during turn. Airspeed indicator: Shows airspeed, Primary instrument for airspeed control during turn. The key: Primary instruments for turns are attitude indicator (attitude), heading indicator (heading), altimeter (altitude), airspeed indicator (airspeed).'

Explain supporting instruments: 'Supporting instruments help confirm primary instrument indications: Turn coordinator: Confirms bank attitude and turn rate (standard rate: 3° per second), Supports attitude indicator and heading indicator. Vertical speed indicator: Confirms altitude trend (should be zero for level turn), Supports altimeter. Compass: Confirms heading, Supports heading indicator. The key: Supporting instruments help confirm what primary instruments are telling you - they provide additional information.'

Explain instrument scan for turns: 'Instrument scan technique for turns: Primary scan: Focus on primary instruments (attitude indicator, heading indicator, altimeter, airspeed indicator), Scan these instruments regularly (every 2-3 seconds), Recognize deviations immediately. Supporting scan: Check supporting instruments periodically (turn coordinator, vertical speed indicator, compass), Confirm primary instrument indications, Use to verify corrections. The key: Scan primary instruments regularly, check supporting instruments periodically - this gives you complete picture of aircraft state during turn.'

Explain standard rate turn: 'Standard rate turn: Turn rate: 3° per second (360° turn in 2 minutes), Bank angle: Typically 15-20° (varies with airspeed - faster airspeed requires more bank), Turn coordinator: Shows standard rate turn (small airplane wings aligned with turn rate marks), Use turn coordinator to establish and maintain standard rate turn. The key: Standard rate turn is 3° per second - use turn coordinator to establish and maintain standard rate turn.'

Explain entering turn: 'Entering turn to heading: First, determine target heading (e.g., turn to heading 090°). Second, determine turn direction (shortest turn - if current heading is 360° and target is 090°, turn right 90°). Third, establish standard rate turn (bank 15-20°, use turn coordinator to confirm standard rate). Fourth, maintain altitude during turn (use attitude indicator to set pitch attitude, use altimeter to monitor altitude). Fifth, maintain airspeed during turn (use airspeed indicator to monitor airspeed, use power to control airspeed). Sixth, monitor heading indicator (heading changing, approaching target heading). The key: Enter turn by establishing standard rate turn, then maintain altitude and airspeed while monitoring heading.'

Explain maintaining altitude during turn: 'Maintaining altitude during turn requires: Altimeter: Monitor altitude constantly, Recognize altitude deviations immediately (±100 feet tolerance), Correct with pitch changes (pitch up to climb, pitch down to descend). Attitude indicator: Set pitch attitude for level turn, Supports altimeter. Vertical speed indicator: Confirm altitude trend (should be zero for level turn), Supports altimeter. The key: Use altimeter to monitor altitude, use attitude indicator to set pitch attitude, correct with pitch changes.'

Explain maintaining airspeed during turn: 'Maintaining airspeed during turn requires: Airspeed indicator: Monitor airspeed constantly, Recognize airspeed deviations immediately (±10 knots tolerance), Correct with power changes (increase power to increase airspeed, decrease power to decrease airspeed). Attitude indicator: Confirm pitch attitude (affects airspeed), Supports airspeed indicator. The key: Use airspeed indicator to monitor airspeed, use power to control airspeed, use attitude indicator to confirm pitch attitude.'

Explain rolling out: 'Rolling out on heading: First, determine roll-out point (typically ½ standard rate turn before target heading - if standard rate is 3° per second, roll out 1.5° before target heading, or use turn coordinator to estimate). Second, begin rolling out (reduce bank angle smoothly, use turn coordinator to confirm). Third, roll wings level (attitude indicator shows wings level, turn coordinator shows no turn). Fourth, check heading indicator (should be on or very close to target heading). Fifth, correct heading if needed (small bank correction if heading is off). The key: Roll out before reaching target heading - typically ½ standard rate turn before target heading.'

Explain correction technique: 'Correction technique: Recognize deviation immediately (altitude, airspeed, or heading deviation), Determine correction needed (pitch, power, or bank change), Apply correction smoothly (small corrections, don't overcorrect), Monitor instruments to confirm correction (check primary instruments), Trim to relieve control pressure (after correction is established). The key: Recognize deviation immediately, apply correction smoothly, monitor to confirm correction.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Fixating on heading indicator (miss altitude and airspeed, poor control), Not scanning regularly (miss deviations, poor control), Overcorrecting (poor control, oscillations), Not recognizing deviations promptly (exceed tolerances), Poor instrument scan technique (miss information, poor control), Not using proper bank angle (too steep or too shallow, poor turn rate), Rolling out too late or too early (miss target heading), Not maintaining altitude or airspeed during turn (poor control). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show turn coordinator: 'Let's review the turn coordinator. Standard rate turn: Small airplane wings aligned with turn rate marks (3° per second), Use turn coordinator to establish and maintain standard rate turn. Bank angle: Typically 15-20° for standard rate turn (varies with airspeed). Use this to plan your turns to headings.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a fundamental instrument flying skill. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe instrument flight operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching.'

diagrams.asciiArt:
TURN TO HEADING CONTROL

ESTABLISHING TURN:
  Determine turn direction (shortest turn)

  Use turn coordinator (3° per second)
  Maintain altitude and airspeed

  Primary: Airspeed indicator (monitor airspeed)

  Control: Power (control airspeed)
  Supporting: Turn coordinator (confirm turn rate)
  Supporting: Vertical speed indicator (confirm altitude trend)

ROLLING OUT:
  Roll out ½ standard rate turn before target
  (Approximately 1.5° before target heading)
  Reduce bank angle smoothly
  Roll wings level
  Check heading indicator
  Correct heading if needed

TOLERANCES:
  Altitude: ±100 feet
  Airspeed: ±10 knots
  Heading: ±10°

  Don't fixate on heading indicator
  Scan all primary instruments regularly

lessonPlans.overview: Recovery from unusual flight attitudes using only flight instruments is a critical safety skill that every CFI candidate must master. This maneuver requires recognizing unusual flight attitudes (steep banks, unusual pitch attitudes) using only flight instruments, then recovering to straight-and-level flight using proper recovery technique. Unusual attitudes can occur due to spatial disorientation, instrument failure, or loss of situational awareness. The recovery technique depends on the type of unusual attitude: nose-high unusual attitude (reduce angle of attack, level wings), nose-low unusual attitude (reduce angle of attack, level wings, avoid excessive airspeed). Recovery from unusual attitudes develops understanding of instrument interpretation, attitude control, and the critical importance of maintaining altitude awareness. CFI candidates must master this maneuver to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of instrument flying fundamentals and prepares students to recover from unusual attitudes safely. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of recovery from unusual flight attitudes procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering recovery from unusual flight attitudes using only flight instruments - a critical safety skill. This maneuver requires recognizing unusual flight attitudes (steep banks, unusual pitch attitudes) using only flight instruments, then recovering to straight-and-level flight using proper recovery technique. Unusual attitudes can occur due to spatial disorientation, instrument failure, or loss of situational awareness. The recovery technique depends on the type of unusual attitude. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: recognize unusual flight attitude using only instruments, determine aircraft attitude from instruments, recover from unusual attitude using proper recovery technique, recover from nose-high unusual attitude, recover from nose-low unusual attitude, maintain altitude awareness during recovery, use proper instrument scan technique, explain recovery technique, explain relationship between instruments during recovery, and teach recovery from unusual flight attitudes to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about being in an unusual attitude using only instruments. How would you know you're in an unusual attitude? What instruments tell you about pitch and bank? How would you recover?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: recognizing unusual attitudes using only instruments requires interpreting multiple instruments simultaneously. Recovery from unusual attitudes teaches us to recognize unusual attitudes, determine aircraft attitude, and recover using proper technique. Let's explore this systematically, starting with the purpose and recognition technique.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Instrument Flying Handbook Chapter 3, your POH for performance data, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on recovery from unusual flight attitudes procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Recovery from unusual flight attitudes serves two purposes: First, it's a critical safety skill that develops understanding of instrument interpretation during unusual attitudes (reading instruments, understanding what they mean, making corrections based on instrument indications). Second, it teaches practical skills needed for instrument flight (recognizing unusual attitudes, determining aircraft attitude, recovering safely). The key: Recovery from unusual flight attitudes teaches critical safety skills - essential for instrument flight safety.'

Explain what unusual attitudes are: 'Unusual flight attitudes are attitudes that are not normal flight attitudes. Types: Nose-high unusual attitude: High pitch attitude (nose up), May have bank angle, Low airspeed, Climbing or descending. Nose-low unusual attitude: Low pitch attitude (nose down), May have bank angle, High airspeed, Descending rapidly. The key: Unusual attitudes are not normal flight attitudes - they require immediate recognition and recovery.'

Explain how unusual attitudes occur: 'Unusual attitudes can occur due to: Spatial disorientation: Loss of outside visual reference, Confusion about aircraft attitude, Can occur in clouds or instrument conditions. Instrument failure: Attitude indicator failure, Loss of primary attitude reference, Can cause confusion. Loss of situational awareness: Not scanning instruments regularly, Missing deviations, Can lead to unusual attitude. The key: Unusual attitudes can occur due to spatial disorientation, instrument failure, or loss of situational awareness - recognizing them immediately is critical.'

Explain recognizing unusual attitude: 'Recognizing unusual attitude requires: Attitude indicator: Check pitch attitude (nose high or nose low), Check bank attitude (wings level or banked), Primary instrument for attitude recognition. Altimeter: Check altitude trend (climbing, descending, or level), Supports attitude indicator. Airspeed indicator: Check airspeed (high, low, or normal), Supports attitude indicator. Vertical speed indicator: Check vertical speed (climbing, descending, or level), Supports attitude indicator. The key: Use attitude indicator to recognize unusual attitude, use supporting instruments to confirm.'

Explain nose-high recovery: 'Recovery from nose-high unusual attitude: First, recognize unusual attitude (attitude indicator shows nose high, may have bank). Second, reduce angle of attack immediately (pitch forward, nose down - this is the most critical step). Third, level wings (roll to level flight, use attitude indicator to confirm wings level). Fourth, return to straight-and-level flight (establish level flight attitude, maintain altitude). The key: Reduce angle of attack first, then level wings - this prevents stall and spin entry.'

Explain nose-low recovery: 'Recovery from nose-low unusual attitude: First, recognize unusual attitude (attitude indicator shows nose low, may have bank, airspeed increasing). Second, reduce angle of attack immediately (pitch up, nose up - this is the most critical step, but don't overcorrect). Third, level wings (roll to level flight, use attitude indicator to confirm wings level). Fourth, avoid excessive airspeed (monitor airspeed indicator, don't pull back too aggressively). Fifth, return to straight-and-level flight (establish level flight attitude, maintain altitude). The key: Reduce angle of attack first, then level wings, but don't overcorrect - avoid excessive airspeed and secondary stall.'

Explain recovery technique: 'Recovery technique: First, recognize unusual attitude immediately (check attitude indicator, altimeter, airspeed indicator). Second, determine aircraft attitude (pitch attitude: nose high or nose low, Bank attitude: wings level or banked). Third, apply recovery technique: Nose-high: Reduce angle of attack, level wings, Nose-low: Reduce angle of attack, level wings, avoid excessive airspeed. Fourth, monitor instruments to confirm recovery (check attitude indicator, altimeter, airspeed indicator). Fifth, return to straight-and-level flight. The key: Recognize unusual attitude immediately, determine aircraft attitude, apply proper recovery technique.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not recognizing unusual attitude promptly (delayed recovery, more altitude loss), Not determining aircraft attitude correctly (wrong recovery technique, worsens situation), Overcorrecting (poor control, oscillations, secondary stall), Not leveling wings (spin entry risk), Not maintaining altitude awareness (altitude loss, terrain risk), Poor instrument scan technique (miss information, poor control). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show attitude indicator: 'Let's review the attitude indicator. Pitch attitude: Nose high (above horizon), Nose low (below horizon), Level (on horizon). Bank attitude: Wings level (no bank), Banked left (left wing down), Banked right (right wing up). Use attitude indicator to recognize unusual attitude and determine recovery technique.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical safety skill. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe instrument flight operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Recovery from unusual attitudes is a critical safety skill - recognizing unusual attitudes immediately and recovering properly can save lives.'

diagrams.asciiArt:
RECOVERY FROM UNUSUAL FLIGHT ATTITUDES

RECOGNITION:
  Check attitude indicator (pitch and bank)
  Check altimeter (altitude trend)
  Check airspeed indicator (airspeed)
  Check vertical speed indicator (vertical speed)

DETERMINE ATTITUDE:
  Nose-high unusual attitude:
    High pitch attitude
    Low airspeed
    May have bank angle
    Climbing or descending

  Nose-low unusual attitude:
    Low pitch attitude
    High airspeed
    May have bank angle
    Descending rapidly

RECOVERY TECHNIQUE:
  Nose-high:
    1. Reduce angle of attack immediately (nose down)
    2. Level wings
    3. Return to straight-and-level flight

  Nose-low:
    1. Reduce angle of attack immediately (nose up, don't overcorrect)
    2. Level wings
    3. Avoid excessive airspeed
    4. Return to straight-and-level flight

KEY:
  Reduce angle of attack FIRST
  Then level wings
  Maintain altitude awareness

scenarios.situation: You're flying using only instruments. You check your attitude indicator and notice the nose is high (above horizon) and the right wing is down (banked right). Nose-high unusual attitude - pitch down and level wings

Continue as is - it will correct itself

lessonPlans.overview: Emergency descent is a critical emergency procedure that every CFI candidate must master. This maneuver requires rapidly descending from altitude to a lower altitude in response to an emergency situation such as cabin depressurization, fire, smoke, or other emergencies. The technique requires maintaining aircraft control, maintaining appropriate airspeed (typically redline airspeed or maximum safe airspeed), maintaining awareness of terrain and obstacles, and communicating the emergency situation to ATC. Emergency descent develops understanding of emergency procedures, decision-making under stress, and the critical importance of maintaining aircraft control during emergencies. CFI candidates must master this procedure to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of emergency procedures and prepares students to handle emergency situations safely. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of emergency descent procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering emergency descent - a critical emergency procedure. This maneuver requires rapidly descending from altitude to a lower altitude in response to an emergency situation such as cabin depressurization, fire, smoke, or other emergencies. The technique requires maintaining aircraft control, maintaining appropriate airspeed, maintaining awareness of terrain and obstacles, and communicating the emergency situation to ATC. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Emergency Descent'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: recognize emergency descent situations, execute emergency descent procedure promptly and safely, maintain aircraft control during emergency descent, maintain appropriate airspeed, maintain awareness of terrain and obstacles, communicate emergency situation to ATC, explain emergency descent procedures, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, and teach emergency descent to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about an emergency situation requiring rapid descent - like cabin depressurization or fire. What would you do? How would you descend quickly while maintaining control? What airspeed would you use? How would you communicate with ATC?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: emergency descent requires rapid descent while maintaining aircraft control and safety. Emergency descent teaches us to descend quickly and safely in response to emergencies. Let's explore this systematically, starting with when emergency descent is needed.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 17, your POH Emergency Procedures section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on emergency descent procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Emergency descent serves one critical purpose: Rapidly descend from altitude to a lower altitude in response to an emergency situation. Emergency situations requiring emergency descent: Cabin depressurization (loss of cabin pressure, need to descend to breathable altitude - typically below 10,000 feet), Fire or smoke (need to descend to lower altitude, may need to land immediately), Other emergencies (any situation requiring rapid descent). The key: Emergency descent is used when you need to descend rapidly to a lower altitude due to an emergency situation.'

Explain emergency descent procedure: 'Emergency descent procedure: First, recognize emergency situation (cabin depressurization, fire, smoke, other emergency). Second, reduce power to idle (reduce power to idle to maximize descent rate). Third, extend landing gear if below gear extension speed (typically below 150 knots, check POH - extends gear to increase drag and descent rate). Fourth, extend full flaps if below flap extension speed (typically below 110 knots, check POH - extends flaps to increase drag and descent rate). Fifth, establish emergency descent attitude (pitch down to establish descent, typically 15-20° nose down). Sixth, maintain appropriate airspeed (typically redline airspeed or maximum safe airspeed, check POH - typically 150-160 knots, do not exceed VNE). Seventh, maintain aircraft control (maintain coordination, avoid excessive bank angles). Eighth, maintain awareness of terrain and obstacles (monitor altitude, avoid terrain, maintain safe altitude). Ninth, communicate emergency to ATC (declare emergency, state intentions, request vectors if needed). The key: Emergency descent procedure requires reducing power, extending gear and flaps if appropriate, establishing descent attitude, maintaining appropriate airspeed, and communicating with ATC.'

Explain airspeed control: 'Airspeed control is critical during emergency descent. Appropriate airspeed: Typically redline airspeed or maximum safe airspeed (check POH - typically 150-160 knots), Do not exceed VNE (never exceed speed), Do not exceed VNO (maximum structural cruising speed) unless necessary. Why: Higher airspeed increases descent rate, but must not exceed structural limitations. The key: Use appropriate airspeed to maximize descent rate while staying within structural limitations - typically redline airspeed or maximum safe airspeed.'

Explain terrain awareness: 'Terrain awareness is critical during emergency descent. Maintain safe altitude: Monitor altitude constantly, Maintain minimum safe altitude (typically 2000 feet AGL minimum, higher in mountainous terrain), Avoid terrain and obstacles. Terrain clearance: Know your position, Know minimum safe altitudes, Avoid descending into terrain. The key: Maintain awareness of terrain and obstacles - emergency descent requires rapid descent, but you must maintain safe altitude.'

Explain ATC communication: 'ATC communication is critical during emergency descent. Declare emergency: Use emergency frequency (121.5 MHz) or current frequency, State: 'Mayday, Mayday, Mayday' or 'Emergency', State aircraft identification, State nature of emergency, State intentions (emergency descent to lower altitude). Request assistance: Request vectors if needed, Request priority handling, Request emergency services if needed. The key: Communicate emergency situation to ATC immediately - they can provide assistance and clear airspace.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not recognizing emergency situation promptly (delayed descent, worsens situation), Exceeding airspeed limitations (structural damage risk), Not maintaining aircraft control (loss of control risk), Not maintaining terrain awareness (terrain collision risk), Not communicating with ATC (missed assistance, airspace conflict), Not following proper procedure (inefficient descent, safety risk). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH emergency procedures: 'Let's check your POH for emergency descent procedures. Typical airspeed: Redline airspeed or maximum safe airspeed (check POH - typically 150-160 knots). Gear extension speed: Typically below 150 knots (check POH). Flap extension speed: Typically below 110 knots (check POH). Use this to plan your emergency descent.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical emergency procedure. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe emergency operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Emergency descent is a critical emergency procedure - proper execution can save lives.'

diagrams.title: Emergency Descent Procedure
diagrams.description: Visual representation of emergency descent procedure.
diagrams.asciiArt:
EMERGENCY DESCENT PROCEDURE

RECOGNIZE EMERGENCY:
  Cabin depressurization
  Fire or smoke
  Other emergency
  Need rapid descent

EXECUTE PROCEDURE:
  1. Reduce power to idle (maximize descent rate)
  2. Extend landing gear (below 150 kts - increase drag)
  3. Extend full flaps (below 110 kts - increase drag)
  4. Establish descent attitude (pitch down 15-20°)
  5. Maintain appropriate airspeed (redline, do not exceed VNE)
  6. Maintain aircraft control (coordination, avoid excessive bank)
  7. Maintain terrain awareness (monitor altitude, avoid terrain)
  8. Communicate with ATC (declare emergency, state intentions)

LEVEL OFF:
  At appropriate altitude (typically below 10,000 feet)
  Reduce descent rate
  Establish level flight
  Maintain airspeed

KEY:
  Execute promptly
  Maintain appropriate airspeed
  Maintain control and terrain awareness

lessonPlans.overview: Emergency approach and landing (simulated) is a critical emergency procedure that every CFI candidate must master. This maneuver simulates a power failure at altitude and requires executing an emergency approach and landing to a suitable landing area (airport or off-airport). The technique requires recognizing the emergency, establishing best glide airspeed, selecting a suitable landing area, planning the approach, and executing the approach and landing (simulated) while maintaining aircraft control. Emergency approach and landing develops understanding of emergency procedures, decision-making under stress, glide performance, and the critical importance of maintaining aircraft control during emergencies. CFI candidates must master this procedure to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of emergency procedures and prepares students to handle power failure emergencies safely. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of emergency approach and landing procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering emergency approach and landing (simulated) - a critical emergency procedure. This maneuver simulates a power failure at altitude and requires executing an emergency approach and landing to a suitable landing area. The technique requires recognizing the emergency, establishing best glide airspeed, selecting a suitable landing area, planning the approach, and executing the approach and landing (simulated) while maintaining aircraft control. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Emergency Approach and Landing (Simulated)'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: recognize power failure at altitude emergency situation, execute emergency approach and landing procedure (simulated), select suitable landing area, establish best glide airspeed, plan approach to selected landing area, execute approach and landing (simulated), maintain aircraft control throughout, explain emergency approach and landing procedures, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, and teach emergency approach and landing to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about a power failure at altitude - engine quits, propeller stops. What would you do? How would you select a landing area? What airspeed would you use? How would you plan your approach? How would you execute the landing?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: emergency approach and landing requires executing a safe approach and landing without engine power. Emergency approach and landing teaches us to handle power failure emergencies safely. Let's explore this systematically, starting with recognizing the emergency.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 17, your POH Emergency Procedures section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on emergency approach and landing procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Emergency approach and landing serves one critical purpose: Execute a safe approach and landing to a suitable landing area after power failure at altitude. Emergency situation: Power failure at altitude (engine quits, propeller stops, no engine power available). The key: Emergency approach and landing is used when you have a power failure at altitude and need to execute a safe approach and landing.'

Explain emergency approach and landing procedure: 'Emergency approach and landing procedure: First, recognize emergency situation (power failure at altitude - engine quits, propeller stops, no engine power). Second, establish best glide airspeed (check POH - typically 70-80 knots for most light aircraft, maintain best glide airspeed throughout approach). Third, select suitable landing area (airport preferred, off-airport if necessary - consider: size and surface, obstacles, wind direction, accessibility). Fourth, plan approach to selected landing area (determine glide path, plan base leg, plan final approach, plan touchdown point, plan go-around point if needed). Fifth, execute approach to selected landing area (maintain best glide airspeed, follow planned approach path, adjust as needed, maintain aircraft control). Sixth, execute landing (simulated) to selected landing area (flare at appropriate altitude, touchdown at selected point, maintain control during landing). The key: Emergency approach and landing procedure requires establishing best glide airspeed, selecting suitable landing area, planning the approach, and executing the approach and landing (simulated) while maintaining aircraft control.'

Explain best glide airspeed: 'Best glide airspeed is critical for emergency approach and landing. Best glide airspeed: Check POH for specific aircraft (typically 70-80 knots for most light aircraft), Maintain best glide airspeed throughout approach (unless adjusting for approach path), Best glide airspeed provides maximum glide distance. Why: Best glide airspeed provides maximum glide distance, allowing you to reach suitable landing areas. The key: Use best glide airspeed to maximize glide distance - check POH for specific aircraft, typically 70-80 knots.'

Explain landing area selection: 'Landing area selection is critical for emergency approach and landing. Airport preferred: Use airport if within glide distance, Use longest available runway, Consider wind direction. Off-airport if necessary: Consider size and surface (large, open field preferred, hard surface preferred, avoid soft or rough terrain), Consider obstacles (avoid power lines, trees, buildings, other obstacles), Consider wind direction (land into wind if possible), Consider accessibility (for emergency services). The key: Select suitable landing area - airport preferred, off-airport if necessary, consider size, surface, obstacles, wind, and accessibility.'

Explain approach planning: 'Approach planning is critical for emergency approach and landing. Determine glide path: Calculate glide distance (glide ratio typically 8:1 to 10:1, check POH), Determine if landing area is within glide distance, Plan approach path. Plan base leg: Position aircraft for base leg, Plan base leg altitude and distance, Plan turn to final. Plan final approach: Plan final approach path, Plan touchdown point, Plan approach angle. Plan go-around point: Determine point where landing is no longer possible, Plan alternative landing area if needed. The key: Plan approach carefully - determine glide path, plan base leg, plan final approach, plan touchdown point, plan go-around point.'

Explain approach execution: 'Approach execution is critical for emergency approach and landing. Maintain best glide airspeed: Maintain best glide airspeed throughout approach (unless adjusting for approach path), Monitor airspeed constantly, Adjust pitch to maintain airspeed. Follow planned approach path: Follow planned base leg, Follow planned final approach, Adjust as needed. Maintain aircraft control: Maintain coordination, Avoid excessive bank angles, Maintain awareness of terrain and obstacles. The key: Execute approach carefully - maintain best glide airspeed, follow planned approach path, maintain aircraft control.'

Explain landing execution: 'Landing execution is critical for emergency approach and landing. Flare at appropriate altitude: Begin flare at appropriate altitude (typically 10-20 feet AGL), Reduce descent rate, Maintain airspeed. Touchdown at selected point: Touchdown at selected touchdown point, Maintain control during landing, Avoid obstacles. Maintain control during landing: Maintain coordination, Avoid excessive bank angles, Maintain directional control. The key: Execute landing carefully - flare at appropriate altitude, touchdown at selected point, maintain control during landing.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not recognizing emergency situation promptly (delayed response, reduces options), Not establishing best glide airspeed (reduces glide distance, may not reach suitable landing area), Not selecting suitable landing area (unsafe landing area, increases risk), Not planning approach (poor approach path, may not reach landing area), Not maintaining best glide airspeed (reduces glide distance, may not reach landing area), Not maintaining aircraft control (loss of control risk), Not executing approach properly (poor approach path, may not reach landing area). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH emergency procedures: 'Let's check your POH for emergency approach and landing procedures. Best glide airspeed: Check POH (typically 70-80 knots for most light aircraft). Glide ratio: Check POH (typically 8:1 to 10:1). Use this to plan your emergency approach and landing.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical emergency procedure. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe emergency operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Emergency approach and landing is a critical emergency procedure - proper execution can save lives.'

diagrams.title: Emergency Approach and Landing Procedure
diagrams.description: Visual representation of emergency approach and landing procedure.
diagrams.asciiArt:
EMERGENCY APPROACH AND LANDING PROCEDURE

RECOGNIZE EMERGENCY:
  Power failure at altitude
  Engine quits
  Propeller stops
  No engine power

ESTABLISH BEST GLIDE:
  Reduce power to idle
  Pitch to best glide attitude
  Maintain best glide airspeed (check POH - typically 70-80 knots)
  Best glide provides maximum glide distance

SELECT LANDING AREA:
  Airport preferred
  Off-airport if necessary
  Consider: size and surface, obstacles, wind direction, accessibility

PLAN APPROACH:
  Determine glide path (calculate glide distance)
  Plan base leg
  Plan final approach
  Plan touchdown point
  Plan go-around point if needed

EXECUTE APPROACH:
  Maintain best glide airspeed
  Follow planned approach path
  Adjust as needed
  Maintain aircraft control

EXECUTE LANDING (SIMULATED):
  Flare at appropriate altitude (typically 10-20 feet AGL)
  Touchdown at selected point
  Maintain control during landing

KEY:
  Establish best glide airspeed
  Select suitable landing area
  Plan approach carefully
  Maintain aircraft control

lessonPlans.overview: Systems and equipment malfunctions are critical emergency situations that every CFI candidate must master. These malfunctions can include electrical system failures, fuel system problems, landing gear malfunctions, flight instrument failures, and other equipment failures. The technique requires recognizing the malfunction, identifying appropriate emergency procedures, executing the appropriate emergency procedures, maintaining aircraft control, and communicating the emergency situation to ATC when appropriate. Systems and equipment malfunctions develop understanding of emergency procedures, decision-making under stress, aircraft systems, and the critical importance of maintaining aircraft control during emergencies. CFI candidates must master these procedures to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of emergency procedures and prepares students to handle systems and equipment malfunctions safely. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of systems and equipment malfunction procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering systems and equipment malfunctions - critical emergency situations. These malfunctions can include electrical system failures, fuel system problems, landing gear malfunctions, flight instrument failures, and other equipment failures. The technique requires recognizing the malfunction, identifying appropriate emergency procedures, executing the appropriate emergency procedures, maintaining aircraft control, and communicating the emergency situation to ATC when appropriate. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Systems and Equipment Malfunctions'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: recognize systems and equipment malfunctions, identify appropriate emergency procedures for specific malfunctions, execute appropriate emergency procedures for specific malfunctions, maintain aircraft control during malfunctions, communicate emergency situation to ATC when appropriate, explain systems and equipment malfunction procedures, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, and teach systems and equipment malfunction procedures to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about various systems and equipment malfunctions - electrical failure, fuel problem, landing gear malfunction, instrument failure. What would you do for each? How would you identify the appropriate emergency procedure? How would you execute the procedure? How would you maintain control?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: systems and equipment malfunctions require recognizing the malfunction, identifying appropriate emergency procedures, and executing those procedures while maintaining aircraft control. Systems and equipment malfunctions teach us to handle various emergency situations safely. Let's explore this systematically, starting with recognizing malfunctions.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 17, your POH Emergency Procedures section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on systems and equipment malfunction procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Systems and equipment malfunctions serve one critical purpose: Handle various emergency situations involving aircraft systems and equipment failures. Common malfunctions: Electrical system failures (alternator failure, battery discharge, electrical fire), Fuel system problems (fuel pump failure, fuel contamination, fuel starvation), Landing gear malfunctions (gear won't extend, gear won't retract, gear unsafe indication), Flight instrument failures (attitude indicator failure, heading indicator failure, airspeed indicator failure, altimeter failure), Other equipment failures (pitot-static system failure, vacuum system failure, communication equipment failure). The key: Systems and equipment malfunctions require recognizing the malfunction, identifying appropriate emergency procedures, and executing those procedures while maintaining aircraft control.'

Explain electrical system malfunctions: 'Electrical system malfunctions: Alternator failure (alternator warning light illuminates, ammeter shows discharge, battery voltage decreasing), Battery discharge (battery voltage decreasing, electrical equipment failing), Electrical fire (smoke, burning smell, electrical equipment malfunctioning). Emergency procedures: Alternator failure - reduce electrical load (turn off non-essential equipment, reduce radio usage, conserve battery), monitor battery voltage, land as soon as practical. Battery discharge - reduce electrical load, monitor battery voltage, land as soon as practical. Electrical fire - turn off master switch, turn off affected equipment, land immediately. The key: Electrical system malfunctions require reducing electrical load, monitoring battery voltage, and landing as soon as practical or immediately.'

Explain fuel system malfunctions: 'Fuel system malfunctions: Fuel pump failure (engine runs rough, engine quits, fuel pressure low), Fuel contamination (engine runs rough, engine quits, fuel system problems), Fuel starvation (engine runs rough, engine quits, fuel quantity low). Emergency procedures: Fuel pump failure - switch to backup fuel pump if available, select different fuel tank, land as soon as practical. Fuel contamination - switch to different fuel tank, land as soon as practical. Fuel starvation - switch to different fuel tank, verify fuel quantity, land as soon as practical. The key: Fuel system malfunctions require switching fuel tanks, verifying fuel quantity, and landing as soon as practical.'

Explain landing gear malfunctions: 'Landing gear malfunctions: Gear won't extend (gear handle down, gear unsafe indication, gear not down), Gear won't retract (gear handle up, gear unsafe indication, gear not up), Gear unsafe indication (gear position uncertain, gear unsafe light illuminated). Emergency procedures: Gear won't extend - use emergency gear extension procedure (check POH), verify gear position, land as soon as practical. Gear won't retract - verify gear position, continue flight, land as soon as practical. Gear unsafe indication - verify gear position visually if possible, use emergency gear extension procedure if needed, land as soon as practical. The key: Landing gear malfunctions require using emergency gear extension procedure if needed, verifying gear position, and landing as soon as practical.'

Explain flight instrument malfunctions: 'Flight instrument malfunctions: Attitude indicator failure (attitude indicator not responding, attitude indicator tumbling), Heading indicator failure (heading indicator not responding, heading indicator precessing), Airspeed indicator failure (airspeed indicator not responding, airspeed indicator showing zero), Altimeter failure (altimeter not responding, altimeter showing incorrect altitude). Emergency procedures: Attitude indicator failure - use backup attitude indicator if available, use other instruments (turn coordinator, altimeter, airspeed indicator), land as soon as practical. Heading indicator failure - use magnetic compass, use GPS if available, land as soon as practical. Airspeed indicator failure - use power setting and pitch attitude, use other instruments, land as soon as practical. Altimeter failure - use backup altimeter if available, use GPS altitude if available, land as soon as practical. The key: Flight instrument malfunctions require using backup instruments if available, using other instruments, and landing as soon as practical.'

Explain other equipment malfunctions: 'Other equipment malfunctions: Pitot-static system failure (airspeed indicator and altimeter affected, vertical speed indicator affected), Vacuum system failure (attitude indicator and heading indicator affected), Communication equipment failure (radio not working, transponder not working). Emergency procedures: Pitot-static system failure - use backup instruments if available, use other instruments, land as soon as practical. Vacuum system failure - use backup instruments if available, use other instruments, land as soon as practical. Communication equipment failure - use backup radio if available, use light signals if needed, land as soon as practical. The key: Other equipment malfunctions require using backup equipment if available, using alternative methods, and landing as soon as practical.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not recognizing malfunction promptly (delayed response, worsens situation), Not identifying appropriate emergency procedure (wrong procedure, worsens situation), Not executing emergency procedure properly (ineffective procedure, worsens situation), Not maintaining aircraft control (loss of control risk), Not communicating with ATC when appropriate (missed assistance, airspace conflict), Not following POH emergency procedures (ineffective procedure, safety risk). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH emergency procedures: 'Let's check your POH for systems and equipment malfunction procedures. Electrical system: Alternator failure, battery discharge, electrical fire. Fuel system: Fuel pump failure, fuel contamination, fuel starvation. Landing gear: Gear won't extend, gear won't retract, gear unsafe indication. Flight instruments: Attitude indicator failure, heading indicator failure, airspeed indicator failure, altimeter failure. Other equipment: Pitot-static system failure, vacuum system failure, communication equipment failure. Use this to plan your response to malfunctions.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as critical emergency procedures. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe emergency operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Systems and equipment malfunctions are critical emergency situations - proper execution can save lives.'

scenarios.correct: Execute appropriate emergency procedure: Recognize alternator failure, reduce electrical load, monitor battery voltage, land as soon as practical, communicate with ATC
scenarios.explanation: When you recognize an electrical system malfunction (alternator warning light illuminates, ammeter shows discharge, battery voltage decreasing), you must execute appropriate emergency procedure immediately. Don't ignore it - alternator failure will drain the battery and cause electrical system failure. Execute the procedure: Recognize the malfunction (alternator failure - alternator warning light illuminates, ammeter shows discharge, battery voltage decreasing), Identify appropriate emergency procedure (check POH - reduce electrical load, monitor battery voltage, land as soon as practical), Execute appropriate emergency procedure (turn off non-essential equipment, reduce radio usage, conserve battery, monitor battery voltage), Maintain aircraft control (maintain coordination, avoid excessive bank angles), Communicate emergency situation to ATC when appropriate (declare emergency, state intentions, request assistance if needed). Don't ignore it - alternator failure requires immediate action. Don't just continue flying - battery will drain and electrical system will fail. Don't wait - time is critical. The key is recognizing the malfunction, identifying appropriate emergency procedure, executing the procedure, maintaining aircraft control, and communicating with ATC when appropriate.

lessonPlans.overview: Emergency equipment and survival gear are critical for safe flight operations and survival in emergency situations. This knowledge-based lesson covers required emergency equipment, survival gear, their proper use, maintenance requirements, and selection based on flight conditions. Emergency equipment and survival gear develop understanding of emergency preparedness, survival techniques, and the critical importance of proper equipment selection and use. CFI candidates must master this knowledge to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of emergency preparedness and prepares students to handle emergency situations safely. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of emergency equipment and survival gear, ACS knowledge standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering emergency equipment and survival gear - critical knowledge for safe flight operations and survival in emergency situations. This lesson covers required emergency equipment, survival gear, their proper use, maintenance requirements, and selection based on flight conditions. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Emergency Equipment and Survival Gear'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: identify required emergency equipment and survival gear, explain purpose and proper use of emergency equipment and survival gear, demonstrate proper location and access of emergency equipment and survival gear, explain maintenance and inspection requirements, explain selection based on flight conditions, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, and teach emergency equipment and survival gear to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about emergency situations - forced landing, ditching, survival situation. What equipment would you need? What survival gear would be essential? How would you use it? How would you maintain it?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: emergency equipment and survival gear must be properly selected, maintained, and used to be effective. Emergency equipment and survival gear teach us to be prepared for emergency situations. Let's explore this systematically, starting with required emergency equipment.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 17, Part 91 equipment requirements, your POH Equipment section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on emergency equipment and survival gear.'

Explain the purpose: 'Emergency equipment and survival gear serve one critical purpose: Provide necessary equipment and gear for survival and rescue in emergency situations. Emergency situations requiring equipment: Forced landing (off-airport landing, need survival gear), Ditching (water landing, need flotation equipment), Survival situation (need survival gear, need signaling equipment), Search and rescue (need signaling equipment, need communication equipment). The key: Emergency equipment and survival gear must be properly selected, maintained, and used to be effective in emergency situations.'

Explain required emergency equipment: 'Required emergency equipment (14 CFR Part 91): Fire extinguisher (required for aircraft with passenger capacity, must be readily accessible, must be appropriate type and size), First aid kit (required for aircraft with passenger capacity, must be readily accessible, must contain appropriate supplies), Emergency locator transmitter (ELT) (required for most aircraft, must be properly installed and maintained, must be tested regularly), Safety belts and shoulder harnesses (required for all occupants, must be properly installed and maintained). The key: Required emergency equipment must be properly installed, maintained, and accessible.'

Explain survival gear: 'Survival gear (recommended/advisable): Water (essential for survival, minimum 1 quart per person per day, store in appropriate containers), Food (high-energy, non-perishable, minimum 3 days supply per person), Shelter (emergency blanket, tarp, or tent, protection from elements), Signaling equipment (mirror, whistle, flare, strobe light, radio, cell phone), Fire starting equipment (matches, lighter, fire starter, tinder), Tools (knife, multi-tool, cord, duct tape), Navigation equipment (compass, GPS, map), Medical supplies (first aid kit, medications, personal needs), Clothing (appropriate for climate, extra layers, rain gear). The key: Survival gear must be appropriate for flight conditions and emergency situations.'

Explain equipment location and access: 'Equipment location and access: Emergency equipment must be readily accessible (not buried in baggage, not difficult to reach, accessible in emergency), Survival gear should be in survival kit (organized, protected, easily accessible), Equipment should be secured (won't become projectiles, won't shift during flight), Equipment should be labeled (clearly marked, purpose identified). The key: Emergency equipment and survival gear must be readily accessible in emergency situations.'

Explain maintenance and inspection: 'Maintenance and inspection requirements: Fire extinguisher (check pressure gauge, check expiration date, check accessibility, replace if needed), First aid kit (check contents, check expiration dates, replace expired items, restock as needed), ELT (check installation, check battery expiration, test regularly, replace battery as needed), Survival gear (check condition, check expiration dates, replace expired items, restock as needed). The key: Emergency equipment and survival gear must be properly maintained and inspected regularly.'

Explain selection based on flight conditions: 'Selection based on flight conditions: Overwater flights (flotation equipment, sea anchor, water desalination, signaling equipment), Overland flights (survival gear, signaling equipment, navigation equipment, shelter), Cold weather flights (warm clothing, shelter, fire starting equipment, extra food), Hot weather flights (water, sun protection, shelter, medical supplies), Remote area flights (extended survival gear, communication equipment, navigation equipment, medical supplies). The key: Emergency equipment and survival gear must be selected based on flight conditions and potential emergency situations.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not carrying required equipment (violation of regulations, safety risk), Not maintaining equipment properly (equipment may not work when needed, safety risk), Not selecting appropriate equipment for flight conditions (equipment may not be suitable, safety risk), Not knowing how to use equipment (equipment may not be effective, safety risk), Not having equipment readily accessible (equipment may not be available in emergency, safety risk). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH equipment section: 'Let's check your POH for equipment requirements and recommendations. Required equipment: Fire extinguisher, first aid kit, ELT, safety belts. Recommended equipment: Survival gear, signaling equipment, communication equipment. Use this to plan your equipment selection.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as critical knowledge for safe flight operations. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach emergency preparedness and proper equipment selection. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate knowledge while teaching. Remember: Emergency equipment and survival gear are critical for survival - proper selection and use can save lives.'

lessonPlans.overview: Engine failure during takeoff before VMC (simulated) is a critical multiengine emergency procedure that every CFI candidate must master. This maneuver simulates an engine failure during takeoff before VMC (minimum control speed) and requires aborting the takeoff safely. The technique requires recognizing the engine failure, maintaining directional control, aborting the takeoff, and bringing the aircraft to a safe stop. Engine failure during takeoff before VMC develops understanding of multiengine emergency procedures, decision-making under stress, VMC and multiengine aerodynamics, and the critical importance of maintaining directional control during engine failures. CFI candidates must master this procedure to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of multiengine emergency procedures and prepares students to handle engine failures during takeoff safely. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of engine failure during takeoff before VMC procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering engine failure during takeoff before VMC (simulated) - a critical multiengine emergency procedure. This maneuver simulates an engine failure during takeoff before VMC and requires aborting the takeoff safely. The technique requires recognizing the engine failure, maintaining directional control, aborting the takeoff, and bringing the aircraft to a safe stop. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe multiengine flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Engine Failure During Takeoff Before VMC (Simulated)'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: recognize engine failure during takeoff before VMC (simulated), execute engine failure procedure during takeoff before VMC (simulated), maintain directional control during engine failure before VMC, abort takeoff safely when engine fails before VMC, explain engine failure during takeoff before VMC procedures, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, and teach engine failure during takeoff before VMC to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about an engine failure during takeoff before VMC - one engine quits while you're still on the ground or just lifting off, before you reach VMC. What would you do? How would you maintain directional control? How would you abort the takeoff? What's the critical decision point?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: engine failure during takeoff before VMC requires aborting the takeoff safely while maintaining directional control. Engine failure during takeoff before VMC teaches us to handle engine failures at the most critical phase of flight. Let's explore this systematically, starting with understanding VMC.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 17, your POH Emergency Procedures section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on engine failure during takeoff before VMC procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Engine failure during takeoff before VMC serves one critical purpose: Abort takeoff safely when engine fails before VMC (minimum control speed). VMC: Minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative (the minimum speed at which directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative), Below VMC: Directional control cannot be maintained with one engine inoperative, must abort takeoff, Above VMC: Directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative, may continue takeoff. The key: Engine failure during takeoff before VMC requires aborting the takeoff safely - directional control cannot be maintained below VMC.'

Explain engine failure during takeoff before VMC procedure: 'Engine failure during takeoff before VMC procedure: First, recognize engine failure (engine quits, loss of power on one side, asymmetric thrust, yaw toward inoperative engine). Second, maintain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain runway centerline, avoid overcorrection). Third, abort takeoff (reduce power on operating engine to idle, apply brakes, maintain directional control, bring aircraft to safe stop). Fourth, secure inoperative engine (mixture idle cutoff, fuel selector off, magnetos off, close cowl flaps, secure engine). The key: Engine failure during takeoff before VMC procedure requires recognizing the failure, maintaining directional control, aborting the takeoff, and securing the inoperative engine.'

Explain directional control: 'Directional control is critical during engine failure before VMC. Asymmetric thrust: Inoperative engine produces no thrust, operating engine produces full thrust, creates yaw toward inoperative engine, must counteract with rudder. Full rudder: Apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain runway centerline, avoid overcorrection. Below VMC: Directional control cannot be maintained, must abort takeoff. The key: Maintain directional control with full rudder opposite to inoperative engine - below VMC, directional control cannot be maintained, must abort takeoff.'

Explain abort procedure: 'Abort procedure is critical for engine failure before VMC. Reduce power: Reduce power on operating engine to idle (reduces asymmetric thrust, reduces yaw, makes directional control easier). Apply brakes: Apply brakes firmly but smoothly (don't lock brakes, maintain directional control, bring aircraft to safe stop). Maintain directional control: Maintain runway centerline, avoid overcorrection, use rudder as needed. Bring aircraft to safe stop: Stop on runway if possible, clear runway if needed, secure aircraft. The key: Abort takeoff promptly and safely - reduce power, apply brakes, maintain directional control, bring aircraft to safe stop.'

Explain decision point: 'Decision point is critical for engine failure during takeoff. Before VMC: Must abort takeoff (directional control cannot be maintained, abort is only option). At or after VMC: May continue takeoff (directional control can be maintained, may continue takeoff with one engine inoperative). The key: Decision point is VMC - before VMC, abort takeoff; at or after VMC, may continue takeoff.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not recognizing engine failure promptly (delayed response, reduces options), Not maintaining directional control (loss of directional control, runway excursion risk), Not aborting takeoff promptly (continuing takeoff below VMC, loss of control risk), Not reducing power on operating engine (increases asymmetric thrust, makes directional control difficult), Not applying brakes properly (inadequate braking, runway overrun risk), Not securing inoperative engine (fire risk, safety risk). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH emergency procedures: 'Let's check your POH for engine failure during takeoff procedures. VMC: Check POH (typically 60-70 knots for most light twins). Abort procedure: Reduce power, apply brakes, maintain directional control. Use this to plan your engine failure during takeoff before VMC procedure.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical multiengine emergency procedure. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe multiengine emergency operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Engine failure during takeoff before VMC is a critical emergency procedure - proper execution can save lives.'

instructorActions: Pre-maneuver briefing: 'Before we practice engine failure during takeoff before VMC, let me walk you through what I'll be doing. Watch my technique and listen to my narration.'

Simulate engine failure: 'Simulating engine failure during takeoff... beginning takeoff roll... power set... airspeed increasing... 40 knots... 50 knots... simulating left engine failure... left engine quits... loss of power on left side... asymmetric thrust... yaw toward left... recognizing engine failure...'

Maintain directional control: 'Maintaining directional control... applying full right rudder... full right rudder... counteracting yaw... maintaining runway centerline... airspeed 55 knots... below VMC 65 knots... must abort takeoff...'

Abort takeoff: 'Aborting takeoff... reducing power on operating engine to idle... power idle... applying brakes... brakes applied... maintaining directional control... maintaining runway centerline... airspeed decreasing... 40 knots... 30 knots... 20 knots... 10 knots... aircraft stopped... abort complete.'
Secure engine: 'Securing inoperative engine... mixture idle cutoff... fuel selector off... magnetos off... closing cowl flaps... engine secured... engine failure during takeoff before VMC complete.'

Explain technique: 'Notice how I executed the engine failure during takeoff before VMC procedure: recognized the engine failure (left engine quits, loss of power, asymmetric thrust, yaw toward left), maintained directional control (applied full right rudder, maintained runway centerline), aborted the takeoff (reduced power on operating engine to idle, applied brakes, maintained directional control, brought aircraft to safe stop), and secured the inoperative engine (mixture idle cutoff, fuel selector off, magnetos off, closed cowl flaps). The key was recognizing the failure, maintaining directional control, aborting the takeoff promptly, and securing the inoperative engine.'

interactiveElements.description: Interactive scenario for practicing engine failure during takeoff before VMC decision-making

scenarios.situation: You're taking off in a multiengine aircraft. At 55 knots, the left engine quits. VMC is 65 knots. What should you do?
options: Continue takeoff - you're almost at VMC

Abort takeoff immediately: Recognize engine failure, maintain directional control with full right rudder, reduce power on operating engine to idle, apply brakes, bring aircraft to safe stop, secure inoperative engine
Just reduce power and continue
Wait and see what happens
scenarios.correct: Abort takeoff immediately: Recognize engine failure, maintain directional control with full right rudder, reduce power on operating engine to idle, apply brakes, bring aircraft to safe stop, secure inoperative engine
scenarios.explanation: When you recognize an engine failure during takeoff before VMC (at 55 knots, VMC is 65 knots), you must abort takeoff immediately. Don't continue takeoff - you're below VMC, directional control cannot be maintained with one engine inoperative. Execute the procedure: Recognize engine failure (engine quits, loss of power on one side, asymmetric thrust, yaw toward inoperative engine), Maintain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine - full right rudder in this case, maintain runway centerline, avoid overcorrection - below VMC, directional control cannot be maintained, must abort takeoff), Abort takeoff (reduce power on operating engine to idle - reduces asymmetric thrust, makes directional control easier, apply brakes - firmly but smoothly, don't lock brakes, maintain directional control, bring aircraft to safe stop), Secure inoperative engine (mixture idle cutoff, fuel selector off, magnetos off, close cowl flaps). Don't continue takeoff - you're below VMC, directional control cannot be maintained. Don't just reduce power - you must abort takeoff. Don't wait - time is critical. The key is recognizing the failure, maintaining directional control, aborting the takeoff promptly, and securing the inoperative engine.

tolerances: VMC: Check POH (typically 60-70 knots for most light twins)
Airspeed: Below VMC, must abort takeoff
Directional control: Apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain runway centerline
