lessonPlans.overview: Engine failure after liftoff (simulated) is a critical multiengine emergency procedure that every CFI candidate must master. This maneuver simulates an engine failure after liftoff and requires continuing the takeoff and climb with one engine inoperative. The technique requires recognizing the engine failure, maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, continuing takeoff and climb, and securing the inoperative engine. Engine failure after liftoff develops understanding of multiengine emergency procedures, decision-making under stress, VMC and multiengine aerodynamics, and the critical importance of maintaining directional control and airspeed during engine failures. CFI candidates must master this procedure to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of multiengine emergency procedures and prepares students to handle engine failures after liftoff safely. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of engine failure after liftoff procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering engine failure after liftoff (simulated) - a critical multiengine emergency procedure. This maneuver simulates an engine failure after liftoff and requires continuing the takeoff and climb with one engine inoperative. The technique requires recognizing the engine failure, maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, continuing takeoff and climb, and securing the inoperative engine. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe multiengine flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: recognize engine failure after liftoff (simulated), execute engine failure procedure after liftoff (simulated), maintain directional control during engine failure after liftoff, maintain airspeed at or above VMC during engine failure after liftoff, continue takeoff and climb with one engine inoperative, explain engine failure after liftoff procedures, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, and teach engine failure after liftoff to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about an engine failure after liftoff - one engine quits after you've lifted off, at or above VMC. What would you do? How would you maintain directional control? How would you maintain airspeed? How would you continue the climb? What's the critical airspeed?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: engine failure after liftoff requires continuing the takeoff and climb with one engine inoperative while maintaining directional control and airspeed. Engine failure after liftoff teaches us to handle engine failures after we're airborne. Let's explore this systematically, starting with understanding VMC and VYSE.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 17, your POH Emergency Procedures section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on engine failure after liftoff procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Engine failure after liftoff serves one critical purpose: Continue takeoff and climb safely with one engine inoperative after liftoff. VMC: Minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative (the minimum speed at which directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative), At or above VMC: Directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative, may continue takeoff and climb. VYSE: Best rate of climb speed with one engine inoperative (the best rate of climb speed with critical engine inoperative, typically 5-10 knots above VMC). The key: Engine failure after liftoff requires continuing the takeoff and climb - directional control can be maintained at or above VMC.'

Explain engine failure after liftoff procedure: 'Engine failure after liftoff procedure: First, recognize engine failure (engine quits, loss of power on one side, asymmetric thrust, yaw toward inoperative engine). Second, maintain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading, avoid overcorrection). Third, maintain airspeed at or above VMC (maintain airspeed at or above VMC, maintain VYSE if possible, do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC). Fourth, continue takeoff and climb (maintain climb attitude, maintain airspeed, maintain directional control, climb with one engine inoperative). Fifth, secure inoperative engine (mixture idle cutoff, fuel selector off, magnetos off, close cowl flaps, secure engine). The key: Engine failure after liftoff procedure requires recognizing the failure, maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, continuing takeoff and climb, and securing the inoperative engine.'

Explain directional control: 'Directional control is critical during engine failure after liftoff. Asymmetric thrust: Inoperative engine produces no thrust, operating engine produces full thrust, creates yaw toward inoperative engine, must counteract with rudder. Full rudder: Apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading, avoid overcorrection. At or above VMC: Directional control can be maintained, may continue takeoff and climb. The key: Maintain directional control with full rudder opposite to inoperative engine - at or above VMC, directional control can be maintained, may continue takeoff and climb.'

Explain airspeed control: 'Airspeed control is critical during engine failure after liftoff. Maintain VMC: Maintain airspeed at or above VMC (minimum control speed, directional control can be maintained), Do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC (directional control cannot be maintained, loss of control risk). Maintain VYSE: Maintain VYSE if possible (best rate of climb speed with one engine inoperative, typically 5-10 knots above VMC, provides best climb performance). The key: Maintain airspeed at or above VMC - do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC, maintain VYSE if possible.'

Explain climb procedure: 'Climb procedure is critical for engine failure after liftoff. Maintain climb attitude: Maintain climb attitude appropriate for one engine inoperative (typically steeper than normal climb, maintains airspeed). Maintain airspeed: Maintain airspeed at or above VMC, maintain VYSE if possible. Maintain directional control: Maintain heading, avoid overcorrection, use rudder as needed. Climb with one engine inoperative: Climb performance is reduced, maintain positive rate of climb, maintain safe altitude. The key: Continue takeoff and climb with one engine inoperative - maintain climb attitude, maintain airspeed, maintain directional control, climb with reduced performance.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not recognizing engine failure promptly (delayed response, reduces options), Not maintaining directional control (loss of directional control, loss of control risk), Not maintaining airspeed at or above VMC (airspeed decreases below VMC, loss of control risk), Not continuing takeoff and climb (attempting to land immediately, unsafe landing risk), Not securing inoperative engine (fire risk, safety risk). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH emergency procedures: 'Let's check your POH for engine failure after liftoff procedures. VMC: Check POH (typically 60-70 knots for most light twins). VYSE: Check POH (typically 5-10 knots above VMC). Climb procedure: Maintain climb attitude, maintain airspeed, maintain directional control. Use this to plan your engine failure after liftoff procedure.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical multiengine emergency procedure. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe multiengine emergency operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Engine failure after liftoff is a critical emergency procedure - proper execution can save lives.'

teachingScript.phase: Demonstration - Engine Failure After Liftoff (20 minutes)
instructorActions: Pre-maneuver briefing: 'Before we practice engine failure after liftoff, let me walk you through what I'll be doing. I'll simulate an engine failure after liftoff, then execute engine failure procedure: recognize the failure, maintain directional control, maintain airspeed at or above VMC, continue takeoff and climb, and secure the inoperative engine. Watch my technique and listen to my narration.'

Simulate engine failure: 'Simulating engine failure after liftoff... normal takeoff... liftoff... climbing... airspeed 80 knots... altitude 200 feet AGL... simulating left engine failure... left engine quits... loss of power on left side... asymmetric thrust... yaw toward left... recognizing engine failure...'

Maintain directional control: 'Maintaining directional control... applying full right rudder... full right rudder... counteracting yaw... maintaining heading... airspeed 80 knots... above VMC 65 knots... directional control maintained...'

Maintain airspeed: 'Maintaining airspeed at or above VMC... airspeed 80 knots... above VMC 65 knots... maintaining VYSE 75 knots... airspeed maintained... do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC...'

Continue climb: 'Continuing takeoff and climb... maintaining climb attitude... maintaining airspeed 75 knots VYSE... maintaining directional control... maintaining heading... altitude 300 feet AGL... 400 feet AGL... 500 feet AGL... positive rate of climb... climb with one engine inoperative established...'
Secure engine: 'Securing inoperative engine... mixture idle cutoff... fuel selector off... magnetos off... closing cowl flaps... engine secured... engine failure after liftoff complete.'

Explain technique: 'Notice how I executed the engine failure after liftoff procedure: recognized the engine failure (left engine quits, loss of power, asymmetric thrust, yaw toward left), maintained directional control (applied full right rudder, maintained heading), maintained airspeed at or above VMC (maintained airspeed 80 knots, above VMC 65 knots, maintained VYSE 75 knots), continued takeoff and climb (maintained climb attitude, maintained airspeed, maintained directional control, climbed with one engine inoperative), and secured the inoperative engine (mixture idle cutoff, fuel selector off, magnetos off, closed cowl flaps). The key was recognizing the failure, maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, continuing takeoff and climb, and securing the inoperative engine.'

teachingScript.phase: Guided Practice - Student First Attempt (25 minutes)
instructorActions: Encourage: 'Your airplane. I'll guide you through this. First, I'll simulate an engine failure after liftoff, then you'll execute engine failure procedure while maintaining directional control and airspeed, and continuing takeoff and climb.'

Simulate engine failure: 'Simulating engine failure after liftoff... normal takeoff... liftoff... climbing... airspeed 80 knots... altitude 200 feet AGL... simulating left engine failure... left engine quits... loss of power on left side... recognize the engine failure... what do you do? Good. Maintain directional control... apply full right rudder... full right rudder? Good. Maintain heading... good. Airspeed? Good. Above VMC? Good. Maintain airspeed at or above VMC... maintain VYSE if possible... good.'

Guide climb: 'Continuing takeoff and climb... maintain climb attitude... good. Maintain airspeed 75 knots VYSE... good. Maintain directional control... maintain heading... good. Monitor altitude... what's your altitude? Good. Positive rate of climb? Good. Climb with one engine inoperative established... good.'
Guide secure: 'Securing inoperative engine... mixture idle cutoff... good. Fuel selector off... good. Magnetos off... good. Closing cowl flaps... good. Engine secured. Good.'

If not maintaining directional control: 'I notice you're not maintaining directional control - remember, maintain directional control with full rudder opposite to inoperative engine (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading, avoid overcorrection). At or above VMC, directional control can be maintained, may continue takeoff and climb. There, directional control maintained. Good.'

If not maintaining airspeed: 'I notice you're not maintaining airspeed at or above VMC - remember, maintain airspeed at or above VMC (do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC, maintain VYSE if possible). If airspeed decreases below VMC, directional control cannot be maintained, loss of control risk. There, airspeed maintained. Good.'

Provide feedback: 'Excellent! Your engine failure after liftoff procedure was good. You recognized the engine failure, maintained directional control, maintained airspeed at or above VMC, continued takeoff and climb, and secured the inoperative engine. Your understanding of multiengine emergency procedures is improving. You're really getting the feel for engine failure after liftoff.'

Address errors constructively: 'I noticed you allowed airspeed to decrease below VMC on that one - remember, maintain airspeed at or above VMC. If airspeed decreases below VMC, directional control cannot be maintained, loss of control risk. Next time, monitor airspeed constantly and maintain airspeed at or above VMC.'

ENGINE FAILURE AFTER LIFTOFF PROCEDURE

NORMAL TAKEOFF:

  Engine quits (simulated)
  Loss of power on one side
  Asymmetric thrust
  Yaw toward inoperative engine

RECOGNIZE FAILURE:
  Engine quits
  Loss of power
  Asymmetric thrust
  Yaw toward inoperative engine

MAINTAIN DIRECTIONAL CONTROL:
  Apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine
  Maintain heading
  Avoid overcorrection
  At or above VMC: Directional control can be maintained, may continue takeoff and climb

MAINTAIN AIRSPEED:
  Maintain airspeed at or above VMC
  Maintain VYSE if possible (typically 5-10 knots above VMC)
  Do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC

CONTINUE TAKEOFF AND CLIMB:
  Maintain climb attitude
  Maintain airspeed
  Maintain directional control
  Climb with one engine inoperative
  Climb performance is reduced
  Maintain positive rate of climb

SECURE INOPERATIVE ENGINE:
  Mixture idle cutoff
  Fuel selector off
  Magnetos off
  Close cowl flaps

VMC:
  Minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative
  At or above VMC: May continue takeoff and climb

VYSE:
  Best rate of climb speed with one engine inoperative
  Typically 5-10 knots above VMC
  Provides best climb performance

KEY:
  Recognize failure promptly
  Maintain directional control
  Maintain airspeed at or above VMC
  Continue takeoff and climb

scenarios.situation: You're taking off in a multiengine aircraft. After liftoff at 80 knots, the left engine quits. VMC is 65 knots. VYSE is 75 knots. What should you do?
options: Land immediately - it's safer

Continue takeoff and climb: Recognize engine failure, maintain directional control with full right rudder, maintain airspeed at or above VMC (80 knots is above VMC 65 knots), maintain VYSE 75 knots if possible, continue takeoff and climb, secure inoperative engine
Just reduce power and glide
Wait and see what happens
scenarios.correct: Continue takeoff and climb: Recognize engine failure, maintain directional control with full right rudder, maintain airspeed at or above VMC (80 knots is above VMC 65 knots), maintain VYSE 75 knots if possible, continue takeoff and climb, secure inoperative engine
scenarios.explanation: When you recognize an engine failure after liftoff (at 80 knots, above VMC 65 knots), you must continue takeoff and climb with one engine inoperative. Don't land immediately - you're at low altitude, landing immediately is unsafe. Execute the procedure: Recognize engine failure (engine quits, loss of power on one side, asymmetric thrust, yaw toward inoperative engine), Maintain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine - full right rudder in this case, maintain heading, avoid overcorrection - at or above VMC, directional control can be maintained, may continue takeoff and climb), Maintain airspeed at or above VMC (maintain airspeed at or above VMC - 80 knots is above VMC 65 knots, maintain VYSE if possible - VYSE 75 knots provides best climb performance, do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC), Continue takeoff and climb (maintain climb attitude, maintain airspeed, maintain directional control, climb with one engine inoperative - climb performance is reduced, maintain positive rate of climb), Secure inoperative engine (mixture idle cutoff, fuel selector off, magnetos off, close cowl flaps). Don't land immediately - you're at low altitude, landing immediately is unsafe. Don't just reduce power - you need to continue takeoff and climb. Don't wait - time is critical. The key is recognizing the failure, maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, continuing takeoff and climb, and securing the inoperative engine.

tolerances: VMC: Check POH (typically 60-70 knots for most light twins)
VYSE: Check POH (typically 5-10 knots above VMC)

lessonPlans.overview: Approach and landing with an inoperative engine (simulated) is a critical multiengine emergency procedure that every CFI candidate must master. This maneuver simulates an approach and landing with one engine already inoperative and requires executing a safe approach and landing with one engine inoperative. The technique requires maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, executing approach and landing, and maintaining aircraft control throughout. Approach and landing with an inoperative engine develops understanding of multiengine emergency procedures, decision-making under stress, VMC and multiengine aerodynamics, and the critical importance of maintaining directional control and airspeed during approach and landing. CFI candidates must master this procedure to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of multiengine emergency procedures and prepares students to handle approach and landing with an inoperative engine safely. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of approach and landing with an inoperative engine procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering approach and landing with an inoperative engine (simulated) - a critical multiengine emergency procedure. This maneuver simulates an approach and landing with one engine already inoperative and requires executing a safe approach and landing with one engine inoperative. The technique requires maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, executing approach and landing, and maintaining aircraft control throughout. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe multiengine flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Approach and Landing with an Inoperative Engine (Simulated)'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: recognize approach and landing with an inoperative engine (simulated), execute approach and landing procedure with an inoperative engine (simulated), maintain directional control during approach and landing with an inoperative engine, maintain airspeed at or above VMC during approach and landing with an inoperative engine, execute approach and landing with one engine inoperative, explain approach and landing with an inoperative engine procedures, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, and teach approach and landing with an inoperative engine to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about an approach and landing with one engine already inoperative - you're approaching to land with one engine out. What would you do? How would you maintain directional control? How would you maintain airspeed? How would you execute the approach and landing? What's the critical airspeed?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: approach and landing with an inoperative engine requires executing a safe approach and landing with one engine inoperative while maintaining directional control and airspeed. Approach and landing with an inoperative engine teaches us to handle the final phase of flight with one engine inoperative. Let's explore this systematically, starting with understanding VMC and approach considerations.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 17, your POH Emergency Procedures section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on approach and landing with an inoperative engine procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Approach and landing with an inoperative engine serves one critical purpose: Execute a safe approach and landing with one engine already inoperative. VMC: Minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative (the minimum speed at which directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative), At or above VMC: Directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative, may execute approach and landing. The key: Approach and landing with an inoperative engine requires executing a safe approach and landing - directional control can be maintained at or above VMC.'

Explain approach and landing with an inoperative engine procedure: 'Approach and landing with an inoperative engine procedure: First, maintain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading, avoid overcorrection). Second, maintain airspeed at or above VMC (maintain airspeed at or above VMC, do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC, maintain approach speed appropriate for one engine inoperative). Third, execute approach (maintain approach path, maintain airspeed, maintain directional control, maintain approach angle appropriate for one engine inoperative). Fourth, execute landing (maintain directional control, maintain airspeed, flare at appropriate altitude, touchdown safely, maintain control during landing). The key: Approach and landing with an inoperative engine procedure requires maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, executing approach and landing, and maintaining aircraft control throughout.'

Explain directional control: 'Directional control is critical during approach and landing with an inoperative engine. Asymmetric thrust: Inoperative engine produces no thrust, operating engine produces thrust, creates yaw toward inoperative engine, must counteract with rudder. Full rudder: Apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading, avoid overcorrection. At or above VMC: Directional control can be maintained, may execute approach and landing. The key: Maintain directional control with full rudder opposite to inoperative engine - at or above VMC, directional control can be maintained, may execute approach and landing.'

Explain airspeed control: 'Airspeed control is critical during approach and landing with an inoperative engine. Maintain VMC: Maintain airspeed at or above VMC (minimum control speed, directional control can be maintained), Do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC (directional control cannot be maintained, loss of control risk). Maintain approach speed: Maintain approach speed appropriate for one engine inoperative (typically higher than normal approach speed, provides safety margin, check POH). The key: Maintain airspeed at or above VMC - do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC, maintain approach speed appropriate for one engine inoperative.'

Explain approach procedure: 'Approach procedure is critical for approach and landing with an inoperative engine. Maintain approach path: Maintain approach path appropriate for one engine inoperative (typically steeper approach, maintains airspeed). Maintain airspeed: Maintain airspeed at or above VMC, maintain approach speed appropriate for one engine inoperative. Maintain directional control: Maintain heading, avoid overcorrection, use rudder as needed. Maintain approach angle: Maintain approach angle appropriate for one engine inoperative (typically steeper approach, maintains airspeed). The key: Execute approach with one engine inoperative - maintain approach path, maintain airspeed, maintain directional control, maintain approach angle.'

Explain landing procedure: 'Landing procedure is critical for approach and landing with an inoperative engine. Maintain directional control: Maintain heading, avoid overcorrection, use rudder as needed. Maintain airspeed: Maintain airspeed at or above VMC, maintain approach speed until flare. Flare at appropriate altitude: Begin flare at appropriate altitude (typically 10-20 feet AGL), reduce descent rate, maintain directional control. Touchdown safely: Touchdown at appropriate point, maintain directional control, maintain control during landing. The key: Execute landing with one engine inoperative - maintain directional control, maintain airspeed, flare at appropriate altitude, touchdown safely, maintain control during landing.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not maintaining directional control (loss of directional control, loss of control risk), Not maintaining airspeed at or above VMC (airspeed decreases below VMC, loss of control risk), Not executing approach properly (poor approach path, may not reach landing area), Not executing landing properly (poor landing technique, loss of control risk), Not maintaining aircraft control during landing (loss of control risk). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH emergency procedures: 'Let's check your POH for approach and landing with an inoperative engine procedures. VMC: Check POH (typically 60-70 knots for most light twins). Approach speed: Check POH (typically higher than normal approach speed). Landing procedure: Maintain directional control, maintain airspeed, execute landing. Use this to plan your approach and landing with an inoperative engine procedure.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical multiengine emergency procedure. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe multiengine emergency operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Approach and landing with an inoperative engine is a critical emergency procedure - proper execution can save lives.'

EXECUTE APPROACH:
  Maintain approach path
  Maintain airspeed
  Maintain directional control
  Maintain approach angle appropriate for one engine inoperative
  Typically steeper approach
  Maintains airspeed

EXECUTE LANDING:
  Maintain directional control
  Maintain airspeed
  Flare at appropriate altitude (typically 10-20 feet AGL)
  Touchdown safely
  Maintain control during landing

VMC:
  Minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative

lessonPlans.overview: Maneuvering with one engine inoperative is a critical multiengine procedure that every CFI candidate must master. This maneuver requires performing various flight maneuvers (turns, climbs, descents, level flight) with one engine inoperative while maintaining directional control and airspeed at or above VMC. The technique requires maintaining directional control with full rudder, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, and performing maneuvers safely with reduced performance. Maneuvering with one engine inoperative develops understanding of multiengine operations, decision-making under stress, VMC and multiengine aerodynamics, and the critical importance of maintaining directional control and airspeed during one engine inoperative operations. CFI candidates must master this procedure to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of multiengine operations and prepares students to handle one engine inoperative situations safely. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of maneuvering with one engine inoperative procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering maneuvering with one engine inoperative - a critical multiengine procedure. This maneuver requires performing various flight maneuvers (turns, climbs, descents, level flight) with one engine inoperative while maintaining directional control and airspeed at or above VMC. The technique requires maintaining directional control with full rudder, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, and performing maneuvers safely with reduced performance. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe multiengine flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Maneuvering with One Engine Inoperative'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: recognize one engine inoperative situation, maintain directional control with one engine inoperative, maintain airspeed at or above VMC with one engine inoperative, perform maneuvers with one engine inoperative, explain maneuvering with one engine inoperative procedures, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, and teach maneuvering with one engine inoperative to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about maneuvering with one engine inoperative - turns, climbs, descents, level flight. What would you do? How would you maintain directional control? How would you maintain airspeed? How would you perform maneuvers? What's the critical airspeed?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: maneuvering with one engine inoperative requires performing maneuvers while maintaining directional control and airspeed at or above VMC. Maneuvering with one engine inoperative teaches us to handle one engine inoperative situations during normal flight operations. Let's explore this systematically, starting with understanding VMC and directional control.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 17, your POH Emergency Procedures section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on maneuvering with one engine inoperative procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Maneuvering with one engine inoperative serves one critical purpose: Perform various flight maneuvers safely with one engine inoperative. VMC: Minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative (the minimum speed at which directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative), At or above VMC: Directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative, may perform maneuvers. The key: Maneuvering with one engine inoperative requires performing maneuvers - directional control can be maintained at or above VMC.'

Explain maneuvering with one engine inoperative procedure: 'Maneuvering with one engine inoperative procedure: First, maintain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading, avoid overcorrection). Second, maintain airspeed at or above VMC (maintain airspeed at or above VMC, do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC, maintain appropriate airspeed for maneuver). Third, perform maneuvers (turns, climbs, descents, level flight) with one engine inoperative (maintain directional control, maintain airspeed, perform maneuver safely with reduced performance). The key: Maneuvering with one engine inoperative procedure requires maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, and performing maneuvers safely with reduced performance.'

Explain directional control: 'Directional control is critical during maneuvering with one engine inoperative. Asymmetric thrust: Inoperative engine produces no thrust, operating engine produces thrust, creates yaw toward inoperative engine, must counteract with rudder. Full rudder: Apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading, avoid overcorrection. At or above VMC: Directional control can be maintained, may perform maneuvers. The key: Maintain directional control with full rudder opposite to inoperative engine - at or above VMC, directional control can be maintained, may perform maneuvers.'

Explain airspeed control: 'Airspeed control is critical during maneuvering with one engine inoperative. Maintain VMC: Maintain airspeed at or above VMC (minimum control speed, directional control can be maintained), Do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC (directional control cannot be maintained, loss of control risk). Maintain appropriate airspeed: Maintain appropriate airspeed for maneuver (turns may require higher airspeed, climbs may require VYSE, descents may require higher airspeed, level flight may require cruise airspeed). The key: Maintain airspeed at or above VMC - do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC, maintain appropriate airspeed for maneuver.'

Explain turns: 'Turns with one engine inoperative: Maintain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain coordination, avoid excessive bank angles), Maintain airspeed at or above VMC (maintain airspeed at or above VMC, may require higher airspeed for turns, do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC), Perform turn safely (shallow to medium bank angles preferred, typically 15-30° bank, avoid steep turns, maintain positive rate of climb or level flight). The key: Turns with one engine inoperative require maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, and performing turn safely with reduced performance.'

Explain climbs: 'Climbs with one engine inoperative: Maintain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading), Maintain airspeed at or above VMC (maintain VYSE if possible - best rate of climb speed with one engine inoperative, typically 5-10 knots above VMC, do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC), Perform climb safely (climb performance is reduced, maintain positive rate of climb, maintain safe altitude). The key: Climbs with one engine inoperative require maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC (VYSE if possible), and performing climb safely with reduced performance.'

Explain descents: 'Descents with one engine inoperative: Maintain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading), Maintain airspeed at or above VMC (maintain airspeed at or above VMC, may require higher airspeed for descents, do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC), Perform descent safely (descent performance may be different, maintain control, maintain safe altitude). The key: Descents with one engine inoperative require maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, and performing descent safely.'

Explain level flight: 'Level flight with one engine inoperative: Maintain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading), Maintain airspeed at or above VMC (maintain airspeed at or above VMC, maintain appropriate cruise airspeed, do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC), Perform level flight safely (maintain altitude, maintain heading, maintain control). The key: Level flight with one engine inoperative requires maintaining directional control, maintaining airspeed at or above VMC, and performing level flight safely.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not maintaining directional control (loss of directional control, loss of control risk), Not maintaining airspeed at or above VMC (airspeed decreases below VMC, loss of control risk), Not performing maneuvers safely (excessive bank angles, steep turns, unsafe maneuvers), Not maintaining aircraft control during maneuvers (loss of control risk). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH emergency procedures: 'Let's check your POH for maneuvering with one engine inoperative procedures. VMC: Check POH (typically 60-70 knots for most light twins). VYSE: Check POH (typically 5-10 knots above VMC). Maneuvering procedures: Maintain directional control, maintain airspeed at or above VMC, perform maneuvers safely. Use this to plan your maneuvering with one engine inoperative procedure.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical multiengine procedure. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe multiengine operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Maneuvering with one engine inoperative is a critical procedure - proper execution can save lives.'

INOPERATIVE ENGINE:
  One engine inoperative
  Asymmetric thrust
  Yaw toward inoperative engine

MAINTAIN DIRECTIONAL CONTROL:
  Apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine
  Maintain heading
  Avoid overcorrection
  At or above VMC: Directional control can be maintained, may perform maneuvers

MAINTAIN AIRSPEED:
  Maintain airspeed at or above VMC
  Maintain appropriate airspeed for maneuver
  Do not allow airspeed to decrease below VMC

PERFORM MANEUVERS:
  Turns: Shallow to medium bank angles (15-30°), maintain directional control, maintain airspeed
  Climbs: Maintain VYSE if possible, climb performance reduced, maintain directional control
  Descents: Maintain airspeed, maintain directional control, maintain control
  Level flight: Maintain altitude, maintain heading, maintain directional control

VMC:
  Minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative
  At or above VMC: May perform maneuvers

KEY:
  Maintain directional control
  Maintain airspeed at or above VMC
  Perform maneuvers safely

lessonPlans.overview: VMC demonstration is a critical multiengine procedure that every CFI candidate must master. This maneuver demonstrates VMC (minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative) by reducing airspeed to VMC with one engine inoperative, recognizing loss of directional control at or below VMC, and demonstrating recovery from loss of directional control. The technique requires reducing airspeed gradually to VMC, recognizing the point where directional control is lost, and recovering promptly by increasing airspeed above VMC. VMC demonstration develops understanding of multiengine operations, decision-making under stress, VMC and multiengine aerodynamics, and the critical importance of maintaining airspeed above VMC. CFI candidates must master this procedure to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of VMC and prepares students to understand the critical importance of maintaining airspeed above VMC. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of VMC demonstration procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering VMC demonstration - a critical multiengine procedure. This maneuver demonstrates VMC (minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative) by reducing airspeed to VMC with one engine inoperative, recognizing loss of directional control at or below VMC, and demonstrating recovery from loss of directional control. The technique requires reducing airspeed gradually to VMC, recognizing the point where directional control is lost, and recovering promptly by increasing airspeed above VMC. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe multiengine flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'VMC Demonstration'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: explain VMC, demonstrate VMC by reducing airspeed to VMC with one engine inoperative, recognize loss of directional control at or below VMC, demonstrate recovery from loss of directional control, explain VMC demonstration procedures, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, and teach VMC demonstration to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about VMC - minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative. What happens if you allow airspeed to decrease below VMC? How would you demonstrate VMC? How would you recognize loss of directional control? How would you recover?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: VMC demonstration requires reducing airspeed to VMC to show where directional control is lost. VMC demonstration teaches us the critical importance of maintaining airspeed above VMC. Let's explore this systematically, starting with understanding VMC.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 17, your POH Emergency Procedures section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on VMC demonstration procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'VMC demonstration serves one critical purpose: Demonstrate VMC (minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative) to show where directional control is lost. VMC: Minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative (the minimum speed at which directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative), At or above VMC: Directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative, Below VMC: Directional control cannot be maintained with one engine inoperative, loss of directional control occurs. The key: VMC demonstration shows the critical airspeed below which directional control cannot be maintained.'

Explain VMC demonstration procedure: 'VMC demonstration procedure: First, establish one engine inoperative (simulate one engine inoperative, maintain directional control, maintain airspeed above VMC). Second, reduce airspeed gradually to VMC (reduce power on operating engine gradually, reduce airspeed gradually, maintain directional control as long as possible, monitor airspeed constantly). Third, recognize loss of directional control (recognize point where directional control is lost, typically at or just below VMC, aircraft begins to yaw toward inoperative engine, full rudder no longer effective). Fourth, recover promptly (increase power on operating engine, increase airspeed above VMC, regain directional control, maintain safe altitude). The key: VMC demonstration procedure requires reducing airspeed to VMC, recognizing loss of directional control, and recovering promptly by increasing airspeed above VMC.'

Explain airspeed reduction: 'Airspeed reduction is critical for VMC demonstration. Reduce gradually: Reduce power on operating engine gradually (reduces thrust, allows airspeed to decrease gradually), Reduce airspeed gradually (allows time to recognize loss of directional control, prevents sudden loss of control), Monitor airspeed constantly (know when approaching VMC, know when at VMC, know when below VMC). The key: Reduce airspeed gradually to VMC - allows time to recognize loss of directional control, prevents sudden loss of control.'

Explain recognition of loss of directional control: 'Recognition of loss of directional control is critical for VMC demonstration. Signs of loss of directional control: Aircraft begins to yaw toward inoperative engine (yaw increases, cannot be controlled with rudder), Full rudder no longer effective (full rudder opposite to inoperative engine no longer maintains heading), Heading changes uncontrollably (aircraft turns toward inoperative engine, cannot maintain heading). The key: Recognize loss of directional control promptly - aircraft begins to yaw toward inoperative engine, full rudder no longer effective.'

Explain recovery procedure: 'Recovery procedure is critical for VMC demonstration. Increase power: Increase power on operating engine (increases thrust, increases airspeed, helps regain directional control). Increase airspeed: Increase airspeed above VMC (allows directional control to be regained, typically 5-10 knots above VMC minimum). Regain directional control: Apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading, regain control. Maintain safe altitude: Maintain safe altitude during recovery, avoid altitude loss, maintain control. The key: Recover promptly by increasing airspeed above VMC - allows directional control to be regained, maintains safety.'

Explain safety considerations: 'Safety considerations are critical for VMC demonstration. Minimum altitude: Practice at adequate altitude (minimum 5000 AGL for practice, provides safety margin in case of altitude loss, higher altitude is better). Recovery altitude: Maintain safe altitude during recovery (allows time to recover, prevents ground contact, maintains safety). Instructor readiness: Instructor must be ready to take controls (loss of directional control can occur quickly, must be ready to assist, must maintain safety). The key: Safety is paramount - practice at adequate altitude, maintain safe altitude during recovery, instructor must be ready to take controls.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not reducing airspeed gradually (sudden airspeed reduction, sudden loss of control risk), Not recognizing loss of directional control promptly (delayed recognition, worsens situation), Not recovering promptly (delayed recovery, worsens situation, altitude loss risk), Not maintaining safe altitude (insufficient altitude, ground contact risk), Not being ready to take controls (instructor not ready, safety risk). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH emergency procedures: 'Let's check your POH for VMC demonstration procedures. VMC: Check POH (typically 60-70 knots for most light twins). Demonstration procedure: Reduce airspeed gradually to VMC, recognize loss of directional control, recover promptly. Use this to plan your VMC demonstration.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical multiengine procedure. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe multiengine operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: VMC demonstration is a critical procedure - proper execution demonstrates the importance of maintaining airspeed above VMC.'

VMC demonstration complete.'

Explain technique: 'Notice how I performed the VMC demonstration: established one engine inoperative (left engine inoperative, maintained directional control, maintained airspeed above VMC), reduced airspeed gradually to VMC (reduced power gradually, reduced airspeed gradually, maintained directional control as long as possible, monitored airspeed constantly), recognized loss of directional control (recognized point where directional control was lost at 64 knots below VMC 65 knots, aircraft began to yaw toward left, full rudder no longer effective), and recovered promptly (increased power, increased airspeed above VMC, regained directional control, maintained safe altitude). instructorActions: Encourage: 'Your airplane. I'll guide you through this. First, I'll simulate one engine inoperative, then you'll reduce airspeed gradually to VMC, recognize loss of directional control, and recover promptly.'

Simulate inoperative engine: 'Simulating one engine inoperative... left engine inoperative... maintain directional control... apply full right rudder... full right rudder? Good. Maintain heading... good. Airspeed? Good. Above VMC? Good. Maintain airspeed above VMC... good.'

Guide airspeed reduction: 'Reducing airspeed gradually to VMC... reduce power on operating engine gradually... power reducing? Good. Monitor airspeed... what's your airspeed? Good. Airspeed decreasing? Good. Maintain directional control... good. Airspeed? Good. Approaching VMC? Good.'

Guide recognition: 'Approaching VMC... airspeed? Good. At VMC? Good. Below VMC? Good. Recognize loss of directional control... is aircraft yawing toward inoperative engine? Good. Is full rudder still effective? Good. Loss of directional control recognized? Good.'

Guide recovery: 'Recovering promptly... increase power on operating engine... power increasing? Good. Increase airspeed... airspeed increasing? Good. Above VMC? Good. Regain directional control... apply full right rudder... good. Maintain heading... good. Directional control regained? Good. Recovery complete. Good.'

If not reducing gradually: 'I notice you're not reducing airspeed gradually - remember, reduce airspeed gradually to VMC (reduce power on operating engine gradually, reduce airspeed gradually, maintain directional control as long as possible, monitor airspeed constantly). Sudden airspeed reduction causes sudden loss of control. There, airspeed reducing gradually. Good.'

If not recognizing loss of control: 'I notice you're not recognizing loss of directional control promptly - remember, recognize loss of directional control (recognize point where directional control is lost, typically at or just below VMC, aircraft begins to yaw toward inoperative engine, full rudder no longer effective). Provide feedback: 'Excellent! Your VMC demonstration was good. You reduced airspeed gradually to VMC, recognized loss of directional control, and recovered promptly. Your understanding of VMC is improving. You're really getting the feel for VMC demonstration.'

Address errors constructively: 'I noticed you didn't recover promptly on that one - remember, recover promptly by increasing airspeed above VMC. Delayed recovery worsens situation and causes altitude loss. Next time, recover immediately when loss of directional control is recognized.'

diagrams.asciiArt:
VMC DEMONSTRATION PROCEDURE

ESTABLISH ONE ENGINE INOPERATIVE:
  Simulate one engine inoperative
  Maintain directional control
  Maintain airspeed above VMC

REDUCE AIRSPEED GRADUALLY TO VMC:
  Reduce power on operating engine gradually
  Reduce airspeed gradually
  Maintain directional control as long as possible
  Monitor airspeed constantly
  Airspeed: 90 knots... 85 knots... 80 knots... 75 knots... 70 knots... 65 knots VMC

RECOGNIZE LOSS OF DIRECTIONAL CONTROL:
  Recognize point where directional control is lost
  Typically at or just below VMC
  Aircraft begins to yaw toward inoperative engine
  Full rudder no longer effective
  Heading changes uncontrollably

RECOVER PROMPTLY:
  Increase power on operating engine
  Increase airspeed above VMC
  Regain directional control
  Maintain safe altitude
  Airspeed: 66 knots... 70 knots... 75 knots... above VMC

VMC:
  Minimum control speed with critical engine inoperative
  At or above VMC: Directional control can be maintained
  Below VMC: Directional control cannot be maintained, loss of directional control occurs

KEY:
  Reduce airspeed gradually
  Recognize loss of directional control
  Recover promptly

scenarios.situation: You're demonstrating VMC with the left engine inoperative. Your airspeed is 90 knots. VMC is 65 knots. You begin reducing airspeed gradually. At 64 knots, the aircraft begins to yaw toward the left engine. Full right rudder is no longer effective. What should you do?
options: Continue reducing airspeed to see what happens
Recover promptly: Increase power on operating engine, increase airspeed above VMC (to at least 70 knots), regain directional control, maintain safe altitude
Just wait and see if it corrects itself
Try harder with the rudder
scenarios.correct: Recover promptly: Increase power on operating engine, increase airspeed above VMC (to at least 70 knots), regain directional control, maintain safe altitude
scenarios.explanation: When you recognize loss of directional control during VMC demonstration (at 64 knots below VMC 65 knots, aircraft yawing toward left engine, full right rudder no longer effective), you must recover promptly. Don't continue reducing airspeed - you've already demonstrated VMC and loss of directional control. Execute the recovery: Increase power on operating engine (increases thrust, increases airspeed, helps regain directional control), Increase airspeed above VMC (increase airspeed to at least 70 knots - above VMC 65 knots, allows directional control to be regained), Regain directional control (apply full rudder opposite to inoperative engine, maintain heading, regain control), Maintain safe altitude (maintain safe altitude during recovery, avoid altitude loss, maintain control). Don't continue reducing airspeed - you've already demonstrated VMC. Don't just wait - loss of directional control worsens with time. Don't try harder with the rudder - full rudder is already applied, airspeed must be increased above VMC. The key is recovering promptly by increasing airspeed above VMC - allows directional control to be regained, maintains safety.

tolerances: VMC: Check POH (typically 60-70 knots for most light twins)
Airspeed reduction: Gradual (allows time to recognize loss of directional control)
Recovery airspeed: At least 5-10 knots above VMC (allows directional control to be regained)
Minimum altitude: 5000 AGL for practice (provides safety margin)

lessonPlans.overview: Demonstration of effects of various airspeeds and configurations during engine inoperative is a critical multiengine procedure that every CFI candidate must master. This maneuver demonstrates how different airspeeds and configurations affect engine inoperative performance, directional control, and aircraft handling. The technique requires demonstrating various airspeeds (high, medium, low) and configurations (clean, gear down, flaps down) with one engine inoperative, observing the effects on directional control, performance, and handling characteristics. Demonstration of effects of various airspeeds and configurations during engine inoperative develops understanding of multiengine operations, decision-making under stress, VMC and multiengine aerodynamics, and the critical importance of airspeed and configuration management during one engine inoperative operations. CFI candidates must master this procedure to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of multiengine operations and prepares students to understand how airspeed and configuration affect engine inoperative performance. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of demonstration of effects of various airspeeds and configurations during engine inoperative procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering demonstration of effects of various airspeeds and configurations during engine inoperative - a critical multiengine procedure. This maneuver demonstrates how different airspeeds and configurations affect engine inoperative performance, directional control, and aircraft handling. The technique requires demonstrating various airspeeds and configurations with one engine inoperative, observing the effects on directional control, performance, and handling characteristics. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe multiengine flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Demonstration of Effects of Various Airspeeds and Configurations during Engine Inoperative'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: explain effects of various airspeeds during engine inoperative performance, explain effects of various configurations during engine inoperative performance, demonstrate effects of various airspeeds with one engine inoperative, demonstrate effects of various configurations with one engine inoperative, explain relationship between airspeed, configuration, and engine inoperative performance, explain relationship to real-world scenarios, and teach demonstration of effects of various airspeeds and configurations during engine inoperative to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about different airspeeds and configurations with one engine inoperative - high airspeed vs low airspeed, clean configuration vs gear and flaps down. How would each affect directional control? How would each affect performance? How would each affect handling?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: different airspeeds and configurations affect engine inoperative performance differently. Demonstration of effects of various airspeeds and configurations during engine inoperative teaches us how to manage airspeed and configuration during one engine inoperative operations. Let's explore this systematically, starting with understanding airspeed effects.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 17, your POH Emergency Procedures section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on demonstration of effects of various airspeeds and configurations during engine inoperative procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Demonstration of effects of various airspeeds and configurations during engine inoperative serves one critical purpose: Demonstrate how different airspeeds and configurations affect engine inoperative performance. Airspeed effects: High airspeed (better directional control, more rudder effectiveness, easier to maintain heading), Low airspeed (less directional control, less rudder effectiveness, harder to maintain heading, approaching VMC), Configuration effects: Clean configuration (better performance, higher VMC, easier to maintain control), Gear down (increased drag, lower VMC, more rudder required), Flaps down (increased drag, lower VMC, more rudder required). The key: Different airspeeds and configurations affect engine inoperative performance differently - understanding these effects is critical for safe operations.'

Explain airspeed effects: 'Airspeed effects during engine inoperative: High airspeed (90-100 knots or higher): Better directional control (more rudder effectiveness, easier to maintain heading, less yaw), More control authority (rudder more effective, easier to counteract asymmetric thrust), Easier to maintain heading. Low airspeed (approaching VMC): Less directional control (less rudder effectiveness, harder to maintain heading, more yaw), Less control authority (rudder less effective, harder to counteract asymmetric thrust), Harder to maintain heading, approaching VMC (directional control becomes critical). The key: Higher airspeed provides better directional control - lower airspeed reduces directional control and approaches VMC.'

Explain configuration effects: 'Configuration effects during engine inoperative: Clean configuration: Better performance (less drag, better climb performance, better speed), Higher VMC (clean configuration typically has higher VMC, more margin above VMC), Easier to maintain control (less drag, less yaw, easier directional control). Gear down: Increased drag (gear down increases drag, reduces performance), Lower VMC (gear down typically lowers VMC, less margin above VMC), More rudder required (increased drag increases yaw, requires more rudder). Flaps down: Increased drag (flaps down increases drag, reduces performance), Lower VMC (flaps down typically lowers VMC, less margin above VMC), More rudder required (increased drag increases yaw, requires more rudder). The key: Clean configuration provides better performance and higher VMC - gear and flaps down increase drag and lower VMC.'

Explain demonstration procedure: 'Demonstration procedure: First, establish one engine inoperative (simulate one engine inoperative, maintain directional control, maintain airspeed above VMC). Second, demonstrate various airspeeds (high airspeed 90-100 knots, medium airspeed 75-85 knots, low airspeed approaching VMC, observe effects on directional control and handling). Third, demonstrate various configurations (clean configuration, gear down, flaps down, observe effects on directional control, performance, and VMC). Fourth, explain relationship between airspeed, configuration, and performance (higher airspeed provides better directional control, clean configuration provides better performance, gear and flaps down increase drag and lower VMC). The key: Demonstration procedure requires establishing one engine inoperative, demonstrating various airspeeds and configurations, and explaining the effects on performance.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not maintaining directional control (loss of directional control, loss of control risk), Not maintaining airspeed at or above VMC (airspeed decreases below VMC, loss of control risk), Not observing effects properly (missing important effects, incomplete understanding), Not explaining relationship properly (incomplete explanation, student confusion). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH emergency procedures: 'Let's check your POH for effects of various airspeeds and configurations during engine inoperative. VMC: Check POH for different configurations (clean, gear down, flaps down). Performance: Check POH for performance with one engine inoperative. Use this to plan your demonstration.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical multiengine procedure. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach safe multiengine operations and proper technique. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Demonstration of effects of various airspeeds and configurations during engine inoperative is a critical procedure - proper execution demonstrates the importance of airspeed and configuration management.'

diagrams.asciiArt:
DEMONSTRATION OF EFFECTS OF VARIOUS AIRSPEEDS AND CONFIGURATIONS

AIRSPEED EFFECTS:
  High airspeed (90-100 knots):
    - Better directional control
    - More rudder effectiveness
    - Easier to maintain heading
    - Less yaw

  Medium airspeed (75-85 knots):
    - Moderate directional control
    - Moderate rudder effectiveness
    - Moderate yaw

  Low airspeed (approaching VMC):
    - Less directional control
    - Less rudder effectiveness
    - Harder to maintain heading
    - More yaw
    - Approaching VMC

CONFIGURATION EFFECTS:
  Clean configuration:
    - Better performance
    - Less drag
    - Higher VMC
    - Easier to maintain control

  Gear down:
    - Increased drag
    - Lower VMC
    - More rudder required
    - More yaw

  Flaps down:
    - Increased drag
    - Lower VMC
    - More rudder required
    - More yaw

RELATIONSHIP:
  Higher airspeed + Clean configuration = Better performance and control

scenarios.situation: You're demonstrating effects of various airspeeds and configurations with the left engine inoperative. You're at high airspeed (95 knots) in clean configuration. You observe good directional control. You then reduce airspeed to 70 knots and extend landing gear and flaps. What effects would you observe?
options: No change - airspeed and configuration don't affect performance

Reduced performance: Less directional control (less rudder effectiveness, harder to maintain heading, more yaw), increased drag (gear and flaps down increase drag, reduce performance), lower VMC (gear and flaps down lower VMC, less margin above VMC), more rudder required (increased drag increases yaw, requires more rudder)

It depends - no clear pattern
scenarios.correct: Reduced performance: Less directional control (less rudder effectiveness, harder to maintain heading, more yaw), increased drag (gear and flaps down increase drag, reduce performance), lower VMC (gear and flaps down lower VMC, less margin above VMC), more rudder required (increased drag increases yaw, requires more rudder)
scenarios.explanation: When you reduce airspeed from high (95 knots) to low (70 knots) and extend landing gear and flaps with one engine inoperative, you would observe reduced performance. Airspeed effects: Lower airspeed (70 knots) reduces directional control compared to high airspeed (95 knots) - less rudder effectiveness, harder to maintain heading, more yaw, approaching VMC. Configuration effects: Gear and flaps down increase drag compared to clean configuration - increased drag reduces performance, lower VMC (gear and flaps down typically lower VMC, less margin above VMC), more rudder required (increased drag increases yaw, requires more rudder). Combined effects: Lower airspeed combined with gear and flaps down results in reduced performance - less directional control, increased drag, lower VMC, more rudder required. Don't think airspeed and configuration don't affect performance - they significantly affect performance. Don't think lower airspeed and gear/flaps down always help - they reduce performance. Don't think it depends - there's a clear pattern. The key is understanding that lower airspeed and gear/flaps down reduce performance - less directional control, increased drag, lower VMC, more rudder required.

lessonPlans.overview: After landing, parking, and securing is a critical postflight procedure that every CFI candidate must master. This procedure requires executing after landing procedures (clearing runway, taxiing to parking), parking procedures (positioning aircraft, setting parking brake, chocking wheels), securing procedures (shutting down engine, securing controls, securing systems), performing postflight inspection, and completing required documentation. After landing, parking, and securing develops understanding of postflight procedures, aircraft care, safety procedures, and the critical importance of proper aircraft securing. CFI candidates must master this procedure to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of postflight procedures and prepares students to properly secure aircraft after flight. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of after landing, parking, and securing procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering after landing, parking, and securing - a critical postflight procedure. This procedure requires executing after landing procedures, parking procedures, securing procedures, performing postflight inspection, and completing required documentation. The technique requires following proper procedures systematically to ensure aircraft is properly secured and ready for next flight. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe flight operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'After Landing, Parking, and Securing'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: execute after landing procedures, execute parking procedures, execute securing procedures, perform postflight inspection, complete required documentation, explain after landing, parking, and securing procedures, explain relationship to real-world operations, and teach after landing, parking, and securing to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about after landing - you've just landed, you're on the runway. What do you do next? How do you clear the runway? How do you park the aircraft? How do you secure it? What documentation do you need to complete?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: after landing, parking, and securing requires following proper procedures systematically. After landing, parking, and securing teaches us to properly care for the aircraft and ensure it's ready for the next flight. Let's explore this systematically, starting with after landing procedures.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Airplane Flying Handbook Chapter 8, your POH Normal Procedures section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on after landing, parking, and securing procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'After landing, parking, and securing serves one critical purpose: Properly secure aircraft after flight to ensure safety and readiness for next flight. After landing procedures: Clear runway safely, taxi to parking area, follow taxi instructions. Parking procedures: Position aircraft properly, set parking brake, chock wheels, secure aircraft position. Securing procedures: Shut down engine properly, secure controls, secure systems, ensure aircraft is safe. The key: After landing, parking, and securing requires following proper procedures systematically to ensure aircraft is properly secured.'

Explain after landing procedures: 'After landing procedures: First, clear runway (exit runway promptly, clear runway completely, follow taxi instructions, maintain situational awareness). Second, taxi to parking (follow taxi instructions, maintain safe taxi speed typically 10-15 knots, maintain situational awareness, watch for other aircraft and vehicles). Third, follow airport procedures (follow airport signs and markings, follow ATC instructions if applicable, maintain communication if required). The key: After landing procedures require clearing runway safely and taxiing to parking area following proper procedures.'

Explain parking procedures: 'Parking procedures: First, position aircraft properly (position aircraft in designated parking area, ensure adequate clearance from other aircraft typically 10-15 feet minimum, position for easy access and egress, consider wind direction). Second, set parking brake (set parking brake firmly, verify parking brake is set, ensure aircraft will not move). Third, chock wheels (place chocks in front of and behind wheels, ensure chocks are properly positioned, verify aircraft is secure). The key: Parking procedures require positioning aircraft properly, setting parking brake, and chocking wheels to ensure aircraft is secure.'

Explain securing procedures: 'Securing procedures: First, shut down engine (reduce power to idle, mixture idle cutoff, turn off magnetos, turn off master switch, verify engine is shut down). Second, secure controls (set controls to neutral position, secure control locks if applicable, verify controls are secure). Third, secure systems (turn off all electrical equipment, turn off fuel pump if applicable, secure fuel selector, verify all systems are secure). The key: Securing procedures require shutting down engine properly, securing controls, and securing systems to ensure aircraft is safe.'

Explain postflight inspection: 'Postflight inspection: First, inspect aircraft exterior (inspect for damage, inspect for leaks, inspect for loose items, note any discrepancies). Second, inspect aircraft interior (inspect for damage, inspect for loose items, verify all equipment is secure, note any discrepancies). Third, document discrepancies (note discrepancies in logbook if required, report discrepancies to maintenance if required, ensure discrepancies are addressed). The key: Postflight inspection requires inspecting aircraft for damage and discrepancies and documenting them properly.'

Explain documentation: 'Documentation: First, complete logbook entries (enter flight time, enter flight date, enter aircraft identification, enter pilot information, note any discrepancies). Second, complete flight records (complete flight log if required, complete maintenance log if required, complete any other required records). Third, file flight plan closure (close flight plan if opened, notify FSS if required, ensure flight plan is properly closed). The key: Documentation requires completing all required logbook entries and flight records properly.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not clearing runway promptly (runway incursion risk, traffic conflict risk), Not following parking procedures properly (aircraft not secure, damage risk), Not securing aircraft properly (aircraft not safe, damage risk), Not performing postflight inspection (missed discrepancies, safety risk), Not completing documentation (regulatory violation, record-keeping issues). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH normal procedures: 'Let's check your POH for after landing, parking, and securing procedures. After landing: Clear runway, taxi to parking. Parking: Position aircraft, set parking brake, chock wheels. Securing: Shut down engine, secure controls, secure systems. Use this to plan your after landing, parking, and securing procedure.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as a critical postflight procedure. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach proper aircraft care and safety procedures. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: After landing, parking, and securing is a critical procedure - proper execution ensures aircraft safety and readiness for next flight.'

diagrams.description: Visual representation of after landing, parking, and securing procedure.
diagrams.asciiArt:
AFTER LANDING, PARKING, AND SECURING PROCEDURE

AFTER LANDING:
  1. Clear runway promptly
     - Exit runway promptly
     - Clear runway completely
     - Follow taxi instructions
     - Maintain situational awareness

  2. Taxi to parking
     - Follow taxi instructions
     - Maintain safe taxi speed (10-15 knots)
     - Maintain situational awareness
     - Watch for other aircraft and vehicles

  3. Follow airport procedures
     - Follow airport signs and markings
     - Follow ATC instructions if applicable
     - Maintain communication if required

PARKING:
  1. Position aircraft properly
     - Position in designated parking area
     - Ensure adequate clearance (10-15 feet minimum)
     - Position for easy access and egress
     - Consider wind direction

  2. Set parking brake
     - Set parking brake firmly
     - Verify parking brake is set
     - Ensure aircraft will not move

  3. Chock wheels
     - Place chocks in front of and behind wheels
     - Ensure chocks are properly positioned
     - Verify aircraft is secure

SECURING:
  1. Shut down engine
     - Reduce power to idle
     - Mixture idle cutoff
     - Turn off magnetos
     - Turn off master switch
     - Verify engine is shut down

  2. Secure controls
     - Set controls to neutral position
     - Secure control locks if applicable
     - Verify controls are secure

  3. Secure systems
     - Turn off all electrical equipment
     - Turn off fuel pump if applicable
     - Secure fuel selector
     - Verify all systems are secure

POSTFLIGHT INSPECTION:
  1. Inspect aircraft exterior
     - Inspect for damage
     - Inspect for leaks
     - Inspect for loose items
     - Note any discrepancies

  2. Inspect aircraft interior
     - Inspect for damage
     - Inspect for loose items
     - Verify all equipment is secure
     - Note any discrepancies

  3. Document discrepancies
     - Note discrepancies in logbook if required
     - Report discrepancies to maintenance if required
     - Ensure discrepancies are addressed

DOCUMENTATION:
  1. Complete logbook entries
     - Enter flight time
     - Enter flight date
     - Enter aircraft identification
     - Enter pilot information
     - Note any discrepancies

  2. Complete flight records
     - Complete flight log if required
     - Complete maintenance log if required
     - Complete any other required records

  3. File flight plan closure
     - Close flight plan if opened
     - Notify FSS if required
     - Ensure flight plan is properly closed

KEY:
  Follow procedures systematically
  Ensure aircraft is properly secured
  Complete all required documentation
