lessonPlans.overview: Seaplane post-landing procedures are critical seaplane operations that every CFI candidate must master. These procedures require executing seaplane post-landing procedures (taxiing on water, approaching dock/beach), anchoring procedures (selecting anchor location, deploying anchor, securing anchor), docking procedures (approaching dock, securing to dock, securing aircraft), mooring procedures (approaching mooring, securing to mooring, securing aircraft), and ramping/beaching procedures (approaching beach/ramp, beaching aircraft, securing aircraft). Seaplane post-landing procedures develop understanding of seaplane operations, water operations, safety procedures, and the critical importance of proper seaplane securing. CFI candidates must master these procedures to ACS standards while simultaneously teaching, as it demonstrates understanding of seaplane operations and prepares students to properly secure seaplanes after landing. This comprehensive lesson provides complete coverage of seaplane post-landing procedures, ACS performance standards, common student errors, and proven teaching techniques.

instructorActions: Greet student warmly: 'Good morning! Today we're covering seaplane post-landing procedures - critical seaplane operations. These procedures require executing seaplane post-landing procedures, anchoring procedures, docking procedures, mooring procedures, and ramping/beaching procedures. The technique requires following proper procedures systematically to ensure seaplane is properly secured after landing on water. Mastering this is absolutely essential for safe seaplane operations and effective instruction.'
Write lesson title on whiteboard: 'Seaplane Post-Landing Procedures'

Present objectives clearly: 'By the end of this lesson, you'll be able to: execute seaplane post-landing procedures, execute anchoring procedures, execute docking procedures, execute mooring procedures, execute ramping/beaching procedures, explain seaplane post-landing procedures, explain relationship to real-world operations, and teach seaplane post-landing procedures to students.'

Ask opening question: 'Think about seaplane post-landing - you've just landed on water. What do you do next? How do you approach a dock? How do you anchor? How do you beach the aircraft? What are the different options?'
Listen actively to student response, noting their understanding and experience level

Transition: 'Great observations. What you're describing touches on the key challenge: seaplane post-landing procedures require choosing the appropriate method (anchoring, docking, mooring, or beaching) and executing it properly. Seaplane post-landing procedures teach us to properly secure seaplanes after landing on water. Let's explore this systematically, starting with post-landing procedures.'

Show reference materials: 'We'll be referencing the Seaplane, Skiplane, and Float/Ski Equipped Helicopter Operations Handbook, your POH Seaplane Operations section, and the ACS for standards. These provide comprehensive guidance on seaplane post-landing procedures.'

Explain the purpose: 'Seaplane post-landing procedures serve one critical purpose: Properly secure seaplane after landing on water using appropriate method. Post-landing procedures: Taxi on water, approach dock/beach, select appropriate securing method. Securing methods: Anchoring (deploy anchor, secure anchor, secure aircraft), Docking (approach dock, secure to dock, secure aircraft), Mooring (approach mooring, secure to mooring, secure aircraft), Ramping/Beaching (approach beach/ramp, beach aircraft, secure aircraft). The key: Seaplane post-landing procedures require choosing appropriate securing method and executing it properly.'

Explain post-landing procedures: 'Post-landing procedures: First, taxi on water (taxi on water after landing, maintain control, maintain safe speed typically 5-10 knots, maintain situational awareness, watch for obstacles and other watercraft). Second, approach dock/beach (approach dock or beach area, maintain control, maintain safe speed, maintain situational awareness, consider wind and current). Third, select appropriate securing method (choose anchoring, docking, mooring, or beaching based on conditions and availability, consider wind, current, and water depth). The key: Post-landing procedures require taxiing on water and approaching dock/beach to select appropriate securing method.'

Explain anchoring procedures: 'Anchoring procedures: First, select anchor location (select suitable anchor location, consider water depth typically 10-20 feet, consider bottom type, consider wind and current, ensure adequate clearance from other watercraft and obstacles). Second, deploy anchor (approach anchor location, reduce speed, deploy anchor from bow, allow anchor to set, verify anchor is holding). Third, secure anchor (secure anchor line to aircraft, verify anchor line is secure, verify anchor is holding, ensure adequate scope typically 5:1 to 7:1 ratio). Fourth, secure aircraft (shut down engine, secure controls, secure systems, ensure aircraft is secure). The key: Anchoring procedures require selecting anchor location, deploying anchor, securing anchor, and securing aircraft.'

Explain docking procedures: 'Docking procedures: First, approach dock (approach dock into wind or current, maintain control, maintain safe speed typically 2-5 knots, maintain situational awareness, watch for obstacles). Second, secure to dock (approach dock slowly, use dock lines to secure aircraft, secure bow line first, secure stern line, secure aircraft to dock, verify all lines are secure). Third, secure aircraft (shut down engine, secure controls, secure systems, ensure aircraft is secure, ensure aircraft is properly secured to dock). The key: Docking procedures require approaching dock, securing to dock, and securing aircraft.'

Explain mooring procedures: 'Mooring procedures: First, approach mooring (approach mooring buoy or float, maintain control, maintain safe speed typically 2-5 knots, maintain situational awareness, watch for obstacles). Second, secure to mooring (approach mooring slowly, attach mooring line to aircraft, secure bow line to mooring, secure stern line if applicable, verify all lines are secure). Third, secure aircraft (shut down engine, secure controls, secure systems, ensure aircraft is secure, ensure aircraft is properly secured to mooring). The key: Mooring procedures require approaching mooring, securing to mooring, and securing aircraft.'

Explain ramping/beaching procedures: 'Ramping/beaching procedures: First, approach beach/ramp (approach beach or ramp area, maintain control, maintain safe speed typically 2-5 knots, maintain situational awareness, watch for obstacles and shallow water). Second, beach aircraft (approach beach/ramp slowly, ground aircraft on beach/ramp, ensure aircraft is properly positioned, ensure aircraft is secure on beach/ramp). Third, secure aircraft (shut down engine, secure controls, secure systems, ensure aircraft is secure, ensure aircraft is properly secured on beach/ramp, consider tide if applicable). The key: Ramping/beaching procedures require approaching beach/ramp, beaching aircraft, and securing aircraft.'

Explain common errors: 'Common errors to watch for: Not maintaining control during approach (loss of control, collision risk), Not selecting appropriate securing method (unsuitable method, safety risk), Not securing properly (aircraft not secure, damage risk), Not considering wind and current (poor approach, collision risk), Not securing aircraft systems (aircraft not safe, damage risk). We'll address each of these during practice.'

Show POH seaplane operations: 'Let's check your POH for seaplane post-landing procedures. Post-landing: Taxi on water, approach dock/beach. Anchoring: Select location, deploy anchor, secure anchor. Docking: Approach dock, secure to dock. Mooring: Approach mooring, secure to mooring. Beaching: Approach beach/ramp, beach aircraft. Use this to plan your seaplane post-landing procedures.'

Set context: 'As a CFI, you'll teach this to students as critical seaplane operations. Understanding these fundamentals enables you to teach proper seaplane securing and safety procedures. This is also a checkride task - you must demonstrate proficiency while teaching. Remember: Seaplane post-landing procedures are critical - proper execution ensures seaplane safety and readiness for next flight.'

diagrams.description: Visual representation of seaplane post-landing procedures.
diagrams.asciiArt:
SEAPLANE POST-LANDING PROCEDURES

POST-LANDING:
  1. Taxi on water
     - Maintain control
     - Maintain safe speed (5-10 knots)
     - Maintain situational awareness
     - Watch for obstacles and other watercraft

  2. Approach dock/beach
     - Approach dock or beach area
     - Maintain control
     - Maintain safe speed
     - Consider wind and current

  3. Select appropriate securing method
     - Choose anchoring, docking, mooring, or beaching
     - Consider wind, current, and water depth
     - Consider conditions and availability

SECURING METHODS:

ANCHORING:
  1. Select anchor location
     - Consider water depth (10-20 feet)
     - Consider bottom type
     - Consider wind and current
     - Ensure adequate clearance

  2. Deploy anchor
     - Approach anchor location
     - Reduce speed
     - Deploy anchor from bow
     - Verify anchor is holding

  3. Secure anchor
     - Secure anchor line to aircraft
     - Verify anchor line is secure
     - Ensure adequate scope (5:1 to 7:1 ratio)

  4. Secure aircraft
     - Shut down engine
     - Secure controls
     - Secure systems

DOCKING:
  1. Approach dock
     - Approach into wind or current
     - Maintain control
     - Maintain safe speed (2-5 knots)

  2. Secure to dock
     - Approach dock slowly
     - Use dock lines to secure aircraft
     - Secure bow line first
     - Secure stern line
     - Verify all lines are secure

  3. Secure aircraft
     - Shut down engine
     - Secure controls
     - Secure systems

MOORING:
  1. Approach mooring
     - Approach mooring buoy or float
     - Maintain control
     - Maintain safe speed (2-5 knots)

  2. Secure to mooring
     - Approach mooring slowly
     - Attach mooring line to aircraft
     - Secure bow line to mooring
     - Verify all lines are secure

  3. Secure aircraft
     - Shut down engine
     - Secure controls
     - Secure systems

BEACHING:
  1. Approach beach/ramp
     - Approach beach or ramp area
     - Maintain control
     - Maintain safe speed (2-5 knots)

  2. Beach aircraft
     - Approach beach/ramp slowly
     - Ground aircraft on beach/ramp
     - Ensure aircraft is properly positioned

  3. Secure aircraft
     - Shut down engine
     - Secure controls
     - Secure systems
     - Consider tide if applicable

KEY:
  Choose appropriate securing method
  Execute procedure properly
  Secure aircraft properly

Just anchor anywhere - it doesn't matter
